webTitle: FSA acts on 'idiotic' radio ad caveats

fields.headline: FSA acts on 'idiotic' radio ad caveats
fields.trailText: The financial services authority yesterday promised an overhaul of the rules surrounding advertisements for investment products on the radio, and described the present situation as "idiotic."
fields.body:
The financial services authority yesterday promised an overhaul of the rules surrounding advertisements for investment products on the radio, and described the present situation as "idiotic."

Michael Foot, the managing director of the regulator, said that with many ads for products such as unit trusts, a large part of the airtime was taken up with a hurriedly spoken wealth warning - which probably left most consumers none the wiser.

Mr Foot also used his speech at the Building Societies Association annual conference in Edinburgh yesterday to deny that the FSA planned to ban the use of past performance figures in investment company advertising.

Responding to comments this week by Standard Life chief executive Jim Stretton - who said such a move would be profoundly damaging for the industry - Mr Foot said: "It is absurd to think that we would ban it. We have not suggested that and we will not be suggesting it."

However, he said the regulator would clamp down on companies that suggested that past success means they will go on being high performers.

Caveats on radio ads, which also include mortgages and typically highlight which regulator oversees the company and stress that the value of investments can go down and up, can take up as much as a third of the airtime.

Mr Foot said the warnings were clearly invented for a reason but added: "It does not appear that people understand them, and it does not appear that they are cost-effective. They are the kind of thing we ought to be thinking about."

He confirmed this was an issue the FSA would be tackling.

An FSA spokeswoman said the move very much fitted in with its aim of trying to get away from the need for small print generally and instead put more emphasis on "up front, practical information."

 Embattled insurance group Standard Life was yesterday urged not to "sit back and await its fate" as the battle rages over whether it should stay member-owned or convert to a public company. Labour MP Andrew Love, chairman of the commons all-party building societies group, said the insurer must learn from societies such as Nationwide which has successfully resisted the carpetbaggers.

webTitle: Defining the gift of a far-sighted few

fields.headline: Defining the gift of a far-sighted few
fields.standfirst:
Mark Milner looks at one man's quest to pin down what might be thought too intangible - that elusive ability to see further than the rest
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Mark Milner looks at one man's quest to pin down what might be thought too intangible - that elusive ability to see further than the rest.
fields.body:
Oh, the vision thing - thus said George Bush, former president of the United States, in response to a suggestion he might turn his attention away from short-term objectives to look at the longer term.

The "vision thing" indeed. Everyone knows you need it, in sport, in business, in politics. But few of us have the time or the energy to set aside pressing day-to-day concerns to work out the future and how to get there.

Among those who try some become prophets without honour in their own lands. Other simply end up without profits. Some choose the right vision and then achieve it, gaining near legendary status. General Electric's Jack Welch and Percy Barnevik, who assembled ABB from Asea and Brown Boveri and then successfully ran the combination, are frequently cited examples.

Of course, one thing about visions is that success instantly transmutes them into examples of the blindingly obvious. But how to pick the winners without the benefit of hindsight? Can it be done and, not only that, can it be nurtured? Is it possible to create a climate within where visionary thinking will develop successfully? Can it be defined, benchmarked?

Professor Andrew Kakabadse, professor of international management development and deputy director at the Cranfield School of Management is convinced that it can and has spent the last several years proving the point - working with both commercial organisations and the public sector.

For Professor Kakabadse the issue is not one of individuals. The one-man-band idea can stifle initiative and creativity. It is what he calls a "top team phenomenon" - a group of managers who re ally run the company. "It may not be just the board, it may be below board level including managers who run operations in different countries or business areas," he says.

Nor is just a question of the big idea, the imaginative leap forward, the sparkle. It is the ability to enter into debate, to be hard-nosed and practical, disciplined enough to master the detail which will see a vision through from concept to execution. "It's about having total understanding about how the organisation works."

Professor Kakabadse argues there is a predictive element in the process. He claims he has been able to tell executives that while they make a good start on projects they will eventually grow bored and lose interest. "Yes, I can put a time element on it. People are surprised it is possible."

The process is not without paradox. Professor Kakabadse argues that in the industrialised world a large percentage of medium and large enterprises are at the mature end of economic development scale. On the one hand they are under pressure to differentiate their products in some way - hence the need for a vision about the way forward. But at the same time they are looking to cut the cost base - all too often a demotivating exercise.

"The ones which succeed are the ones which apply the cost discipline levers while at the same time providing that extra something - customer service, care for the environment - which will hopefully give them greater dominance in the marketplace."

But aren't those who are involved in both the creation of the vision and its implementation born, not made?

Professor Kakabadse is dismissive of any such notion. That idea, he says, came in with Nietzsche in the 19th century. This is what led to the idea of "the right person for the right job - the assumption of the "fit". The evidence from his database covering 10,000 organisations in 14 countries is that this is "sheer nonsense".

Look instead, he says, at the teachings of Aristotle, Socrates and Plato - indeed, Professor Kakabadse reckons Plato's school of government was probably the world's first business school: "Leaders can certainly be made." But you cannot ignore the personal element. Motivation is crucial. "Not everyone has the will to elevate themselves to another level."

Professor Kakabadse is about to get an opportunity to test his views in the UK. BT, in partnership with with Cranfield, Management Today and Sunday Business, has just launched a competition to determine what is brilliant and unexpected in British industry. The project, Vision 100, aims to develop an index to measure the creativity and adaptability of private sector companies and public sector organisations, with Professor Kakabadse involved in evaluating and judging submissions.

He rejects any idea that in seeking to measure visionary capability by taking away the mystique will undermine it. Helping to define visionary capability and create it are part of the same process, he says. "It is a professional thing to do."

 Mark Milner is the Guardian's deputy financial editor

webTitle: Financial watchdog to run new business

fields.headline: Financial watchdog to run new business
fields.standfirst:
Patrick Collinson looks at a new source of independent information for investors
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Looking for the right financial product? In spring 2001, regulatory watchdog the Financial Services Authority will launch a service which will help consumers to make their own choices more confidently, rather than having to rely on insurance salesmen.
fields.body:
Looking for the right financial product? In spring 2001, regulatory watchdog the Financial Services Authority will launch a service which will help consumers to make their own choices more confidently, rather than having to rely on insurance salesmen.

It is to open a call centre-based financial supermarket which will send out individually-tailored lists of the best products to take out in a move which has sent shockwaves through the UK's 20,000 independent financial advisers.

The FSA database will hold up-to-the-minute details on all mortgages, personal pensions, unit trust Isas, endowments and investment bonds. Savings and bank accounts may be added at a later stage.

FSA director of consumer relations Christine Farnish said this week: "People will be able to phone up giving details of what product they are interested in, their age band, and how much money they are thinking of investing. We can then print out a bespoke table for them with all the general guidance."

All the information will also be posted on an FSA website where users can manipulate the data according to criteria such as price, charges and flexibility to produce their own league tables.

The move is a radical departure for the watchdog, which until now has been more concerned about regulating the sales process rather than steering consumers towards particular products. It follows a pledge made by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in the 1999 Budget, to give consumers league tables that will "guarantee a better deal and avoid the mis-selling of the past."

However, the regulator has stepped back from issuing its own "best buy" tables, and will instead list products in its "bespoke" tables in alphabetical order.

Independent financial advisers were quick to dismiss the FSA scheme as "just another source of information" which will not reduce the need for financial advice.

Paul Smee, head of the Association of Independent Financial Advisers, said: "This will only give you the basic product information and no guidance on whether the product is right for you. You will find some people who will try to do it themselves, buy the wrong product then realise they have made a big mistake.

"And they won't have any comeback against the FSA, which will surround the database with lots of disclaimers, and which in any case has statutory immunity."

As revealed in Jobs & Money in October last year, the regulator also confirmed that the information it gives out will not include any data on the past performance of investments. The FSA thinks past performance does not give consumers "objective and meaningful" information on which to base buying decisions. FSA researchers "were not able to identify any statistical correlation between good performance in the past and good performance in the future."

Academic research backs up the FSA's position. One statistician says that predicting future investment performance from past results is less reliable than using last night's winning trap numbers at a greyhound race as an indicator of which dog will win the next race.

The implications for the investment industry are enormous. Almost all its advertising is peppered with references to past performance, and the industry this week reacted vehemently to any suggestions that such practices might be banned.

Standard Life chief executive Jim Stretton warned that a ban on past performance figures would be "profoundly damaging" for the industry and its customers.

He said a ban would be "sinister" and would put mutual societies such as Standard Life (currently besieged by carpetbaggers) at a major disadvantage.

fields.headline: Build a dream house
fields.standfirst:
You can have your ideal home for around 20% less if you do it yourself, says Patrick Collinson
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Building your own home to your own specification is for most people a daunting but ultimately rewarding task. But easing the path is the growing number of lenders now willing to back your dream home with hard cash.
fields.body:
Building your own home to your own specification is for most people a daunting but ultimately rewarding task. But easing the path is the growing number of lenders now willing to back your dream home with hard cash.

Norwich & Peterborough building society is the market leader for self-build home loans, with more than 10% of all of its mortgages granted to self-builders. But there are a number of other lenders entering this growing market, from the Ecology building society, a specialist in environmentally conscious homes, through to giant high street names such as Lloyds TSB.

Moneyfacts lists 31 lenders who offer finance packages for self-build. However, you will still need a reasonable reserve of cash to start the process. The main rule of thumb is that a lender will give you up to 80% of the valuation or purchase price of the plot of land and release more money to cover the cost of building in stages dependent on an ongoing valuation. Most will release the full sum of money (with a maximum of 95% of valuation) once the roof is in place and the building is near completion.

Mortgage companies insist that the self-build project has to be for your own occupation and nearly all rule out lending against the building of flats or maisonettes.

Plots of land for a decent-sized home rarely come cheaper than £40,000-£50,000, and building a 125sq m home adds at least another £80,000-£90,000, so anybody thinking of self-build should have at least £20,000 initial capital to invest, and probably much more to finance building ahead of the staged release of mortgage finance.

The good news is that Norwich & Peterborough estimates that, on average, self-build homes cost around 20% less than buying the equivalent home on the open market.

Before they will grant you a mortgage, lenders will want to see a number of documents:

 Outline planning permission for the initial advance.

 Detailed planning permission for the first stage of building finance.

 Building regulation approval.

They also want to know who is building it. "Self-build is a bit of a misnomer. You can do a self-build without ever picking up a brick if you use sub-contractors, although the cost of labour can mount up," says N&P's Alison Lipscombe.

However, your lender will want to be satisfied that the builder or contractor is a reputable company and is registered with the NHBC. Generally speaking, self-build is not for the keen DIY amateur, although there is a growing number of house building kits on the market.

Lenders also want to be sure that if you need to sell the property, they can recover the mortgage outstanding. Architect Heimer Salt, who formed a self-build project in Leeds to erect three terraced houses, found that big lenders were less than enthusiastic about his more radical design ideas.

"If you say you are doing a timber-frame building with a turf roof, they immediately put the phone down on you," he says. Mr Salt turned to the Ecology building society. This lends to individuals wanting to build homes with a low environmental impact in terms of energy use, pollution and saving resources. "Additionally we ask if it will be a healthy home and cheap to run," says Ecology's George Penaluna.

Once you have found a plot of land, a lender and a builder, the next stage is obtaining the staged release of funds during the building process. For example, N&P gives you 15% of the total loan amount once the foundations are in place, a further 15% at first floor joist level and 15% at wall plate level. "At each stage the society's valuer will carry out a re-inspection before the next stage payment can be released. Architects' certificates will also be required where appropriate," it says.

Anyone considering undertaking a self-build should also factor in other costs. The list can run on and on and includes valuation fees, the cost of connecting services such as electricity, gas and water, professional fees, VAT, stamp duty and legal costs.

Making a realistic assessment of the true costs of self-build is essential:

 Don't turn a blind eye to what the real costs are going to be, or rely on the black economy to cut corners.

 Assess how long it will take; the fastest self-build kits can be put up in a few months, although most projects take at least one year.

 Think about employing a project manager. Although this can add 15% to the total costs, not having one will mean that you have to deal personally with the architectural plans, planning permission, ordering and delivering materials, handling sub-contractors and so on.

 Begin the work in winter, when contractors can be both cheaper and easier to hire.

 Avoid paying unnecessary VAT. You can get back all the VAT you pay on materials by registering as a self-build project before you begin work, so remember to save your receipts.

 Maximise the amount of labour time you can put in, as labourers cost anything from £50 to £100 a day.

 Obtain an NHBC 10-year certificate at the end of the project. These cost only a small sum, although you will have to pay surveyor's fees.

Anyone thinking of starting a self-build project still has time to visit the Southern Homebuilding and Renovating Show this weekend, which closes on Sunday June 11 at 5pm. The show is held in Sandown Park Exhibition Centre in Surrey. Free tickets from handrshow@aol.com.

 Norwich & Peterborough: www.npbs.co.uk or 01733-372372. Ecology building society: www.ecology.co.uk or 0845-674-5566. Association for Environment Conscious Building: 01559-370908.

Everyone thought we were mad - but it was worth it

Tootie Russell had just had her sixth child, Nick, and her husband David was setting up a wild flower seed business. The right time, then, for them to begin building a six bedroom home with almost no outside help?

"I know everybody thought we were mad," says Mrs Russell. Seven years later, with the house complete (and worth nearly 10 times the cost of building) she will tell anyone considering doing it themselves to think long and hard. "We came close to divorce several times. At one time I fell off the chimney, 26 feet up, and was on crutches for nearly two months. David just wanted to know when I could get back to work on the house. About the worst point was when I got a set of chisels for my birthday."

The family of eight lived for years in a caravan attached to the two-bed bungalow on the four acre plot they bought in the village of Osmington in Dorset for £38,000. With little spare cash, they did nearly all the work themselves, including installing the electrics, plumbing and drainage, although the installation had to be certified by experts to meet building regulations.

Building costs were around £40,000, and now the six-bed, three-bathroom home is valued at around £330,000. On paper, it sounds like a no-brainer, but Mr Russell warns: "You have to be completely resolute and see it through.

"You have to be very adaptable, able to cope with bad weather, endless setbacks and help not materialising. When things go wrong, it's easy to get disheartened." Mr Russell's top tip is to make sure your plans and drawings are as detailed as possible before you start. "A good drawing complete in all details from an architect saves you a host of problems."

Shopping around for building materials also saves you a small fortune. The Russells wanted their house to be built in local stone, but it turned out to be very pricey. Then they found a school in nearby Dorchester which was being demolished. "We got the stone very cheaply. I think of myself living now in a DIY Corfe Castle," says Mrs Russell.

In total, the Russells had to buy 18 tons of tiles, a mile and a half of boarding and one and a half hundredweight of nails. That was on top of Mr Russell struggling to keep his wild flower seeds business, Heritage Seeds, afloat during the recession.

Now with the house complete and the business thriving, the Russells can afford to relax.

 Heritage Seeds, tel: 01305-834504

David just wanted to know when I could get back to work on the house. About the worst point was when I got a set of chisels for my birthday." The family of eight lived for years in a caravan attached to the two-bed bungalow on the four acre plot they bought in the village of Osmington in Dorset for £38,000. With little spare cash, they did nearly all the work themselves, including installing the electrics, plumbing and drainage, although the installation had to be certified by experts to meet building regulations. Building costs were around £40,000, and now the six-bed, three-bathroom home is valued at around £330,000. On paper, it sounds like a no-brainer, but Mr Russell warns: "You have to be completely resolute and see it through. "You have to be very adaptable, able to cope with bad weather, endless setbacks and help not materialising. When things go wrong, it's easy to get disheartened." Mr Russell's top tip is to make sure your plans and drawings are as detailed as possible before you start. "A good drawing complete in all details from an architect saves you a host of problems." Shopping around for building materials also saves you a small fortune. The Russells wanted their house to be built in local stone, but it turned out to be very pricey. Then they found a school in nearby Dorchester which was being demolished. "We got the stone very cheaply. I think of myself living now in a DIY Corfe Castle," says Mrs Russell. In total, the Russells had to buy 18 tons of tiles, a mile and a half of boarding and one and a half hundredweight of nails. That was on top of Mr Russell struggling to keep his wild flower seeds business, Heritage Seeds, afloat during the recession. Now with the house complete and the business thriving, the Russells can afford to relax.  Heritage Seeds, tel: 01305-834504

fields.headline: Now American deals hit town
fields.standfirst:
New types of loans are arriving in the UK, but it still pays to look before you dive in, writes Tony Levene and Rupert Jones
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: New types of loans are arriving in the UK, but it still pays to look before you dive in, write Tony Levene and Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
The Atlantic is shrinking as US-style lending comes to these shores. On Monday, Cahoot, Abbey National's new e-bank, opens for business with American-style differential credit card and overdraft rates. It will introduce a range of rates, making it difficult to tie down its position in best buy tables.

And earlier this week Standard Life Bank, owned by the carpetbagger-besieged mutual, launched Futureperfect, the UK's first-ever 25-year capped rate mortgage. Long life loans are a permanent feature of the US scene.

The Standard Life mortgage is capped at 6.25% - borrowers can never pay more but will pay less if the product's special variable rate falls below the Futureperfect rate. This is an average rate of four major lenders including Standard Life and now stands at 7.54%. Variable rates last stood below 6.25% in 1963 and bank base rates will have to fall to around 4.5% from their present 6% level before the cap kicks in. Standard Life claims Futureperfect "is ideal for homebuyers seeking certainty over the loan's life."

Ray Boulger at broker John Charcol says: "It offers good value coupled with long-term security. But there are many cheaper loans if you don't want or need the security."

And the deal is not without other downsides. Redemption penalties range from 10 months' interest in the first year - £5,208 for a £100,000 loan - down to five months' interest in year five. In most US fixed rate long term mortgages, borrowers can walk away from loans without big penalties although the interest rates they pay are higher than those of Futureperfect.

Futureperfect is only sold to people aged less than 42, because Standard Life says it is a 25-year mortgage rather than a five-year convenience. And it is only available on a repayment basis, making it less attractive for those looking for an interest-only loan to go with existing endowments and Isa plans.

The plan demands a minimum 10% deposit and the maximum loan is £350,000. But worst of all, Standard Life concedes that this is not a flexible product - payment holidays and regular overpayments are banned, although interest is calculated daily.

Previous long-term mortgage deals available in the UK from the likes of US bank Bear Stearns, Barclays and Cheltenham & Gloucester failed to catch on because they were sold with 25-year fixed rates and very high exit penalties. When interest levels fell, borrowers were left high and dry.

Barclays bowed this week to the Consumers' Association and the Office of Fair Trading pressure, ditching most long-term exit penalties and capping others.

Abbey National's new e-bank "cahoot.com" starts with a current account and credit card; personal loans will follow later this year, while savings accounts are a strong possibility. But there are no plans for home loans.

The bank wants to put clear water between itself and web-based rivals Intelligent Finance from Halifax and Open Plan from Woolwich and is keeping pricing details close to its corporate chest.

It is likely to pay around 4.5% on accounts in credit. But the real attention will be focused on overdrafts and credit cards, which will feature differential pricing.

Varying interest rates for different customers are used widely in the US credit card industry, where customers are assessed for a number of factors including usage and creditworthiness.

For instance, Providian Bank under its Aria label has Platinum Premier with no annual or start-up fees and a fixed 7.99% rate, Platinum at 12.99% fixed, Portrait at a minimum 19.99% and Persona at 23.99%, no free interest period and annual charges of up to $89.

US rival Capital One has a range encompassing Platinum with a $20,000 credit line and 9.9% to Secured where credit is limited to $500 - and holders have to put down a deposit starting at $99.

Cahoot.com will also embrace a wide price range but as the account is being aimed at the creditworthy, the main differentials will depend on how the account is used.

Accountholders who are overdrawn for a few days each month may opt for one rate of interest, while those permanently in the red may have to pay fees - possibly with a lower rate.

Rates will also depend on services demanded. Customers who are prepared to go without a cheque book will get a better deal.

All this will make Cahoot's position in tables almost impossible to pin down. All customers will be told their rate and charges but non-customers will simply see a range. Cahoot intends to be the best deal "where we choose to compete".

Other innovations on the lending front include:

 Hanley Building Society and Mortgage Next are teaming up to offer "fe3" - a fee-free brokerage selling a wide variety of home loans.

 Yorkshire Building Society is listing flexible loans on Telewest digital TV.

 Bank of Scotland is taking flexible mortgages a stage further with fixed rates on up to 50% of the loan - the three-year rate is 6.99% - details from branches.

 Entertainment group SFX has joined forces with MBNA Bank to launch "Live", a credit card giving discounts on plays, operas, ballets and rock concerts. The card's standard rate is 13.9%. Tel: 0800-776262, quoting code 35CZ.

 Sainsbury has a new credit card with a 5.9% rate for six months, reverting to 15.9%. There's a Rewards point link but only 50 days' interest free period. Tel: 0500-40-50-60.

webTitle: So much regard but so little reward

fields.headline: So much regard but so little reward
fields.standfirst:
Many careers seen as important in today's society do not have the salaries to match. Jessica McCallin examines some serious under-earners
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Many careers seen as important in today's society do not have the salaries to match. Jessica McCallin examines some serious under-earners.
fields.body:
Ever thought about the person who tests your blood and tissue samples to see if you have any nasty diseases or disorders? It may seem a strange question, but think about it. As the saying goes, "it's dirty job, but someone's gotta do it" - so who is this someone?

Unfortunately, he or she is probably an overworked, underpaid and somewhat demoralised science graduate. For pathologists, as they are formally known, are paid badly - and that means really badly.

To enter the profession as a graduate trainee you need to have an undergraduate degree and at least one year of postgraduate work experience, but can only expect a starting salary of between £7,000 and £9,500 a year.

At £7,000, these graduates are teetering on the edge of the minimum wage - a situation made possible by the fact that trainee schemes are excluded from minimum wage legislation.

Their predicament will improve with time, but pathologists can never expect to be millionaires. The top salary bracket for laboratory-based work is around £19,000. To make more than that they would have to move into management and this is usually only possible after several years or even decades in the profession.

This scenario clashes somewhat with the common perception of university graduates as bright young things with very little to worry about.

Unlike their parents, they will probably have a bit of debt following them around in the few years after graduation, but people assume that they are all going to walk into high-flying and high-paying jobs upon graduation anyway, and so a bit of debt would hardly be a problem.

Teachers are the obvious exception to this view. Everyone knows that after a degree and teacher training course they go into jobs with bad pay, bad conditions and no prospects of a high-flying salary no matter how high they fly within their chosen profession.

The problem is that while the crisis surrounding teachers' remuneration is a serious one, it pales in comparison to the situation other graduates find themselves in. And pathologists are by no means the only ones.

In a totally different sphere of economic life, museum curators can also expect pay packets which verge on the insulting.

Given that they are experts in their chosen field, you won't be surprised to discover that most curators have at least one, and often two, postgraduate degrees.

On top of this, many are expected to have a specialist diploma in museum management or curating. All these qualifications will have put the applicants into serious debt, yet entry level salaries are only around £10,000 to £11,000.

There are other examples. Clinical psychologists, graduates who already have or are in the process of getting a masters degree, can expect starting salaries of around £13,000.

Trainee journalists, especially those starting out on a local newspaper, will be looking at around £10,000.

Charity work can also be badly paid, despite the finely tuned skills and experience the organisations require. A qualified lawyer working for a human rights charity is unlikely to make more than around £20,000.

Even our much-loved actors and entertainers can suffer incomes below subsistence level. Those who trained at a university will be in a bad enough situation, but those who trained at one of the country's drama schools will really be in trouble.

Fees can be in the region of £9,000 a year and you don't get any state help in paying them. Add that to the cost of living and aspiring actors are in dire financial straits. And while some of them go on to win world fame and fortune, most don't.

In a recent survey, Equity, the actors' trade union, found that more than half its members made less than £10,000 a year from actual entertainment work. Some 42% made less than £5,000 a year.

Put simply, it would be hard to pay off your student debts - currently averaging a minimum of £4,000 a year for undergraduate study and more for postgraduate - with this sort of salary, let alone try and save for a house, take out a pension, put some money away for a rainy day, go on holiday or, indeed, bring up a family.

The reasons why some highly skilled jobs pay so badly is unclear. Often it's simply a case of supply and demand.

Psychologist Terry Kellard at Warwick Consultants says the problem with clinical psychologists is that there are just too many of them. They are also working in the notoriously badly paying public sector, as are museum curators and pathologists.

In the charity sector it's a bit more tricky. Charities are non-profit-making organisations which simply can't pay high salaries and, anyway, charity employees are unlikely to be motivated by money in the first instance.

But all this is missing some of the more important points. One is the fact that many of these low paying jobs are not valued as much as high paying ones.

Bharti Patel, director of the Low Pay Unit, certainly thinks that this attitude lies behind the dreadful pay doled out to many nurses and care workers.

Another is that it leads to recruitment and retention problems. Dan Smith, a pathologist at Oxford's John Radcliffe Hospital, says he finds it very hard to recruit and keep staff. One job, he says, has been advertised since last October but he has yet to receive a single application.

He also mentioned a couple who were working for him who wanted to buy a house. Even when they combined their salaries, a property in Oxford was out of the question. So they both left and joined a drugs company with the increased pay, share options, and other perks and bonuses which all come with working in the private sector.

More importantly, however, the pay structures are likely to lead to some people into giving up on the idea of careers in some of these sectors altogether. Without financial support from family and friends they may find that the pay simply doesn't justify the debt.

The government is currently getting its knickers in a twist about one A-level pupil's failure to get into Oxford to read medicine. Perhaps it should be concerned that people from similar backgrounds to this sixth-former could be priced out of certain careers as well.

Two degrees for under ten grand

David Aird, a pathologist at Oxford's John Radcliffe hospital, has two degrees yet he started work on a trainee rate of just £9,600.

This rose to £12,500 a year later and will continue rising by about £500 a year, but to make any more David has to do shift work, working nights, weekends and other anti-social hours.

The shifts boost his pay to £16,500 and can be a good way around the bad pay pathologists get. The problem is that not all hospitals offer work round the clock and those that do offer it on a strictly first come first served basis, which means the only way to get on the rota is to put your name on a list and wait until someone leaves.

David is hopeful for the future. "I take comfort from what nurses have been able to achieve over the past few years. I am not too bothered by it as pay was never the most important thing for me, but lots of my colleagues are very demoralised and staff turnover is very high.

"I do like the fact that I'm helping people through my job. It's also worth noting that while the pay is very bad, redundancies are almost unheard of. Once you're in, you've got a job for life."

When choosing art for art's sake

Anne Steinberg's first foray into museum work came when she volunteered at a photo archive in Venice. A modern language student with an interest in Venetian art, Anne realised that volunteering was important to eventually getting work in museums.

She was obviously hooked, because a master's degree in Italian art and three years at the Ashmolean museum in Oxford followed. Then, last summer, she was recruited by the Victoria and Albert museum in London as one of 30-odd assistant curators. The museum gives recruits structured training and rotates them around different departments to make sure they get a wide range of experience. But at £13,800, the salary is low.

"It's very hard to make ends meet in London. I rarely go out to eat or drink with friends and have to live in a flatshare because buying or renting something is out of the question.

"We [the assistant curators] do moan a bit about the salary but it's a very rewarding and satisfying job and working among all these beautiful objects is wonderful.

"At the end of the day we all know we are very privileged to have been taken on by such an institution. These things make up for the low pay."

fields.headline: High winds in Jamaica
fields.standfirst:
A Carribean hurricane forced Matthew Hooper to abandon the launch of his first marketing operation and brought about a change of direction, as Eileen Sheridan discovered
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A Carribean hurricane forced Matthew Hooper to abandon the launch of his first marketing operation and brought about a change of direction, as Eileen Sheridan discovered.
fields.body:
It looked like Matthew Hooper had everything sorted when he landed in Jamaica in 1986, but he had reckoned without the force of mother nature. The managing director of multi-discipline marketing company Interfocus was in the Caribbean to launch what would have been his first marketing operation when Hurricane Gilbert stormed over Jamaica and blew Hooper's plans out of the water.

"I was the first person in about 20 years to get a work permit for marketing. I went on Friday and on Sunday morning Hurricane Gilbert arrived and ripped through the island," he recalls. "I was in a house and the roof was taken off, palm trees came out the ground and were hurled like tent pegs across the garden. I had never seen such destruction.

"Suddenly, the whole island was taken apart and I thought - they are not going to need a marketing person, these people are homeless, the economy is destroyed. The last thing they will need is marketing."

But, as Hooper says now, the power of nature gave him his big break - an ill wind and all that.

As a result of the devastation his hand was forced and he came back to the UK to brave the sceptics with his view that companies needed more than one discipline in an agency to give them the right marketing mix. It was an idea that had grown with Hooper during his years at advertising agency Clarke Hooper and then as a client when he was marketing manager for the Johnny Walker whisky brand at United Distillers.

"It was then that I realised the agencies were not really understanding clients," he says. "It was at that point when I was dealing with sales promotion, advertising and packaging agencies that they were all coming and

selling their wares to me, but no-one was really getting under the skin of my brand or my commercial problems. All they were interested in was what amount of money I would be spending with each of them and trying to convince me that their solution was the best solution.

"I had a very small marketing department and it was then I thought that if I had an agency that could act as a surrogate marketing depart ment who could work with me and objectively advise me as to what they thought would be the best mix of disciplines and provide me with a solution, then I would work with that agency and probably pay them a premium."

The Stowe-educated 36-year-old had always wanted to do his own thing and had already earned his business spurs by setting up in the hospitality business at the age of 18. "I bought a double decker bus and called the business Upstairs, Downstairs which was a hospitality and catering business." He was featured on BBC's Nationwide and during this time grew the business until he was employing 100 or more people.

Hooper kept Upstairs Downstairs going while he studied at Westminster College and emerged with a degree. "Hospitality and catering wasn't what I really wanted to do, I had always wanted to get into marketing," he says.

His father had been in the advertising and marketing business and Hooper had lived abroad as a child. He attributes his open-mindedness to those early years. When he first ran out the idea of a multi-disciplinary marketing agency he met with scepticism.

"The English attitude is when something is new and different it won't work." It took guts to fly in the face of received marketing wisdom at the age of 25, but Hooper found an ally and partner in Sandy Scott and backing from BBDO. "I had an older partner which gave people a greater degree of confidence, plus the backing of a large advertising group which gave us some credibility."

There are multi-disciplinary agencies in regional markets, but Interfocus was the first player in a major market and is credited with that in the business. It is now a 125-strong agency which boasts blue-chip clients like Microsoft,

Lloyds TSB, London Transport, Eddie Bauer, Eurobet and Bass Brewers.

The next step for Interfocus is to go global, says Hooper. It would be a logical step to have agencies or affiliates in key countries. And besides that Hooper has unfin- ished business on the other side of the Atlantic. "I would love to go back and do something in the Caribbean," he says.

The managing director of multi-discipline marketing company Interfocus was in the Caribbean to launch what would have been his first marketing operation when Hurricane Gilbert stormed over Jamaica and blew Hooper's plans out of the water. "I was the first person in about 20 years to get a work permit for marketing. I went on Friday and on Sunday morning Hurricane Gilbert arrived and ripped through the island," he recalls. "I was in a house and the roof was taken off, palm trees came out the ground and were hurled like tent pegs across the garden. I had never seen such destruction. "Suddenly, the whole island was taken apart and I thought - they are not going to need a marketing person, these people are homeless, the economy is destroyed. The last thing they will need is marketing." But, as Hooper says now, the power of nature gave him his big break - an ill wind and all that. As a result of the devastation his hand was forced and he came back to the UK to brave the sceptics with his view that companies needed more than one discipline in an agency to give them the right marketing mix. It was an idea that had grown with Hooper during his years at advertising agency Clarke Hooper and then as a client when he was marketing manager for the Johnny Walker whisky brand at United Distillers. "It was then that I realised the agencies were not really understanding clients," he says. "It was at that point when I was dealing with sales promotion, advertising and packaging agencies that they were all coming and selling their wares to me, but no-one was really getting under the skin of my brand or my commercial problems. All they were interested in was what amount of money I would be spending with each of them and trying to convince me that their solution was the best solution. "I had a very small marketing department and it was then I thought that if I had an agency that could act as a surrogate marketing depart ment who could work with me and objectively advise me as to what they thought would be the best mix of disciplines and provide me with a solution, then I would work with that agency and probably pay them a premium." The Stowe-educated 36-year-old had always wanted to do his own thing and had already earned his business spurs by setting up in the hospitality business at the age of 18. "I bought a double decker bus and called the business Upstairs, Downstairs which was a hospitality and catering business." He was featured on BBC's Nationwide and during this time grew the business until he was employing 100 or more people. Hooper kept Upstairs Downstairs going while he studied at Westminster College and emerged with a degree. "Hospitality and catering wasn't what I really wanted to do, I had always wanted to get into marketing," he says. His father had been in the advertising and marketing business and Hooper had lived abroad as a child. He attributes his open-mindedness to those early years. When he first ran out the idea of a multi-disciplinary marketing agency he met with scepticism. "The English attitude is when something is new and different it won't work." It took guts to fly in the face of received marketing wisdom at the age of 25, but Hooper found an ally and partner in Sandy Scott and backing from BBDO. "I had an older partner which gave people a greater degree of confidence, plus the backing of a large advertising group which gave us some credibility." There are multi-disciplinary agencies in regional markets, but Interfocus was the first player in a major market and is credited with that in the business. It is now a 125-strong agency which boasts blue-chip clients like Microsoft, Lloyds TSB, London Transport, Eddie Bauer, Eurobet and Bass Brewers. The next step for Interfocus is to go global, says Hooper. It would be a logical step to have agencies or affiliates in key countries. And besides that Hooper has unfin- ished business on the other side of the Atlantic. "I would love to go back and do something in the Caribbean," he says.

fields.headline: Devil and the detail
fields.standfirst:
House/Lights
Tramway
Glasgow *****
fields.trailText: Elisabeth Mahoney reviews House/Lights at the Tramway, Glasgow
fields.body:
In the darkness, breathing: thick, sexual breaths; primal breaths, fighting for life. It is the calm before the storm - the physical, dramatic, and sexual storm - that is to follow in a kaleidoscopic hour- and-a-half of theatre encompassing Gertrude Stein, a film about a wicked lesbian dominatrix, some ballet, Frankenstein and an artificial viper. Yes, the Wooster Group are in town.

What that means is theatre coming as close to carnival, to circus even, as you can imagine, but with a searing intellect running through it. So House/Lights is as audacious and magical a visual spectacle as any of their productions (a set like a lab, only with balloon-like electric lights hanging down and swaying in the foreground; six television screens; moments of almost giddy dancing and prancing across the stage), but it has a rare intelligence not only in its blending and bending of odd-bedfellow texts, but in every visual detail, every sound.

The core to the drama is Faust's encounter with the Devil, as retold by Stein in her 1939 libretto Doctor Faustus Lights the Lights, in which Faust sells his soul to invent electricity. This is paralleled with a dodgy 1964 B-movie, in which Olga (played by Suzzy Roche, who is also the Devil in the Stein) makes Elaine (Kate Valk, playing Faust too) in her own wicked image. The Stein is retold, largely in monologue by Valk with a Betty Boop hairdo and girly voice, while scenes from the film are re-enacted on stage as they appear on screen. The two narratives chase each other, collide hilariously and, only together, make some strange, perfect sense.

Big questions lurk, about power and corruption, and more specifically about women and power, but it's what the Woosters make out of an avant-garde plotless wonder and an over-plotted hammy flick that dazzles, makes you catch your breath.

Ends tonight. Box office: 0141-287 3900.

fields.headline: Going round in circles
fields.standfirst:
Sleeping Beauty
Royal Albert Hall
London **
fields.trailText: Judith Mackrell reviews the ENB's Sleeping Beauty at the Royal Albert Hall
fields.body:
When Petipa choreographed Sleeping Beauty in 1890, he didn't plan on his bad fairy Carabosse getting wolf whis tles as she entered the stage, nor, as diva dominatrix, attempting to seduce the good Prince Florimund with her trashy wiles. But Petipa wouldn't recognise much in ENB's current production of his ballet - which is just as director Derek Deane planned. This, after all, is ballet for the people, not for purists: scaled up for the vast circular stage of the Albert Hall and with spectacle, not choreography, driving the evening.

Since this is the third classic that Deane has staged this way, it's wearisome to rehearse the familiar arguments - accessibility and fun traded against the distancing effect of the huge venue, and the violation of classical dance principles imposed by the in-the-round format. But for Beauty, the most delicately constructed of all the classics, the trade-off proves the least convincing. Take Carabosse, a role tarted up by Deane for the dubious talents of ex-Kirov babe Anastasia Volochkova. In tra ditional stagings this mad, bad fairy is already a riot: she sweeps the stage with her grotesque cohorts, and her power is articulated in the witty mime with which she viciously satirises other, prissier fairies. Deane, who has excised most of Petipa's original text, has tried to update this mime, but his resort to rampant kicking and preening looks neither sexy nor dangerous, rather as if Carabosse is having an alcoholic tantrum.

Much of the new choreogra phy is almost as weak: the Cat and Blue Bird pas de deux have been re-written to ugly and unmusical effect and although the Fairy variations in the Prologue have some very pretty steps, why bother when the originals served so well? More Petipa survives in the choreography for the lead couple, and while it's irritating to have the ballerina and her Prince constantly revolving to face all their audience (leaving us staring at Aurora's knickers during parts of the Rose Ada gio) there are moments where we can still admire the assured performance of the very young, very tiny Erina Takahashi. She has tremendous power, and if she looks somewhat bland in this Beauty, she obviously has huge potential.

The production's other consolation is a clever trick of the staging. Though much of the design is an unperiod assortment of acid-toned costumes in cheap-looking fabrics, the back wall of the Albert Hall has been disguised as the facade of a huge castle. The orchestra, seated high on a platform, look as if they are playing Tchaikovsky on the balcony of a fairy chateau.

Until June 20. Box office: 020-7589 8212.

fields.headline: Executive action gives competitive advantage
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's executives are better trained and in a stronger position to match the skills of their overseas competitors than ever.
fields.body:
Britain's executives are better trained and in a stronger position to match the skills of their overseas competitors than ever. Over the past decade the quantity and quality of management training in UK organisations has accelerated for the first time, according to a study, Achieving Management Excellence, from the Institute of Management (IM). Training has risen by 18% in larger organisations and 25 % in smaller companies since 1996. There is also growing recognition of the value of a planned and co-ordinated approach to training in Britain's companies. More than half (51% ) now have a written statement of management development - up from 43 % in 1996. Among organisations that took part in both surveys (1996 and 2000), 60% of those which give management training a high priority reveal an increase in financial turnover compared with others in their sector. Enlightened corporations are starting to see training as an investment rather than simply a cost with four in 10 managers saying their organisation has an explicit management development budget. The report costs £50 or £25 for IM members: tel;020-7421-2702

Up to 150 applications for recognition from trade unions are expected over the next 12 months by the independent Central Arbitration Committee, (CAC) the body charged with administering the new legal procedures whicht came into force this week. Under the first pro-union legislation for more than a quarter of a century, unions will be able to use the CAC to compel employers to recognise their right to represent their members in negotiations over wages and conditions.

The government plans to set "tough" 10-year targets to cut numbers of injuries and deaths in the workplace, John Prescott announced this week . The deputy prime minister said employers had to give health and safety a higher priority. The government wants the number of serious injuries and deaths reduced by 10% and the number of working days lost due to accidents cut by nearly a third - 7.5m a year - by 2010. Mr Prescott outlined 44 proposals designed to make health and safety at work "a core requirement of business activity" including requiring companies to make a director responsible for health and safety. Tougher penalties for law-breakers include prison sentences for most offences and a rise in the maximum fines from £5,000 to £20,000

webTitle: Standard Life amends ballot because of snub to divorcees

fields.headline: Standard Life amends ballot because of snub to divorcees
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Standard Life has outraged 11,000 divorced women by sending out demutualisation voting packs in the names of their ex-husbands, meaning windfalls potentially worth thousands of pounds could be pocketed by their former partners.
fields.body:
Standard Life has outraged 11,000 divorced women by sending out demutualisation voting packs in the names of their ex-husbands, meaning windfalls potentially worth thousands of pounds could be pocketed by their former partners.

Even women who took over policies after divorce and paid the premiums have found membership of Standard Life has remained with the original signatory. In almost every case this was the husband.

Last night Standard Life moved to correct the situation after receiving calls from many women. It is promising to reissue ballot papers and says the holders of "assigned" policies - where the payment of premiums and benefits has been transferred - will receive any potential windfall, rather than the original signatory.

Around 2.3m voting packs have gone out to Standard Life members over the past few days and must be returned by June 23. If the vote goes in favour of demutualisation, members would be in line for average windfalls estimated at up to £7,000. Personal pension holders who have invested for 15 years or more will receive substantially higher payouts.

A Standard Life spokesman said: "We are sending out new forms and cancelling ballot slips for ex-partners, whether they have cast their vote or not. There are 11,000 in this situation. Any windfall shares would have been given to the person paying even if the votes went to the wrong hands."

The mistake occurred because Standard Life only looked at the first name on policies held jointly - usually the man - when sending out voting papers. It ignored any policy assignment.

One South Wales divorcee told the Guardian: "I have paid all the premiums and should get all the benefits including any votes. We divorced four years ago and I ended up with the endowment we bought in 1986. My ex-husband is history and he has no rights over my policy."

The ballot results will be announced on June 27.

webTitle: Corner shops beat new online supermarkets

fields.headline: Corner shops beat new online supermarkets
fields.standfirst:
As more and more fund shops hit the net, Tony Levene finds that traditional IFAs are cheaper
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As more and more fund shops hit the net, Tony Levene finds that traditional IFAs are cheaper.
fields.body:
Move over Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda and Waitrose - there's a new set of supermarkets in town. But while you won't find organic oregano or frozen fish in them, you'll easily be able to spend thousands.

The new-style online supermarkets sell unit trusts and investment funds. And this week planned and actual openings were coming in thick and fast.

But anyone looking for pile 'em high and sell 'em cheap unit trusts could be in for a disappointment. Unlike US counterparts, fund supermarkets may cost more than "corner shop" IFAs. And unlike real supermarkets, you may have to take your trolley around several sites before you find what you want.

Fidelity led the way with FundsNetwork on www.fidelity.co.uk. This gives access to 14 leading fund managers including Aberdeen, Barings, CGU, Deutsche, Fidelity, Flemings, Henderson, HSBC, Invesco, Mercury, Newton, Norwich Union, Schroders and Virgin. Fidelity claims "it offers a broad selection of the industry's most popular and better quality funds".

But the shelves are bare of products from leading providers such as Gartmore, M&G, Jupiter, Threadneedle, Perpetual, SocGen, Legal & General, Scottish Widows, Standard Life and a further 100 investment managers.

Fidelity says it will add firms later on. However, the first four of the above list intend opening Consolidated Funds, their own joint supermarket, later this year - although the plan is to aim this at financial advisers rather than the public.

The Fidelity site offers around 250 funds including some from Fidelity itself. There are tools which help narrow the selection.

Fund managers outside the supermarket say choice will largely be determined by past performance - criticised earlier this week by the Financial Services Authority as no better than random selection - so trusts which have had a poor record but are now improving or which come from "niche" companies will find it hard to get a look-in.

The size and advertising spend of each company are significant factors - just as they are in the grocery trade. One fund manager, who wanted to remain anonymous, complained: "We don't have a great past performance and while we think we have a great story going forward, they don't see us as an easy sale. Will customers be put off if we're not there and buy something else?"

In theory, funds supermarkets should offer one-stop shopping both for investors and advisers. People should find it easy to click on to what they need and place their orders.

Jason Hollands of IFA Best Investment reckons the supermarkets are the best thing since sliced bread. He says: "The ability to buy funds from different providers with one online account has major advantages including a widened choice, information on your holdings and the ability to switch funds at one click."

But supermarket pricing may be more expensive than corner shops. Fundsnetwork boasts that "nearly 90% of funds have initial charges of 1.25% or less. This is significantly lower than traditional Isa charges which can be as much as 5.25%."

However, many discount IFAs refund the entire upfront charge, living on the 0.5% annual commission. Supermarket companies will get commission.

Supermarkets will have differing pricing criteria. Some such as Egg, which opened earlier this year, have little interest in IFAs and can adopt whatever charges they fancy to gain market share.

But others, including Fidelity and the planned Gartmore/M&G/Jupiter/Thread-needle tie-up, also need IFA corner shops for sales and may be less price competitive with fewer no-load funds.

However, they might offer better facilities. US players, such as Charles Schwab and E-Trade, have investment research material, asset allocation assistance, tax reporting help and even a "college saver program" for educational expenses.

Duncan Coombe of Investec Guinness Flight believes "supermarkets have a clear role in the UK. A good one really adds value but a bad site falls into fund overload - too many funds with just a listing and little or no added value. And that's no use to anyone."

fields.headline: Standard finds 'lost' divorcees
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than 11,000 Standard Life members will have votes restored ahead of the vital June 27 demutualisation ballot - thanks to Jobs & Money.
fields.body:
More than 11,000 Standard Life members will have votes restored ahead of the vital June 27 demutualisation ballot - thanks to Jobs & Money.

Both Standard Life, which wants a "no" vote, and the carpetbaggers, led by Monaco-based Fred Wollard and hoping for big windfalls, are fighting for every vote in what could be a close race.

The 11,000 who were disenfranchised are divorcees, mostly women. They took over with-profits policies from their ex-partners as part of a divorce settlement. But voting forms were sent to former partners, even though they had assigned all benefits and premium payments to ex-spouses.

Divorcees who alerted Jobs & Money complained that voting forms were addressed to ex-partners. One said: "We bought a policy in 1986 and divorced in 1996. My former husband assigned the policy to me as part of our settlement. He no longer has any rights to it. But when I phoned the Standard Life helpline I was told there had been a rule change in 1991 which meant that the first-named on a joint policy became the member, even if he gave up all interests in the endowment. I was amazed - no one had told either of us about this when we split."

When Jobs & Money asked Standard Life whether it was their intention to disenfranchise divorcees, it investigated and speedily conceded that the wrong people were being sent voting forms.

It immediately put a team on to the task of locating divorcees and others in this situation. It now says that disenfranchised members should receive new voting forms by early next week and ballot papers sent to former partners are to be cancelled. "It's only when you do a mailing that people care about anomolies that are thrown up," says Standard Life.

The life insurer says that even where policyholders appeared disenfranchised, they would still receive windfalls if the vote goes against mutuality: "Any benefits from a policy will be paid to the real owner - ex-spouses in this situation will not profit."

But that's not the only problem to hit the Standard Life helpline (0845-6060-076). Many members are angry about what they see as a boardroom move to direct votes. The four-page ballot form has one page devoted to a "say NO to demutualisation" message, a second page attacking carpetbaggers and asking for a "no" vote and a "vote no to all the resolutions" exhortation on the voting paper itself.

Other members are angry that while Standard Life is distributing a statement from the anti-mutual Standard Life Members Action Group it says it "can accept no responsibility for the accuracy of the statement and believes it makes a number of misleading assertions".

One with-profits holder said: "It's a pity the members' group is not allowed to comment on Standard Life's statement. I'm sure it is legally watertight, but I would have liked to see an admission that our endowment mortgages might produce a shortfall instead of the assurance that they had performed well so far. It's the future that is worrying - not the past."

 Backing the board or cheering the carpetbaggers? Give us your views. E-mail jobs.and.money@theguardian.com.

But when I phoned the Standard Life helpline I was told there had been a rule change in 1991 which meant that the first-named on a joint policy became the member, even if he gave up all interests in the endowment. I was amazed - no one had told either of us about this when we split." When Jobs & Money asked Standard Life whether it was their intention to disenfranchise divorcees, it investigated and speedily conceded that the wrong people were being sent voting forms. It immediately put a team on to the task of locating divorcees and others in this situation. It now says that disenfranchised members should receive new voting forms by early next week and ballot papers sent to former partners are to be cancelled. "It's only when you do a mailing that people care about anomolies that are thrown up," says Standard Life. The life insurer says that even where policyholders appeared disenfranchised, they would still receive windfalls if the vote goes against mutuality: "Any benefits from a policy will be paid to the real owner - ex-spouses in this situation will not profit." But that's not the only problem to hit the Standard Life helpline (0845-6060-076). Many members are angry about what they see as a boardroom move to direct votes. The four-page ballot form has one page devoted to a "say NO to demutualisation" message, a second page attacking carpetbaggers and asking for a "no" vote and a "vote no to all the resolutions" exhortation on the voting paper itself. Other members are angry that while Standard Life is distributing a statement from the anti-mutual Standard Life Members Action Group it says it "can accept no responsibility for the accuracy of the statement and believes it makes a number of misleading assertions". One with-profits holder said: "It's a pity the members' group is not allowed to comment on Standard Life's statement. I'm sure it is legally watertight, but I would have liked to see an admission that our endowment mortgages might produce a shortfall instead of the assurance that they had performed well so far. It's the future that is worrying - not the past."  Backing the board or cheering the carpetbaggers? Give us your views. E-mail jobs.and.money@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Owners left to pick up the bill after storms wreak havoc

fields.headline: Owners left to pick up the bill after storms wreak havoc
fields.standfirst:
As the clear-up after last weekend's flash floods continues in the north, Rupert Jones reports on the 6m householders without contents cover
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As the clear-up after last weekend's flash floods continues in the north, Rupert Jones reports on the 6m householders without contents cover.
fields.body:
Hundreds of homeowners were this week counting the cost of the flash floods which struck with a vengeance in many parts of northern England last weekend, leaving a trail of mud, damaged property and ruined possessions in their wake.

And while the majority were thanking their lucky stars that they were covered by insurance, scores of those affected will not have had any contents cover, and in some cases will have been left thousands of pounds out of pocket.

One of the areas worst affected by the floods was the West Yorkshire town of Todmorden, where the River Calder burst its banks following heavy rain. Living just four yards away from the river, Pam Parnell and her family felt the full force of Mother Nature's wrath.

At one point her end-of-terrace house was under several feet of filthy, foul-smelling water. She says the total bill for repairing the damage and replacing waterlogged possessions is likely to be around £10,000.

Mrs Parnell was woken late on Saturday night by one of her sons, who warned that the river was extremely high and was starting to come through the walls at the back of the house. She and her husband Stephen started frantically moving various items to safety, but it wasn't long before the water was pouring in through the front and back doors.

"We just started to try and move as much stuff as we possibly could. My mother is here on holiday and she was helping as well. We were trying to get stuff upstairs but within a quarter of an hour there was nearly 4ft of water in the house," she says.

"We managed to salvage one television, a video recorder and photographs. I took out the drawers and put them on the top of units. Then we grabbed some candles, cans of pop, biscuits and crisps, and went upstairs."

The waters started subsiding later that morning, at which point the family came down and surveyed their sodden home. "I phoned up my insurance company and they came round on Sunday. They took the carpets out for us and sprayed this stuff down for bugs and things. The water that came in was filthy and foul. A loss adjuster came out as well. They walked in, had a good look round and said 'The whole lot's got to go'."

Items that will have to be replaced include a three-piece suite, washing machine, freezer, tumble dryer, two televisions and a video recorder.

"My kitchen looks like it is going to have to be replaced - all the doors have warped. The floors are probably going to have to be replaced, and there is going to be plasterwork that needs to be done. It's going to take months."

The Parnells are hoping to carry on living there while their home dries out, as it is quite large and some parts were less affected than others. Luckily, as they were fully covered, they can let their insurance company sort out the financial side of the mess.

Mrs Parnell is all too aware how crucial it is to be properly insured - she works for Todmorden firm Donald Rigg Insurance Brokers, which has a lot of clients in the town and was this week deluged with calls from people who suffered flood damage.

Despite the growing number of bad weather incidents in recent years, from flash floods to tornadoes, it is estimated that 25% of households - 6m homes - are not covered by contents insurance. This figure rises to 42% in London.

"People say, 'I don't need insurance, nothing is ever going to happen', or 'I haven't got much'. You don't realise what you've got in your house until you actually sit down and really look," says Mrs Parnell.

The Association of British Insurers (ABI) says that while no one can control the weather, there are things homeowners can do to reduce the risk of suffering flood damage. In the event of a flood alert, anything that can be moved easily should be taken upstairs.

You may also wish to move your car or caravan on to higher ground for a couple of days. Move yourselves upstairs too if necessary, making sure you take food, warm clothing, a torch, first aid kit and important phone numbers with you.

If you are unlucky enough to be hit by floods, the priority should be to stop the damage getting worse, says the ABI. Contact your insurance company as soon as possible - most have 24-hour emergency helplines. They may be able to send someone round to do repairs.

"If you need work done, get it done," says Ian Frater at insurer CGU. However, keep hold of receipts for all work carried out as they will be needed when you make your claim.

Other advice includes:

 Don't use electricity or gas or drink tap water until the all-clear is given.

 Remove sodden floor coverings and wash down affected floors and walls with disinfectant or water.

 Leave as many doors, windows and cupboards open as possible, and try to get the warm air circulating.

 Pull furniture away from walls, and oil all of your hinges and locks to prevent them corroding.

Ideally, insurers like to see everything in situ, but use common sense - if a carpet is absolutely sopping wet, leaving it down may well just make things worse, so it may be better to shift it into the garden. However, you should take a photograph before you do this.

Most buildings and contents policies cover the cost of alternative accommodation if your home is so badly damaged that you have to move out while repairs are carried out.

Finally, don't be in a hurry to redecorate - it may take weeks or even months for walls and floors to dry out completely.

"Very often the damage you see initially is only the tip of the iceberg. Once the house has dried out it can be 12-18 months before you see shrinkage in wood panelling," warns Mr Frater.

"But don't be frightened of going back to your insurer at that point. If it is damage that can rightly be put down to the original flooding, then it is covered by the policy."

fields.headline: From the top
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two weeks after the collapse of Boo.com, an online search for recent company information produces an "unknown" response. If evidence was needed that those who rise fast fall fast here it is.
fields.body:
Two weeks after the collapse of Boo.com, an online search for recent company information produces an "unknown" response. If evidence was needed that those who rise fast fall fast here it is.

Commentators have been as quick to leap on the failure of the glamour coupling of Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander as to celebrate the end of the Hugh Grant/Liz Hurley power relationship. A new phrase "burn rate" was used to explain the demise of internet companies which consume cash at prodigious rates.

Among many stories of mis-management, one stood out: the visit by journalist John Cunningham to the company's offices days after the liquidators were called in. What he found was not employees fuelled by anger at being let down but individuals ready to move on with confidence in their future, because they had shared in the dream of their leaders.

The new generation of entrepreneurs may lack man agerial skill but have an instinctive ability to lead based on an understanding of the world in which they live. In her new book In Search of Leaders Hilarie Owen talks of leading through the translatory circle: the place where individuals are able to make sense of reality. For the first of the western philosophers, Thales, the challenge was to understand what the world was made of; for Pythagoras it was to understand number and pattern and relationship to the universe.

For e-entrepreneurs the challenge is to harness technology to create new global lifestyles. They pose a threat because they present realities which are incomprehensible to many business leaders. They also offer a model of leadership which challenges corporate conventions. The absence of suits in any e-commerce environment is seen as signalling a rejection of convention, but more significant shifts are in process.

The US-led Tom Peters generation focused on the unique qualities of visible leaders in defining and controlling a vision. The next generation's view of leadership is represented not by America, home of corporate man, but by liberal, unconventional Sweden. Two Swedes, Jonas Ridderstr le and Kjell Nordstrom of the Stockholm School of Economics are defining how talent needs to be managed if the business benefits of knowledge are to be realised.

They recognise that the only real asset e-businesses have is the knowledge of their staff, and in the world of knowledge workers' obedience is not a key competence. Rather than focus leadership energies on command and control, they should be directed towards creating the conditions which allow people to focus on what matters to them. Those conditions may look like chaos to corporate man: the impossibility of managing people who work unconventional hours or rarely attend the office, the challenge of maximising productivity when Playstations are encouraged rather than banned at work.

To Ridderstr le and Nordstrom, such apparent chaos frees people to operate at their best but does not re duce the need for leadership. Leaders provide meaning for those who work with them. They become the inspirers, the storytellers, the people who create the climate in which others want to be.

For all that Boo.com failed, the response of their staff suggests Malmsten and Leander did provide such meaning. One high-visibility failure should not suggest that the future of e-commerce lies in reasserting traditional management disciplines.

 Carole Pemberton is managing consultant at Career Matters. Hilarie Owen: In Search of Leaders (Wileys 2000) Jonas Ridderstr le and Kjell Nordstrom: Funky Business (FT.Com 2000)

webTitle: Redknapp faces surgery to save career

fields.headline: Redknapp faces surgery to save career
fields.trailText: The Liverpool midfielder Jamie Redknapp, who missed out on Euro 2000 through injury, is to undergo surgery in the United States as he tries to save his career.
fields.body:
The Liverpool midfielder Jamie Redknapp, who missed out on Euro 2000 through injury, is to undergo surgery in the United States as he tries to save his career.

Redknapp, who celebrates his 27th birthday this month, has been told that he may be forced into retirement unless a top specialist can unearth the cause of a persistent knee problem. Redknapp is to be treated by Richard Steadman, one of the world's leading orthopaedic surgeons, at the Steadman-Hawkins clinic in Vail, Colorado.

Late last week the Merseyside club confirmed that Redknapp's injury was so serious that he would be unable to resume even light training before August, the inference being that he would be sidelined until December.

The fear is that Redknapp's troublesome knee has been subjected to so much wear and tear in recent years that he may now be suffering from cruciate ligament damage.

Since fracturing an ankle playing for England against South Africa in 1996, Redknapp has only rarely achieved full fitness and he made only a handful of appearances for Liverpool last season after knee surgery in November.

The clinic, which Redknapp entered this week, does, however, boast a good track record in terms of retrieving what were seen as lost causes.

The former Germany striker Karlheinz Riedle received successful treatment on a cruciate injury there as did Redknapp's Anfield team-mate Patrik Berger. Ruud van Nistelrooy this week underwent a successful operation at the clinic to replace a knee ligament he injured in training after the breakdown of his transfer to Manchester United.

The Everton manager Walter Smith, who has been looking for a deal involving Don Hutchison, has proposed a swap with Coventry for the striker Noel Whelan.

Rangers yesterday signed the Danish youngster Peter Lovenkrands after the striker was advised to commit himself to the Glasgow giants by the former Ibrox star Brian Laudrup. Lovenkrands, 20, has joined on a four-year deal from AB Copenhagen. Newcastle, who claim they have a written pledge from the striker, plan to lodge a complaint with Fifa.

The Leicester City skipper Matt Elliott has ended speculation that he is to follow Martin O'Neill to Celtic by signing a new contract that will commit him to the Foxes until the summer of 2004.

It was the second boost for City yesterday after Muzzy Izzet insisted that he wants to tie up his long-term future at the club. The midfielder, who has 12 months left of his contract, will hold further talks when he returns from Euro 2000 duty with Turkey.

The chances of Peter Taylor becoming Leicester's new manager appeared to grow last night after the Gillingham chairman Paul Scally admitted he could not keep Taylor at the Priestfield Stadium. "I know there's nothing I can do to stop him and now I fully expect him to leave," he said.

Jim Smith is to sign a new deal that will commit him to Derby for two more seasons.
