fields.headline: Gregory faces Villa crisis
fields.trailText: John Gregory flies back from holiday today with Aston Villa threatening meltdown after Gareth Southgate requested a transfer out of Villa Park.
fields.body:
John Gregory flies back from holiday today with Aston Villa threatening meltdown after Gareth Southgate requested a transfer out of Villa Park.

The central defender's plea to be given the chance to "play in the biggest games possible and challenge for the championship" will add to the Villa manager's worries about the future of several of his players.

Gregory flies out to Euro 2000 tomorrow as a pundit for ITV and his brief stay in England makes it inevitable that the storm clouds will continue to gather in his absence, with Chelsea the favourites to land Southgate, 29, for a fee in the region of £4.5m. Southgate's £20,000-a-week wages would be no obstacle.

Gregory declined to comment although Villa released a statement saying that the club captain was staying.

"Gareth Southgate is contracted to Aston Villa Foot ball Club for a further period of three years and remains an Aston Villa player for this period," a spokesman said.

"Gareth and the manager are out of the country at present and the manager will be discussing the matter with Gareth at the earliest possible opportunity."

This is unlikely to be until Southgate returns from Euro 2000 duty with England and he seems determined to leave.

"I have given everything to Villa over the last few years but, if I am to achieve what I want to achieve in my career, it is time to move on," he said.

Southgate, though, is not Gregory's only problem. Ugo Ehiogu and the striker Julian Joachim have also asked for moves, Paul Merson is unhappy with his contract, Steve Watson and Alan Thompson appear to be for sale and the midfielder Lee Hendrie has been dismayed by the lack of contact from the club about talk of a transfer to Leeds.

Gregory has so far been un able to persuade Benito Carbone to stay at Villa Park and, while Luc Nilis has signed, there appears to be a lack of money available for further purchases, with building work under way to raise Villa Park's capacity to more than 50,000. Villa failed to qualify for the Uefa Cup last season after losing to Chelsea in last month's FA Cup final and will instead enter the InterToto Cup.

Home attendances last season averaged less than 35,000, and Robert Dore, the co-ordinator of the Aston Villa Shareholders Association, yesterday criticised the policy of expanding the stadium ahead of building the team. "We need big European nights to fill it," he said, "not InterToto Cup ties."

 Sheffield Wednesday and Kilmarnock have missed out on a place in next season's Uefa Cup. Lierse SK of Belgium and the Spanish club Rayo Vallecano were pulled out in a draw of the 14 clubs with the best fair-play record in Europe.

fields.headline: Man's job for England's teenager
fields.standfirst: Gareth Barry has played 26 minutes at the top level but the left foot counts
fields.trailText: Gareth Barry has played 26 minutes at the top level but the left foot counts. Roy Collins checks out the man with a talent that is all too rare among English footballers.
fields.body:
Gareth Barry is a name that ought to belong to the latest Welsh fly-half prospect. Instead it is the lilting handle of one of those rarest of English footballers, one who can kick a ball with his left foot, which has propelled him to Euro 2000 as the youngest and most surprising member of Kevin Keegan's squad, with a quietly building clamour for him to play.

Barry, 19, admits to experiencing a medley of emotions when he learned he was in Keegan's provisional 28 for Euro 2000. Disbelief and elation were among them but, believing he had less chance than Andy Cole of making the final 22, he also felt disappointment at being deprived of a place in the Under-21 tournament. "I was looking forward to going away with them," he says.

Even that turned out to be a lucky break, his former team-mates losing twice in three matches as they were eliminated before the knockout stage. Had Barry been one of them, he would now be getting over it on a foreign beach on the holiday he had promised himself. Instead he will swap a deckchair for a less relaxing seat on England's bench, waiting for the call to arms.

Unless the tummy bug that kept Tony Adams out of the game in Malta spreads through the dressing room this weekend, that is unlikely to come in time for Monday's opening game against Portugal because Keegan says he picked his team in his mind ages ago.

If, however, Phil Neville has one of his nightmares at left-back, Barry might find himself stripping off his tracksuit sooner than he imagined. Many people are beginning to suggest that, if England are to persist with 4-4-2, it would make sense to employ a left-back who can kick with that foot, a theory so logical it defies argument.

Weighed against it, of course, is that Barry has hardly got his knees brown at international level and is barely out of short trousers at league level. He admits: "I am not going with a lot of experience and I know there is not a lot for people to judge me on. But I have been doing my best to impress people and I am ready and confident if I am asked to play."

Barry can take encouragement from Nicky Barmby, another late and, to many observers, surprising addition to the squad, who has done so well, so quickly that he is now reckoned to be, in cricketing terms, first change. Barry says: "There probably are still opportunities for players to come in. No one is relaxing, everybody is still trying to impress the manager and, if that was not so, it wouldn't be right."

International football is totally different from the Premiership, he says, because "you're playing against foreigners who play a different kind of football," though it surely cannot be much different from facing Chelsea.

Barry, whose substitute appearances in the last two matches add up to 26 minutes of international experience, has completed only two full seasons in the Villa first team and was dropped towards the end of last term when his previously exemplary form faltered. Yet his Villa team-mate Gareth Southgate does not believe he would let his country down.

Southgate, just the sort of person you would like to appear from behind the screens to talk about you on This Is Your Life, says: "At Villa, we've seen him come through in such a very short space of time that we have tended to say that he is a very exciting prospect. But he is a very exciting talent here and now and he gives the manager an opportunity in terms of balance and his use of the ball."

Southgate, who still seems in need of counselling over his missed penalty against Germany which ended England's hopes of reaching the final of Euro 96, says he will not be volunteering this time. But Barry seems such a confident young man that, if he is playing, you can imagine his hand being one of the first in the air. The only worry, given the implications of his name, is that he would strike it over the bar.

Speaking before he flew out to Belgium with the rest of his team-mates, the Aston Villa central defender insisted: "We don't want moral victories, we want real ones. They are the ones that count. There was a bit of euphoria when we came home from the 1998 World Cup but the players don't believe that was a successful campaign.

"The truth of the matter is we had been knocked out in the second round and I found the reception we got on our return embarrassing. You are in this game to win things and be a success."

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • England will be hoping that Romania's run of bad luck since arriving in Belgium continues when the sides meet in Charleroi on Tuesday week. The players were forced to wait for 10 minutes before clearing customs, leaving the captain Gheorghe Hagi saying they had been treated like "criminals"; just before their arrival for their first training session a nearby car exploded and burst into flames; and, when they finally got going, Catalin Haldan was involved in a heavy collision with Miodrag Belodedici and knocked unconscious.
fields.body:
 England will be hoping that Romania's run of bad luck since arriving in Belgium continues when the sides meet in Charleroi on Tuesday week. The players were forced to wait for 10 minutes before clearing customs, leaving the captain Gheorghe Hagi saying they had been treated like "criminals"; just before their arrival for their first training session a nearby car exploded and burst into flames; and, when they finally got going, Catalin Haldan was involved in a heavy collision with Miodrag Belodedici and knocked unconscious.

 Luis Figo and Nuno Gomes scored hat-tricks as Portugal warmed up for their opening match against England by beating the Dutch part-timers DVS 33 11-0. Portugal's Everton defender Abel Xavier has set the standard off the pitch by dying his hair and beard bright yellow.

 England's match against Portugal will be refereed by the Swede Anders Frisk, who was in charge for Kevin Keegan's side's 2-1 victory over Belgium last October. Scotland's Hugh Dallas will referee Turkey and Italy on Sunday and England's representative, Graham Poll, begins with France against the Czech Republic a week today.

 Italy's injury problems continue to stack up after Alessandro Nesta, Gianluca Zambrotta and Paolo Negro were all injured in training. Zambrotta has hurt his right calf and will be replaced by Fiorentina's Angelo di Livio if he fails to recover in time for Italy's opening match against Turkey on Sunday. Negro has an ankle problem and Nesta injured his left shin. The Italians have already lost their first-choice striker and goalkeeper, Christian Vieri and Gianluigi Buffon respectively.

 A court has given Yugoslavia the go-ahead to play in the tournament. Kosovo-Albanian associations in Belgium had sought to prevent the national team from competing, citing a European Union resolution which keeps representatives of the Yugoslavian president Slobodan Milosevic's regime from entering other EU nations.

 Concerns over security have been taken to the extreme by the local authority in Amsterdam which has banned the wearing of balaclavas in the town for the duration of the tournament. Other rules include fines for climbing on fences and allowing Amsterdam's mayor to redirect traffic in a bid to maintain order.

 Sander Westerveld will face a church v country conflict if Holland live up to their billing as tournament favourites as he is the best man at his brother Wouter's wedding on June 30, two days before the final. "The ceremony is at one o'clock in the afternoon and, if I was given permission to go, that would be all I would attend," said the goalkeeper. "I would not go to the reception."

 Lothar Matthäus seems certain to play in Germany's opening game against Romania on Sunday after recovering from a thigh injury. The 39-year-old sweeper was substituted after half an hour of his side's friendly against Liechtenstein on Wednesday with muscle tightness in his left leg. He had previously been suffering with a torn muscle in his right thigh.

fields.headline: Shearer injury scare for England
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan could become the victim of his own bad planning after Alan Shearer yesterday became a major injury doubt for England's opening European Championship game against Portugal on Monday.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan could become the victim of his own bad planning after Alan Shearer yesterday became a major injury doubt for England's opening European Championship game against Portugal on Monday.

The captain underwent a scan on his knee yesterday and will not resume training until at least tomorrow.

Shearer hurt the knee falling awkwardly in the friendly against Malta last Saturday. But the question is why he was risked in the first place, because yesterday he admitted he had a "slight niggle" in his knee going into the game.

As the match was largely a flag-waving exercise Shearer's presence was hardly mandatory, especially as he had played in the previous two friendlies against Brazil and Ukraine. By starting him Keegan not only risked aggravating the "niggle" but also missed an opportunity to try out a different strike partnership as a fail-safe should he have to do without Shearer.

Now Keegan faces the prospect of going into the tournament with a rookie international strike-force, comprising Michael Owen and one of his Liverpool team-mates, Emile Heskey or Robbie Fowler.

Fowler has been struggling for match fitness after a lengthy injury lay-off. The only other striker in the squad is the newcomer Kevin Phillips.

The 29-year-old Shearer, who is due to retire from international football after Euro 2000, last scored for England seven games ago. But his tournament record - seven goals from nine matches in Euro 96 and the last World Cup - makes him England's only proven international goalscorer.

The injury has proved worse than first thought. When Shearer did not train on Wednesday Keegan insisted: "Alan Shearer will train tomorrow. He is fine. At a push he could have trained today."

But the Newcastle striker did not train yesterday and instead underwent a scan on his knee before flying out to the squad's base in Belgium.

"I had a scan this morning just as a precaution to see if there's anything in there," he said. "We'll wait for the results and take it from there. I don't think it will be a problem.

"I think it needs another day or two to settle down. I'm very confident, and the medical staff are very confident, that I'll be back in training on Saturday."

Keegan was also trying to look on the bright side. "The scan is a precaution," he said. "I'm not worried about Alan. I think he will be fine. The scans are the same thing with every player. Eight players have had scans this week. The technology is there and we use it."

However, the situation has uncomfortable echoes of Andy Cole's exit from the squad. He was deemed "fit" after visiting a specialist, only to be ruled out a couple of days later.

Keegan has until Monday's first-match deadline to bring a replacement for Shearer into the squad.

fields.headline: Banks: England should drop Shearer
fields.standfirst: Find out who Tony Banks, Charles Kennedy, John Redwood and Max Clifford reckon should play for England against Portugal.
fields.trailText: Labour MP Tony Banks
fields.body:
Labour MP Tony Banks

"I have picked a fluid 3-3-2-2 formation, with Beckham, Gerrard and Barmby playing in a tight midfield three and Scholes and Wise allowed the freedom to roam.

"The most obvious point about my selection is there's no Shearer. I certainly don't think he's past it - but Heskey and Owen offer something new. Heskey is big and strong up front, and what he lacks in pace is more than made up for by picking Owen.

"The same logic applies to choosing Seaman over Martyn. The Leeds keeper has had a very good season in goal and has proved himself for England, and so deserves his place. It was close with the Neville brothers - but both were just edged out on current form."

Team : Martyn; Campbell, Adams, Barry; Beckham, Gerrard, Barmby; Scholes, Wise; Heskey, Owen

Football Unlimited comment: Banks is a well-known football anorak, so it's no surprise to see him devising his own 3-3-2-2 formation, and choosing an attacking side which balances youth with experience. But there has to be a question mark over the lack of width - if Beckham and Barmby are pushed in, it places a heavy onus on Scholes and Wise to find space on the flanks. And does Heskey lack pace?

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy

"I would like to see the English team playing the 3-5-2 formation outlined below - it's a more progressive system, which encourages a European-style game and has a greater emphasis on attack. I appreciate that Seaman is amongst the best goalkeepers in the country, but Nigel Martyn's performance against Ukraine more than warrants his starting position in my team.

"I have chosen not to play the Neville brothers because they are not on form. It's a shame Kieron Dyer and Rio Ferdinand didn't make the squad - they are players of the future and would have benefited from some major tournament experience."

Team: Martyn; Southgate, Adams, Campbell; Beckham, Ince, Wise, Scholes, Barmby; Shearer and Owen. Subs: Keown, MacManaman, Phillips, Gerrard, Seaman

Football Unlimited comment: As you might expect, the Liberal Democrat leader goes for a continental-style 3-5-2. However his formation is tempered with a surprising amount of realism. The central midfield of Ince and Wise has a hard edge to it - and there's no place for floppy-haired maverick McManaman either.

Tory MP John Redwood

"I think control of the midfield is the key to winning a football match, which is why I have chosen 3-5-2. To be honest, I am not a huge football buff - my team is the result of advice I have received in the Commons pubs and bars."

Team (3-5-2) Martyn; Campbell, Keown, Adams; Barmby, Wise, Beckham, Scholes, P.Neville; Shearer, Owen

Football Unlimited comment: It was brave of John Redwood to step in when other Tories bottled out. For the record William Hague was "too busy", Michael Portillo claimed it would be "slightly disingenious" to name a team considering his lack of footballing knowledge, while Nigel Evans - the Tory spokesman on constitutional affairs - cut us off because he had another interview to go to and never managed to get back in touch, although our temperemental phone system may have had something to do with it.

So it would be slightly harsh of us to attack a team which, all-in-all, is quite sensible. Except, perhaps, for the choice of Phil Neville and Nick Barmby in the midfield.

PR guru Max Clifford

"I've got a lot of time for Campbell, but Adams and Keown work well together and know each others game inside out - which is why I've chosen them. McManaman deserves his place on the left because he adds that extra touch of flair. He can turn something out of nothing. And Shearer must start up front. He has the experience and is very good at what he does."

Team (4-4-2): Seaman, G.Neville, Adams, Keown, P.Neville; Beckham, Ince, Scholes, McManaman; Shearer, Owen

Football Unlimited comment This could well be the England team (and formation) against Portugal on Monday. It looks fairly solid, although Seaman and the Neville brothers won't be everyone's flavour of the month.

webTitle: Down and out in Belgium and Holland

fields.headline: Down and out in Belgium and Holland
fields.standfirst: Harry Pearson doesn't have to travel far to enjoy chips and beer with his football
fields.trailText: Harry Pearson doesn't have to travel far to enjoy chips and beer with his football
fields.body:
"Why," a German journalist at the World Cup in France asked rhetorically, "do people bother travelling half the length of the world to see strange things when Belgium is on their doorstep? Belgium is just as weird as Haiti, except that," he paused momentarily before delivering the clincher, "you eat better!"

Not perhaps the kind of endorsement a national tourist board might seek, but perhaps a fair summary of what awaits fans visiting the southern half of the Low Countries this summer.

Belgium is, of course, most often noted for being dull. Nothing could be further from the truth. But when you have been invaded as often as Belgium has, you adopt survival techniques. Boringness is Belgium's camouflage. "Nothing interesting here," is the message it sends to invaders. "Why don't you press on to France or Holland, eh? They've got loads of good stuff."

As a consequence, Belgium is a bit like one of those Magic Eye books. You can study it intently for hours without making out anything remarkable at all, then just as you are turning away something striking apears out of nowhere.

On the train from Lille to Brussels, just outside the town of Ath, you see a flock of ostriches strutting about in a sewage farm. You come across a dentist's surgery in Namur with a window display made up of a row of two-feet-high dolls, each clutching a lifesize pair of false teeth. A nearby wig shop offers a discount to students. In East Flanders there is a poodle parlour with the arresting English name Dogs' Toilet.

Not to be outdone, West Flanders boasts a whole museum devoted to bread, rolls, cakes and icing. One of the nation's biggest-selling ice lollies is called Big Nuts. People have net curtains in their windows embroidered with pictures of dinosaurs and straw post boxes in the shape of beehives. In Brussels the Museum of Underpants is said to have reopened after a period of closure. The owner is a friend of Noel Godin, the Belgian performance artist best known for smacking Bill Gates in the face with a cream pie.

There is a smattering of the bizarre in the Netherlands, too. How else can you describe a theme park of Biblical landmarks erected on a couple of hundred acres of marsh near Eindhoven, or the popular sport of pole-sitting? Generally speaking, though, it might be true to say that while Belgians have surrealism, the Dutch have efficiency. While Belgians, fed up with state corruption and incompetence, berate their nation as "a third world country in the heart of Europe", their northern neighbours sit back, confident in the knowledge that everything works properly in Holland.

And it's kept clean too. As far back as the 17th century, Holland's cleanliness was a source of wonder to visitors from the rest of Europe. Even members of Cromwell's puritan regime were impressed by the sparkling streets and the gleam of Dutch door hinges. A certain looseness may have crept into Amsterdam in recent years, but the rest of the nation remains impressively spotless. The morning after a night of disturbances in central Maastricht, a friend went down to see the extent of the damage. He found nothing. "In the Netherlands," he concluded, "even the hooligans clear up after themselves."

Cafes proliferate in both nations. However, the Netherland's Calvinist values gave local drinkers a tougher time of it than they had in Catholic Belgium (though the Protestants also banned opera, so at least they did some good). As a result, the per capita ratio of cafes is roughly three times higher there. Belgian prices are generally lower too, which explains the string of bars and drink warehouses that line the border like a licenced version of the Maginot Line.

The Dutch also lag behind when it comes to variety of beers they make, though their nation's merchant past has helped them promote the ones they do produce, such as Heineken, very successfully to the world at large. Belgian brewers are relentlessly inventive, spicing their ales with everything from coriander to woodruff. In most cafes you will find at least two dozen to choose from. In specialist establishments the list can run into four figures. Holland, though, is the only place where you can drink one that's spiked with cannabis. Well, legally anyway.

The Belgians take eating very seriously. The best English-language book on the subject of the local gastronomy is called, with admirable and thoroughly Flemish straightforwardness, The "You Always Eat Well In Belgium" Cookery Book. Dutch gardens are full of flowers; Belgian gardens are full of livestock. Just outside Brussels I once came across a man who had chickens, pigeons, rabbits and a pregnant sheep in his suburban backyard. The only vegetation apart from grass was a herb patch and a row of onions. It wasn't very pretty, but try making a decent stew out of tulips.

Chips are a unifying culinary item. The Belgian variety is justifiably famous, but the Dutch version is just as good. You can buy them at a street corner shop or mobile caravan. Depending on your whereabouts, you might eat them with frogs' legs, snails, shrimp croquettes or sausage. You can have them on their own, dolloped with mayonnaise or, if you are in Wallonia (the French-speaking south of Belgium), in a "mitrailleuse", the local answer to the chip butty.

Beer, chips and football. As my German colleague remarked, "Why go further?"

Not perhaps the kind of endorsement a national tourist board might seek, but perhaps a fair summary of what awaits fans visiting the southern half of the Low Countries this summer. Belgium is, of course, most often noted for being dull. Nothing could be further from the truth. But when you have been invaded as often as Belgium has, you adopt survival techniques. Boringness is Belgium's camouflage. "Nothing interesting here," is the message it sends to invaders. "Why don't you press on to France or Holland, eh? They've got loads of good stuff." As a consequence, Belgium is a bit like one of those Magic Eye books. You can study it intently for hours without making out anything remarkable at all, then just as you are turning away something striking apears out of nowhere. On the train from Lille to Brussels, just outside the town of Ath, you see a flock of ostriches strutting about in a sewage farm. You come across a dentist's surgery in Namur with a window display made up of a row of two-feet-high dolls, each clutching a lifesize pair of false teeth. A nearby wig shop offers a discount to students. In East Flanders there is a poodle parlour with the arresting English name Dogs' Toilet. Not to be outdone, West Flanders boasts a whole museum devoted to bread, rolls, cakes and icing. One of the nation's biggest-selling ice lollies is called Big Nuts. People have net curtains in their windows embroidered with pictures of dinosaurs and straw post boxes in the shape of beehives. In Brussels the Museum of Underpants is said to have reopened after a period of closure. The owner is a friend of Noel Godin, the Belgian performance artist best known for smacking Bill Gates in the face with a cream pie. There is a smattering of the bizarre in the Netherlands, too. How else can you describe a theme park of Biblical landmarks erected on a couple of hundred acres of marsh near Eindhoven, or the popular sport of pole-sitting? Generally speaking, though, it might be true to say that while Belgians have surrealism, the Dutch have efficiency. While Belgians, fed up with state corruption and incompetence, berate their nation as "a third world country in the heart of Europe", their northern neighbours sit back, confident in the knowledge that everything works properly in Holland. And it's kept clean too. As far back as the 17th century, Holland's cleanliness was a source of wonder to visitors from the rest of Europe. Even members of Cromwell's puritan regime were impressed by the sparkling streets and the gleam of Dutch door hinges. A certain looseness may have crept into Amsterdam in recent years, but the rest of the nation remains impressively spotless. The morning after a night of disturbances in central Maastricht, a friend went down to see the extent of the damage. He found nothing. "In the Netherlands," he concluded, "even the hooligans clear up after themselves." Cafes proliferate in both nations. However, the Netherland's Calvinist values gave local drinkers a tougher time of it than they had in Catholic Belgium (though the Protestants also banned opera, so at least they did some good). As a result, the per capita ratio of cafes is roughly three times higher there. Belgian prices are generally lower too, which explains the string of bars and drink warehouses that line the border like a licenced version of the Maginot Line. The Dutch also lag behind when it comes to variety of beers they make, though their nation's merchant past has helped them promote the ones they do produce, such as Heineken, very successfully to the world at large. Belgian brewers are relentlessly inventive, spicing their ales with everything from coriander to woodruff. In most cafes you will find at least two dozen to choose from. In specialist establishments the list can run into four figures. Holland, though, is the only place where you can drink one that's spiked with cannabis. Well, legally anyway. The Belgians take eating very seriously. The best English-language book on the subject of the local gastronomy is called, with admirable and thoroughly Flemish straightforwardness, The "You Always Eat Well In Belgium" Cookery Book. Dutch gardens are full of flowers; Belgian gardens are full of livestock. Just outside Brussels I once came across a man who had chickens, pigeons, rabbits and a pregnant sheep in his suburban backyard. The only vegetation apart from grass was a herb patch and a row of onions. It wasn't very pretty, but try making a decent stew out of tulips. Chips are a unifying culinary item. The Belgian variety is justifiably famous, but the Dutch version is just as good. You can buy them at a street corner shop or mobile caravan. Depending on your whereabouts, you might eat them with frogs' legs, snails, shrimp croquettes or sausage. You can have them on their own, dolloped with mayonnaise or, if you are in Wallonia (the French-speaking south of Belgium), in a "mitrailleuse", the local answer to the chip butty. Beer, chips and football. As my German colleague remarked, "Why go further?"

fields.headline: Transport of delight
fields.standfirst: Des Lynam gets the rock-star treatment, when he tours Euro 2000 with ITV. Adam Sills flags down the Desmobile
fields.trailText: Des Lynam gets the rock-star treatment, when he tours Euro 2000 with ITV. Adam Sills flags down the Desmobile
fields.body:
A chariot maybe, a limousine certainly, but Des Lynam being transported in a bus? What is the world coming to? First it was having to deal with adverts and now this.

But before Mrs Outraged of Surrey puts in a call to ITV to complain at such ghastly treatment of her beloved Dessie, it should be made clear that this is not just any common or garden No 22.

Far from it. For Lynam is to anchor ITV's Euro 2000 coverage from a transporter fit for the Spice Girls, Bryan Ferry and Tina Turner. Paul Weller handed over the luxury liner at the end of May and Des will hold court for the next month. He is going on tour: finally his true rock-star status is being recognised. If a bus more used to groupies than group games is not the most conventional means of transport for a 57-year-old football presenter, then it is, according to ITV's head of football Jeff Farmer, the most appropriate for Euro 2000. Farmer does not want a repeat of the problems at the 1998 World Cup where a strike by Air France meant that a Lear jet had to be hired for four days to ensure that the production team were not left stranded.

Lynam will be covering 10 live games in 12 days including nine changes of venue, and given the proximity of the host towns in the Netherlands and Belgium, a bus will give the team more flexibility. ITV executives have carried out two coach tours of the eight venues in the past two years and each time the reconnaissance mission took just five days.

Anyway, if that other housewife's favourite, Tom Jones, can cope with the rigours of life on a bus, Lynam should surely take to it like a duck to water.

"The Desmobile is not a gimmick. It won't have a jacuzzi or luxury beds," says Farmer. "Then again it won't be just 58 seats. There will nice comfortable armchairs and it will be very similar to when a pop star is using it. Des is very laidback and he is very comfortable with the arrangements."

While Lynam and his team of producer, assistant producers, director, make-up artist and secretary will not sleep in the bus, it will be used as a mobile base from which he can watch videos of matches, study particular players, collect statistics together and have use of fax and email.

But ITV are sensitive enough to the feelings of their female viewers not to let Lynam be seen on television on a bus in front of a stack of video screens.

He will present matches from within the stadiums, only retiring to the Desmobile once the cameras have been switched off.

Travelling around in a bus may not be quite what Lynam envisaged when he completed his reputed £1.25m transfer from the BBC, but money aside, it was the attraction of hosting live rather than recorded football that enticed him to agree to the move.

He made his debut last September for Chelsea v Milan in the Champions League and, Farmer insists, he has exceeded expectations. "Des has made an enormous impact and he's had a great season. I have worked with many people over the years but Des is definitely the best," he says.

"His input into programmes is excellent and his performance on the screen is there for everyone to see. He has a three-year contract and he'll find it very difficult to give up. He loves football and he loves broadcasting and, as he says, it's a bit different to a proper job."

Just like being a rock star -- and lucky Lynam will get a taste of that world as well this month.

The line-ups:

ITV

Anchorman: Des Lynam

Fellow presenters: Bob Wilson, Gabby Yorath

Pundits: Glenn Hoddle, Terry Venables, Bobby Robson, Kevin Keegan (once England are knocked out), Barry Venison, Ruud Gullit, Ally McCoist

Commentators: Clive Tyldesley, Peter Drury, Guy Mowbray, Peter Brackley, David Pleat, Ron Atkinson

Reporters: Gary Newbon, Gabriel Clarke, Dave Beckett

Strengths: Lynam still reigns supreme and Tyldesley is now the best football commentator on television. Impressive line-up of pundits, and the capture of Keegan should boost ratings.

Weaknesses: Always a danger with England hasbeens that they will hark back to the good old days. Yorath and Wilson have not convinced as understudies to Lynam while Atkinson and Pleat remain unpredictable.

BBC

Anchorman: Gary Lineker

Fellow presenter: Ray Stubbs

Pundits: Alan Hansen, Trevor Brooking, Mark Lawrenson, Martin O'Neill, David O'Leary, Johan Cruyff, Dion Dublin

Commentators: John Motson, Barry Davies, Jon Champion, Tony Gubba

Reporters: Hazel Irvine, Garth Crooks, Mark Bright, Mark Pougatch

Strengths: Hansen remains at the top of the punditry pile, while O'Neill was a hit at the last World Cup. Stubbs is a capable deputy to Lineker, who has done his best to fill the void left by Lynam.

Weaknesses: Whether Cruyff is as big a success as Gullit was at Euro 96 remains to be seen and the commentary department could do with some freshening up.

fields.headline: The online line-up
fields.standfirst: While TV and radio are still first choice for live coverage, more and more information-hungry punters are turning to the internet. Paul MacInnes looks at what it has to offer
fields.trailText: While TV and radio are still first choice for live coverage, more and more information-hungry punters are turning to the internet. Paul MacInnes looks at what it has to offer
fields.body:
When more than a billion people visited the official France 98 website during the last World Cup, it was hailed as a watershed for the internet. Instead of turning to the radio or even TV for information, it was claimed, people across the world were turning on their PCs.

In the two years since Zinedine Zidane's face scowled down from the Arc de Triomphe the internet, of course, has undergone a dot.com revolution. Squillions of pounds in venture capital have funded almost as many sports sites, all of which will be covering Euro 2000. But while investment has increased the opportunity for entrepreneurs, it hasn't necessarily extended choice for users.

This applies particularly to news coverage. It is rare that a site without a media partner will have its own correspondents and, as a result, stories tend to replicate from site to site. There is not a lot of difference between the news stories on, say, the CBS-owned Sports.com - for whom Euro 2000 is just one of many current competitions (football.sports.com/euro2000/) - and Danny Kelly's specialised Eurofinals 365 (english.eurofinals365.com).

Instead, sites attempt to distinguish themselves by their comment and opinion. 365 is always first in line to provide tub-thumping analysis of England's chances (they want Kevin Phillips to partner Alan Shearer this summer), while ZOOfootball (zoofootball.com) has signed up Jack Charlton to share his experience and his head for names with the readers. Also worth an occasional read is Steve Curry's weekly column for Planetfootball (planetfootball.com).

While the musings of a Sunday Telegraph football writer may not be your idea of cutting-edge technology, one area in which the net really scores is the depth of statistics available. The undisputed king of facts is Soccerbase (soccerbase.com). If you ever wanted to know Zlatko Zahovic's goals-to-games ratio (0.47) or the number of clubs Romania's Gica Popescu has played for (five if you include Spurs), this is the place. The Italian site Soccerage (SoccerAGE.com) also has reasonably up-to-date line-ups and, if the player plays in Serie A, lots of information on their recent form.

The wealth of available statistics is accompanied by a plethora of fantasy football-style games which have been set up in time for the tournament. The original (fantasyleague.com/euro2000) is running two types of league for the duration of the tournament -- one open league and one for private competition among (so-called) friends. And in a move that must have cost a pretty penny, the World Soccer Xchange has secured the address euro2000.com to house a special edition of its football-based stock-trading game.

Punters may be disappointed not to find any audio or video of the big games online. While radio commentary on Premiership matches is commonplace (and increasingly popular), Uefa sold the broadcasts rights to the tournament way back in 1993, before even the creators of the Champions League had realised what a money-spinner the net could be.

Don't expect the situation to be the same in four years' time, if Uefa's official site for Euro 2000 (euro2000.org) is anything to go by. By far the best site online this summer, Lennart Johansson's technical munchkins have served up everything their commercial rivals have to offer and more. There is news, interviews, profiles of teams and players, schedules, travel guides and interactive polls. But knocking everything else out of the box is the video archive of goals from Italy 1980 to England 1996, which allows you to watch Marco van Basten crack the ball from an impossible angle past Dasayev at your leisure. Now that's technology at work.

Top five Euro 2000 sites

euro2000.org
The official site, and the best.

fsa.org.uk/
The electronic home of the Football Supporters' Association. Not a bad address to have if you get stuck in the Lowlands.

ec-2000.com/fans/
An informative guide to the host cities in Belgium and Holland from a Dutch site. Also contains a plea to all supporters to "have a great party, make it one of the best and nicest times of your life, but please behave".

The AA
The men in yellow help you to drive to Euro 2000.

footballunlimited.co.uk
News and reviews from the Guardian and Observer, plus daily email updates, live coverage, When Saturday Comes analysis, and even cartoon match reports. Unrivalled, naturally.

webTitle: News of the World journalists arrested for carrying offensive weapons

fields.headline: News of the World journalists arrested for carrying offensive weapons
fields.trailText: Three News of the World journalists have been arrested by Belgian police after they were caught posing with hunting knives and a crossbow.
fields.body:
Three News of the World journalists have been arrested by Belgian police after they were caught posing with hunting knives and a crossbow.

Police in Brussels would not confirm their identities, but said the three men had been taking photographs in a park while in possession of the weapons.

A spokeswoman for The News of the World claimed the journalists were investigating the widespread availability of lethal weapons on the eve of Euro 2000. "The three men were engaged in an entirely legitimate journalistic exercise in the public interest," she said. "We are extremely concerned at their detention and have taken immediate steps with the authorities to secure their prompt release." But a police spokesman revealed the three journalists were facing possible charges for possessing weapons "without good reason".

He explained: "Nobody can carry weapons without a valid reason or authorisation. They were carrying hunting knives - and they were not hunting so they were breaking the law".

The final decision will be taken this afternoon by the Public Prosecutor's Office.

webTitle: Attack is England's best means of defence

fields.headline: Attack is England's best means of defence
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 home
fields.trailText: Get themselves right and England can make the semi-finals at least. And that means going 3-5-2 and incorporating as many attack-minded players as possible.
fields.body:
I am sorry to say this is the least confident I have felt about England's prospects in a major championship for some time. But I know how I would set about things to give the team the best chance. Get themselves right and England can make the semi-finals at least. And that means going 3-5-2 and incorporating as many attack-minded players as possible.

Against Portugal I would use David Beckham, Paul Scholes and Steve McManaman as the trio in the middle of the park. Radical, yes; predictable, no. And that is the key.

England have traditionally gone into tournaments looking to be solid and hard to beat. The old 4-4-2, with a midfield ball-winner and the emphasis on crosses, has failed. It made us too stereotyped. So let's try something different. Let's see more flair and take the game to the opposition.

Beckham, Scholes and McManaman have great energy and quality. They can play combinations and feed the strikers. McManaman has shown at Real Madrid that he can make things happen. People here expect him to run with the ball but he has developed into a very good quick-passing player.

If those three dictate a high-tempo, quick-passing game, they will pull opponents out of position and make space to run. So I would omit Paul Ince and Dennis Wise and supplement my midfield by using the Nevilles at wing-back.

That makes my starting XI for Monday's opening game against Portugal: Martyn; Keown, Adams, Southgate; G Neville, Beckham, Scholes, McManaman, P Neville; Shearer, Owen.

I know Kevin Keegan does not agree with my choice of keeper but I go for Nigel Martyn ahead of David Seaman because he is the man in form. I opt for Gareth Southgate ahead of Sol Campbell because he is uncomplicated and reliable, never over-ambitious. At the moment Campbell seems more concerned with charging upfield with the ball than concentrating on defence. He has disturbed me a bit in his defensive work, and the shock of coming out of the side might buck him up.

The Neville brothers are an obvious choice. Firstly they bring experience but I also feel wing-backs should be defenders who can attack rather than attackers who can defend. Gareth Barry is composed and left-footed but at the moment he is not the greatest defender and against Portugal he'd be fishing Luis Figo, who is close to being the best player in the world.

The Portuguese have another world-class midfielder in Rui Costa. Manchester United let him roam in Florence in a Champions League match last season and he ripped them to pieces. The idea of my line-up is to force him to defend. When England got going against Ukraine and played without inhibition they were impressive.

I hope Keegan goes with his natural instincts. But, however England play, France are my favourites. They arrive with the confidence and know-how of world champions and are even stronger than in 1998.

Then they lacked a world-class striker. Now they have three excellent centre-forwards in Nicolas Anelka, David Trezeguet and Thierry Henry, who I think could be the tournament's star. I saw some of his performance in the 5-1 win over Morocco on Tuesday and he's really on song. In fact it's hard to see a weakness in the French side.

Fabien Barthez's move to United will have given him fresh impetus, Lilian Thuram is one of the world's best defenders and Marcel Desailly thrives on these occasions. In midfield Patrick Vieira is a marvellous player. I think he'll come in for Didier Deschamps and, although I would have liked to have seen David Ginola, his international time has gone.

I also expect Holland, one of France's group rivals, to be in the frame. When they hit a streak they can beat anybody but their biggest problem might be the self- destruct button. You're never quite sure how the internal politics in their camp might go off.

Watch out also for Italy. As far as I'm concerned Italian football is not on the wane and the lack of expectation might help them. They are looking for a new Roberto Baggio and in Francesco Totti they might have found him.

But the team I've got a little fancy for as dark horses are Yugoslavia. They've always had some of the best talent in Europe and in Savo Milosevic, Darko Kovacevic and Predrag Mijatovic they certainly have some fine strikers.

I always think this is a better tournament than the World Cup because there is less of a gap in quality between the teams without anyone from Oceania, Asia, etc. And for all the talk about more sophisticated defences, if last season's Champions League was anything to go by, there will be plenty of goals.

But, however England play, France are my favourites. They arrive with the confidence and know-how of world champions and are even stronger than in 1998. Then they lacked a world-class striker. Now they have three excellent centre-forwards in Nicolas Anelka, David Trezeguet and Thierry Henry, who I think could be the tournament's star. I saw some of his performance in the 5-1 win over Morocco on Tuesday and he's really on song. In fact it's hard to see a weakness in the French side. Fabien Barthez's move to United will have given him fresh impetus, Lilian Thuram is one of the world's best defenders and Marcel Desailly thrives on these occasions. In midfield Patrick Vieira is a marvellous player. I think he'll come in for Didier Deschamps and, although I would have liked to have seen David Ginola, his international time has gone. I also expect Holland, one of France's group rivals, to be in the frame. When they hit a streak they can beat anybody but their biggest problem might be the self- destruct button. You're never quite sure how the internal politics in their camp might go off. Watch out also for Italy. As far as I'm concerned Italian football is not on the wane and the lack of expectation might help them. They are looking for a new Roberto Baggio and in Francesco Totti they might have found him. But the team I've got a little fancy for as dark horses are Yugoslavia. They've always had some of the best talent in Europe and in Savo Milosevic, Darko Kovacevic and Predrag Mijatovic they certainly have some fine strikers. I always think this is a better tournament than the World Cup because there is less of a gap in quality between the teams without anyone from Oceania, Asia, etc. And for all the talk about more sophisticated defences, if last season's Champions League was anything to go by, there will be plenty of goals.

fields.headline: Welcome to Euro 2000
fields.standfirst: This year's European Championship is going to remembered for many years to come, predicts David Lacey
fields.trailText: This year's European Championship is going to remembered for many years to come, predicts David Lacey.
fields.body:
The first European Championship of the 21st century should be a memorable experience. Whether or not it will be remembered for the right reasons, however, is hard to tell.

For the tournament to be an unqualified success three things need to happen. The football has to be of a high technical level while at the same time being imaginative and positive, the refereeing should combine discipline with commonsense, and the Armageddon threatened by multinational hooligan mobs converging on the Low Countries must be a non-event.

The matches themselves ought to have the least difficulty meeting these criteria. Most of the finalists will field the best talents of the Champions League apart from South Americans, Africans and the odd antipodean.

France, the World Cup holders, will vie with Holland, arguably the best team in 1998, for the position of favourites, and much will depend on the form, mood and fitness of such outstanding individuals as Zinedine Zidane and Dennis Bergkamp, Laurent Blanc and Patrick Kluivert. Thierry Henry is a major threat since Arsenal converted him into a striker, David Trezeguet is in equally good scoring form and perhaps Nicolas Anelka will emerge from his latest slough to take Euro 2000 by storm.

European Championships have a habit of producing ill-considered finalists who sometimes win the prize: Czechoslovakia in 1976, for example, or Denmark, reinstated after Yugoslavia's disqualification, in 1992. Few thought Belgium would finish runners-up in 1980 and the Czech Republic only lost the 1996 final at Wembley to Oliver Bierhoff's winner for Germany in sudden-death overtime.

The dark horses this time are not so much the Czechs, who won all their qualifiying games, as teams like Yugoslavia, Portugal and, yes, England, whose overall record in this competition is so wretched (only four victories in the tournament proper) that Kevin Keegan's side might suddenly surprise everybody, not least themselves.

Certainly England will not fail for a lack of maturing talent. What would Germany not give for a David Beckham, a Michael Owen, a Paul Scholes or even a Steven Gerrard? Maybe Erich Ribbeck's team are the darkest horses of all but when Jens Jeremies, industrious and perceptive though hardly another Franz Beckenbauer, is Germany's most consistent player there is clearly a lot of work to do.

Italy and Spain will carry shorter odds than England or Germany even though neither has won a European Championship since the 60s. In fact both have a tendency to punch below their weight in this competition, witness Italy's collapse in 1996 after Arrigo Sacchi had mucked about with his team in the first round.

The Czech Republic would appear to be the best bet to become only the third team from eastern Europe to win the tournament, although Romania and Yugoslavia can match them for quality of players. For sustained quality and excitement no European Championship, before or since, has equalled the semi-finals and final of 1976 when Yugoslavia, West Germany and Czechoslovakia produced enthralling football at a breathtaking pace before Antonin Panenka's nonchalant penalty, after Uli Hoeness had missed in the shoot-out for the Germans, took the Henri Delaunay Cup to Prague.

Add Gunther Netzer's inspired performance for West Germany when they beat the Soviet Union 3-0 in the final four years earlier, Marco van Basten's remarkable volley which completed Holland's 2-0 victory over the Soviets in the 1988 final, the sheer joy of the Danish triumph against Germany in 1992 and Bierhoff's history-making "golden goal" last time and there you have some of the best European Championship memories.

For England, of course, 1996 was all about football coming home and chariots swinging low, Paul Gascoigne's outrageously impudent goal against Scotland, the sudden fusillade against Holland, David Seaman's save in the shoot-out with Spain and Darren Anderton coming within a post's width of beating German in extra time in the semi-finals, before Gareth Southgate met his calvary when the game went to penalties.

Overall it was not the greatest of European Championships. Too many players fell below expected form with the Dutch and the French not least among them. The introduction of sudden death if scores were level after 90 minutes did not prevent two quarter-finals and both semi-finals being decided on penalties. For once the better matches were seen in the opening groups.

Refereeing howlers are unavoidable but it is to be hoped that none will be as blatant as the moment in Euro 96 when Dorinal Munteanu's shot for Romania struck the Bulgarian crossbar and bounced down well behind the line only for a goal to be refused. Or the trip by Gascoigne on Alfonso which sent the Spaniard tumbling in the England penalty area without a penalty being given.

The refereeing this time should take its cue from the Champions League, which this last season has generally struck a proper balance between the need for strict control and an unnecessary preponderance of yellow and red cards. The referees in Euro 2000 should emulate the more sensible aspects of the easing-up on cards in England since the New Year, while ignoring the absurd lengths to which this leniency has sometimes stretched.

Then there are the noises off. It is a sad fact that since 1980 every European Championship in which England have been involved has been accompanied by hooliganism in varying measures. Even the amiable, carnival atmosphere of Euro 96 was let down by the violence in central London which followed England's defeat on penalties by Germany in the semi-finals.

Not that the English fans have always been responsible for the violence. The teargas riot which halted England's game against Belgium in Turin in 1980 was instigated by local Juventus supporters. In West Germany 1988 and again in Sweden in 1992, the worst outbreaks of mayhem involved Germans, but in each case it was England's long-standing association with hooliganism which caught the media's attention.

With Fifa voting to decide who will host the 2006 World Cup only four days after the European Championship final, this would be a bad time for television pictures of English skinheads engaged in running battles with Dutch or Belgian police having smashed up bars in Eindhoven or Charleroi to be flashed around the globe.

Insisting that England and Germany meet in tiny Charleroi, instead of Brussels or Rotterdam, could be a fateful error by Uefa which may affect the whole tournament. Such fears may prove groundless, but this time too many troublemakers are within commuting distance of getting, and giving, their kicks.

fields.headline: You bet your life!
fields.trailText: Four men, each with a habit of throwing good money after bad. One online bookmaker, foolish enough to provide each of the men with £50 to squander. One goal: to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you by BlueSq.
fields.byline: Paul MacInnes, Mike Hodgkinson, Scott Murray and Sean Ingle
fields.body:
Four men, each with a habit of throwing good money after bad. One online bookmaker, foolish enough to provide each of the men with £50 to squander. One goal: to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you by BlueSq.

Mike Hodgkinson

Belgium v Sweden: Frederik Ljungberg first scorer 12/1 (£5)

Sweden are not the quite the force they were in qualifying but they won't let in too many goals during the tournament, which always makes them worth considering for first scorers. Arsenal's self-confessed porn aficionado appeals because he'll not only mop up any of his strikers' near misses, he'll also take the occasional unprovoked pop goalwards.

Italy v Turkey: Turkey to win 4/1 (£10)

Turkey are one of the most under-rated and overpriced teams of the tournament - the midfield know each other like brothers rather than distant cousins and when he's on song Hakan Sukur can bury anything, including Italy's chances of winning their opening match. Without Vieri, the Azzuri may look a bit pale and the likes of Inzaghi and Del Piero have not been too sharp of late.

Fancy a wager?

Paul MacInnes

Belgium v Sweden: 0-0 correct score 5/1 (£5)

First of all I must confess that I know bugger all about betting. I would never go into a bookies just in case some old man persuaded me to put all my wages on a lame donkey. I know slightly more about that game they call football, however, and as far as I can remember, opening games in major tournaments aren't usually that exciting (Argentina crashing to Cameroon aside). So that's why my first wager, all £5 of it, is going on a 0-0 draw between Belgium and Sweden at odds of 5-1.

Holland v Czech Republic: Patrick Kluivert last goalscorer 4/1 (£5)

For a mug like myself, Sunday is much more confusing. Should I back moody Nic Anelka to bag the first goal for France against Denmark? Or pick Turkey (at a tasty 9/2) to have a half-time lead against Italy? Eventually I decided on neither and put another fiver (even units are best, I've decided) on the match of the day: Holland v Czech Republic. I'm not the biggest fan of big Pat Kluivert, but he seems to like playing in orange and I've backed him at 4-1 to score the last goal of the game. £10 down, £40 to go...

Fancy a wager?

Scott Murray

Belgium v Sweden: 1-1 correct score 5/1 (£5)

Tournament curtain-raisers always seem to be low-scoring, tedious affairs which, by the time sixty minutes are up, make you pine for the opening ceremony. As neither Belgium or Sweden are big on free scoring or entertainment, it's 1-1 all the way for me, one midway through each half to ensure a total lack of drama. And if I'm wrong, at least we get a classic match. Unless it's 0-0, of course, in which case we'll all be sorry.

Italy v Turkey: Italy to win 4/6 (£10)

Now to try to claw back some ground after yesterday's disaster. Turkish football may be on something of a high, but Galatasaray didn't exactly set the world alight with the manner in which they won the Uefa Cup. On the other hand, they did hilariously plonk Milan out of Europe in the early stages of this year's Champions League. But the Italians have too many good players for their recent poor run to continue, so a vote in favour of the big boys is my reckless shout here.

Fancy a wager?

Sean Ingle

Belgium v Sweden: 2-3 goals scored 10/11 (£5)

Opening games have a reputation for being soulless and goalless, but the evidence doesn't really back this up. The first game in the past three European Championships for instance (1988: West Germany 1-1 Italy, 1992: Sweden 1-1 France, 1996: England 1-1 Switzerland) have all been scoring draws. Why should it be any different when Belgium play Sweden?

That's why I've resisted the temptation to back the Red Devils and instead bet £5 on game containing two or three goals. If you need further encouragement, Belgium are full of goals at the minute (last week they drew 2-2 with Denmark, and they've had two recent high-scoring draws against Holland) and they will attack in front of their home fans. So even if Sweden play it tight, it's not unreasonable to expect the net to bulge.

Win double France and Holland to win 8/13 and 4/6 (£5)

On Sunday I go for a £5 win double: France (8/13) to beat Denmark, and Holland (4/6) to beat Czech Republic. Together the double pays just under two-and-a-half to one, which spells value in anybody's language.

Fancy a wager?

webTitle: How much is that dog in the window?

fields.headline: How much is that dog in the window?
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 is turning into a cattle market, says Darren Tackle, and he should know
fields.trailText: Euro 2000 is turning into a cattle market, says Darren Tackle, and he should know.
fields.body:
Ask any of the assorted tossers, students and muppets what make up the media and that, what they reckon Euro 2000 is all about and they'll tell you it's the great players, the heroes, the role models. They'll drone on about your Zidanes, your Rauls and your Phil Nevilles of this world. Oh aye, all you have to do to see them all at it is to switch on any television station or radio outfit (BBC Hereford and Worcester's coverage can be particularly recommended as it will include the expert thoughts of a certain tough-tackling, overlapping wing-back scandalously overlooked for national duty by badger hair).

Yeah, there'll be your goals of the tournament phone-in polls (calls cost 90p per minute and last a minimum of 25 minutes) and your dribbles of the week in super slo-mo flash back. Des Lynam will raise an eyebrow about some fancy French dan and Martin O'Neill will get all overexcited, jumping up and down, wetting his tracksuit at the sight of Dutch technique. Everyone will be banging on about quality, quality and quality.

Which is exactly why your media and that hasn't got a clue. Like many an honest, home-grown professional, quite literally sweating his cods off on the coal face that is the English Premiership, Darren Tackle will be observing the Euro 2000 tournament with a very different focus. His eye, trained very much by experience to home in on what matters, will be locked on the one crucial issue thrown up by the tournament. Namely, yours truly will be scanning the horizon for Romanian cart horses, Portuguese plodders, Norwegian no-marks and Slovenian donkeys what will be putting their diving, water-carrying and whinging very much in the shop window, hoping, praying even, to be taking the jobs of your Darren Tackles of this world come August.

Don't try and pretend that's not what Euro 2000's about. It's all a bleedin conspiracy by club chairmen and managers to fill their teams with cheap continental imports no better than the honest, decent local talent while claiming they is buying international players with tournament experience. How do you think Old Demo got hold of the Bosnians? Although, come to think of it, I seem to remember summat about them coming over via Dover under a tarpaulin in the back of some truck owned by one of Mr Chairman's mates what's in haulage. Anyhow, the point is this. If you want to know who'll be turning out for your team come next season, there's no point looking at what Des Lynam says.

Alessandro Del Piero for Bradford? Nicolas Anelka for Derby? Anybody at all what can play keepy-uppy for more than 25 seconds for Spurs? Come on, get real. No if you really want to spot the shape of things to come, check out Slovenia, Portugal, Denmark, Sweden and Norway. Trust Tackle on this one. He'll be watching them. Through the sight of his AK47.

fields.headline: Grammar school vote upheld
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government has thrown out a complaint about the conduct of a ballot which failed to convert Ripon grammar school in North Yorkshire into a comprehensive.
fields.body:
The government has thrown out a complaint about the conduct of a ballot which failed to convert Ripon grammar school in North Yorkshire into a comprehensive.

In the first ballot of its kind under legislation introduced by Labour, parents voted by two to one this year to preserve selection arrangements at England's oldest grammar school.

The Ripon branch of the Campaign against Selective Education had complained the ballot rules were unfair and that a pro-grammar school campaign video featured both the headteacher and his secondary modern counterpart, who were supposed to be neutral.

The Department for Education said yesterday: "The decision to uphold the ballot result means there can be no petitions or ballots before June 2005."

Yesterday Kelvin Koogan swore on Mohamed Al-Fayed's especially holy Koran that Alan Shearer would have "until kick-off" to prove his fitness for England's opening match against Portugal. So it was no surprise that by this afternoon he'd completely changed his mind. The deadline, Koogan told journalists in his best Hollywood baddie voice, had suddenly been moved back 36 hours - for no reason whatsoever.

"If Alan cannot announce his fitness by Sunday morning then we will name a team that does not include him," Koogan told the press, before adding a complete unnecessary "Ha ha ha ha!" And just to prove he'd got tough with his favourite player, Koogan said, "If Alan says 'look, I am not fit, but I want to play' then obviously he can't play. My decision would be not to play him."

But Koogan remains confident that Shearer will be ready for the Portuguese. "I am always optimistic. I think he will be fit to play. But I am not an expert," he said, talking (we think) about knee scans rather than football management. Koogan then went on to insist that even if Shearer doesn't make the first game, "he has five days before the next game. That is a plus point with Alan." And everyone else as well, surely?

In fact Koog was so confident that Shearer would be OK, he refused to get drawn into the debate over which player he would bring into the squad should his top striker need replacing. "I don't think we have to go down that line with Alan Shearer," he said. "If he does not make the first game, he will be fit for the second game," he reiterated, before anybody could mention Chris Sutton.

ADVERTISEMENT

http://www.theaa.co.uk/euro2000 Free one-stop information shop for fans travelling to Euro 2000. An inclusive AA service offering routes, traffic reports, practical advice and lots more.

ENGLAND'S SOCCER SCUM SHAME

The first English arrests of Euro 2000 have been made. Three men carrying hunting knives and a crossbow have been apprehended by Belgian police after they were spotted in a Brussels park taking photographs of each other as they posed with their weapons. Who are these sick, twisted, maniacal individuals? Are they part of a sinister organisation hell-bent on causing trouble wherever they go?

"Our journalists were investigating the widespread availability of lethal weapons on the eve of Euro 2000," explained a spokeswoman for the News Of The World, the employers of the men in question. "The three men were engaged in an entirely legitimate journalistic exercise in the public interest," she continued as a nation belly-laughed as one. The Belgian police weren't as amused, however. "Nobody can carry weapons without a valid reason or authorisation," a spokesman said earlier today. "They were carrying hunting knives - and they were not hunting so they were breaking the law."

As ever, the News Of The World demanded instant justice. "We are extremely concerned at their detention and have taken immediate steps with the authorities to secure their prompt release," whined their spokesperson. And sure enough, the hacks were quickly freed without charge. The Fiver, however, holds no truck with this sort of wishy-washy liberal posturing. Our message is simple, and our message is clear: take their passports away, put 'em in jail and throw away the key. That's the only language these scum understand!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We thought it would be nice to offer an orange coffin in the coming weeks." A spokesman for Bijnen undertakers in Dutch town Vught, revealing his company's Euro 2000 special. Holland are in the group of death after all.

A QUICK FIX

Vote-rigging. It's not big, and it's not clever. However, if it means that every footballer in Europe will suddenly sit up and take notice of Kelvin Koogan's brave boys, instead of clutching their stomachs and laughing hysterically until they cough up half a lung, we're all for it.

So thank God for an email which today encouraged just about everyone in England to go to the website of Italian paper Gazetta dello Sport and vote for Kelvin's men in their 'Who will win Euro 2000?' online poll. Early this morning, someone with nothing better to do noticed that England had polled less than 4 percent, and, determined to restore English pride, sent out an email entitled 'Lord Kitchener says Your Country Needs You', complete with instructions on how to make a mockery of the democratic process.

Sure enough, the whole country soon was logging on at http://www.gazzetta.it, clicking the "Inghiltera" button, hitting "vota", and then looking at the "resultati". But was it worth the effort? Well, at last look, England were sitting pretty on 67 percent while the useless old Italians had only polled 11 percent. Now that's bound to have the whole of Europe on the run. Resultato!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal have joined Manchester United and Chelsea in the chase for Gareth Southgate. The Aston Villa defender is expected to fetch £10m.

Aston Villa's defence could be further weakened by the departure of Gareth Barry, supposedly a £10m target for Manchester United.

Everton and Coventry are negotiating a swap deal involving Don Hutchison and Noel Whelan. Both players are on the transfer list and both could leave on a Bosman free next year - the clubs are attempting to ensure they do not lose money on their investments.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The winners of the rights to show Premiership football for the next three years will be announced next Wednesday.

George Burley has confirmed that Richard Wright will be told to sign a new deal or he will be sold. "If Richard won't sign his contract he will be put up for sale," revealed Burley. "We are quite clear about this. The negotiations have been going on for two years now and we need to know his intentions."

Romania captain Gheorghe Hagi has been given the all-clear to face Germany on Monday. Hagi has been troubled by a groin injury and there were fears he might miss all three group games. But team doctor Pompiliu Popescu insisted today: "Hagi will play on Monday."

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Three Lions (10.30pm)
England don't do very well in a tournament and lose. England do quite well in a tournament and lose. Repeat cycle for 55 minutes.

Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm)
Probably not about Euro 2000, given that it's on Sky.

British Eurosport: Gillette Dream Team (7pm, 11.30pm)
Featuring a player who gets his head kicked in after shaving with a Wilkinson Sword.

Euro 2000 News (8.57pm)
Nice time slot.

Road To Euro 2000 (9pm)
France, Denmark, Czech Republic and Netherlands all embark on their journey to hell.

webTitle: Should we have the right to go naked in public?

fields.headline: Should we have the right to go naked in public?
fields.standfirst: To be nude is practical and desirable in some public places argues Mark Nisbet, Editor of Health & Efficiency Magazine, but in the UK recent uses of the Public Order Act put nudists legally beside sexual exhibitionists. Solicitor Sue Ashtiany reminds him that concepts of decency differ, and the rights of one group have to co-exist with the expectations of the rest. Have your say.
fields.trailText: To be nude is practical and desirable in some public places argues Mark Nisbet, Editor of Health & Efficiency Magazine, but in the UK recent uses of the Public Order Act put nudists legally beside sexual exhibitionists. Solicitor Sue Ashtiany reminds him that concepts of decency differ, and the rights of one group have to co-exist with the expectations of the rest. Have your say.
fields.body:
Dear Ms Ashtiany,

For years many European countries have not legally insisted that their citizens wear clothes. The right to partake in non-sexual public nudity, while not actively promoted, has not been an indictable offence in Denmark, Holland or Germany for a generation. It is legal to sunbathe nude in parks, on beaches and on private property without fear of prosecution.

Like all good legislation with goodwill from both sides, this is a two way thing. Few citizens would wish to go to the supermarket naked. Most nudists respect other people*s opposition to nudity. In the UK there is no law forbidding public nudity, but several laws are used to prosecute public nakedness. Nudists apprehended on beaches are reprimanded and fined with Victorian legislation also used to prosecute flashers. Unsurprisingly, they feel insulted by this association with lewd public behaviour.

Lately, the Public Order Act (Section 4) has been used against some nudists. The nudist is now looking for equality under the law. Some nudists are getting vociferous. Underlying the whole philosophy of social nudism, scanty as it may seem to outsiders, is a physical and psychological revulsion against the mandatory wearing of clothes. The prospect of the UK legal system being advised by Europe to recognise the legality of non-sexual public nudity has excited many nudists. Parallels with persecuted gays in the 60s have been made. OK, we nudists are a little behind, but we are in the queues at Strasbourg.

Yours sincerely,
Mark Nisbet
Editor of Health & Efficiency Magazine

Dear Mr Nisbet,

The UK is much like other European jurisdictions, including those you quote. No worse, no better. But I boggle at the idea of a physical and mental revulsion against the mandatory wearing of clothes. Is their revulsion brought about by the mandatoriness?

If we gave them the right to take their clothes off whenever and wherever they wished, would this cure the problem? Could they bank the right without needing to use it, so that (provided they knew they could take their clothes off if the desire seized them) they would be happy to be covered up? Or are they saying that they have some physical or psychological condition which prevents them from wearing clothes? These are lawyer's questions, but they do have a point. I cannot see that it helps naturists to be identified as victims of a mildly ridiculous condition for which we have to make allowances.

Yes, there are public decency offences and also provisions allowing the police to prevent breaches of the peace. And such provisions are used, including possibly last week at the Freedom To Be Yourself demonstration in Brighton. But surely there are few naturists who wish to make exhibitions of themselves. It is a question of balancing rights. With a bit of discretion naturists can, and have for years, been able to do things without having to wear clothes. In no jurisdiction can they wonder about the streets naked and expect not to be challenged.

It is really how far this freedom should become a public right. Far be it from me to stop you from wishing to address these issues to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. But I am intrigued to know what you will ask for.

Yours sincerely,
Sue Ashtiany
Solicitor

Dear Sue,

I am not overstating things. Nudists under UK law experience far more prosecutions than their counterparts in the rest of Europe. In 1998 the East Riding of Yorkshire council attempted to ban nudity along 96 miles of the coastline and backed up its prejudice with warden patrols. In 1998 a Gloucester man was fined for walking nude in his garden. In 1999 a male nude sunbather on Ainsdale beach, Lancashire, was prosecuted. His wife, also arrested, was not charged.

This sort of thing does not happen in Holland or Denmark, and elsewhere, because the right to be publicly naked, however legally circumscribed, exists. In Munich's English Gardens, nudists attract complaints not because they are nude but for making too much noise splashing in the lake. In continental Europe simple human nudity, in time and place, is no big deal. The overall atmosphere is more relaxed. In the UK the policy has always been to tolerate nudity providing it is confined to remote private woodland clubs. As soon as nudists use beaches and parks simple nudity provokes the law.

A mandatory clothing policy is what nudists feel operates against their enjoyment of public places where to be nude is practical and desirable. The beach is an obvious place, the countryside less so. On many southern European beaches the clothed and the nude happily share the sands. This is not allowed here. Nudity is a state of mind and body that is liberating. Nudists are vexed by segregation and angered at being one notch up from sexual exhibitionists in the eyes of the law. Nudists require the ability to pursue discreet nudity in public free of such constraints.

Yours sincerely,
Mark Nisbet

Dear Mark,

I feel that you are confusing several issues. In Denmark, Article 232 of the Criminal Code can and has been used to prosecute naturists. More commonly the matter is left to local police discretion under the Police Code. This is similar to what we do here where police will act under their general powers to prevent breaches of the peace rather than use more severe powers under criminal statutes.

What you are saying is that in most areas in the UK we aren't happy to share our public parks with people wandering about in the nude over the age of about five. We do have places within public areas where people can take all their clothes off. More interestingly, the question you originally raised was about bringing a claim under the European Convention on Human Rights. You are now talking about edging along the limits of discretion. What I am not sure about is which human right you are asserting. What about those people who have a physical and psychological revulsion against being forced to wear clothes? How do they fit in with your rather more gentle idea that we should not cavil at a few more people taking off a few more clothes on sunny days?

Where exactly are you going?

Yours,
Sue Ashtiany

Dear Sue,

The point I'm trying to make is that the moral and legal climate in the UK is very harsh when it comes to public nudity. It encourages apprehension and fear among those nudists who are less bold than the very small minority of nudists with an attitude, who go nude wherever they chose. What this means for the average nudist, who is not confrontational, is that they feel their right to self-expression, their belief system about the moral, spiritual and recreational value of social nudity, and their ability to express their beliefs, are being suppressed. These are the human rights that are under constant attack.

Social nudity cannot develop in a climate of fear in which local authorities, landowners, and some members of the public readily call in the police to deal with low key, innocent public nudity. This they do and treat nudists as sexual miscreants using the Vagrancy Act 1824 and the Town Police Clauses Act 1856. It is time for these laws to be reassessed; being nude in a public place should not become an offence against public decency. Perhaps it would be best if we nudists became a religious order, produced a manifesto and became like the Sadhus in India, claiming religious minority privileges. What do you think is our best next move?

Yours,
Mark

Dear Mark,

The rights of one group of people have to co-exist with another group's expectations and freedoms. This is the margin of appreciation that is built into human rights law. Concepts of decency differ at different times and places. If people call the police, then they are presumably affronted and it is not surprising that the police respond. I don*t have a clear picture of the problem as perceived by nudists or naturists. I suspect that someone like you - you describe yourself as non-confrontational - would like the police to respond less. Others would like to confront the whole issue more directly, which is probably counter-productive.

But then, if you are not going to confront societal attitudes, you are going to have to settle for incremental change. You ask for my advice. How about starting a dialogue with chief officers of police? Or doing a public opinion survey? What about a focus group? There will always be complex definitions of what is a public place. Even Sadhus would have a hard time of it popping down to the shops!

Yours and good luck,
Sue Ashtiany.
