webTitle: Papers clash over pictures of prince

fields.headline: Papers clash over pictures of prince
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: A bitter battle between several national newspaper editors and St James's Palace over a set of pictures of Prince William last night threatened to overshadow his 18th birthday.
fields.body:
A bitter battle between several national newspaper editors and St James's Palace over a set of pictures of Prince William last night threatened to overshadow his 18th birthday.

Senior newspaper industry figures warned that the unseemly tussle over 10 pictures taken to commemorate the prince's coming of age was the first indication that the media interest in Prince William could match that which engulfed his mother, Diana, Princess of Wales.

The row over the pictures culminated last night in an extraordinary attack by Charles Moore, editor of the Daily Telegraph, on the Prince of Wales's private secretary, Stephen Lamport. Mr Moore accused Mr Lamport and his team of deliberately breaking an agreement with the Telegraph in handling the distribution of the pictures, taken over the course of Prince William's final term at Eton College.

The original plan reflected the palace's principle of fair and equitable access to the young princes. A Daily Telegraph photographer, Ian Jones, was commissioned by the palace to take pictures of the prince to be shared among all national and regional newspapers for publication next weekend - before the prince's birthday on June 21. The idea, sources say, was to protect the prince from photographers on his birthday, when he is due to sit one of his A-level papers.

The skirmish began when the editor of the Mail, Paul Dacre, suspected Mr Moore had gained an advantage by processing the pictures early. Concerned that the Telegraph would thus be able to flaunt a glossy magazine next Saturday, while its rivals would be confined to using the pictures on their news pages, the Mail and the Times both complained to St James's Palace.

To Mr Moore's disgust, St James's promptly issued copies of the pictures to the Times and the Mail. Mr Moore maintains St James's Palace had agreed that the Telegraph alone could put them in its magazine as a reward for its services in taking and distributing the pictures.

Calling the palace's behaviour "appalling" and "unprofessional", Mr Moore said: "They have been weak and incompetent and have broken faith with us ... we had a clear agreement and they've broken it."

The timing of the fracas is sensitive. Lord Wakeham, chairman of the press complaints commission, is expected to make a speech next week setting out guidelines for editors on how to cover Prince William as he becomes an adult. The PCC is understood to have been engaged in diplomatic negotiations between Mr Lamport and the newspaper editors.

Senior sources within the newspaper industry cautioned that the reaction of the editors was over the top and reminiscent of the frenzy that would surround new photographs of Diana, Princess of Wales. One senior industry observer said: "This is our first taste of Prince William as a commodity ... it does not bode well."

 The Newspaper Publishers' Association yesterday asked national newspaper editors whether they object to the Ministry of Defence's decision to use only two papers, the Sun and Daily Telegraph, to allocate 2,000 tickets for the Queen Mother's celebration pageant in central London next month.

The original plan reflected the palace's principle of fair and equitable access to the young princes. A Daily Telegraph photographer, Ian Jones, was commissioned by the palace to take pictures of the prince to be shared among all national and regional newspapers for publication next weekend - before the prince's birthday on June 21. The idea, sources say, was to protect the prince from photographers on his birthday, when he is due to sit one of his A-level papers. The skirmish began when the editor of the Mail, Paul Dacre, suspected Mr Moore had gained an advantage by processing the pictures early. Concerned that the Telegraph would thus be able to flaunt a glossy magazine next Saturday, while its rivals would be confined to using the pictures on their news pages, the Mail and the Times both complained to St James's Palace. To Mr Moore's disgust, St James's promptly issued copies of the pictures to the Times and the Mail. Mr Moore maintains St James's Palace had agreed that the Telegraph alone could put them in its magazine as a reward for its services in taking and distributing the pictures. Calling the palace's behaviour "appalling" and "unprofessional", Mr Moore said: "They have been weak and incompetent and have broken faith with us ... we had a clear agreement and they've broken it." The timing of the fracas is sensitive. Lord Wakeham, chairman of the press complaints commission, is expected to make a speech next week setting out guidelines for editors on how to cover Prince William as he becomes an adult. The PCC is understood to have been engaged in diplomatic negotiations between Mr Lamport and the newspaper editors. Senior sources within the newspaper industry cautioned that the reaction of the editors was over the top and reminiscent of the frenzy that would surround new photographs of Diana, Princess of Wales. One senior industry observer said: "This is our first taste of Prince William as a commodity ... it does not bode well."  The Newspaper Publishers' Association yesterday asked national newspaper editors whether they object to the Ministry of Defence's decision to use only two papers, the Sun and Daily Telegraph, to allocate 2,000 tickets for the Queen Mother's celebration pageant in central London next month.

fields.headline: Hunting the truth
fields.standfirst: With the announcement that the government is to let MPs vote on a hunting ban, it's time those who defend the sport admitted their real reasons for taking part, writes environment correspondent Paul Brown
fields.trailText: With the announcement that the government is to let MPs vote on a hunting ban, it's time those who defend the sport admitted their real reasons for taking part, writes environment correspondent Paul Brown.
fields.body:
At last Labour has stopped sitting on the fence and will let members of parliament have a free vote on whether to ban hunting.

Tony Blair and his cabinet colleagues have tried, several times, to avoid pushing the issue because the backlash from the shires seemed much more angry and powerful than they had first imagined.

The last prevarication was the appointment of Lord Burns, a fair-minded and respected former civil servant, to inquire into all the issues. His report goes to the Home Office today and will set out the facts on hunting as far as they are known. At least it will bring some semblance of order into a sometimes hysterical debate.

The debate will encompass issues such as whether hunting is cruel, how many would lose their jobs if hunting were banned and what damage a ban would do to the rural economy. But what about the fundamental question of whether hunting is a necessary method of controlling foxes, deer, mink and hares?

There are still some die-hards who claim that hunting is vermin control but it is increasingly difficult to sustain that argument. Hares are already dying out because of intensive farming, deer are culled by marksmen, mink numbers are so great hunting makes no difference, and fox numbers seem to be similar whether there is a hunt nearby or not.

In areas of the country where hunting has faded away, there is no evidence that any of the species once preyed upon are found in greater numbers or cause more trouble than before. If any of these species become too much of a nuisance, farmers shoot them - but mostly they are simply left alone.

The debunking of the vermin argument comes today with the allegation that the Beaufort Hunt has been feeding foxes in artificial earths to make sure there are enough animals to hunt. History is repeating itself. In the 1890s deer were released in front of the hounds in Buckinghamshire so the Prince of Wales could have some sport. No one pretended then that deer hunting was for keeping down the deer, it was so the gentry could have some sport. Let's not delude ourselves now.

fields.headline: Intervention 2000
fields.trailText: Scottish Fashion Week doesn't have quite the same exotic ring as Paris or London Fashion Week (I'm allowed to say this, being Scottish: don't try it if you're English). After all, Scotland doesn't exactly have a stellar reputation for producing world-class designers.
fields.body:
Scottish Fashion Week doesn't have quite the same exotic ring as Paris or London Fashion Week (I'm allowed to say this, being Scottish: don't try it if you're English). After all, Scotland doesn't exactly have a stellar reputation for producing world-class designers. Fabric-wise, the fashion industry knows it can always look to Scotland for quality and authenticity - we're famous for producing tweed and cashmere, while tartan is never off the international catwalks for more than two seasons. But famous names? Nuh. Ireland has John Rocha and Lainey Keogh, Wales has Julien MacDonald, and England ... well, England has loads. So where's the next big Scottish thing?

Perhaps they are languishing in obscurity, unable to vault the tall fence of London-centricity that surrounds the M25. Intervention is definitely needed. Which is where Intervention 2000 comes in. Now in its second year, Intervention was set up by Glasgow nightclub The Arches (0141 221 4001) to give Scots a platform to show their wares. This year's event runs from June 14-22 and features designers from the Shetland Islands right down to the Borders. Events include three catwalk shows, an exhibition of Scottish fashion photography, a hair, beauty and design masterclass, and a fashion and business conference attended by some of the industry's leading lights - particularly useful for fledgling designers wanting practical advice. There will also be a street market selling clothes.

Most noteworthy for students, though, are the Railtrack Scotland Fashion Awards, open to any Scottish student or student training in Scotland. With prizes on offer to a total value of £8,000, this represents serious financial support. "Railtrack have a three-year commitment," says Intervention spokesperson Lisa Watt. "We just feel it's time to put Scottish fashion firmly on the map." We concur.

fields.headline: Rag week
fields.standfirst: Laura Craik gets to grips with graduate fashion
fields.trailText: You know you're at Graduate Fashion Week because the audience whoops and claps. Rather then being made up of jaded fashion editors and po-faced buyers, it's made up of mum, dad, granny, lil' sister and hundreds of over-excited students. The atmosphere makes for one of the most exciting weeks on the fashion calendar.
fields.body:
You know you're at Graduate Fashion Week because the audience whoops and claps. Rather then being made up of jaded fashion editors and po-faced buyers, it's made up of mum, dad, granny, lil' sister and hundreds of over-excited students. The atmosphere makes for one of the most exciting weeks on the fashion calendar. You can gasp at Gucci, you can marvel at McQueen, but only Graduate Fashion Week will bring a lump to your throat and a tear to your eye. All that hard work - three years of slogging your guts out over a steaming toile - just to take a five-minute spin on the catwalk and hope that someone, somewhere, proclaims you the next Galliano.

"What paper are you from?" asked one mum at the Surrey show. "My daughter is called Kathryn. Will you be mentioning her?"

As a general rule of thumb, the more ridiculous the creation, the louder the cheers from the parents. They don't want to see well-cut trouser suits; they want to bask in the spectacle of it all. "Look, Jim. Somebody's made a wooden codpiece! Isn't that marvellous!" But all in all, this was a very commercial year. The proverbial three-legged trousers were almost entirely absent, though there was a distressing predilection for plastic, diaphanous, seethrough chiffon and stiff felted wool, none of which are particularly easy to wear.

Central St Martins is the only show the fasherati bothers to turn up to, because of its track record of producing McQueen, McCartney and Galliano. Hell, even Prince Andrew showed up at this one. To his credit, he remained rapt throughout the entire two-hour-and-10-minute production. Although no one student blew me away, this was a strong year: favourites were Gerard Wilson's mono presentation of electric blue leather, chiffon and sequins (80s, but wearably so) and Kamalijit Thandi's delicately textured eau de nil and bronze dresses. Biggest laugh of the week came courtesy of James Doidge, whose menswear was far and away the most likely to do well - at least on the knowing streets of Trendy London.

Too much menswear this week was made up exclusively of loose, baggy combat pants and heavily logo'd hoodies that relied on the smug hip-hop swagger of a bunch of "rugged" male models to pull it off. This "urban" uniform is well-established and well-liked among men, but it's so HUMOURLESS! Which is why Doidge's knitted alsatian jumper was such light relief. The green shellsuit festooned with hamsters might be a bit outré for your average man, but the denim jacket sewn with patches naming different dog breeds ... well, you could see Spike Jonze wearing it.

Westminster had an excellent year: Jasmine Ghazilian showed a sophisticated collection featuring woven leather jackets in pearlised green, worn with flowing chiffon tops folded like origami. Sarah Patching mixed vintage lace with hand-embroidered digital prints and beading for a collection rich in textures and patterns. Rachael Scott's supple white leather miniskirts and asymmetric tops embroidered with silver thread were good, but the fact that she chose a thudding trance track to accompany her collection somehow made the clothes look cheaper, like eveningwear for disco dollies. Eirini Tigkaraki's gauzy eveningwear embroidered with red diamanté stones looked promising.

Also strong was Ravensbourne. Pusia Fleming sent out long felted wool skirts with punched-out holes in pastel pink, while Sarah Markham's long stripy dresses were childlike in their brightness. Both very commercial collections.

Highlights from Nottingham Trent included Julia Dransfield (full maroon suede skirts, cowl-necked jumpers and chunky-knit scarves), Robert Whitehead (long dogtooth check skirts, fuchsia blouses, colourful ribbon trims) and Julie-Anne Crowfoot (40s-inspired daywear in Air Force and army colours). If Julie-Anne gets famous, will she change her surname? Some lucky students have names simply made to be strung in lights along the Place Vendme. Chloe Croft. Coralie Enthoven. Helen Sartoris. Signe Rose (I jest not). Sadly, most British names just don't have the romance of their Italian and French counterparts.

The Surrey Institute are a pushy lot. Kathryn's mother excepted (we'll put that down to familial pride), it's the Surrey students who bombard people like me with CD-roms, website information and phone calls to check we're coming. If you're a journalist trying to get a front row seat so you can report on the shoes, you'll have to oust an angry parent first. Surrey also had by far the glossiest (and most helpful) brochure. Trust a Surrey student, then, to be the talk of London before the show had even commenced. In fact, two Surrey students battled it out for Next Big Thing: Amrik Chagger and Benjamin Shine (two more fine names, you'll agree). Chagger got some blokes to build an ice sculpture "live" on the catwalk, before showing hand-sewn pinstripe tailoring jazzed up with mad metallic accessories, including a solid "silver" jacket. Shine's ace-in-the-hole was work experience at Chloe - and the rumour that he'd achieved the highest pass-mark the college had ever given. Another rumour - "He knows Ringo Starr" - was perhaps less kind.

Neither of these boys really did it for me: far more assured was Joseph Pollard's collection. His belted trenchcoats with their shiny woodgrain print, lemon-yellow panelled skirts and graphic tops were just the right side of quirky. Good luck, Joseph. Good luck to everyone. And farewell to Bhs, who have come to the end of their five-year commitment to sponsor Graduate Fashion Week. Their support has been appreciated.

Top 5 overused ideas

1 Nylon tights worn over shoes
2 Origami techniques
3 Moby's Porcelain
4 Shiny-faced models
5 Bloomers

Top 5 ripped-off designers

1 Hussein Chalayan
2 Dries Van Noten
3 Rei Kawakubo
4 Alexander McQueen
5 Marni (new entry)

Top 5 attention-grabbers

1 An ice sculpture
2 Clogs made of ice
3 Using a "famous" model
4 Male model smoking a "joint"
5 A dog

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Amex Award
fields.trailText: Here at the Guardian, we like to ensure students are fully aware of all the prizes/shortcuts to success on offer in the fashion firmament. After all, it's a long, slow way to the top. The American Express Innovation Award is a prize with a difference: it comes fully endorsed and supported by Alexander McQueen. Amex already supports McQueen's London Fashion Week catwalk show: this award further consolidates its commitment to fashion. McQueen hand-picked the winner himself after hours of deliberation, taking into account commerciality and creativity. Presented for the first time at last night's GFW Gala, the winner (still to be announced at the time of going to press) will receive a three-month paid work placement with McQueen, as well as access to a financial adviser to help them with business plans.

fields.headline: Most everywhere: long fringes
fields.trailText: Fashion students pride themselves on being rebels with a style cause. As well as the usual array of blaggers trying to nick champagne from the press tent and posing as hacks to get into the shows at Graduate Fashion Week, an interesting new hair trend has been in evidence. Fringes weeks beyond their trim-by date were spotted sprouting from many a trainee fashionista's hairline. So long are these bangs that one can barely see the wearers' eyes - giving a distinctly "mop top" look. First seen back in the 70s on rock chick Chrissie Hynde (who still sports the same jet black do) and more recently on Roisin from Moloko (hers is a peroxide barmaid version), the long fringe has made a blinding come-back in colleges across the nation.
fields.body:
Fashion students pride themselves on being rebels with a style cause. As well as the usual array of blaggers trying to nick champagne from the press tent and posing as hacks to get into the shows at Graduate Fashion Week, an interesting new hair trend has been in evidence. Fringes weeks beyond their trim-by date were spotted sprouting from many a trainee fashionista's hairline. So long are these bangs that one can barely see the wearers' eyes - giving a distinctly "mop top" look. First seen back in the 70s on rock chick Chrissie Hynde (who still sports the same jet black do) and more recently on Roisin from Moloko (hers is a peroxide barmaid version), the long fringe has made a blinding come-back in colleges across the nation.

"It's really popular among the Scandinavian students. I cut mine myself," says Swedish-born Karin Holm of the Surrey Institute Of Art and Design. But can she see where she's going? "No, but it looks really cool."

This fall-under-a-bus-for-fashion attitude was epitomised when Kate Moss appeared, post-Priory, with a stunning fringe veiling her weary face. If there's one thing students excel at, it's late nights and copious amounts of alcohol. And what better way to cover your excess under-eye baggage than with very stylish hair? These students are smarter than we think.

fields.headline: The Royal family
fields.standfirst: Graduate Fashion Week closed last night but there is one crucial collection yet to take centre stage: that of the Royal College of Art's final year students. Course director Wendy Dagworthy gives  Laura Craik a sneak preview.
fields.trailText: Graduate Fashion Week closed last night but there is one crucial collection yet to take centre stage: that of the Royal College of Art's final year students. Course director Wendy Dagworthy gives Laura Craik a sneak preview.
fields.body:
For those of you not yet sick of the elitism debate, or at least wondering whether it applies to fashion colleges, be assured that it does. Although they certainly don't pick students in direct proportion to the poshness of their school, Central St Martins and the Royal College of Art are still the Oxbridge of the fashion world, with the longest lists of alumni and the most consistent reputations for producing world-class designers.

Graduate Fashion Week closed last night with a gala performance highlighting the cream of design talent from colleges all over England and, as always, the Royal College of Art was absent. The world-famous institution, based in London's swanky Kensington Gore, never shows in Graduate Fashion Week, instead staging its final year catwalk collection a week later. This isn't idle snobbery, though: RCA graduates are educated to MA level (representing an extra two years' study), while Fashion Week students have just completed their three-year BA.

Many of these new BA graduates will hope to go on to study for an MA, either at St Martins or at the RCA. Its two-year course represents a unique chance to add polish to students' work, as well as facilitating vital links with the industry. With past pupils including Julien MacDonald, Antonio Berardi, Boudicca and Philip Treacy, it's not surprising that places are hotly contested (around 60 are available, 500 apply) and that applications come from all over the world. "The students here are very lucky," says Professor Wendy Dagworthy, Course Director of Fashion. "It's real one-to-one teaching."

This year - ta da! - the fashion school is celebrating its 50th anniversary. Set up by Robin Darwin, the RCA's reforming rector, the course aimed to replace traditional dressmaking crafts with a syllabus that would ensure fashion design was accorded academic status. In what was a very bold move at the time, Darwin appointed Madge Garland, a former Vogue editor and fashion consultant to leading retailers, the UK's first Professor of Fashion. She had no knowledge of drawing, cutting or sewing, but what she lacked in basic skills she made up for in charisma and genuine passion for new design. "Paris comes to Kensington!" trumpeted the headlines. Her Vogue editorship had furnished her with a superlative list of contacts, which she shared avidly with her students. "She took you under her wing," says Jane Brogden, a former pupil who became Professor of Fashion in 1971. "She invited students to private cocktail parties because 'it would be good for you'."

To this day, the fashion school prides itself on its close links with the industry, its bulging contacts book and its focus on directional teaching. Wendy Dagworthy is a kind of Madge Garland for the 21st century: she had her own successful design company for 16 years, defecting to the RCA after 10 years' teaching at rival Central St Martins. Dressed in a Marni felted jacket (pink), Prada Sport trainers (silver), Jonathan Aston fishnets (red) and a jaunty full skirt made by an ex-student, Dagworthy cuts a colourfully imposing (or imposingly colourful) figure. Her teaching philosophy is simple: to push students as far as their imaginations will take them, offering steady support all the way. "We encourage them not to be afraid of making mistakes. You have to take risks to create something new." With 98% of graduates going straight into jobs, this philosophy is a sound one.

Another course benefit is the special projects on offer: this year's graduates have worked with Daks, Benetton and Marks & Spencer's Autograph to produce collections which may go into production. "Working on their own collection as well as one for another company helps them get used to juggling their time," Dagworthy says. Students also get the benefit of working with a wider variety of fabrics. "We did a project with Mila Schon, which was fantastic for the students because they got to use double cashmere at £250 a metre."

Of course, for most students, an MA is not an option: however talented, your average student is left impoverished after a three-year BA course, particularly when fabric costs are added to already high living costs. Yet Dagworthy claims money is made available to those who need it: if the applicant is talented enough, they will find a way. Some get sponsored, others win bursaries (either from the college or from private companies) and there is always prize money to be won from external projects.

Although they certainly don't pick students in direct proportion to the poshness of their school, Central St Martins and the Royal College of Art are still the Oxbridge of the fashion world, with the longest lists of alumni and the most consistent reputations for producing world-class designers. Graduate Fashion Week closed last night with a gala performance highlighting the cream of design talent from colleges all over England and, as always, the Royal College of Art was absent. The world-famous institution, based in London's swanky Kensington Gore, never shows in Graduate Fashion Week, instead staging its final year catwalk collection a week later. This isn't idle snobbery, though: RCA graduates are educated to MA level (representing an extra two years' study), while Fashion Week students have just completed their three-year BA. Many of these new BA graduates will hope to go on to study for an MA, either at St Martins or at the RCA. webTitle: There's nothing more divisive than chinos

fields.headline: There's nothing more divisive than chinos
fields.trailText: Shane Watson on dressing down
fields.body:
This week, on the same day that papers carried the story that Tony Blair considered the conventional men's suit to be one of the "tyrannies of modern life" (really, Tony, you should get out more), the same papers carried a picture of one of the doctors embroiled in the baby-organs scandal. Call me old-fashioned, but as he stood there in his corduroy-collared poacher's-style jacket, denim-effect shirt and casual trousers, I saw someone ill-equipped to deal with the difficult times ahead. I saw someone whose appearance suggested he was not as meticulous, disciplined and upright as he might be. I saw someone in desperate need of a suit.

Adults with lives will probably have clutched their heads in despair when they turned on Newsnight on Monday to see Kirsty Wark chairing a debate on the question of suit-wearing at work (dress-down Friday, smart casual - where will it end?). But the issue of suit-wearing is really rather an important one. The problem is that everyone has been approaching it as if it were nothing more than a question of sartorial choice: old buffers with rolled umbrellas versus hip young gunslingers with tanned bare feet in penny loafers. Call Me Tony claims that he's striking a blow for comfort and modernity but, of course, he thinks he's challenging a symbol of the "forces of conservatism" when, as it happens, there is nothing more divisive than chino rule.

We already know that just days after Arthur Andersen initiated "dress-down Friday" in January they had to issue directives on how to do it because there was so much confusion and misery.

Women know that - while it would be pushing it to describe it as a tyranny of modern life - there are few things more time-consuming than dressing appropriately for every occasion without formal guidelines. Uniforms, including the suit, are a great leveller, allowing chaps to look pretty much the same and get on with the business of proving that they are better than each other by other means. Suits are liberating. Why else did women get into them when they got into positions of power in the 80s, and (don't want to worry you here, but) why will they be back in them this autumn if designers have anything to do with it? Because flipsy-dipsy dress and flopsy-dopsy cardy get in the way of serious graft, whereas a rock-hard tailored suit is not just clothes to make money in, but armour, protecting you from exposure as the inexperienced, shit-scared not-one-of-them-at-all that you really are. And the same applies to men, in spades.

Which brings me back to the more serious issues surrounding non-suit-wearing. Can you really trust a man who is got up in smart casual? Tony, though he won't come right out and say it, fancies himself down-dressing like his pal Clinton, or even Al Gore, pictured in this month's American Vogue looking suitably presidential in jeans and polo shirt. But who's to say that loose morals don't begin with loose clothes? Would Monica have found it quite so easy to deal with the fly buttons on a sturdy pair of bespoke flannel pinstripes? ("Buttongate" certainly doesn't have the same ring.) Would Clinton have seemed less attainable had he not been slopping about the Oval office in chinos looking at leisure and ready for pleasure rather than businesslike and upstanding, so to speak?

I recently had my hand stitched up by a doctor sporting smart casual as opposed to buttoned-up white coat, and couldn't quite get out of my head the idea that he was doing a Paul McGann and just trying out medicine until he was caught. You don't want to have that feeling - nor with your bank manager, boss, dentist, train driver, pilot, or politicians. Or footballers for that matter. How much more confidence boosting was the sight of our boys heading off to Belgium in matching suits and blue ties than the Blair endorsed alternative - Becksy in bandana and capri pants, Shearer in fleece leisure suit and Seaman sporting Hawaiian print shirt and tight white trousers. They looked together, as in tidy and united.

Likewise, I find that if I arrive at my desk wearing flip-flops, pyjama bottoms, bird's-nest hair and soup-stained vest (the prerogative of the freelance), it isn't long before I'm starting to act like Waynetta Slob, wondering if a kip in the corner by the dustbin would be out of the question and what the point of ashtrays is when you've got a perfectly good egg-covered plate to hand. Even if you don't go along with the slippery-slope theory, there's no reason to take the matter of appearance lightly. I don't think many of us, when it comes down to it, can face the thought of a dressed-down John Prescott first thing in the morning.

fields.headline: A high price for hubris
fields.standfirst:
Microsoft brought this fate on itself

The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft has got no more than it deserves. Its arrogance in refusing to admit any of the serious charges against it has goaded Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, a conservative Reaganite appointment, into inflicting a more severe penalty than would have happened had the software company shown any serious sign of regret or even of willingness to meet half way. Now, unless an appeal court or the supreme court overturns the judgment, Microsoft will be split into two separate companies.
fields.body:
Microsoft has got no more than it deserves. Its arrogance in refusing to admit any of the serious charges against it has goaded Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, a conservative Reaganite appointment, into inflicting a more severe penalty than would have happened had the software company shown any serious sign of regret or even of willingness to meet half way. Now, unless an appeal court or the supreme court overturns the judgment, Microsoft will be split into two separate companies. One company will house the Windows operating system and the other, much the more attractive option, when the dominance of personal computers is under attack from the internet and other platforms, will take over the applications. Both will still be monopolies. Windows resides in over 90% of the world's PCs and Excel and Word have an even bigger share of of the spreadsheet and word processing markets.

What will happen? No one really knows. It will depend on human behaviour. It is possible that the two new companies will act like Siamese twins or parallel monopolies, each feeding off the other's monopoly position: new versions of the applications could boost demand for a more advanced version of Windows, and vice versa. If both are run by Microsoft's existing top brass, imbued with its culture, that could easily happen.

The more exciting scenario is that, once freed from umbilical linkage to Windows, the applications company would start to sell its products (and lots of new ones) much more aggressively for other operating systems - like the freely available Linux. It could also unleash more of the huge creative and entrepreneurial talent concentrated at the company's campus, where there is more intellectual fire power per square yard than at almost any other big corporation.

None of this may ever happen. Microsoft may convince higher courts that the justice department got it all wrong. It has a vested interest in stringing the suit out because it will be able to hang on to its monopoly profits for the duration. It knows it will take ages to engineer the break-up when the supreme court has finally ruled. If Microsoft eventually wins, then the US authorities will be saying that old economy rules do not apply in the new age. That would have very serious consequences. Meanwhile, it is reassuring to know that the world's biggest companies are still subject to the rule of law. Even in the globalised economy.

webTitle: Widow appeals for information as terror group says it killed British envoy

fields.headline: Widow appeals for information as terror group says it killed British envoy
fields.standfirst: Full text of Heather Saunders' statement
fields.trailText: The widow of British defence attache Stephen Saunders today issued a tearful appeal for information on her husband's killing as the elusive November 17 urban guerrilla group claimed responsibility for yesterday's fatal shooting in Athens.
fields.body:
The widow of British defence attache Stephen Saunders today issued a tearful appeal for information on her husband's killing as the elusive November 17 urban guerrilla group claimed responsibility for yesterday's fatal shooting in Athens.

Heather Saunders said her husband's murder had "destroyed" her and her family. "Stephen was my life. I stand before you half the person I was yesterday morning," she said outside her Athens home. "Anyone who saw anything, even a little thing, please tell the police."

Flanked by her two teenage daughters, Mrs Saunders said her husband was a loving father and "a man committed to peace" who had never raised his gun to kill anyone. He once hesitated to defend himself in Northern Ireland to prevent innocent bystanders from being hurt, she said.

Mr Saunders was shot yesterday morning by two assailants on a motorcycle as he drove to work on the busy Kiffisias Avenue in northern Athens. He was shot four times in the head, chest and hands and died three hours later in hospital.

Mrs Saunders thanked the Greek people for their support and especially the hospital staff who tried to save her husband, saying that, as a nurse, she understood the impossible task they tried to tackle.

"The Greek people, I know, are not responsible for what happened yesterday. But for the sake and future of Greece within a European community, I feel that these wicked men must be brought to justice," she said.

November 17 sent a 13-page document to the leftwing Greek newspaper Eleftherotypia saying it had carried out the killing in retribution for Britain's role in Nato's air war in Kosovo.

"We chose the senior English officer not only because England took part actively in the bombardments like it does with the United States during the periodic bombardment of Iraq, but because the English policy... even surpassed the Americans in provocation, cynicism and aggression," the statement said.

The British embassy in Athens said Mr Saunders had had "no direct role" in Nato's campaign. "He performed the duties you would expect of a Nato military attache in a Nato country during a crisis in which Nato was engaged," an embassy official said.

November 17, which takes its name from the date in 1973 when a student uprising against Greece's ruling military junta was crushed, is an extreme leftwing group opposed to capitalism, Nato and the European Union. It has carried out 23 killings though none of its members has ever been arrested. Foreign Office investigators and Scotland Yard anti-terrorist officers have flown to Athens to help in the investigation.

November 17, which has attacked British and American targets in Greece in the past, was from the beginning the main suspect in the murder, which was condemned by prime minister Tony Blair as a "contemptible and senseless" act of terrorism.

The prime minister, who spoke by telephone to the brigadier's widow, paid tribute to him as a "consummate professional".

Mr Blair also spoke by telephone to the Greek prime minister, Costas Simitis, who expressed his "shock and sorrow" at the killing and assured him that the authorities would do everything they could to track down the killers, said Mr Blair's official spokesman. Greece has come under strong international criticism for its failure to make any headway against the group, which has acted with impunity since its creation in 1975. A recent US congressional report - vehemently rebutted in Athens - suggested that Greece did not cooperate fully in the fight against terrorism and said it could theoretically be subjected to US sanctions along with Pakistan.

"This highlights again that Greece needs to take a tougher stance against terrorism," US defence department spokesman Ken Bacon said yesterday. He said Washington's views on the guerrilla threat in Athens were well known and were repeated "every time we visit".

The Foreign Office conducted a security review of British embassy staff in Athens in March, and security has been increased for today's visit to Athens by defence minister Baroness Symons. The Foreign Office said security at the British embassy was being increased after the shooting, although there was nothing to suggest Lady Symons was likely to be targeted by terrorists.

fields.headline: Getting it right
fields.standfirst: On Tuesday Guardian writer  Linda Grant  won the prestigious Orange prize for fiction. Yesterday her celebrations were cut short when the Times accused her of basing some of her characters' dialogue on letters and diaries from a history book - without attributing it. Here she explains why the attack is misleading and unfair
fields.trailText: On Tuesday Guardian writer Linda Grant won the prestigious Orange prize for fiction. Yesterday her celebrations were cut short when the Times accused her of basing some of her characters' dialogue on letters and diaries from a history book - without attributing it. Here she explains why the attack is misleading and unfair
fields.body:
In her review of my novel, When I Lived in Modern Times, in the Guardian, Ruth Gorb complained of the dialogue that people "simply would not talk like that". I burst out laughing when I read it and was sorely tempted to write back to her that, on the contrary, some of the dialogue of my characters was taken from lengthy interviews I did with people who were in Tel Aviv in the late 40s, or from their published diaries and letters.

Writing about the past, particularly the recent past, presents a novelist with taxing dilemmas. There are those who use it as a mere series of suggestions - notional material on to which the writer can impose their own fictional reality. There is no reason at all why a writer could not publish a novel set during the period of, for example, the Great War of 1909 to 1915. Robert Harris's Fatherland created a parallel reality in which the Germans had won the second world war. We could, if we wished, write about a Britain ruled by King Becks and Queen Posh or an FA cup final in which Manchester United is beaten by Ipswich Town. Telling downright lies isn't the problem: it is telling the truth that gets you into trouble. If you make John F Kennedy a walk-on character in your fiction, do you invent dialogue for him that he never said, or do you use his own written and spoken words, which may be denied you by copyright laws that are intended to protect intellectual property? Without the freedom to use characters from history, writers such as Don DeLillo, say, would find it impossible to publish.

As a novelist and a journalist, all my tendencies are towards realism, and what interests me most is how individuals are affected by the historical changes that are going on around them. My themes are always concerned with idealism, with those who lay themselves personally on the line for a cause and what might happen to them when that cause fails.

I started writing my first novel, The Cast Iron Shore, after the fall of the Berlin Wall. I had spent some years knowing members of the Communist party in the US who had survived the worst of the McCarthy period and its purges. Watching eastern Europe fall apart - Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia - I thought of those who invested their lives in the dream of socialism and who now saw that dream totally overthrown. What did I feel for them? Compassion. The same compassion I feel for the early socialist Zionists who genuinely believed, without the benefit of hindsight, that they were building a Jewish utopia on the shores of the Mediterranean and who could not foresee the society they wound up with, ravaged by war and religious intolerance.

To write novels like these, one cannot invent history. History is the point. My greatest fear when I was writing When I Lived in Modern Times was that a reviewer would say: "Linda Grant makes a great many mistakes about the period. It wasn't like that." What was it like, then? To find out one must consult something other than one's own imagination. Writing about the era of McCarthyite America, I read The Romance of American Communism by Vivian Gornick, a landmark work of oral history in which the author interviewed those whose lives had been given to the party - and some who had been destroyed by it - and the terrible times they lived through. I was deeply impressed by the words of a woman who spoke under the name "Diana Michaels", now a lawyer, who said: "I know I was vain, silly, mad for sexual success, but I was a communist and being a communist made me better than I was. It could all have been so much worse."

Diana Michaels became Sybil Ross, the narrator of The Cast Iron Shore. I did not use her history - Sybil's was entirely different - but without reading those words of "Diana Michaels" there could have been no Sybil. And without Gornick's painstaking research, there would have been a much poorer understanding of the mindset of those who stayed inside the party during its worst years.

webTitle: Countryside Alliance vows to oppose hunting ban

fields.headline: Countryside Alliance vows to oppose hunting ban
fields.standfirst: Countryside Alliance
fields.trailText: The Countryside Alliance today threatened "consistent, deliberate and prolonged" opposition if the government goes ahead with an attempt to ban fox-hunting. The Alliance made its statement as the home secretary took delivery of the Burns inquiry into the sport's future.
fields.body:
The Countryside Alliance today threatened "consistent, deliberate and prolonged" opposition if the government goes ahead with an attempt to ban fox-hunting. The Alliance made its statement as the home secretary took delivery of the Burns inquiry into the sport's future.

After almost three years of stalling and setbacks, it also emerged that the government is to bring forward legislation on the controversial sport. However, Alliance chief executive Richard Burge warned that the government was not giving people enough time to consider the report.

Although the Alliance had not yet decided whether to mobilise mass protests against moves to ban fox-hunting, Mr Burge said the resolve of rural people was "even stronger than in 1998... What we want is a sensible and sane debate on the facts and decisions made by parliament based on evidence and not prejudice."

Rather than leave a backbencher to introduce a Private Member's Bill proposing a ban - an option which has seen previous attempts talked out by parliamentary opponents - the government is now ready to announce that it will introduce its own Bill.

The new Bill is expected to give a range of options on hunting. MPs would be able to choose from an outright ban, local bans or no change to the law.

Ministers are apparently hoping that by being seen to take account of the views of MPs on both sides of the Commons, the House of Lords will shy away from throwing out a Bill. If they did so anyway, the government intends to include a ban in the next Labour election manifesto.

The Burns report, details of which Mr Straw will disclose to parliament on Monday, has gathered evidence from pro- and anti-foxhunting groups on the likely threat to rural jobs posed by a ban.

Gordon Prentice, MP for Pendle, who has been prominent among Labour backbenchers campaigning for a ban, welcomed the idea of a government Bill. "It would come to the Lords with all the legitimacy of a Government Bill, and it would be a free vote as well, it wouldn't be a whipped vote," he said.

However, Lembit Opik, the Liberal Democrat MP for Montgomeryshire and joint chairman of the Middle Way Group, a cross-party body which has been proposing a compromise solution to the hunting debate, was alarmed by the suggestion of an options-based Bill.

"An options Bill will give MPs a number of choices to vote for. These are likely to present a range of alternatives over the future of hunting," he said. "But it all depends on what questions you ask. My worry is there's so much emotion and so little logic being applied to this issue that people will simply vote for the strongest ban, unless there is a safeguard to force a rational consideration of the Burns recommendations." He added that a debate attended by 20 MPs and a vote by 500 did not constitute an adequate consideration.

Conservative home affairs spokesman David Lidington accused the government of using the fox-hunting Bill to try to appease demoralised Labour MPs. Fox-hunting, he said, was not a high priority for people - they wanted the government to concentrate on issues such as schools and hospitals

Parliamentary Labour Party chairman Clive Soley dismissed suggestions that the disclosure that there was to be a Bill was linked to Tony Blair being heckled by the Women's Institute earlier this week. There had been meetings on the issue for some time and there was no connection between the two, he told the Today programme.

fields.headline: The European single currency
fields.standfirst: A new report says Britain is about to meet Gordon Brown's conditions for joining the single currency. Julian Glover explains the economics behind swapping the pound for the euro
fields.trailText:
Why is this issue in the news?
Because of comments in a report issued this week by the influential Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The OECD says the British economy is becoming more and more like the economy in 'euroland' - made up of the countries which have already joined the euro. It suggests that on many of the most important tests of economic performance, the British and European economies are now running on similar lines. For instance, prices are rising in both Britain and euroland by around two per cent a year. The report suggests that the behaviour of Britain's economy will soon be closer to the European average than that of some countries which have already joined.
fields.body:
Why is this issue in the news?
Because of comments in a report issued this week by the influential Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The OECD says the British economy is becoming more and more like the economy in 'euroland' - made up of the countries which have already joined the euro. It suggests that on many of the most important tests of economic performance, the British and European economies are now running on similar lines. For instance, prices are rising in both Britain and euroland by around two per cent a year. The report suggests that the behaviour of Britain's economy will soon be closer to the European average than that of some countries which have already joined.

Is this important?
Yes - for two reasons. First, the OECD is an independent organisation. It doesn't have a political interest in persuading Britain either to join the euro or to stay out, so its comments will have a significant impact. Secondly, the greater the similarities between the British economy and the rest of Europe, the easier it should be for Britain to replace the pound with the euro without economic disruption. British opponents of the euro have long argued that membership would be a mistake because the British and European economies run differently - meaning that what might be good for Germany would not be good for Britain. This report makes that case look weaker.

The Treasury must be happy?
Not exactly. While flattered to be praised by the OECD for Britain's 'rather enviable' economic performance, the Treasury is worried that reports such as this will bring the issue of joining the euro to the top of the political agenda. Ministers would rather leave the question until after the general election. They worry that the Conservatives will be able to turn the election into a contest about euro membership - and every opinion poll shows that at the moment the public do not want to join. In fact the Treasury is so worried about this that it apparently persuaded the OECD to tone down those remarks suggesting that Britain was ready to join the single currency.

So what do we have to do to join?
The British have to meet two conditions - known as the 'convergence criteria'. The first, the 'Maastricht criteria', were put in place by the 1991 Maastricht Treaty, which led to the single currency. These require that any country wanting to join the euro passes a set of tests on its economic performance, in areas such as debt, inflation, interest rates and borrowing. Britain meets these with flying colours, so according to the rules we could join the euro tomorrow if we wanted to. But in October 1997 the chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced five further tests he wants the British economy to pass before it joins. These mostly cover the impact of the euro on Britain's international competitiveness, but the most important of them requires Britain and Europe's economic cycles to be parallel, so that European interest rates do not cause economic harm when they are imposed on this side of the channel.

Do we meet Gordon Brown's tests?
Not quite. The new OECD report says Britain is close to doing so (although it also doubts the value of Brown's tests) but the recent low value of the euro against the pound means that few economists think Britain could safely join at the moment. There are signs, though, that the euro is beginning to rise in value, which would make this less of a problem.

So we will join?
Ah. At this point, economics matter less than politics. It looks as if Britain will meet every possible criteria for joining the single currency soon after the next election - but if the prime minister thinks the public don't want to go in, he may still shy away from holding the referendum he has promised on the issue. And even if the referendum does take place, there's no guarantee that it will be won by those who think we should join. So the pound looks safe for some time yet.

webTitle: Hague capitalises on 'out-of-touch' Blair's WI debacle

fields.headline: Hague capitalises on 'out-of-touch' Blair's WI debacle
fields.standfirst:
The Tory leader has branded the prime minister arrogant and remote. Mark Tran reports
Full text of William Hague's speech
fields.trailText: The Tory leader has branded the prime minister arrogant and remote. Mark Tran reports.
fields.body:
An increasingly confident William Hague today predicted that the Tories could win the next election because Tony Blair was the most "out-of-touch" prime minister Britain has ever had.

Mr Hague portrayed the Conservatives as the voice of the mainstream on a host of issues from crime to asylum seekers, unlike the "out-of-touch progressives in Islington".

Capitalising on the rude reception Mr Blair received from members of the Women's Institute this week, the opposition leader said the incident demonstrated that the prime minister had failed to deliver his policy pledges and had become a remote figure.

Calling Mr Blair "the most out-of-touch, arrogant, opportunistic, remote prime minister we've ever had", Mr Hague said the prime minister "is the man who had it all, and then threw it all away".

Delivering a keynote speech to the Welsh Conservative party conference in Llandudno, Mr Hague launched a lengthy and scathing personal attack on his Labour counterpart. "They [the public] know that Tony Blair enjoyed every political advantage when he walked into No 10 on that morning in May three years ago, and now they slow clap him as he squanders those advantages day by day," Mr Hague said. "He looks around for someone else to blame - the media, the Tories, the Labour party, now even the Women's Institute. But there is only one person to blame: Tony Blair himself."

A new poll published on Friday said Labour's lead over the Tories had halved over the past year. But Mr Hague still has a long way to go. Labour was still streets ahead of its rivals, enjoying a comfortable 15 points lead. However, the goverment's approval rating has fallen to 39.4% - the first time it has gone below 40%.

Pressing the familiar Conservative hot buttons, Mr Hague said he would change the law to put it on the side of the householder instead of housebreaker - referring to the case of Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer found guilty of murder after he shot a teenage intruder.

"We're going to scare the living daylights out of the criminals," said Mr Hague, adding that the Tories were "ready to champion the mainstream majority against criminals."

Apart from facing a resurgent William Hague, the prime minister today faced further dissension in his cabinet on the single European currency. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, told the Daily Mirror that the government needed to make the case for joining the euro.

"We do have to be putting the case both for Europe and the euro," Mr Byers said. The remarks risk reopening cabinet tensions over the single currency as the chancellor, Gordon Brown, wants to kick the issue into touch until after the next election.

Mr Blair's dilemma on the euro was further heightened by a report from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development which found the business cycles of the UK and Europe coming into line, interest rates getting closer and structural reform in euroland gathering pace.

The OECD's regular assessment of UK economy said that in some respects Britain's economy was more like the economy in 'euroland' - made up of the countries which have already joined the euro - than some of the European single currency zone's existing members.

Seeking to exploit Labour's discomfiture on Europe, Mr Hague called on the government to hold referenda on all constitutional legislation, particularly over Britain's links with Europe. Mr Hague said the government was preparing to allowing more power to be leeched away by the European Union, with a key treaty agreement expected to be agreed by the end of the year.

"The mainstream majority believe that there is a limit to political union," he said, "and they do not want to see more of their rights and powers handed over to unelected bureaucracies in Brussels without their permission."

Conservative Party

webTitle: Want to watch England from a jacuzzi?

fields.headline: Want to watch England from a jacuzzi?
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of wisden.com's gossip column, Charles de Lisle investigates a Caribbean-style gimmick at the Riverside, and mingles with several former Test cricketers and one former Prime Minister at the opening of the Peter May Sports Centre
fields.trailText: Durham lay on a jacuzzi for England fans
fields.body:
Durham lay on a jacuzzi for England fans

The word warm-up will take on a new meaning next month when England play at Chester-le-Street for the first time - and spectators get the chance to watch the action from a jacuzzi.

The hot tub makes its international debut in English cricket during the "carnival weekend" of one-day games at the Riverside on July 15-16. England play West Indies on the Saturday - with Darren Gough, no doubt, steaming in - before West Indies take on Zimbabwe next day.

Whatever the weather at England's most northerly international venue, the tub should be overflowing during the first match, for which only 750 of the 15,000 tickets remain unsold. Steel bands and costume characters will add to the atmosphere in the "party zone" featuring the tub.

Aimed at the 18-30 age group, the jacuzzi takes eight people at a time and has a good view of play. It's deliberately sited well away from members who might blanch at the sight of fans in Speedos or bikinis taking the plunge. As at other matches in the triangular tournament, there will, for the first time, be bursts of music at exciting moments.

The tub was tried out during the Durham Dynamos' National League match against the Surrey Lions last month. Sue Newton, Durham's marketing director, says: "It was cold and overcast that day. But the tub is a tremendous way of warming up, and proved popular. Quite a few people watched the game from there."

Durham's move is welcomed by the ECB and Channel 4, which originally proposed that Caribbean-style swimming pools be introduced for Tests this summer. The idea was dropped, after "serious consideration", when it emerged that the pools could not be fitted in at Test grounds. MCC made it clear that such frivolity was felt to be unworthy of Lord's.

However Lord's, along with other major venues, has agreed to let Caribbean bands perform during the lunch intervals of Windies Tests. The relaxation - for all international matches except those at Lord's - on the ban on bringing in musical instruments and whistles is another victory for the ECB and Channel 4's campaign to jazz up the game, and widen its appeal. "Lord's would rather keep things more traditional," says an ECB spokesman. "We respect that."

Cricket Do of the Week (the second in an occasional series)

Occasion The opening on Tuesday, June 6, of the Peter May Sports Centre, a £5m complex at Walthamstow, north east London, developed by the London Playing Fields Society.

Format Champagne reception at 11am, brief speeches from HRH the Duke of Gloucester - who opened the facility - and others, lunch in the indoor cricket school/multi-purpose sports hall, then an exhibition game between two scratch sides, staged on the best of the four cricket squares.

Attendance 250. Strong turn-out from England players of May era: Ted Dexter, Colin Cowdrey, Trevor Bailey, Raman Subba Row, Peter Richardson, Fred Titmus and Doug Insole. More recent internationals included Mickey Stewart, Derek Underwood, John Lever, Graham Gooch, Mike Gatting and Gladstone Small. Also there: politicians led by John Major, wearing his Surrey president's hat, and Kate Hoey, the Minister for Sport. There was a surprising degree of warmth between the two, but then she is MP for the Oval - well, Vauxhall.

Notable absenteeNasser Hussain, who pulled out at the last minute when he had to play in Essex's current Championship match in search of some runs.

Main revelation Kate Hoey admitting in her speech that it's not just Tory governments which are responsible for the disastrous sell-off of thousands of council sports grounds for development over the past 20 years. She promised that New Labour is now "moving forward" with firm support for efforts to preserve playing fields.

Main talking point A fitting memorial to England's greatest post-war batsman, and a good day for the future of English cricket, was the general verdict. In other words, relief and delight at the rescue of the 32-acre Wadham Lodge playing fields on which the young Gooch played some of his early knocks. The transformation of vandalised and abandoned grounds owes much to a £3.85m grant from the Sports Lottery Fund, and £600,000 from the Peter May Memorial Appeal.

The centre, which will also nurture local talent in soccer, rugby, hockey, badminton and martial arts, is aimed particularly at young people from ethnic communities; Essex and Arsenal both hope to spot and develop future international stars here.

Principal entertainment The 15-over match, in which Mrs Peter May's XI, led by Gatting and including Small, defeated an Essex CCC President's XI, starring Gooch, by six runs. Gooch, rising 47, would have been a strongish contender for a Man of the Match award had there been one.

Oddly, he opened the bowling, not the batting. Trundling in with the new ball off seven paces, partnering Lever (51), Gooch took three for two in two overs. Then, coming in at four, with his side well behind the nine-an-over asking rate, he struck a fluent 27 off 16 balls, including three successive fours and a straight six. Handy practice for his first-class comeback next month, when he leads MCC against New Zealand A at Oxford.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He can be contacted at cdelisle@compuserve.com

webTitle: June 9: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 9: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Gielgud tribute to be broadcast, Christian Slater and John Woo team up, Tim Burton seeks Matt Damon for Apes, and Jeff Goldblum, Simon Baker and Clea DuVall on the casting couch
fields.body:
 A three-hour tribute to the late Sir John Gielgud, who died last month aged 96, will be broadcast on BBC Radio 3 next Thursday (June 15). The programme will be hosted by Michael Billington, The Guardian's theatre critic. It will include contributions from friends and colleagues, such as Alan Bennett, Peter Hall, Felicity Kendal, Irene Worth and Richard Eyre.

 Christian Slater, whose last film offering was 1998's poorly received Very Bad Things, will team with Mission: Impossible 2 director John Woo for Windtalkers. The second world war film will also star Nicolas Cage.

 As pre-production begins on Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes remake, The Hollywood Reporter reckons that Burton met with Matt Damon regarding the film's lead (human) role. Damon is said to be waiting for the most recent revision of the film's script before coming to a decision.

 Jeff Goldblum will add his voice to Warner Bros.' live-action/animated comedy feature Like Cats and Dogs. Antz director Larry Guterman will direct, Tobey Maguire, Susan Sarandon, Michael Clarke Duncan and Joe Pantoliano have already signed up to the project.

 Aussie actor Simon Baker, last seen in Ride With the Devil, is in final negotiations to star as the love interest of Oscar-winner Hilary Swank in the period drama The Affair of the Necklace.

 Clea DuVall is set to co-star in the sci-fi action thriller John Carpenter's Ghost of Mars, opposite Courtney Love and Ice Cube. DuVall is best known for her role in last year's teen horror picture The Faculty.

webTitle: 'Not only have they killed my husband, they have destroyed me and my family'

fields.headline: 'Not only have they killed my husband, they have destroyed me and my family'
fields.standfirst: The following is the text of a statement from Heather Saunders, widow of murdered Brigadier Stephen Saunders given today.
fields.trailText: "Stephen was my life and our lives were so deeply entwined that today I stand before you half the person I was yesterday morning.
fields.body:
"Stephen was my life and our lives were so deeply entwined that today I stand before you half the person I was yesterday morning.

"Stephen was a wonderful loving man. He was a man committed to peace and throughout his 35 years in the Army, he never raised his gun to kill anyone.

"In fact in the past, I know he hesitated once, when someone opened fire on him in Northern Ireland, in case he hit an innocent bystander.

"He was a wonderful and proud father of our two daughters Nicola and Catherine, who now will have to go through their lives without him.

"In fact to quote both my little girls, 'he was the best daddy in the world'. They loved him very much.

"I only hope the people that carried out this cowardly act on an unarmed man simply travelling on his way to work, will realise the total devastation they have caused.

"Not only have they killed my husband, they have destroyed me and my family.

"I would like to thank the Greek people for all their help and support at this awful time.

"I especially want to thank the doctors and nurses at the Red Cross hospital who tried so hard to save Stephen's life. They did what they could in an impossible situation.

"We must make sure this never happens again. I appeal to the Greek people and to anyone who knows anything, because someone must know something about this terrible murder.

"We must prevent this kind of thing from happening again.

"Anyone who saw anything, anyone who knows anything please tell the police so that no-one else has to go through what we are going through today.

"The Greek people are not responsible for what happened yesterday but for the sake of the future of Greece these wicked men must be brought to justice.

"Stephen was a forgiving man. As yet I cannot forgive the perpetrators of this horrible crime.

"But God may help me to forgive in time. I don't know. Thank you."

fields.headline: Obituary: Frédéric Dard
fields.standfirst: French detective writer whose underworld tales sold more than 27 million copies
fields.trailText: The French detective writer Frédéric Dard, who has died of a heart attack aged 78, was a prolific novelist, whose work was compared to that of Georges Simenon and who was acclaimed as a "magician" with language. The French president, Jacques Chirac, described him as "an immensely generous writer".
fields.body:
The French detective writer Frédéric Dard, who has died of a heart attack aged 78, was a prolific novelist, whose work was compared to that of Georges Simenon and who was acclaimed as a "magician" with language. The French president, Jacques Chirac, described him as "an immensely generous writer".

He produced over 300 books, more than half of them based around the partnership of two police officers, Superintendent San Antonio and his sidekick Inspector Berurier. Known as the "San Antonio" books - Dard reportedly chose his hero's name by simply going through lists of cities on a map of the United States - they had sold a phenomenal 27m copies by the time of the author's death.

Dard was born in Bourgoin-Jallieu, in the Isère region of France, the son of an artisan, turned businessman. He was brought up by his grandmother while his parents were busy with their central heating company. It was his grandmother, he said later, who first gave him a love of literature by encouraging him to read. Of all his childhood memories, his most vivid was the sight of the family possessions being seized when his father's business collapsed into bankruptcy in the 1930s. The family were forced to move to Lyon, where the best future for the young Frédéric seemed to be working as a clerk.

Instead, his uncle, who worked in a garage, managed to put him in touch with a local magazine, Le Mois de Lyon. Here, as a young journalist writing about Lyon's city street life, Dard discovered a new world of brothels, pimps and criminals - and the work of "les flics", the police.

Dard published his first novel in 1940, at the age of only 19. Several books later, he was encouraged by Georges Simenon to try and adapt one of them for the theatre. In 1950, convinced that this was where his future lay, Dard moved to Paris with his wife Odette, whom he had married in 1942, and their two children.

But the theatre was not the immediate answer to his problems. As a struggling writer trying to support a young family, Dard needed money, and, in desperation, went back to writing novels. He needed to have quick success, and was influenced by the American thriller writer Peter Cheyney, who had produced a string of popular pulp-fiction books in the 1940s.

Dard was encouraged by Armand de Caro, a new young publisher he had met, and, with his main detective character San Antonio - himself a criminal by nature - already formed in his mind, he looked back to his childhood to find his hero's assistant. Inspector Berurier was based on a neighbour haunted by the first world war.

Dard worked at an extraordinary rate, producing up to five novels a year - while still holding on to the possibilities of cinema and television productions. But, as he became more famous, he found the pressures building up. He was constantly being interviewed, and despite their new-found wealth, he and Odette experienced marital difficulties. In 1965, Dard attempted to commit suicide by hanging himself. He and Odette finally split up, and in 1969 he married de Caro's daughter Françoise.

By the 1960s, the academic world had become particularly infatuated by Dard's use of language. Whole seminars were given over to the San Antonio books, and the way that Dard combined words; for "sleet", which consists of "rain-pluie" and "snow-neige", he would write of the weather, "il pleige"; on other occasions, he would invent entirely new Franch words, such as "adulttre".

It is little wonder that there were those who thought he should be elected to the Académie Française. But Dard was not impressed, just as he remained unaffected by the admiration of French politicians, including the then president of France, François Mitterrand.

Outside the detective genre, Dard wrote many novels using a pseudonym. These ranged from Frédéric Charles to Kaput and L'Ange Noir (The Black Angel). In 1983, Josephine, his daughter with Françoise, was kidnapped while the family were living in Switzerland. Although, after her release, the novelist said it was the most traumatic moment of his life, he later used the idea of the kidnapping in one of his books. He would also often invent imaginary moments in French history and, although he said he feared death, his one regret was that he would not be able to use it in one of his own books.

Dard is survived by his second wife, Françoise, and three children, two of them from his marriage to Odette.
Douglas Johnson

 Frédéric Charles Antoine Dard, novelist, born June 29 1921; died June 8 2000

fields.headline: Plums off the tree
fields.standfirst: Plagiarism stinks, but this is not plagiarism
fields.trailText: Plagiarism stinks, but this is not plagiarism
fields.body:
The novelist Linda Grant should now be celebrating her winning of the Orange Prize for fiction. Instead she is having to contend with a raft of hostile newspaper reports claiming plagiarism in terms which demand a vigorous self-defence. As Ms Grant freely admits, she read and much appreciated the work of an academic, AJ Sherman, in the course of her research for her historical novel, When I Lived In Modern Times. She noted down a few details from diary entries and letters which he quoted in his work Mandate Days: British Lives In Palestine 1918-1948 and reworked them into her dialogue. None of the offending details originated with Dr Sherman; he has simply quoted extracts from what he found in his work in archives in Oxford. He has counted just 17 instances where Ms Grant has reworded detail from his book in a novel which runs to some 80,000 words.

To describe what she did as plagiarism is palpably false. Both the amount and the nature of the material which Ms Grant used makes it clear that this is purely a question of attribution. That the hardback edition contained no fuller acknowledgment was her publisher's decision, not hers. Five weeks ago, it was agreed between the publisher and Dr Sherman that the paperback edition would contain an appropriate credit for his book. That should have been the end of the matter, but Dr Sherman apparently was unwilling to let the matter rest and continues to air it at length in the media.

Any historical novelist, by definition, depends on meticulously researching the accounts of people's experience in the period in question. Authenticity requires that the novelist is faithful to that material, incorporating turns of phrase, ideas and details of their lives into the characters in the novel. The novel's originality lies in its structure, style and characterisation. Are we going to call Shakespeare a plagiarist because he relied so much on Holinshed's chronicles?

He has counted just 17 instances where Ms Grant has reworded detail from his book in a novel which runs to some 80,000 words. To describe what she did as plagiarism is palpably false. Both the amount and the nature of the material which Ms Grant used makes it clear that this is purely a question of attribution. That the hardback edition contained no fuller acknowledgment was her publisher's decision, not hers. Five weeks ago, it was agreed between the publisher and Dr Sherman that the paperback edition would contain an appropriate credit for his book. That should have been the end of the matter, but Dr Sherman apparently was unwilling to let the matter rest and continues to air it at length in the media. Any historical novelist, by definition, depends on meticulously researching the accounts of people's experience in the period in question. Authenticity requires that the novelist is faithful to that material, incorporating turns of phrase, ideas and details of their lives into the characters in the novel. The novel's originality lies in its structure, style and characterisation. Are we going to call Shakespeare a plagiarist because he relied so much on Holinshed's chronicles?

webTitle: Animated Clerks fails to animate TV audiences

fields.headline: Animated Clerks fails to animate TV audiences
fields.trailText: Just as Dogma director Kevin Smith predicted, his animated comedy, Clerks, is going out of business - after just two airings.
fields.body:
Just as Dogma director Kevin Smith predicted, his animated comedy, Clerks, is going out of business. After just two airings, US TV station ABC has pulled the plug on the series, which is based on Smith's 1994 cult indie feature.

As well as poor ratings, ABC executives have also had to deal with advertiser defections from the show after the edgy content scared off several major sponsors.

Smith has been vocal in his displeasure about how ABC scheduled and promoted the series, (see our feature), but Miramax TV president Billy Campbell was diplomatic, praising Smith and his team for their work, and commenting that the show simply "wasn't right for ABC."

webTitle: Pinocchio's and Adam and Eve, Norwich

fields.headline: Pinocchio's and Adam and Eve, Norwich
fields.trailText: Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

Telephone: 01603 613318.
Address: Pinocchio's, 11 St Benedict's, Norwich
A reader wrote in saying it was all very well going on about A-1 Italian restaurants in Rome,(actually in Weekend) but what about finding something nearer to home and not in London. Well, what about Pinocchio's? I won't pretend it's in the same class as the Ristorante Abuzzo, nor would it pretend to be so, but the pitch pine floor, beech chairs and general good cheer all have a nice bright glow to them, and the food likewise is disarmingly cheap (lunch; £5.50 for pizza or pasta and salad). Proper main courses are serious contenders (wild boar Callantara). Pizza bases are thin and crisp, toppings perky and vibrant. Pastas are precisely cooked and authentically sauced.

Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Telephone: 01603 667423.
Address: Adam and Eve, Bishopsgate, Norwich.
Golden oldie, as it were, and feels like it, what with settles, panels, tiles and a snug. Parts date back to 1249. No matter, the business within is a bit more up to date. They even welcome kids. Class Adnams, Greene King IPA and Theakston's OP on the pumps (plus guest beers), Addlestone's cider and proper wines. And the food? I thought you'd never ask. Everything from chunky soups (cheese and ale with pastry thatching) to weighty puds (spicy bread and butter) by way of substantial main/single dishes (sausage casserole). For quick biters, however, there are sandwiches, baps and French breads filled with all manner of goodies. Then it's off to the cathedral for a spot of spiritual uplift.

On the menu: Bedfordshire clanger

What's in a name?
What, indeed? Well, what then?
Oh, I see what you mean. Pork and apple. That's it?
Not quite. There's a suet crust, you see, all golden and glazed and shaped like an oblong box. And inside there's the meat, usually pork for the rich and bacon for the poor, at one end, with apple at the other. A kind of main course and pudding all in one?
That would seem to be about the size of it. In fact, clangers were once made of boiled suet, like a roly poly, with meat inside and fruit stuck into the pastry. Very convenient, but why clanger?
No one knows, but maybe because it clangs to the sides of your tummy. Very droll.

Cheats kitchen
Cheat's raspberry fool

455g raspberries
1 carton Ambrosia custard
1 284 ml pot whipping cream
juice half a lemon
2 tbsp caster sugar

1 Blast the raspberries, lemon juice and sugar in a blender or food processor.
2 Whip the cream until stiff.
3 Stir the raspberry goo into the custard, and then add the whipped cream.
4 Chill for 30 minutes to one hour.

Serves 4 or 6 (depending on how greedy they are).
Ms S Taylor, Cumbria

· If you have any hints for Cheat's kitchen, send them to The Guzzler, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London, EC1R 3ER

Food on the net
nextdaychampagne.co.uk

Does exactly what it says - delivers a bottle of bubbly to your door the next day, provided you order before 2pm. Choose from vintage or N-V (and read up on your choice on the site) and pen your own message to be printed on the label.

Pros: Speedy service and an ideal site for a present that gives the impression of having been planned more than 24 hours in advance. Very easy to use. Competitive prices.

Cons: Delivery could be anytime during the day, so you'll have to be at home, or pay a supplement for a specific "deliver by" time.

Delivery: next day, not surprisingly.

Charges: all included, unless you want a specific time; then up to £9 on top.
