fields.headline: Swimming against the tide
fields.standfirst: Scotland's farmed salmon industry is under siege.  Matthew Fort  reports on how some farmers are fighting back by going organic - and explains how to tell the good fish from the bad and the ugly
fields.trailText: Scotland's farmed salmon industry is under siege. Matthew Fort reports on how some farmers are fighting back by going organic - and explains how to tell the good fish from the bad and the ugly
fields.body:
Oh dear: 395,000 farmed salmon have fled their cages and swum off into the far blue yonder in the first five months of this year, according to a report this week. Well, there's a surprise.

Or perhaps not. Apparently another 225,000 of the slippery bleeders got away last year. It seems that they have been at it for years, mingling with their wild cousins, probably interbreeding with them, with untold consequences for the genetic make-up of the fish - including the incredible inbuilt code that tells them how to come back, year after year, to the same rivers to breed. And then there's the possibility that the farmed salmon, once in the wild, are spreading the diseases to which they are notoriously prone.

The report is another blow to the embattled Scottish salmon farming industry, which in recent years has had to cope with infectious salmon anaemia, accusations of habitual overuse of chemicals and general environmental mayhem. Not to mention the fact that international prices are being kept uneconomically low by the vast state-supported and less tightly controlled Norwegian industry, which dumps huge quantities of farmed fish on the open market.

The downward forces on the price of salmon has made it the cod de nos jours . In fact, as stocks of the free-swimming cod have crashed, pushing the price higher and higher, it is now enjoying a kind of celebrity and fashionableness that only relative rarity and expense can bring.

Salmon, on the other hand, is now cheap and ubiquitous. In 1998 the Scottish industry produced 86,000 tonnes of the stuff. This may be dwarfed by the tonnage that the Norwegians churn out, but it's still a lot of fish flesh. Small wonder that super market chiller cabinets are stacked with neatly trimmed bricks of salmon fillets. It lends itself to the array of ready-prepared cook-chill lines. Then there are the salmon fishcakes, seared salmon, blackened salmon, pan-fried salmon, roasted salmon, salmon carpaccio or salmon tartare dishes without which no restaurant menu seems complete. We are almost at the point reached 200 years ago, when the apprentices of London went on strike in disgust at being fed salmon more than five times a week.

Large-scale salmon farming is not much different from large-scale broiler chicken farming. The principles are that you cram as many fish as possible into a given area - 20kg of fish per cubic metre. The cages - the largest of which can hold up to 750,000 fish - are anchored in protected coastal lochs. You feed the salmon a mix of fish-meal protein, fish oil, vitamins and minerals to produce quick growth, as well as pigment to achieve the desirable pink colour. You regularly dose them with large quantities of any one of 19 authorised chemicals to deal with the infestations of sea lice and certain diseases caused, in part, by the conditions of close confinement.

It isn't surprising that, under these circumstances, the quality of the end product is not that great. You can always tell an intensively farmed fish from the rounded, stumpy shape of its head and nose, the often stunted, sometimes deformed nature of its fins, and the ragged, ill-formed state of the tail. You can always tell the uncooked flesh by its floppy, flabby condition and the distinctive, regular layers of creamy white fat between the pink sections of flesh, which together create a kind of herringbone effect. And when you pop the cooked article into your mouth, well, it's hard to believe that this is related to the wild salmon. Indeed, in spite of its popularity in the catering trade, few top chefs will touch intensively farmed fish.

Unfortunately, the wild salmon is in very serious trouble too. Stocks of salmon have been in decline for several decades, but so bad have the spawning runs up rivers become in recent years - particularly in spring - that fishermen in England have been forbidden to kill any salmon before June 15, and many of the prime Scottish rivers have set limits of one fish per rod per week. There has even been talk of a total moratorium on salmon fishing in rivers for 10 years.

Quite why this decline is happening is something of a mystery, although it seems likely to be a combination of over-netting in the mouths of some rivers; over-fishing at sea; contamination of the coastal lochs due to salmon farming; and general pollution. The decline certainly isn't the result of over-fishing in rivers. Fishing for salmon with a fly, or even spun bait, is among the least efficient ways of catching fish yet devised by man.

Unquestionably, a wild salmon is a beautiful creature to look on, shaped like a torpedo, with a bullet-shaped head and nose, a tail like a triangular spade and the colour of a silver ingot shimmering with pink and blue. It is a noble thing to eat, as well - firm, flaky, with a sweet, curdy flavour. Few of us are likely to enjoy it again. However, all is not lost.

The Scottish salmon farming industry is tentatively embracing non-intensive and organic practices. The Orkney Salmon Company and Aquascot, which also has sites in Orkney, have been working on an organic certification scheme with the Soil Association, guardian of all things organic, for some years, and their considerable investments of time and money are beginning to pay off - at least for the shoppers in selected Sainsbury's and Waitrose stores, to which virtually the entire organic output goes at present.

There are a number of farms, too, around the coast of both southern and northern Ireland that have been developing non-intensive practices for some time. The Clare Salmon Company carries German organic certification. Ocean Farm at Killybegs, Fanad Fisheries in Donegal, and the Northern Salmon Fisheries of Glenarm all produce non-intensively reared fish, even if they don't necessarily subscribe to full organic methods.

The difference between the intensive and the non-intensive systems is marked. The fish densities are halved to 10kg of fish per cubic metre. The fish feed is strictly controlled: it contains less fish oil, uses fish from sustainable sources and is coloured only with crushed prawn shells, part of the salmon's diet in the wild. In order to qualify for organic certification, the fish cannot be dosed with any chemical agents. Instead, the farmers have to rely on the natural movement of the sea water to keep them free of lice. For this reason the cages are anchored in areas with fierce tidal movements; this has the extra advantage of giving the fish a thorough workout each time the tide changes, thus improving tone and texture.

And if the finished fish does not quite have the ravishing beauty to the eye of its fresh-caught spring-run cousin, when it comes to eating even the most discriminating gourmet would be hard-pressed to tell them apart. Of course there is a price - about £16/kg as compared to £12/kg for intensively farmed salmon. But if the Scottish salmon farming industry is to recover its lost lustre, we had better be prepared to pay it.

fields.headline: Compulsive gamblers
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the nation's favourite pastime
fields.trailText: 1. The National Lottery has lured Britain into becoming a nation of gamblers. Nearly three quarters of all adults now have a regular flutter, according to a survey by the National Centre for Social Research.
fields.body:
1. The National Lottery has lured Britain into becoming a nation of gamblers. Nearly three quarters of all adults now have a regular flutter, according to a survey by the National Centre for Social Research.

2. Before the lottery craze took hold, only 20% of women and 40% of men regularly gambled. The steep rise is causing concern in charities such as Gamcare and Gamblers Anonymous. Gamcare reckons that about one in 100 gamblers - some 300,000 people - are seriously addicted.

3. The internet is crammed with lottery sites offering tips, patent systems and detailed analysis of the numbers. The odds against winning the jackpot remain roughly 14,000,000 to one. In six years, the lottery has created some 900 millionaires.

4. The National Lottery Commission calculates that more than £8bn of punters' cash has so far gone to "good causes".

5. Spending on gambling has not only been boosted by the lottery and scratchcards. There is also a small but growing market for online betting.

6. William Hill, the biggest name in UK internet gambling, offers odds on racing and a wide range of sporting events.

7. There is a growing trend for offshore betting, which is cheaper because it is not subject to tax.

8. There is also a large and growing list of online casinos. City nerds with a taste for risk might prefer to go in for one of the many sites specialising online spread betting.

9. More traditionally-minded punters may care to prop up the flagging football pools industry. Only 9% of British adults now regularly do the pools.

10. However, the bookies are set to receive a tide of footy cash in the coming days, with the onset of Euro 2000.

webTitle: Fox and Farrelly brothers sign for further three years

fields.headline: Fox and Farrelly brothers sign for further three years
fields.trailText: Twentieth Century Fox has signed Conundrum Entertainment, the partnership of writer/directors Peter and Bobby Farrelly and producer Bradley Thomas, for a further three years.
fields.body:
Twentieth Century Fox has signed Conundrum Entertainment, the partnership of writer/directors Peter and Bobby Farrelly and producer Bradley Thomas, for a further three years.

The Farrellys' last Fox release, the 1998 comedy There's Something About Mary, grossed more than $360m worldwide. The duo was widely courted by comedy-hungry studios, but Conundrum stayed put at Fox.

The Conundrum trio christened their new deal by formalising the cast of the next Farrelly movie Shallow Hal - Jack Black and Garry Shandling are poised to join Gwyneth Paltrow.

The new and improved Fox deal will enable Conundrum to crank out a steadier diet of their kind of comedies, Bobby Farrelly (pictured) told Variety. Alongside the The Six Billion Dollar Man, Conundrum's future projects include No More Mr. Nice Guy, which will star Rob Schneider and will be produced with Stanley Wilson, and Sonny Bright, a Wayne Rice and Gina Goldman-scripted pic that Doug (Go) Liman will direct.

"We like to direct a movie every other year, but there are a lot of scripts we like and now have a bunch of really good guys to get them done," Farrelly said.

webTitle: Scream series may not be over yet

fields.headline: Scream series may not be over yet
fields.trailText: Despite swearing that Scream 3 would the be the last of the series, it seems that Wes Craven is now relenting and considering a fourth episode
fields.body:
They swore that the third was the last, and that the hugely successful run of Scream films had come to its natural conclusion with the absurdly ironic Scream 3. As Film Unlimited editor Xan Brooks wrote, "with Scream 3, the performing dog catches up with its own tail and proceeds to devour itself. In the end, all that's left is a sly smile and a knowing wink."

And yet it seems that director Wes Craven is relenting, perhaps encouraged by the $100m that Scream 3 took in just three weeks at the US box-office, and another Scream movie is in the pipeline.

Craven might not be helming the project this time round, but a close friend remarked: "Even if Wes is not involved at all, there is such a massive audience out there of kids. The series is a cult."

Neither Scream regulars Neve Campbell or Courteney Cox are likely to appear in the next venture though there is talk of a cameo from Jada Pinkett Smith - who was actually killed off in Scream 2.

fields.standfirst: All today's transfer talk put into a pipe and smoked
fields.trailText: Arsenal have joined Manchester United and Chelsea in the chase for Gareth Southgate. The Aston Villa defender is expected to fetch £10m.
fields.body:
Arsenal have joined Manchester United and Chelsea in the chase for Gareth Southgate. The Aston Villa defender is expected to fetch £10m.

The Mirror claims that Aston Villa's defence will be further weakened by the departure of Gareth Barry, supposedly a £10m target for Manchester United.

Everton and Coventry are negotiating a swap deal involving Don Hutchison and Noel Whelan. Both players are on the transfer list and both could leave on a Bosman free next year - the clubs are attempting to ensure they do not lose money on their investments.

But the Mirror suggests Hutchison may be on his way to the North-east, with both Sunderland and Newcastle prepared to pay £2m. Everton manager Walter Smith would use the money to sign Rangers striker Seb Rozental - the Chilean wants to move to Goodison, and the Gers are prepared to let the injury-plagued player go for £1.5m.

The Express claims that Tottenham have offered Leicester £3m for Muzzy Izzet, who will be out of contract at the end of next season.

Ipswich keeper Richard Wright is "unlikely" to sign a contract extension, according to the player's agent. The 22-year-old has one year left on his Portman Road contract and Ipswich may decide to cash in when they can. Celtic manager Martin O'Neill is said to be interested, according to Planet Football.

Sunderland will monitor the progress of Belgian winger Gert Verheyen during Euro 2000.

Zinedine Zidane is interested in a move to Barcelona, according to Planet Football. But Juventus are adamant that he will remain in Turin. "We will never sell Zidane," insisted Juventus official Luciano Moggi.

Birmingham defender Gary Rowett is a £2.5m target for Charlton, according to the Express. Alan Curbishley wants to add more Premiership experience to his squad, and Rowett's time at Everton and Derby means that he fits the bill.

There is increased speculation that Fulham's Lee Clark will soon be moving to Middlesbrough after the player angrily left a press conference when asked about his future at Craven Cottage.

Lee Hughes is prepared to sign a long-term deal with West Brom. The news comes after Birmingham failed to sign the 24-year-old striker with a £3m bid.

Nottingham Forest are interested in Rotherham keeper Mike Pollitt, who is out of contract.

Moammer Gaddafi, son of Libyan leader Colonel Gaddafi, has been approached by Perugia. But he want to play for Internazionale - "Ronaldo has asked me to play alongside him to gain experience," he said.

webTitle: Joanne Whalley wins Jackie Kennedy role

fields.headline: Joanne Whalley wins Jackie Kennedy role
fields.trailText: Those of you whose patriotic sensibilities were offended by the casting of Texan Renee Zellweger in the role of British singleton Bridget Jones, can take heart that British actresses can win plum parts from their American counterparts too.
fields.body:
Those of you whose patriotic sensibilities were offended by the casting of Texan Renee Zellweger in the role of British singleton Bridget Jones, can take heart that British actresses can win plum parts from their American counterparts too. British actress Joanne Whalley has beaten off US stars to land the role of the former first lady of America Jackie Kennedy.

The 35-year-old star has signed up to do a four-hour TV mini-series, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis: A Life, which is being filmed this summer. The series follows Jackie's childhood, her marriage to John F. Kennedy, who went on to become US president, her time as first lady, her career as a book editor and the last years of her life.

Formerly married to Val Kilmer, Whalley rose to fame in the award-winning BBC drama Edge Of Darkness, and made her name in the US when she took the title role in the Gone With The Wind sequel Scarlett in 1994 (pictured here).

Whalley's screen roles have been scaled down over the past few years, although she appeared with Bill Murray in 1997's The Man Who Knew Too Little.

webTitle: Ainsley's Meals in Minutes is not enough!

fields.headline: Ainsley's Meals in Minutes is not enough!
fields.standfirst: What if Shearer's unfit? What is Lawro saying? And what is the giant Jan Koller doing to Karel Poborsky?
fields.trailText: What if Shearer's unfit? What is Lawro saying? And what is the giant Jan Koller doing to Karel Poborsky?
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"I've seen front page headlines in great big letters saying 'Zoff folly', 'Zoff stupid', 'Zoff crazy'. After the tournament there's a place for it but not before" - Dino Zoff refrains from offering the Italian press any more headlines. Like "I'm Zoff", "Zoff you go" or "I'll have you Zoff lad".

THE EURO-TORIAL

Alan Shearer has a problem. In his leg. Nobody seems to know just how bad the injury to the England captain's left knee actually is, but he will not train until tomorrow at the earliest and will be given "until kick-off" to prove his fitness for England's match with Portugal on Monday night. This may be the best solution for Kevin Keegan, but surely England's medical team won't be looking forward to prodding Shearer's tricky lower limb while the skipper is exchanging pennants.

While the Euro remains hopeful that the striker we so confidently backed the other day will still turn out for England and score 92 goals, it might be time to consider - deep breath - the other options.

If Shearer doesn't play, Keegan is expected to partner Michael Owen with Emile Heskey. In that way England retain some of Shearer's power up front (not the sort of power Freddie Ljungberg was talking about, by the way) as well as somebody who can hold the ball up. The only problem being that while Heskey could play in Shearer's position, he quite patently doesn't at the moment.

Robbie Fowler is "still not match fit", but also hasn't had a good game at senior level since September. Which leaves Kevin Phillips, a striker who, like Shearer, is great in and around the box but has nowhere near the same commanding presence on the field. Phillips has spent the past three years proving people wrong, however, and it could be the Sunderland man's tournament. But if the Euro was Kevin Keegan (which it could be, it hasn't checked), it would pack the midfield with the creative trio of Scholes, Barmby and McManaman and let Owen play by himself up front.

The irony of the whole situation is, of course, that because Shearer played in all of the recent friendlies, none of the other strikers have had much of a run out together. And if Shearer hadn't played in the Malta game, he wouldn't have got injured. Doh.

A LAWRO, LAWRO LAUGHS

You pay a hefty licence fee to the BBC. They give you stuff like Songs of Praise, Ainsley's Meals in Minutes and the latest Nick Berry vehicle. Good value in anybody's language, except that they also chuck loads of your money in the direction of Mark Lawrenson for "expert" football "analysis". An interview in this week's Heat magazine highlights the qualities you're getting for your cash.

"Raul and Morientes will be Spain's players to watch," Lawro confidently opines, treating the fact that Mr Morientes isn't actually in the Spanish squad with wanton disregard.

"I think all three teams [Holland, France and Spain] will be in the last four," the ex-Liverpool defender expertly predicts, even though the draw allows only two of those teams to reach the semi-final stage.

And not only does the man in the cheap suit and even cheaper moustache disgrace himself with factual inaccuracies, he also swears like a speeding sailor with Tourette's syndrome. Well, OK, he says "shit" once. Can we have our licence fee back?

EURO GUARDIAN

Read unrivalled coverage of Euro 2000 in the Guardian, featuring the best in sports writing, comment and humour.

Our new signings, Ron Atkinson, Dennis Bergkamp, Ron Manager and Jorge Valdano will combine with David Lacey, Richard Williams, Harry Pearson, Steve Bell, Vivek Chaudhary, Ian Ross, Martin Thorpe, Darren Tackle, Martin Kelner, Jon Brodkin and Daniel Taylor to bring the finest writing from and about the summer's great football tournament.

Read our 12-page broadsheet section on Saturdays and Mondays and our new special 24-page tabloid section from Tuesday to Friday.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Football and beer. They go together like... well, top sporting action and a tasty liquid beverage. Win a crate of beer for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Amsterdam coffee shop owners are locked in fierce talks with local officials over the right to stay open during Euro 2000. (Actually it's not so much fierce talks as, you know, like an open honest mature discussion between like two groups of people who are all the same underneath the skin man). Coffee shop owners believe that the sale of cannabis to travelling football fans could solve the hooligan problem. And bring down the crypto-fascist new world order that controls the planet from some place in Ohio.

In other intoxication news, the Dutch authorities have hit upon the idea of introducing a special tournament lager which will combat hooliganism by having only half the normal amount of alcohol in it. This lovely 2.5% strength beverage is called Festival Beer and will be on sale in all city centres where games will be played. Start queuing now.

Dutch bankers have advised their national team not to win Euro2000, or risk the direst inflationary consequences. Economists from the Abn-Amro bank, with their heads very much in the real world, have completed a report entitled Soccernomics in which they suggest: "A further boost to confidence [in The Netherlands] could be harmful." They advise their countrymen to make sure the economy only achieves growth of between 0.3% to 0.7% during the tournament. So don't be buying that orange and black jester's hat then.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi it's Karel Poborsk... aaaiiiieeeeee!!!

Ug! I am the giant Jan Koller! I am over sixty foot tall! I throw Karel Poborsky out of Eurorumour Towers and over yonder mountain so I can tell you rumours myself! And as I speak you I will be pounding my chest with my big fists, because I am powerful and huge!

Chelsea have made a £6m offer to Aston Villa for Gareth Southgate.

Manchester United are preparing a £10m bid for Villa's Gareth Barry, according to the Mirror.

Zinedine Zidane is interested in a move to Barcelona, according to Planet Football. But Juventus are adamant that he will remain in Turin. "We will never sell Zidane," insisted Juventus official Luciano Moggi.

Ug! I feel guilty about terrorising little Poborsky. Sniff. And why am I suddenly surrounded by angry men in helicopters?

TV AND RADI(EUR)O TONIGHT

BBC1: Three Lions (10.30pm)
The history of the England team since 1986. Go on, have a good cry.

Sky Sports: are pretending this tournament isn't happening.

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 News (8.57pm)
Set your videos for over two minutes of in-depth coverage!

Road To Euro 2000 (9pm)
How France, Denmark, Czech Republic and Holland started out on the road to death.

SATURDAY TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC1: Football Focus (12.20pm)
Go on, Stubbsy - get stuck into Lawro.

Auntie's Soccer Showdown Bloomers (6.25pm)
No. Under no circumstances watch this.

MOTD at Euro 2000 (11.10pm)
Which you won't be watching because you'll have already seen the game live.

Euro 2000 Replay (12.30am)
Now don't milk it.

ITV: The Big Match Live (7pm)
Belgium v Sweden. Sadly, we can no longer enjoy the sight of Bob Wilson fluffing his first lines at the opening match of a major tournament. Shame, shame, shame.

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Opening Ceremony (6pm)
Bad singing and dancing. There will probably also be a pompous fat man at a podium delivering a tedious speech.

Live Euro 2000 Football (7.30pm)
Belgium v Sweden. As ITV but without half-an-hour of smooth moustachioed continuity.

SUNDAY TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC1: Match of the Day - Live (1.15pm)
Turkey v Italy. Three matches today. Too excited.

Match of the Day - Live (7.30pm)
Holland v Czech Republic. Already seen two matches. Still far too excited.

A Question of Sport Euro 2000 Special (12.10am)
Now we've actually got some proper action to watch, do you really think we're going to stay up for this?

Euro 2000 Replay (12.40am)
Erm, yes, because we're going to stay up for this.

ITV: The Big Match - Live (4.30pm)
France v Denmark. Seen one match already. Don't care. Still really excited.

British Eurosport: Live Euro 2000 Football (7pm)
As BBC1 but without Martin O'Neill starting an argument at half-time.

webTitle: Half strength beer to quell football fans' Dutch courage

fields.headline: Half strength beer to quell football fans' Dutch courage
fields.trailText: It looks the same and even costs the same but once England fans arriving in Eindhoven get their first taste of it they will realise that it is certainly not the same.
fields.body:
It looks the same and even costs the same but once England fans arriving in Eindhoven get their first taste of it they will realise that it is certainly not the same.

In an attempt to minimise trouble while still allowing fans to enjoy themselves, officials have decided that only specially brewed, half strength beer can be sold in central Eindhoven, where most fans are expected to congregate, ahead of England's opening Euro 2000 match against Portugal on Monday.

Festival Beer contains 2% alcohol, compared with the normal local brew's 5%. Thousands of gallons have been ordered. The decision to introduce it was taken after the city authorities and police decided that bars should remain open over the weekend, when the majority of England fans are expected to arrive in the city.

Johann Beelem, an Eindhoven police spokesman, said: "We want to make sure that all fans arriving in Eindhoven have a good time and enjoy the party and we don't want to stop them from drinking.

"But we have to make sure that fans behave themselves. It's a precautionary measure. I'm sure that most of the fans will not notice once they have had a few glasses."

Police are expecting up to around 20,000 fans to descend on the city. Around 2,000 officers will be on duty over the weekend and on matchday. They have warned that bars will be closed if there is any trouble.

fields.headline: Cannabis may soothe Euro 2000 hooligans
fields.standfirst:
Amsterdam's drug-selling coffee shops win right to stay open during football tournament after negotiations with the city authority

Euro 2000
No Violence Campaign
National Criminal Intelligence Agency
Football (Offences and Disorder) Bill
fields.trailText: It has become of one the Netherlands' most famous products, and if those who advocate its virtues get their way then Euro 2000 could be the most peaceful and laid-back football tournament in sporting history.
fields.body:
It has become of one the Netherlands' most famous products, and if those who advocate its virtues get their way then Euro 2000 could be the most peaceful and laid-back football tournament in sporting history.

Representatives of Amsterdam's coffee shop owners, where cannabis is openly sold and smoked, have been locked in negotiations with the city's authority, after fears that they would be forced to close along with hundreds of bars in the city during Euro 2000 because of possible violence.

During the weeks of negotiations, representatives of growers and sellers of cannabis have told the city authority that it would be better off ensuring that the coffee shops remain open and that as many football fans as possible visit them, to ensure that peace reigns in the city. Meetings have taken place with the Netherlands justice department, local police officials and the local authority which regulates the coffee shops and issues licences for the selling and smoking of cannabis.

"Fortunately we have made them see sense," said Roland Dam, founder of Amsterdam's Cannabis College which provides information on the industrial, medicinal and recreational uses of the herb. "There is always less trouble when cannabis is involved. I mean, have you ever heard of anyone smoking a joint and then starting a riot? Keeping the coffee shops open is good news for the city and the tournament as a whole."

Owners of coffee shops or those involved in cannabis manufacture are not under Dutch law allowed to directly encourage its usage, but have been allowed to point to the wider benefits it could bring to Euro 2000. Officially, cannabis is not legalised in the Netherlands but is decriminalised with the authorities turing a blind eye to its use. Millions of people visit the city each year, which has become famous for offering one of the widest selections of cannabis in the world that can be smoked without fear of arrest.

"We are not saying that fans should come and smoke," emphasised Mr Dam. "But we are saying that smoking a joint is likely to contribute towards a peaceful tournament. People will be very relaxed, they will be more objective about the games and they will also become a bit more tolerant if their team loses."

Around the city's red-light district yesterday, where almost all Amsterdam's coffee shops are located, preparations for Euro 2000 were being made in a manner that befits the product being offered for sale. Many coffee shops have been granted late licences and will be able to stay open beyond 1am, while several are planning to erect giant television screens where fans can puff while their teams play. "I must admit we haven't got around to it yet," said a worker in the Dutch Flowers coffee shop.

Among the handful of customers there was relief that the coffee shops would remain open but dread at the arrival of thousands of football fans, even though some were not totally up to date with what was going on, given that most of the day had been idled away in the Dutch Flowers.

"I'm hoping there's not going to be a lot of violence," said Paul, an Australian backpacker travelling around Europe. "But which teams are playing and when does it begin?" he asked through a puff of smoke. "Who cares who wins so long as it's Holland," said Gary, a local resident.

"It should be fun. I hope the fans have a good smoke and just love each other."

In total there are around 230 coffee shops in Amsterdam and the average cost of cannabis is around £15 for a five gram bag. Football fans have been warned that they will not be allowed to drink or smoke cannabis on the street and that while bars will remain open in city centres they will be closed around grounds.

Like football teams, the cannabis world operates a league to see which is proving to be the most popular with smokers. Currently topping the premier pot league is a Dutch-produced cannabis called Real McCoy followed by Pot of Gold, another domestically produced cannabis.

"It should prove to be an interesting tournament," said Mr Dam. "We are preparing for a massive party.

"I think Real McCoy will prove to be the most popular but don't ask me who is going to win at the football. We just want it to be fun and peaceful."
fields.bodyText: It has become of one the Netherlands' most famous products, and if those who advocate its virtues get their way then Euro 2000 could be the most peaceful and laid-back football tournament in sporting history. Representatives of Amsterdam's coffee shop owners, where cannabis is openly sold and smoked, have been locked in negotiations with the city's authority, after fears that they would be forced to close along with hundreds of bars in the city during Euro 2000 because of possible violence. During the weeks of negotiations, representatives of growers and sellers of cannabis have told the city authority that it would be better off ensuring that the coffee shops remain open and that as many football fans as possible visit them, to ensure that peace reigns in the city. Meetings have taken place with the Netherlands justice department, local police officials and the local authority which regulates the coffee shops and issues licences for the selling and smoking of cannabis. "Fortunately we have made them see sense," said Roland Dam, founder of Amsterdam's Cannabis College which provides information on the industrial, medicinal and recreational uses of the herb. "There is always less trouble when cannabis is involved. I mean, have you ever heard of anyone smoking a joint and then starting a riot? Keeping the coffee shops open is good news for the city and the tournament as a whole." Owners of coffee shops or those involved in cannabis manufacture are not under Dutch law allowed to directly encourage its usage, but have been allowed to point to the wider benefits it could bring to Euro 2000. Officially, cannabis is not legalised in the Netherlands but is decriminalised with the authorities turing a blind eye to its use. Millions of people visit the city each year, which has become famous for offering one of the widest selections of cannabis in the world that can be smoked without fear of arrest. "We are not saying that fans should come and smoke," emphasised Mr Dam. "But we are saying that smoking a joint is likely to contribute towards a peaceful tournament. People will be very relaxed, they will be more objective about the games and they will also become a bit more tolerant if their team loses." Around the city's red-light district yesterday, where almost all Amsterdam's coffee shops are located, preparations for Euro 2000 were being made in a manner that befits the product being offered for sale. Many coffee shops have been granted late licences and will be able to stay open beyond 1am, while several are planning to erect giant television screens where fans can puff while their teams play. "I must admit we haven't got around to it yet," said a worker in the Dutch Flowers coffee shop. Among the handful of customers there was relief that the coffee shops would remain open but dread at the arrival of thousands of football fans, even though some were not totally up to date with what was going on, given that most of the day had been idled away in the Dutch Flowers. "I'm hoping there's not going to be a lot of violence," said Paul, an Australian backpacker travelling around Europe. "But which teams are playing and when does it begin?" he asked through a puff of smoke. "Who cares who wins so long as it's Holland," said Gary, a local resident. "It should be fun. I hope the fans have a good smoke and just love each other." In total there are around 230 coffee shops in Amsterdam and the average cost of cannabis is around £15 for a five gram bag. Football fans have been warned that they will not be allowed to drink or smoke cannabis on the street and that while bars will remain open in city centres they will be closed around grounds. Like football teams, the cannabis world operates a league to see which is proving to be the most popular with smokers. Currently topping the premier pot league is a Dutch-produced cannabis called Real McCoy followed by Pot of Gold, another domestically produced cannabis. "It should prove to be an interesting tournament," said Mr Dam. "We are preparing for a massive party. "I think Real McCoy will prove to be the most popular but don't ask me who is going to win at the football. We just want it to be fun and peaceful."

webTitle: Hague calls for votes on all big EU changes

fields.headline: Hague calls for votes on all big EU changes
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader's referendums plan outflanks his shadow spokesman

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Tory leader's referendums plan outflanks his shadow spokesman
fields.body:
William Hague will today step up the Conservative campaign against unchecked integration of the European Union by endorsing plans to make referendums on such constitutional changes compulsory in the future.

With a cross-party alliance of peers, including ex-cabinet members, David Owen, Jim Prior and Denis Healey, tabling such an amendment to the government's political parties bill there is a chance it may win in the Lords, forcing ministers to overturn it.

As Tony Blair gears up for a crucial EU summit where such changes are on the agenda, passions are starting to run high again on both sides. Yesterday the former deputy prime minister, Michael Heseltine, used a speech to denounce the extremism of his party's Eurosceptics and what he called their "North-American owned" newspaper allies.

A crucial test for both wings of the Tory Euro-war comes tonight when party activists pick a candidate to succeed John Major in Huntingdon, one of the most landslide-proof seats in Britain. A 35-year-old pro-European barrister is being tipped.

But the Conservative leader is determined to run the European issue against Mr Blair.

In a speech to his party's Welsh conference today he will go further than his foreign affairs spokesman, Francis Maude, who yesterday confined his own demand for a referendum to a single issue - the forthcoming Treaty of Nice. In Llandudno Mr Hague will say all major constitutional changes within the EU should be ratified by popular referendum.

The Hague plan would guarantee that any bill or part of a bill which the Speaker certified as being "of first rate constitutional importance" would be subject to a referendum.

One sign of Tory tension is evident in the fight for Mr Major's Huntingdon seat.

Allies of the ex-premier who made his own plea for a sensible dialogue on Europe this week, angrily deny claims that he is busily fighting behind the scenes to thwart any Euro-sceptic candidate. "He has not been involved at all," said one.

Mr Major avoids attacking Mr Hague. But Mr Heseltine was more dismissive. "The Conservative agenda for Eu rope today has an appeal in this country, particularly amongst those who are attracted to its Little Englandermessage, " he told an investors conference in London.

"The problem is that it has virtually no appeal to our European partners without whose agreement virtually none of its objectives can besecured."

In an unmistakable jibe at the Hague-Maude initiative he added: "It is perfectly possible to advocate all manner of change to satisfy a domestic audience.

"But what purpose does it serve if its consequence is to reconfirm in the minds of one's partners that we are detached from the enterprise of uniting Europe in which they are engaged?"

webTitle: Britain told: economy is ripe for euro

fields.headline: Britain told: economy is ripe for euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The government's attempt to keep the lid on the debate over joining the euro until after the election was undermined yesterday by an independent report from the world's top economic thinktank which said the British and core European economies were close to converging.
fields.body:
The government's attempt to keep the lid on the debate over joining the euro until after the election was undermined yesterday by an independent report from the world's top economic thinktank which said the British and core European economies were close to converging.

In spite of strenuous efforts by the Treasury to delete mention of anything remotely contentious, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's regular healthcheck on the UK economy said that in some respects the UK would soon be more like Euroland than some of the new currency zone's existing members.

Treasury officials spent six weeks haggling with the OECD over the report on a line-by-line basis in an attempt to water down the comments on the single currency. With polls showing the public 2-1 against Britain joining monetary union, the government is keen to prevent William Hague from turning the election into a referendum on the pound.

However, the report is likely to widen the cabinet rift over the single currency, providing a boost to the group - including the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, the trade secretary Stephen Byers, and the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson - who want the government to campaign more strongly for monetary union.

The Treasury said that the government's policy remained unchanged and that the UK would need to pass the five tests set by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in October 1997, before joining the euro. "The government will publish as assessment of the progress against the five tests early in the next parliament," said a spokesman.

But the OECD's message was welcomed by pro-monetary union campaigners who said it destroyed the myth that it was economically unsafe for Britain to join the euro.

Denis MacShane, Labour MP for Rotherham, said: "This blows out of the water the economic arguments of the anti-Europeans who allow their ideological hostility to Europe to overshadow hard economic facts. Pamphlets are being produced every week saying Britain is moving further and further away from Europe when the economic reality is that our future depends on deepening economic ties. I am glad that the OECD confirms that view."

The report complimented the government for its economic reforms, calling the outlook for growth and inflation "rather enviable". But it urged ministers to make sure the much-needed extra cash being poured into the health service as part of the new spending review was well spent and said one of the major challenges ahead was what to do about euro membership.

The OECD's view is that the UK passes the Maastricht criteria on debt, inflation, interest rates and borrowing levels with flying colours and is well on its way to fulfilling the chancellor's five tests, even though it doubts their objectivity.

With the two business cycles coming into line, interest rates getting closer and structural reform in the euro area gathering pace, it said: "In sum, on several scores, even as an 'out', the United Kingdom is projected to be as close, or even closer, to the economic centre of gravity of the euro area than some of the current 'ins'." The gap between UK and Euroland interest rates narrowed further yesterday when the European Central Bank raised borrowing costs by half a percentage point to 4.25%. UK interest rates are 6%.

The OECD added that the pound/euro exchange rate remained a problem, although some City economists say that the recent fall of sterling shows that the markets are beginning to take a more realistic view of the pound's value. The euro rallied to a seven-month high against the pound yesterday, bolstered by the shrinking interest rate gap.

Britain in Europe, the pro-European lobby group, welcomed the OECD report, saying it showed "that those people who say Britain will never be able to join the single currency have got their facts wrong. As the high pound does increasing damage to manufacturing industry and inward investment, it is becoming clear that exclusion from the single currency is not a cost-free option."

But Janet Bush, director of New Europe, the anti-monetary union thinktank, said: "The OECD offers a highly selective and glib view of economic convergence between Britain and Euroland, basing its analysis on a handful of economic indicators that may well prove to be ships passing in the night. It offers no evidence of the 'sustainable and durable convergence' that the chancellor of the exchequer has declared essential."

Condemning the chancellor's five tests as a sham, shadow chancellor Michael Portillo, said: "The government is already committed in principle to join the euro. They are now waiting for a convenient time to hold a referendum.

"This government is committed to following the politics of expediency not the politics of principle, so when they think they can con the electorate into voting to scrap the pound they will."

webTitle: Danish doubts add to woes of euro

fields.headline: Danish doubts add to woes of euro
fields.standfirst:
The vote on the krone's future could echo across the EU

Economic and Monetary Union: special report

Europa: For information on EU institutions and a calendar of events
fields.trailText: It is early evening in Jutland and the local Rotarians are enjoying a light supper of beef, red wine and chocolate marzipan  gateau  before another round in Denmark's great euro-debate.
fields.body:
It is early evening in Jutland and the local Rotarians are enjoying a light supper of beef, red wine and chocolate marzipan gateau before another round in Denmark's great euro-debate.

Chatting at candle-lit tables in an ambience of understated Scandinavian chic, the well-heeled guests have paid 150 krone (£13) each to hear the government's case for joining the single currency.

Henrik Dam Kristensen, the most popular minister in the centrist coalition, has arrived from Copenhagen to deliver the carefully honed speech he will repeat many times before the referendum on September 28.

Tonight, though, he is preaching to the converted: most of the 160-odd guests have made up their minds long before the sun sinks over the Vjele fjord and pine forests beyond the picture window of the hotel dining room.

"Voting no will lead to more uncertainty than yes," Mr Kristensen concludes, explaining how the euro will shield Denmark from global market crises, protect its treasured welfare state and boost economic well-being. "Yes is a safe vote. Yes is best for Denmark."

Yet even here there are doubts. "Economically, the arguments for the common currency are straightforward," agrees Tim Eskesen, a shipping broker who does most of his business with Germany and Sweden. "But I don't like the way the EU is built, with all that power in Brussels."

With less than four months to go before Denmark's seventh referendum on a European question since 1972, this country of 5.3m is divided across regions, classes and even families.

Worryingly, for the Social Democratic prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, the debate seems to line up the establishment - business, industry, banks, the media and union leaders against ordinary people, especially the poor.

For many, it is a question of heart versus head. "I don't want to sell my soul for money," says Hans-Peter Kafode, a middle-aged architect.

The yes camp had a strong lead when Mr Rasmussen announced the polling date to the Folketing, the Danish parliament, in March. But last week an IFKA institute survey gave euro-opponents 35% compared with 34% for supporters; some 23% were undecided.

Most other recent polls spell bad news for the government, while random sampling suggests it will be too close to call on the big day.

The stakes are dramatically high. "If we lose," warns Mr Kristensen, "everything will be very uncertain. It will be years before we can discuss this again."

If Danes do vote no, Sweden will probably abandon plans to call its own referendum, while Tony Blair's choice in even more eurosceptic Britain becomes tougher still.

Conversely, a Danish and Swedish yes would make euroland a club of 14 of the EU's 15 members, leaving a lonely Britain in the cold and reinforcing fears of a two-speed Europe. No surprise then, that Denmark's polite debate is being keenly watched from afar.

Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, did the yes camp no favours when he stated last month that, once in Euroland, there was no way out - the opposite of what he injudiciously told a British paper shortly afterwards.

The poor performance of the single currency, which has lost a third of its value against the dollar in the 17 months since it was launched, has had little effect. But Danish conservatives were dismayed by the EU sanctions imposed on Austria when Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party entered government and they were angered that the big guys were ganging up on another small country.

Denmark's monetary independence is already more apparent than real. The krone was pegged to the mighty deutschemark in the 1980s and under the exchange-rate mechanism, it has to stay within 2.25% of the euro.

So when the European Central Bank in Frankfurt raised interest rates by 0.5%, its Danish counterpart responded minutes later by lifting its lending rate from 2.85 to 3.3%.

Symbols matters, however. "We are not arguing against the euro for economic reasons," insists Jens-Peter Bonde, a veteran sceptic and Euro MP. "We are against it for institutional and political reasons because you can't have a common currency without a common government."

Independent observers argue that the yes camp needs to emphasise the wider benefits of EU membership. "The government is trying to pretend this is all just about economics," says Michael Seidelin, political editor of the respected Politiken daily. "That's been the problem here for 30 years."

Denmark's dilemmas

1972 Danes back first national referendum on joining European Economic Community. Sale of bacon to Britain is a key factor in historic yes vote.

1973 Denmark joins along with Britain and Ireland on January 1, 1986. New referendum approves Single European Act, allowing majority voting for the single market. But fears grow about national identity and loss of sovereignty to Brussels.

1992 Europe stunned by Danish rejection of Maastricht treaty, paving way for economic and monetary union. Delighted Eurosceptic British MPs sing Wonderful, wonderful Copenhagen.

1993 Maastricht accepted in second referendum, but only with laboriously-negotiated Danish opt-outs on EMU, defence justice and citizenship.

1998 Amsterdam Treaty accepted despite concerns about too much integration. Danish leaders promise "no more union".

2000 Referendum called on joining euroland and scrapping the krone. Danes deeply divided. Far-reaching implications for Britain, Sweden, and entire EU. The prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, promises practical benefits.

webTitle: A way to end our Euro-impasse

fields.headline: A way to end our Euro-impasse
fields.standfirst:
We need a new electoral system to end our Europe policy limbo

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: We need a new electoral system to end our Europe policy limbo
fields.body:
A month ago, Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, sketched the shape of a more federal European Union. At the end of this month France takes over the EU presidency. Things are on the move in Europe. Yet Britain is stuck in a limbo. The government can neither commit itself to the Europe that is shaping up around the Franco-German axis nor act effectively to change it.

The political deadlock on Britain's future in Europe is not the result of divisions in the government, real as they are. It is a consequence of the two-party system. It can only be broken by a change in the voting system at Westminster. First past the post can only result in a continuing stalemate.

Labour's landslide has had some unexpected consequences. In the aftermath of the Tories' devastating defeat, William Hague has rebuilt his party around fear and loathing of Europe. By defining the Tories in anti-European terms, he has polarised British politics as never before.

Ironically, one of the results of the Tory swing to nationalism has been to import a reactionary politics that is unpleasantly reminiscent of continental Europe. Hague's harping on the dangers posed by refugees is part of a larger strategy. His goal is to rally Tory supporters against Britain's "liberal establishment" - which in practice means setting his party against the largely liberal values of the British majority.

British politics has been split between radically different views of the world. For Hague this can be seen as a success. But for the country as a whole it is a disaster. It is not that Hague has any prospect of winning a general election. Rather, the effect of the Tories' conversion to a reactionary politics of identity is to make a political settlement of the European issue impossible under the existing two-party system.

Whenever it is held, it is a near-certainty that the next general election will result in a reduced Labour majority. It is unthinkable that a referendum on the euro could be held against that background. The danger is not so much that it might be lost, but that it could fail to settle the issue. A narrow vote in favour of joining might not be taken as final. In the current configuration of British politics, a bare majority may not be enough. Having come close to prevailing, the Tories might choose to keep the question alive.

Britain could end up in the worst of all worlds - still deeply undecided about the sort of country it wants to be and unable to act effectively to shape the Europe that is developing around it. Britain will remain stuck on the mar gins of Europe so long as its politics are polarised as they are today. Electoral reform is a prerequisite of any durable settlement on the European issue.

But the necessary fundamental political realignment does not require proportional representation. It can be achieved by a much more modest change. The system recommended by Lord Jenkins's independent commission on the voting system was a hybrid of the Australian alternative vote with European-style PR so contrived and opaque in its workings that it would probably be rejected by voters in a referendum. Moreover, because it involves two tiers of MPs, thereby weakening the link with constituencies, it is unlikely to be acceptable to a majority in the Commons. As a result, PR is dead in the water for the foreseeable future. But that does not mean the voting system for the Commons should stay as it is.

The supplementary vote (SV) - used in the recent London mayoral election - gives voters the option of casting a second-preference vote. If no candidate wins 50% of first preferences, second preferences come into play. Even this, the most minimal form of the alternative vote, would transform British politics.

On reasonable projections, SV would greatly increase the number of Liberal Democrat MPs without significantly affecting Labour's position. The chief losers would be the Tories. For the Lib Dems the result would be to bring them within sight of becoming the second party in the land. SV would confront the Tories with the choice of becoming a minority party of disgruntled reactionaries or returning to the centre ground. Either way, it would bring about a new political configuration that allowed the European issue to be finally resolved.

Electoral reform does not guarantee any particular outcome for a referendum on Europe. Nor should it. It is in no way self-evident that the model of European integration on offer in Brussels meets Britain's needs - or those of an enlarged EU. But unless the government grasps the nettle of electoral reform, the clear danger is Britain's future in Europe will be decided by default.

 John Gray is professor of European thought at the London School of Economics comment@theguardian.com
fields.bodyText: A month ago, Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, sketched the shape of a more federal European Union. At the end of this month France takes over the EU presidency. Things are on the move in Europe. Yet Britain is stuck in a limbo. The government can neither commit itself to the Europe that is shaping up around the Franco-German axis nor act effectively to change it. The political deadlock on Britain's future in Europe is not the result of divisions in the government, real as they are. It is a consequence of the two-party system. It can only be broken by a change in the voting system at Westminster. First past the post can only result in a continuing stalemate. Labour's landslide has had some unexpected consequences. In the aftermath of the Tories' devastating defeat, William Hague has rebuilt his party around fear and loathing of Europe. By defining the Tories in anti-European terms, he has polarised British politics as never before. Ironically, one of the results of the Tory swing to nationalism has been to import a reactionary politics that is unpleasantly reminiscent of continental Europe. Hague's harping on the dangers posed by refugees is part of a larger strategy. His goal is to rally Tory supporters against Britain's "liberal establishment" - which in practice means setting his party against the largely liberal values of the British majority. British politics has been split between radically different views of the world. For Hague this can be seen as a success. But for the country as a whole it is a disaster. It is not that Hague has any prospect of winning a general election. Rather, the effect of the Tories' conversion to a reactionary politics of identity is to make a political settlement of the European issue impossible under the existing two-party system. Whenever it is held, it is a near-certainty that the next general election will result in a reduced Labour majority. It is unthinkable that a referendum on the euro could be held against that background. The danger is not so much that it might be lost, but that it could fail to settle the issue. A narrow vote in favour of joining might not be taken as final. In the current configuration of British politics, a bare majority may not be enough. Having come close to prevailing, the Tories might choose to keep the question alive. Britain could end up in the worst of all worlds - still deeply undecided about the sort of country it wants to be and unable to act effectively to shape the Europe that is developing around it. Britain will remain stuck on the mar gins of Europe so long as its politics are polarised as they are today. Electoral reform is a prerequisite of any durable settlement on the European issue. But the necessary fundamental political realignment does not require proportional representation. It can be achieved by a much more modest change. The system recommended by Lord Jenkins's independent commission on the voting system was a hybrid of the Australian alternative vote with European-style PR so contrived and opaque in its workings that it would probably be rejected by voters in a referendum. Moreover, because it involves two tiers of MPs, thereby weakening the link with constituencies, it is unlikely to be acceptable to a majority in the Commons. As a result, PR is dead in the water for the foreseeable future. But that does not mean the voting system for the Commons should stay as it is. The supplementary vote (SV) - used in the recent London mayoral election - gives voters the option of casting a second-preference vote. If no candidate wins 50% of first preferences, second preferences come into play. Even this, the most minimal form of the alternative vote, would transform British politics. On reasonable projections, SV would greatly increase the number of Liberal Democrat MPs without significantly affecting Labour's position. The chief losers would be the Tories. For the Lib Dems the result would be to bring them within sight of becoming the second party in the land. SV would confront the Tories with the choice of becoming a minority party of disgruntled reactionaries or returning to the centre ground. Either way, it would bring about a new political configuration that allowed the European issue to be finally resolved. Electoral reform does not guarantee any particular outcome for a referendum on Europe. Nor should it. It is in no way self-evident that the model of European integration on offer in Brussels meets Britain's needs - or those of an enlarged EU. But unless the government grasps the nettle of electoral reform, the clear danger is Britain's future in Europe will be decided by default.  John Gray is professor of European thought at the London School of Economics comment@theguardian.com

fields.trailText: Brigadier Stephen Saunders was the epitome of the kind of modern British soldier the army is trying to promote. Though his early career was conventional, he later took on a variety of exotic missions - including training foreign armies abroad.
fields.body:
Brigadier Stephen Saunders was the epitome of the kind of modern British soldier the army is trying to promote. Though his early career was conventional, he later took on a variety of exotic missions - including training foreign armies abroad.

In the early 1990s, he was on loan to the Zimbabwe national army (ZNA) which involved visits to Mozambique where the ZNA was helping government forces in the civil war with Renamo guerrillas.

His commanding officer at the time praised him for his "tact, firmness and professionalism". He added: "[Saunders] is endlessly patient and his sense of humour allows him to make his point firmly but in an acceptable manner".

Immediately before that, he was in Hong Kong, engaged in capturing illegal immigrants along the border with China as well as helping the government cope with refugees from Vietnam.

Brig Saunders was a military attache in Canberra and defence adviser in Papua New Guinea from 1993-96 at a time when British companies were providing the army with weapons.

The next year, he was appointed military assistant to the commander of the Iraq-Kuwait observer mission, where, as the Ministry of Defence put it yesterday, he "travelled throughout Iraq and frequently visited Baghdad for discussions with Saddam Hussein's regime".

Brig Saunders, 52, was commissioned into the Duke of Edinburgh's Royal Regiment in 1967 and served with his battalion in Berlin, Cyprus, Northern Ireland and Germany.

In 1993, he was elected a fellow of the Royal Geographical Society. As an undergraduate on army scholarship at Bristol university, where he studied geography and economics, he took part in one of the society's sponsored expeditions to the Hindu Kush in Afghanistan.

He was promoted to brigadier last year when he was appointed defence attache to Greece. He leaves a wife, Heather, and two daughters, Nicola 15, and Catherine, 14.

fields.trailText: The night before he was shot Brigadier Stephen Saunders attended a dinner in Athens hosted by the British ambassador, David Madden. Guests included Baroness Symons, the British defence procurement minister, and the Greek deputy defence minister.
fields.body:
The night before he was shot Brigadier Stephen Saunders attended a dinner in Athens hosted by the British ambassador, David Madden. Guests included Baroness Symons, the British defence procurement minister, and the Greek deputy defence minister.

There can be little doubt that they discussed the recent Greek decision to buy 60 Eurofighters, which are being made by a consortium including British Aerospace. The Greeks are still negotiating the details of a contract.

Greece, like its Nato ally but traditional enemy, Turkey, is a huge purchaser of arms. One of the tasks of a defence attache is to help promote the sales of British weapons. There are two sides to this: opening the doors to visiting British ministers and companies, and gathering early information about the type of military equipment the host country is after and identifying the key players to influence.

Defence attaches keep their ears open for any political or military information useful to Whitehall, including the MoD's defence intelligence staff.

Brigadier Saunders's role in Athens is likely to have included monitoring Greek military opinion on Nato's involvement in Kosovo, on Turkey, and negotiations over the divided island of Cyprus.

It is the task of MI6 station chiefs to monitor Greek political opinion and perceived terrorist threats though they liaise with defence attaches.

Defence attaches also have a high profile representational role, attending national days and receptions in uniform.

There are 116 defence attaches - who are appointed from all three armed services - serving in 73 missions abroad. Recently the government has asked them to take on another function: what it calls "defence diplomacy".

This includes training and giving advice to armed forces in the developing world, in the former Soviet Union and in the new democracies of eastern and central Europe.

Last year's strategic defence review said examples of defence diplomacy included soldiers building schools in Bosnia, helping to feed refugees in Africa, monitoring arms control agreements, and conducting joint military exercises.

A new MoD outreach programme included English language training programmes, the development of "democratically accountable, cost effective, armed forces", and military education. Defence attaches, says the MoD, should also have a "role to play as ambassadors for peace and security worldwide".

The new emphasis on defence diplomacy will provide important support for Britain's foreign and security policy objectives, using defence resources in constructive and imaginative ways, the MoD adds. "This, will put Britain in a strong position to make a real contribution to conflict prevention."

1975 Unknown attackers tried to firebomb the British consulate in Naples, a group calling themselves the "armed territorial squads" claimed responsibility. The fire bomb failed to explode

Murdered in the line of duty

1976 Ambassador to Ireland, Chris Ewert Biggs, killed in Dublin by an IRA car bomb

1979 Ambassador to the Netherlands, Sir Richard Sykes, killed in the Hague by an IRA car bomb

1984 Director of the British Council in Athens, Kenneth Whitty, assassinated in what is believed to have been an attack by the Abu Nidal Palestinian terrorist group. His killers are believed to have mistaken him for the MI6 officer in Athens from whom Whitty had bought a car.

1984 Diplomat Percy Norris killed in Bombay also by Abu Nidal

fields.trailText: There was no warning, no danger signal as Brigadier Stephen Saunders drove through the heat of the Athens rush hour. The British diplomat, in sunglasses and suit, had stopped at a set of traffic lights on a busy road three miles from the embassy when his assailants, on a motorbike, rode past on the driver's side of his white Rover. It was 7:50am.
fields.byline: Helena Smith in Athens and  Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
There was no warning, no danger signal as Brigadier Stephen Saunders drove through the heat of the Athens rush hour. The British diplomat, in sunglasses and suit, had stopped at a set of traffic lights on a busy road three miles from the embassy when his assailants, on a motorbike, rode past on the driver's side of his white Rover. It was 7:50am.

Seconds later, Brig Saunders was lying in a pool of blood - his hands, head and chest hit by the gunmen who had fired four shots, then sped away. He had become the 23rd victim of November 17.

Even before Brig Saunders had died in hospital, Greek officials were publicly announcing that he had been targeted by the notorious Marxist-Leninist group.

After one of its longest lulls in violence, the gang had emerged again, using its signature .45 calibre pistol. The other hallmark was the brazen nature of the assassination. The attack was carried out in broad daylight by gunmen acting in an almost nonchalant manner.

November 17, which is thought to operate as a series of independent cells, first appeared in 1975 upon the collapse of eight years of hated military rule in Greece. In the ensuing 25 years, and despite intense attempts to unravel its secrets, little is known about the organisation. No one knows who they are or how many they are, though the group is thought to be small. In 25 years, none of its members has been arrested.

What is known is that November 17 is named after the date in 1973 when the Greek military junta crushed a student uprising at the Athens polytechnic university. It is a group defined by what it is against, rather than by what it believes in. It is anti the Greek establishment, anti-Turkey, anti-Nato, anti-American and, by extension of that last category, anti-British. It is ultra nationalist: it wants US bases out of Greece, Greece out of Nato, and Turkey out of Cyprus.

The list of the group's victims is, in terrorist terms, impressive: a CIA station chief, Richard Welch, in 1975, a US navy captain and air force sergeant; two Turkish diplomats, two junta torturers and more than a dozen prominent Greeks including rich industrialists.

The site and method of yesterday's attack was almost identical to that of other November 17 killings, including a 1983 ambush that killed the US navy captain George Tsantes and his driver and the 1988 murder of the Greek publisher Alexandros Athanassiadis.

In 1998, November 17 took credit for a series of rocket attacks at foreign targets in the Athens area, including a branch of the US-based Citibank.

Although it never claimed responsibility for them, November 17 is suspected by Washington of conducting rocket attacks against US, Greek and other third-country interests during the Nato bombing campaign against Serbia in 1999.

No arrests

The targets included two offices of Pasok, the ruling Greek party, American, French and British-owned banks, and the Dutch embassy. A rocket attack on the German ambassador's home left extensive forensic evidence but no arrests were made.

Brig Saunders is the first Briton to be killed by November 17 but why was he targeted? Several theories circulated yesterday, many speculating that the "special relationship" between Britain and the US may have inspired the group's attentions.

Over the past year Britain has joined the US in providing Greece with counter-terrorism equipment and expertise, not least with the training members of its 300-strong anti-terrorism squad. This weekend is also the first anniversary of the end of the Nato bombing campaign against Yugoslavia, in which Britain played a central role. The government's support for sanctions against Serbia - November 17 has championed Belgrade's cause - were raised as a further possible motive.

Athens is widely seen as the most dangerous post in Europe for British diplomats, and staff at the Athens embassy are given security training before arriving. They are told to change their driving routes regularly and maintain vigilance.

Like the US embassy - which spends more on security in Athens than any other city - the British embassy is thought to invest highly in protecting its staff.

While admitting they have a "terrorist problem", Greek officials say they have an even bigger problem in countering it. In an interview with The Guardian, Michalis Chrysohoidis, the public order minister recently blamed widespread police ineptitude for the failure to root out terrorists.

"Until the collapse of the junta, being a policemen meant being an informant and as a result standards became very lax. Greece is very behind in counter-terrorism and what we are desperately trying to do is reorganise the police force in terms of its philosophy, culture and mentality."

All too often, international counter-terrorism officials say, Greek authorities are overly defensive about the issue, viewing outside help and criticism as an encroachment on the country's affairs. The resulting international wrangling has allowed November 17 to slip through the net. Last year the group taunted the authorities by inviting them to "come and get us". They did not, and Brig Saunders paid the price.

fields.standfirst:

fields.trailText: Greece condemned for lax response to 25 years of terrorism
fields.byline: Helena Smith  in Athens and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Scotland Yard anti-terrorist officers were preparing to fly to Athens last night as Greece was roundly condemned for failing to act against a small terrorist group suspected of killing a senior British diplomat in a ride-by shooting.

Brigadier Stephen Saunders was shot four times in the head, chest and hands by two helmeted assailants on a motorcycle who then disappeared among heavy traffic in central Athens. He died about three hours later in hospital.

Bullet cartridges found at the scene showed that it was the work of November 17, an urban guerrilla group that has acted with impunity since 1975.

It emerged last night that the Foreign Office had conducted a security review of British embassy staff in Athens in March.

Brig Saunder's car had normal Greek licence plates and no diplomatic insignia - a safety precaution taken by most Western embassies in Athens, police said.

Greece's Nato allies are fast losing patience with its failure to arrest members of November 17.

Athens police yesterday launched a manhunt, setting up roadblocks all over the capital and sending out scores of plainclothes officers to search for the attackers. But its response failed to quell criticism of the authorities' sluggish approach to November 17, none of whose members has been apprehended.

"The Greeks have got to get their act together," a Foreign Office source said last night, adding that four officers from the anti-terrorist branch would work with the Greek police.

"This highlights again that Greece needs to take a tougher stance against terrorism," said US Defence Department spokesman Ken Bacon.

A contrite Greek prime minister, Costas Simitis, telephoned Tony Blair and expressed his horror at the assassination.

"The Greek government will do its duty and defend with all means _ citizens' safety," Mr Simitis said in a statement.

The killing comes only three days after a US congressional commission on terrorism alleged that Greece was "the weakest link" in European counter-terrorism efforts.

The report urged that Greece, along with Pakistan, should be categorised as nations which were not cooperating fully with anti-terrorist efforts and said Greeks should no longer qualify for the US visa waiver programme under which most European Union nationals now travel to the US.

The US report caused outrage in the Greek press and was officially condemned by the Greek ambassador to Washington as "unacceptable" and by a government spokes- man in Athens as bearing "no relation to reality".

Yesterday, Greek foreign minister George Papandreou promised a "most merciless" response against suspected terrorists. "We will not let the international image of our country be plagued," he said.

In the past 25 years, there have been 146 attacks on American targets in Greece, an average of one every two months. Four US officials have died in that time. Of the 146 attacks, only one has been solved.

Britain's defence minister, Baroness Symons, who is in Athens on an official visit, said Brig Saunders was "an enormously valued member of the ambassador's staff. It is a tragedy that such a good man has had his life cut short."

Mr Blair told a cabinet meeting in London that Brig Saunders' death was "an act of terrorism. It was as contemptible as it was senseless, and will be condemned by all right minded people."

fields.headline: The best London gangster scene
fields.standfirst: Gangster no. 1
fields.trailText: Gangster no. 1
fields.body:
1968. Mayfair. Gangster (Paul Bettany) visits the plush townhouse of underworld boss Freddie Mays (David Thewlis). Three henchmen sit around the sunken lounge as Freddie enters. Gangster glances up. He speaks in voiceover.

"In he came. There he was in those handmade Italian leather shoes. Silk socks. The suit? Do me a favour - the man was class. Im-fucking-peccable. What a man. I mean a real man."

Freddie sits opposite Gangster.

"All right. How you doing?"

"Doing good."

"You want a drink?"

"Yeah."

"You look a bit scared, son. You scared?"

"Nah."

Trevor, one of Freddie's henchmen, starts sniggering.

"I hear you've been hanging around with Mad John. This incident last week, apparently you handled yourself quite well."

"Yeah."

Trevor sniggers again.

"Trevor heard that as well. Didn't you, Trev?"

"Yeah," replies Trevor.

"He thinks you're a bit of a laugh."

"Does he?"

"He's a bit of a wide boy, our Trev. Bit of an independent thinker..."

Freddie finishes his drink, then strolls up to Trevor.

"You see, when you work for me, you do things my way. There's no going out on your own... and there's no FUCKING INDEPENDENT THINKING."

Suddenly Freddie lunges forward, glassing Trevor over the head. Trevor falls to the floor, screaming . Freddie turns to Gangster.

"It appears we have a vacancy. You're in, son."

See also: Get Carter, The Long Good Friday, Performance

Don't see also: Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels

Gangster glances up. He speaks in voiceover. "In he came. There he was in those handmade Italian leather shoes. Silk socks. The suit? Do me a favour - the man was class. Im-fucking-peccable. What a man. I mean a real man." Freddie sits opposite Gangster. "All right. How you doing?" "Doing good." "You want a drink?" "Yeah." "You look a bit scared, son. You scared?" "Nah." Trevor, one of Freddie's henchmen, starts sniggering. "I hear you've been hanging around with Mad John. This incident last week, apparently you handled yourself quite well." "Yeah." Trevor sniggers again. "Trevor heard that as well. Didn't you, Trev?" "Yeah," replies Trevor. "He thinks you're a bit of a laugh." "Does he?" "He's a bit of a wide boy, our Trev. Bit of an independent thinker..." Freddie finishes his drink, then strolls up to Trevor. "You see, when you work for me, you do things my way. There's no going out on your own... and there's no FUCKING INDEPENDENT THINKING." Suddenly Freddie lunges forward, glassing Trevor over the head. Trevor falls to the floor, screaming . Freddie turns to Gangster. "It appears we have a vacancy. You're in, son."
