fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: The Cup | Animal Farm | Deep Blue Sea
fields.trailText: The Cup | Animal Farm | Deep Blue Sea
fields.body:
The Cup
Retail (£15.99)
Alliance Atlantis Cert PG
*****

Hollywood has had its say on Tibet in recent years. Now we have a Tibetan film directed by a lama and starring a cast of Buddhist monks. If you're thinking stern devotional art movie, nothing could be further from the truth. This is a hilarious Ealing comedy, Tibetan-style. Who knows if there's a Tibetan Alec Guinness fan club, but The Cup is far nearer the deftly-sketched character comedy set in a close community he used to star in than anything these islands have produced in years.

The story claims to be "inspired by true events". Two new recruits arrive at a monastery of exiled Tibetans in the Indian Himalayas. One, Orgyen, a tough, determined 14-year-old, is revealed to have a Ronaldo T-shirt on under his robes. "His head's shaved but he's not a monk," he explains to his colleague. It's the latter stages of the 1998 World Cup and Orgyen is determined to see as many matches as possible and to persuade the abbot Geko, a revered and distant figure, to let him hire a TV to let the monks see the final. ("You must pray for France," he tells a monk as they prepare to take on Italy. "Why, are they sick?").

Football - it's the new religion, you know - has roughly the same effect on this austere community as food did in Babette's Feast. The comedy comes from worried intermediaries' attempts to explain the World Cup to Geko ("Two civilised nations fighting over a ball?" he responds in bafflement) and Orgyen's methods of raising money to hire the TV, mainly through extortion. The film is as cynical about outsiders and authority as Ealing ever was too - the Indians as well as the Chinese.

Writer-director Khyentse Norbu marshals his cast admirably. There's no hint of "comedy acting": it's played in deadly seriousness and the result is delightful, including a final in which Orgyen's favourite player takes on his favourite team, France "the only country that loyally supports Tibet". Warmly nostalgic, too, for those of us whose money was on France.

Animal Farm
Retail and DVD (£19.99)
Mollin Cert PG
***

The advance of animatronics made a live action Animal Farm almost inevitable, and this video debut does a pretty good job with George Orwell's marvellous tale, which works with or without its political allegory. John Stephenson's film stays in period and is largely faithful to the book, published in 1945.

Pete Postlethwaite plays Farmer Jones and many animals have well-known voices - Kelsey Grammer (Snowball), Ian Holm (Squealer), Paul Scofield (Boxer), Patrick Stewart (Napoleon) and, unrecognisably, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, as Mollie, who has a voiceover role. Comically, it also keeps the class roles of the time - the only cockney is a rat, the hens are northern and the pigs positively Churchillian. Key scenes like the flight of Snowball are mostly well-handled, and of the film's innovations, a militaristic scene with drilled ranks of animals works well. Unfortunately, like Halas and Batchelor's striking 1955 cartoon version, it softens the ending, presumably to appease the sensibilities of younger viewers.

Deep Blue Sea
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Warner Cert 18
**

You used to know where you were with Hollywood sharks. They kept out of sight apart from the fins, occasionally surfaced to look mean and toothy in the style of Lee van Cleef, and ate the cast in reverse order of billing. But Renny Harlin's monsters here are half shark, half guided missile (they've been injected with human brain cells in Alzheimer research), can smash through steel doors and ignore cast-list etiquette.

The motley crew, who may or may not make it to the end credits, include Saffron Burrows (an ex-model, so obviously cast as a scientist), Stellan Skarsgard, breaking some more waves, and, unusually, two black actors - LL Cool J and Samuel L Jackson (or SL Very Cool J). Once the sharks have up-ended the floating laboratory, it's Jaws meets The Poseidon Adventure as "the smartest animals in the world" battle with the dullest script of the week.

fields.headline: Chow Yun-Fat
fields.trailText: What was the first film you saw?
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

Dracula (Christopher Lee and Peter Cushing) in Hong Kong.

What is your favourite film?

The Godfather. The acting, directing, story and lighting - the whole production is marvellous.

Last time you walked out?

I never do because I enjoy every type of film, drama, comedy, action, too much.

The last time you snogged?

It's unusual for Chinese to do that in a public place, especially during my life. I did give a thank you kiss to my wife for all her support at the premiere of Anna and the King in LA.

The last time you cried?

I'm a big boy now and, as I read in the LA Times, I'm the coolest man in the world. I only cry in front of the camera.

Most erotic scene?

Prison of Fire II when I dive from the dam into the water naked with another man. We had a good time, swimming up and down.

Which actor would you like to be?

Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, they are both powerful and express emotion very well. Also, Yul Brynner, he was great in The King and I and those cowboy films.

Which actress?

Jodie Foster for her beauty, charm and talent. I enjoyed every second during our scenes together.

If you were king, what would you change?

I'd destroy all nuclear weapons.

Any differences between Hollywood and Hong Kong film making?

The budget is limited in Asia and production moves at a very fast pace. Hollywood is more systematic.

Are you a better actor than Jackie Chan?

He's one of my idols, my action hero. We are in two different categories.

Anna and the King deals with Westerners adapting to Eastern culture. What do you think Westerners should learn from it?

I think Asians are more family and community orientated, and approach human relationships in a more philosophical way.

 Chow Yun-Fat stars in Anna and the King, out on video on Monday.

fields.headline: Martin's Momma mia
fields.trailText: The main character may be into cross-dressing, but the producers of Big Momma's House are more interested in cross-over - that is to say, will the predominantly white American cinema audience take to Martin Lawrence's new film about a black FBI man?
fields.body:
The main character may be into cross-dressing, but the producers of Big Momma's House are more interested in cross-over - that is to say, will the predominantly white American cinema audience take to Martin Lawrence's new film about a black FBI man?

The answer from the box office after the film opened last weekend would appear to be a resounding yes. A comedy about an FBI agent who goes undercover disguised as a large southern granny defied lukewarm reviews and took $26m at the box office over the weekend, only just behind Mission: Impossible 2, despite the fact that it was playing in 800 fewer cinemas. Dinosaur, Shanghai Noon and Gladiator made up the top five.

Comedic cross-dressing has worked happily from Some Like it Hot to Tootsie to Mrs Doubtfire, but the acceptability of black actors in comedies to white audiences and vice versa does not have quite such an established history.

The top television show for black viewers in the US, for instance, is The Parkers, a comedy about a black mother and daughter going to the same college. It features nowhere amongst white audiences. Equally, Friends and Frasier do not make it into the top 10 shows among black viewers, despite being huge hits with white audiences.

Eddie Murphy has long since crossed the gulf but Lawrence has a more varied CV, including brushes with the law, and until the last weekend it was not clear how far his new vehicle, driven by director Raja Gosnell, would travel. The fact that Lawrence performs in a fat suit just like Eddie Murphy's in The Nutty Professor will not bother any of the film's backers.

By chance, The Measure of a Man, Sidney Poitier's second volume of autobiography, finds itself in the best-selling book charts just as Martin Lawrence finds his movie in the best-selling film charts. When Poitier started acting in the 50s, a black person was not allowed to embrace a white person on screen, and it was only in 1957 that the Motion Picture Code was changed to permit this.

Many of the parts then available to a black actor were as a servant or a buffoon and Poitier reveals that he turned down a chance to act in the film version of Porgy and Bess because he felt it was insulting to black people. In The Defiant Ones, Poitier and Tony Curtis played escaped convicts chained together and Poitier's character gives up his chance of freedom to help the injured Curtis. When the film was first shown, Harlem audiences shouted at the screen and told Poitier to get back on that train.

Black people were shouting at the screen during Big Momma's House last week-end but it was with laughter as Lawrence slipped into something uncomfortable and spent most of the film in drag. So Lawrence, who was discovered on Star Search as a stand-up comic in 1987, could have a bigger hit on his hands than any of his previous films such as Blue Streak, Life or House Party.

"Racism is obviously a factor in Hollywood," said Denzel Washington at the Guardian interview at the National Film Theatre in March. "Where I think the most work needs to be done is behind the camera. That said, it's very difficult for women of any colour in Hollywood. The men get older and the women get younger and I think the bottom of the totem pole is African-American women or women of colour. They get the fewest opportunities."

Well, two of them get big opportunities in Big Momma's House. Nia Long, named one of People magazine's 50 most beautiful people (whatever that means), is Sherry, the love interest, and Ella Mitchell got to play the real Big Momma and to attend last week's opening bash at the House of Blues in Hollywood along with the black entertainment aristocracy of Will Smith, Magic Johnson, Carl Lewis, Laila Ali and Jermaine Jackson.

One genuinely exclusive piece of information I can pass on about the film: the sound of breaking wind is made by a greenish goo contained in a plastic carton, manufactured in Switzerland and, for those people who never quite outgrew the whoopee cushion, available in toy shops under the name of Wind Breaker. Rib-tickling fun is to be had using it in cinemas during dramatic or romantic moments.

Crossovers of a different kind seem to be happening on the stage. Following the translation of The Graduate from film to theatre, comes the musical stage version of The Full Monty which opened at the Old Globe theatre (not to be confused with the upstart new Globe theatre in England) in San Diego last weekend and is now thought likely to make it to Broadway.

As is now the way of everything from Colditz onwards, the gallant British heroes from Sheffield have been transmogrified into Americans from Buffalo, New York. The Gaz character, played by Robert Carlyle in the film, has been turned by playwright Terrence McNally into a bit of a homophobe who realises the error of his ways. That's the way they do it in LA.

webTitle: 'To talk about violence is to talk about the history of the world'

fields.headline: 'To talk about violence is to talk about the history of the world'
fields.standfirst:
Xan Brooks meets Bruce Reynolds, the mastermind behind the Great Train Robbery and consultant on Gangster No.1

More information on the film, including where it's showing
Win exclusive merchandise from the movie
fields.trailText: Xan Brooks meets Bruce Reynolds, the mastermind behind the Great Train Robbery and consultant on Gangster No.1
fields.body:
There's a scene stuck right at the start of the new British mobster movie Gangster No. 1 that plays as a bizarre mirror image of a scene from another, very different American movie. It's a scene in which a bunch of old-lag criminals relax around a table, watching a low-rent boxing match and reminiscing over days gone by. Whether consciously or not, the moment echoes the introductory scene from Woody Allen's 1984 comedy Broadway Danny Rose. Sure, one features a bunch of Borscht Belt Jewish comics and the other a crop of suited and booted criminals, but in tone, mood and sheer fly-on-the-wall authenticity, the scenes are cut from the same cloth, and cut - more importantly - by a tailor who knows what he's doing.

It's this very authenticity that marks Gangster No. 1 out from the crowd. Directed by Paul McGuigan, this is a very different breed of modern gangster picture: serious where the likes of Love, Honour and Obey and Rancid Aluminium opted for self-conscious gags, realistic where Lock, Stock was the stuff of lads' mags fantasies. Duff ending aside, it's a film that walks it like it talks it. All the little details ring true.

Credit for much of this must go to Bruce Reynolds, who served as a 'special consultant' on the project. Reynolds, a thief by trade, was the mastermind behind the Great Train Robbery of 1963 (for which he subsequently served 10 years of a 25-year sentence), and is a man intimately acquainted with the 1960s underworld that the film details. "Bruce's input was invaluable," says McGuigan. "His inside knowledge and sense of authenticity was a big help. He also worked with us on the language of the piece."

Reynolds is no stranger to the film world: he worked in a similar capacity on 1998's Great Train Robbery picture Buster. He is currently teaming up with his former partner in crime Ronnie Biggs to help develop a Great Train Robbery computer game. Even on the straight and narrow, crime still pays for 68-year-old Reynolds. He's one of a select band of former criminals ('Mad' Frankie Fraser and Dave Courtney in recent times, George Raft in days gone by) who have parleyed their former notoriety into a lucrative sideline in the entertainment industry. From con to consultant in one fell swoop.

Reynolds, not surprisingly, feels that this can only be a healthy development. "We're freeing ourselves from all that Victorian hypocrisy," he points out, smoking Silk Cut in a comfortable London office. "We're basically saying: 'these are the people who did these things. Maybe by giving them a voice, we can learn what the nature of their particular criminality is, and what the nature of criminality in general is'."

In person, certainly, Reynolds confounds the image of the stereotypical con. The man who enters the room is bespectacled, refined, delicately built - a white-haired Buster Keaton with a sarf London accent. He critiques Gangster No.1 like an Oxbridge intellectual (the direction, he says, is "very Nic Roeg-ish"), remarks that one of his favourite film-makers is Robert Bresson, and relates how he once enraged inmates while working in the prison library by screening Monte Hellman's radical art-house classic Two Lane Blacktop at his weekly film show. It's no surprise that on leaving school the man had his heart set on becoming a foreign correspondent and worked for several years (first as a messenger boy, then in the accounts department) at the Daily Mail.

But then Reynolds sits slightly at odds with the image of the archetypal hard man. His role in the Great Train Robbery (which he refers to as "a flawed masterpiece") was that of a Machiavelli - the brains and the ringleader of a crack band of experienced criminals.

"I fully own up to the fact that I was a professional thief," he says. "Maybe it's a question of semantics, but I was a part of what people refer to as a gang, [but] I refer to as a team. If you're a member of a gang, that makes you a gangster. From my point of view a thief is someone who steals the money without the confrontational aspect, whereas a gangster is using the threat of violence to extort money from people directly." He pauses to light another fag. "Now you might say that morally there's not a whole lot of difference, and I suppose there isn't really, but there's not a whole lot of difference between various methods of government either."

The one black mark against Reynolds, of course, remains the fact that Jack Mills, the engineer on the mail train, was severely beaten in the robbery and never entirely recovered from his injuries. "Yeah, we were guilty of using violence to achieve out ends but it was never part of our plan. So it shouldn't have happened, but it did happen. It's a personal regret."

Violence, needless to say, looms large throughout Gangster No. 1. "Inevitably you could argue that there's been a dumbing-down in cinema because of that," Reynolds says. "It's like Raymond Chandler says: 'When you get stuck with the plot, have someone come through the door with a gun'. You can't lose. But at the same time we're all fascinated about it. To talk about violence is to talk about the history of the world."

Reynolds describes Gangster No. 1 as a "slice of life, a Greek tragedy". He down-plays his own contribution and wryly points out that a lot of his suggestions were eventually rejected. "I would tell them things that didn't sound right to me - the fact that a getaway driver would get out of the van to join in the action, for instance. Now that would never have happened in my line of work. He stays where he is. He's your lifeline, to get you out of there. But who's to say that it wouldn't have happened at some point? People have their own individual ways of doing things." Even so, Reynolds feels that the end product is significantly more accurate a portrait of underworld Britain than, say, Guy Ritchie's debut. "What, Lock, Stock and Smoked Salmon?" he laughs. "I mean, I give it four out of five for entertainment value, but the hype machine got out of control and said it was the new Get Carter, when it manifestly wasn't."

These days Reynolds lives with his wife in Croydon, dabbles in journalism and reckons he's found a contentment that eluded him even when he was living off his ill-gotten gains in Mexico. He claims he fell into crime in the same way that kids fall into religious cults: because it offered a sense of order, duty and community. "You're taught the basic rules: to look after each other, not grass people up, help out those who are in trouble," he says. "Except that you later discover, as with all other systems, that there are people at the top who are abusing it for their own ends."

The Reynolds of today is at once a part of that realm and oddly removed from it. With one foot in the underworld and the other in the entertainment business, he is straddling two camps and ultimately has two systems working in his favour.

"We're freeing ourselves from all that Victorian hypocrisy," he points out, smoking Silk Cut in a comfortable London office. "We're basically saying: 'these are the people who did these things. Maybe by giving them a voice, we can learn what the nature of their particular criminality is, and what the nature of criminality in general is'." In person, certainly, Reynolds confounds the image of the stereotypical con. The man who enters the room is bespectacled, refined, delicately built - a white-haired Buster Keaton with a sarf London accent. He critiques Gangster No.1 like an Oxbridge intellectual (the direction, he says, is "very Nic Roeg-ish"), remarks that one of his favourite film-makers is Robert Bresson, and relates how he once enraged inmates while working in the prison library by screening Monte Hellman's radical art-house classic Two Lane Blacktop at his weekly film show. It's no surprise that on leaving school the man had his heart set on becoming a foreign correspondent and worked for several years (first as a messenger boy, then in the accounts department) at the Daily Mail. But then Reynolds sits slightly at odds with the image of the archetypal hard man. His role in the Great Train Robbery (which he refers to as "a flawed masterpiece") was that of a Machiavelli - the brains and the ringleader of a crack band of experienced criminals. "I fully own up to the fact that I was a professional thief," he says. "Maybe it's a question of semantics, but I was a part of what people refer to as a gang, [but] I refer to as a team. If you're a member of a gang, that makes you a gangster. From my point of view a thief is someone who steals the money without the confrontational aspect, whereas a gangster is using the threat of violence to extort money from people directly." He pauses to light another fag. "Now you might say that morally there's not a whole lot of difference, and I suppose there isn't really, but there's not a whole lot of difference between various methods of government either." The one black mark against Reynolds, of course, remains the fact that Jack Mills, the engineer on the mail train, was severely beaten in the robbery and never entirely recovered from his injuries. "Yeah, we were guilty of using violence to achieve out ends but it was never part of our plan. So it shouldn't have happened, but it did happen. It's a personal regret." Violence, needless to say, looms large throughout Gangster No. 1. "Inevitably you could argue that there's been a dumbing-down in cinema because of that," Reynolds says. "It's like Raymond Chandler says: 'When you get stuck with the plot, have someone come through the door with a gun'. You can't lose. But at the same time we're all fascinated about it. To talk about violence is to talk about the history of the world." Reynolds describes Gangster No. 1 as a "slice of life, a Greek tragedy". He down-plays his own contribution and wryly points out that a lot of his suggestions were eventually rejected. "I would tell them things that didn't sound right to me - the fact that a getaway driver would get out of the van to join in the action, for instance. Now that would never have happened in my line of work. He stays where he is. He's your lifeline, to get you out of there. But who's to say that it wouldn't have happened at some point? People have their own individual ways of doing things." Even so, Reynolds feels that the end product is significantly more accurate a portrait of underworld Britain than, say, Guy Ritchie's debut. "What, Lock, Stock and Smoked Salmon?" he laughs. "I mean, I give it four out of five for entertainment value, but the hype machine got out of control and said it was the new Get Carter, when it manifestly wasn't." These days Reynolds lives with his wife in Croydon, dabbles in journalism and reckons he's found a contentment that eluded him even when he was living off his ill-gotten gains in Mexico. He claims he fell into crime in the same way that kids fall into religious cults: because it offered a sense of order, duty and community. "You're taught the basic rules: to look after each other, not grass people up, help out those who are in trouble," he says. "Except that you later discover, as with all other systems, that there are people at the top who are abusing it for their own ends." The Reynolds of today is at once a part of that realm and oddly removed from it. With one foot in the underworld and the other in the entertainment business, he is straddling two camps and ultimately has two systems working in his favour.  More information on the film, including where it's showing  Win exclusive merchandise from the movie

webTitle: The woman who knew too much

fields.headline: The woman who knew too much
fields.standfirst: When Dublin crime reporter Veronica Guerin was murdered Hollywood scrambled to make her story. Now the first of those films, When the Sky Falls, is here
fields.trailText: When Dublin crime reporter Veronica Guerin was murdered Hollywood scrambled to make her story. Now the first of those films, When the Sky Falls, is here
fields.body:
When Dublin crime journalist Veronica Guerin and screenwriter Michael Sheridan began meeting at Cafe Java, near Dublin's O'Connell Street in July 1995, they were working on a film script - about a woman journalist fighting to expose Dublin's heroin underworld - that had no ending and no takers.

A year later the final scene was delivered in the best traditions of Dublin's black underworld. It was one o'clock in the afternoon and Guerin was stopped at a motorway traffic light. The horseman of the Apocalypse appeared riding a white 1,000cc Honda and wearing a black helmet. Five bullets were pumped into her red Opel car at close range in broad daylight. She couldn't have written it better herself.

Ireland's most famous crime writer, having survived two shootings, was finally taken out by the heroin hoods. No romance, no Bugsy Malones, no Al Capones - just bad, bad men. Hollywood was at her husband's door even as the funeral procession wove its way to the airport cemetery in Dublin's northern suburbs.

Disney, Warner Bros and Spielberg began sniffing around the story. Since then two books have been written, a movie has been made and an option remains on a second for Disney. "Jesus, Veronica has only been dead for seven weeks," said her friend Lise Hand at the time, when the speculation over who would play the female lead had already started.

In the period since her murder, the number of heroin addicts in Dublin has almost doubled to 13,000. Throughout 1995 and 1996, when Sheridan and Guerin met, she demystified the drug world to him, just as she was explaining it weekly to the readers of Ireland's Sunday Independent. It was inhabited by dangerous men, who the courts couldn't catch, but who were given pseudo-names by the newspaper, and then convicted every Sunday by Guerin.

They included Tosser, a killer who masturbated in front of female interrogation officers when he was brought in for questioning, Dutchy, who had his own special method of assassination and the Warehouse Man, who got into the business robbing cigarette warehouses but who would eventually order Guerin's execution. These were the people running a business that last month left six heroin addicts dead in a single day.

Guerin had been shot at twice and beaten up before her murder but, as well as selling a lot of newspapers, she was filling a large gap in a justice system which, until her death, was ignoring an epidemic.

The men who ran Dublin's drug underworld were, they believed, untouchable. They killed each other off, and the kids their heroin killed died in dark alleyways or bedsits in the wrong part of town. Guerin's thriller-killer series changed all that: it put heroin under the noses of the government and the police, and made Guerin - after just six years in the business - the most famous journalist in Ireland.

John Mackenzie's When the Sky Falls is a considerably more authentic portrait of the Dublin underworld than John Boorman's The General - still its best-known depiction. Boorman turned one of the most ruthless of Ireland's criminals, Martin Cahill, into a Jesse James with a brogue. The man who orchestrated some of the most daring robberies in Ireland was given a Van Morrison backing track and became a hero - a chubby chap who, in Boorman's movie, crept round posh Dublin houses with Pink Panther music playing in the background providing for his nine children and two wives. (Both sisters. Nice twist.) Forget the knee-cappings, the blowing up of an elderly forensic scientist who still lives with the agony in his legs.

In When the Sky Falls, there's no need to create a heroine. Whatever gave her the incredible drive she had (and the movie doesn't really explain it), she showed huge bravery in her pursuit of the men behind the heroin.

Fifteen years ago, when I skirted around the edge of the drug world in Dublin working for the Sunday Tribune, it was a much gentler place. The hoods were flattered by the attention from nice girls who worked from offices on St Stephen's Green, or the Independent on the Quays.

In the early 80s, the bad guys were yobs like "Dazzler" Dunne, in ill-fitting designer suits, spending their drugs money drinking Dom Perignon in the Leeson Street nightclubs. Most of them were either in prison or dead within a couple of years, leaving their wives and many children with double-glazed PVC conservatories at the back of their council houses, conservatories they filled with wicker furniture and where they would sit for hours telling you things like the Guinness family were killing far more people from sclerosis of the liver than ever got killed by heroin. I remember watching the grandfather of them all, old Bronco Dunne standing on the steps of Criminal Court 16 waving a silver-tipped walking stick in the air and shouting: "You think we're bad; wait until you see what's coming."

By the time Guerin started reporting, their successors were running multi-million pound drug empires, with impunity. The police, starved of resources, dealt with their frustration by scraping the heroin bosses' cars with their own keys. The men Guerin started to write about had an awful lot to lose.

In the early 80s Dazzler and the boys got their kicks taking their pals to nightclubs; the new men had higher aspirations. They moved out of the slums to the posh suburbs of north Dublin; to nice houses in leafy Kildare or along the sea at Howth. They lived in houses with real French windows - not extensions - and sent their kids to fancy schools while their wives tried to get in with the horsy set. Then along came that bitch Guerin telling the whole street who Dazzler was.

The feeding frenzy of publicity that followed her death ensured that Hollywood stepped in swiftly. The resulting film paints a true, brutal picture. There is the treachery of her main informer, who gets his kicks feeding her titbits he likes to read in the Sunday Independent - and then, when she goes too far, shoots her himself. He calls at her front door when she is alone, watching Manchester United on the television. He unscrews the porch light so she doesn't recognise that the man behind the balaclava is the same one that has sat in her car every Tuesday. A man who knows her well but still runs the barrel of a .45 pistol along her thigh before he lets rip.

The film-makers tried to get Winona Ryder and Jodie Foster, both of whom apparently expressed interest in playing the part of Guerin. In the end American actress Joan Allen took the role. It's a good performance: warm, funny and, in the end, one that makes you weep.

Guerin's death turned her into a national figure. Mary Robinson, the president of Ireland, held her son Cathal, then six years old, at the altar of the airport church in Dublin. The Taioseach joined the crowds paying their last respects at Stafford's Funeral Parlour on the Howth Road. The resulting pressure on the police and the government led to the first real crackdown on heroin for 15 years, when £15m worth of criminal assets were seized. Guerin has undoubtedly saved a lot of lives in the city that took hers.

Her grave in a quiet cemetery, lined with poplar trees just off the old Airport Road North, usually has at least one bunch of fresh flowers. The question that lingers is why she kept going, after being beaten up and shot. This film hints at the answer, but doesn't give it. Her newspaper encouraged her to keep going, claiming she was out of control but still allowing her to let her pen scrape along the bones of the most dangerous men in Ireland - great bloody copy.

But she was not a child. She was besotted with a job that turned her professional life from the dreariness of a second-rate book-keeper to the stardom of crime reporting. Every week, she led the Irish public on another little tour of her snake pit. The names of the General, the Coach, the Warehouse Man became part of some macabre soap, another week another episode.

She kept going, I believe, because she believed passionately that the drug barons should be taken on and because no one seriously considered that the Dublin underworld would begin executing journalists. Since her death the new Irish gangsters have gone international and moved to Holland where they continue to kill each other. Another Irish mobster was found dead last week in a bloody bedsit, and last month the charred and mutilated bodies of three others appeared in a £600-a-month flat in Scheveningen just outside the Hague.

Ireland's heroin addicts, at an average age of 23, are the youngest in Europe and there are twice as many of them than there were when she was buried by her husband and son under the poplar trees on the old airport road. But at least she tried to expose the awful heroin world that Ireland, its belly fat and purring like a Celtic tiger, was happy to ignore.

 When the Sky Falls is released next Friday.

The heist life
Ireland's underworld on screen:

The General

Rambunctious account of the criminal career of Dublin gangster Martin Cahill, aka The General, who netted some £40m in a lifelong commitment to professional thievery. Director John Boorman first came across Cahill when the latter broke into his house and stole the gold record Boorman had won for Duelling Banjos, the hit song from Deliverance.

Ordinary Decent Criminal

Another take on the Cahill story, with Kevin Spacey playing Robin Hood-esque villain Michael Lynch. Like Cahill, Lynch orchestrates elaborate jewel thefts and art heists, enjoys unconventional relationships with his wife and sister in law, and runs foul of the IRA. Directed by Thaddeus "December Bride" O'Sullivan.

Night Train

Elements of Cahill-style brutality filter through in John Lynch's dour tale of crooked accountant John Hurt on the run in Dublin's bedsit-land. Night Train's crime kingpin Billy (Lorcan Cranitch) is first seen inserting a drill into the kneecap of a hapless associate.

I Went Down

Brendan Gleeson, who played Cahill in The General, excels again in a gangster comedy scripted by Conor "The Weir" McPherson. The landscape here isn't the mean streets of Dublin but the rural roads of the south-west, through which Gleeson, as veteran gangster Bunny, has to accompany ex-con Git (Peter McDonald), paying off a debt by picking up a bag of money in Cork.

Waking Ned

Not so much a case of violent crime; more a dose of petty larceny. Kirk Jones's lottery-swindle comedy exploits rural eccentricity in its most soft-focus, sentimentalised form. The (fictional) setting is the tiny village of Tulaigh Mohr, aka Tully More, but the film was shot on the Isle of Man.

Angel

Neil Jordan's debut movie from 1982 treads the thin line that separates sectarian violence from more conventional crime in Troubles-era Belfast. Saxophonist Stephen Rea witnesses a double murder that's the by-product of a protection-racket dispute and finds himself paddling in murky paramilitary waters as he machine-guns his way through the team of killers. Produced by John Boorman.

 Andrew Pulver

fields.headline: Eye of the Beholder
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A real thriller takes more effort than a surreal thriller, and this one is boringly directed... with Ewan and Ashley phoning in their performances
fields.body: Ewan McGregor, that excellent and engaging actor, has made another worrying career choice with Eye of the Beholder, a surreal thriller based on Marc Behm's cult noir novel from 1980. He is a government surveillance operative known simply but very, very pretentiously as The Eye. The Eye conceives a long-lens obsession for a female criminal called Joanna, played by the oddly crotchety, schoolmarmy Ashley Judd, quite often to be glimpsed sloping about in her underwear. Is it really happening, or is it all illusion and fantasy, the hallucinatory enactment of some kind of universal voyeurism and sexual alienation? The answer is: we don't know and we don't give a monkey's. A real thriller takes more effort than a surreal thriller, and this one is boringly directed by Stephan Elliott, with Ewan and Ashley phoning in their performances.

fields.headline: Working girls
fields.standfirst: Fast, funny and independent - the "flappers" of the 1920s changed the rules for women on screen. Tom Dewe Matthews looks back
fields.trailText: Fast, funny and independent - the "flappers" of the 1920s changed the rules for women on screen. Tom Dewe Matthews looks back
fields.body:
The 1920s were roaring and youth was starting to flame. And dancing in the fire were the flappers, the "jazz babies" whose bodies were sleek, whose faces were painted and whose skirts were getting shorter, along with their hair. They were "fresh", they flirted and they were determined to kick over their mothers' traces because, as Gloria Swanson boasts in the 1924 movie Manhandled, "Modern girls do not sit by the fire and knit."

During the 20s, Hollywood films fanned those flames. They had to because the vast majority of the cinema audience was made up of young women. And because those young women for the first time had the chance to work, unlike their mothers. They could also afford to indulge themselves on their own terms, with money for fashion, make-up and going out to show themselves off. After centuries of servitude, these uncorseted, bob-haired free spirits were free to choose their own entertainment, sexual or otherwise.

In short, flappers had girl power. But Laura Mulvey of Birkbeck college, who is currently presenting a season of flapper films at National Film Theatre, thinks that 20s social attitudes changed not so much through women's freedom to purchase products or even select their own politics, but more through their chance to choose their own partners. "The competition that the new young women presented in the marketplace and the power they gained through the vote was nothing compared to the threat posed at the time by their interest in sexual choice."

Hollywood had to reflect that interest. They had to find a new female image of liberated sexuality and it couldn't be foreign, voluptuous and fatal like the sultry vamps of the previous decade, who were too exotic and self-conscious for the young girls flooding into cinemas on both sides of the Atlantic. The new image had to be tough and saucy, but also vivacious and good-natured. She had to be a flapper.

The woman who would epitomise this spirit was still a girl in 1923. That year, Clara Bow came to her first audition in Hollywood as a 16-year-old, without make-up and in her old clothes, but still ready to perform for the boorish Paramount chief, BP Schulberg. "Laugh," shouted Schulberg. She did, uproariously. "Stop laughing. Cry." Immediately, at the snap of a finger, a flood of tears drenched Bow's cheeks. "She's an emotional machine," Schulberg cried out in glee.

Bow wasn't quite that, but working women responded to her warmth, sense of abandon and unsophisticated sexuality. Bow's intentions were never veiled like Garbo or Jean Harlow's. Setting eyes on the male of her choice in It, the film that launched her, Bow puckers her brow and sticks her hip forward before setting off into action with the brief, admiring exclamation: "Hot socks!" Here, for the first time on the US screen, was a woman who not only knew about sex but openly showed she enjoyed it.

Clara Bow was far bigger than the other flapper film stars, Gloria Swanson, Marion Davies and Joan Crawford. Her fan mail ran to over 1,000 letters a day, some addressed simply to "The It Girl, Hollywood". Her fame reached beyond a name but the famous "It" that she embodied - the term created by the English novelist, Elinor Glyn - didn't just connote sex appeal. "He or she must be entirely unselfconscious," Glyn insisted, "and full of self-confidence and indifferent to the effect he or she is producing." In other words, "It" wasn't just a matter of looking sexy, but also having a sexy mind and an optimistic outlook.

Clara Bow had all of it by the cartload. She had pizazz. As the go-getting shopgirl who sets her cap at the boss in It, she shuts out a potential rival with the threat, "I'll soon take the snap out of her garters." But she also shows loyalty to female friends, claiming an illegitimate child as her own because, otherwise, the real unmarried mother would be shunned.

"Clara is prepared to be seen as an unmarried mother," says Laura Mulvey, "not only because she thinks her boyfriend's suspicions are vulgar beyond belief but also because she has to show solidarity with a friend. She shows she's a sensible working girl." No doubt working women would have respected that solidarity, but they would have identified even more closely with the roles Bow played and especially with the way their heroine had to make do.

Working girls in the audience would have noticed especially that Bow makes her own dress for the evening by cutting up an old frock and sticking odd bits and pieces on to it. "Those sort of off-the-peg fashions went to Europe where the flapper image had a huge impact," says Mulvey. "If you used paper patterns to copy movie stars' fashions, that meant you could stop looking like your mother and, perhaps even more importantly, stop following the fashion dictated by the aristocracy. So the idea that you could look like a movie star was an enormous liberation for young working women."

The new wave of female liberation, however, stirred up constant backlashes from the heartland, from churches and from Christian women and temperance groups. At the centre of the moral storm, the star, who had almost single-handedly democratised glamour, fought back against constrictions now being imposed by her studio. Bow refused to sign the morality clause inserted into her contract by Paramount - which insisted you couldn't behave "in any way which would bring the studio into disrepute." But scandal rocked her. "If she has 'IT' they get 'IT'," screamed a Hollywood tabloid, referring to her many lovers, who included Gary Cooper.

Also, she had been so overworked - she made 29 feature films in 1925-26 - that it was little wonder Schulberg referred to her as "Crisis-a-day-Clara". The films soon became stuck in Cinderella plots, in which Bow's shop girl flapped her way past snooty rivals into a millionaire's arms. By 1931, she was bored into submission and she left Hollywood, aged only 26. "All they were interested in was my box-office appeal," she later said. "I made them millions but I received nothing but a salary, untrained leading men, and any old story they fished out of wastebaskets."

Mulvey believes that cynicism played a big part in the plotting of Clara's movies, but adds: "What I don't think is cynical at all is the power and persona of Clara Bow on the screen. Her presence up there is incredibly important to the culture of the time because it was emblematic of what young, modern womanhood stood for - independence: living on your own, earning your own living and being prepared to put your friends before romance."

Maybe that kind of aspiration was possible in flapper films only because they were so revolutionary. After all, apart from computer-generated characters like Lara Croft, who is providing a role model for the flappers of tomorrow?

How to be a flapper

Tom Dewe Mathews gets the lowdown from Jenny Hammerton, senior cataloguer at Pathé:

Figure: You have to be shaped like rolled-up linoleum - straight up and and down, no curves, or that diamante-beaded dress won't drop straight from the shoulder. Don't forget girdles and corsetry had been abandoned by the 20s, so anything over B-cup and you'll have to bind that bust down.

Dress: The dress has to be tip-top, embroidered velvet or brocade with peek-a-boo slinky net sleeves, jewelled chiffon or the most sumptuous layer upon layer of beaded fabulousness. Don't forget that your dress should be designed to be seen in movement.

Accessories: Certain accoutrements are compulsory: a long cigarette holder obviously, but also a mascot - a lapdog, preferably, or a doll. The more smoking paraphernalia the better. Trinkets such as a cigarette dispenser in which you press a button and your cigarette comes out and lights itself are indispensable. Cigarettes can be secreted away in your garter but always in a case, never in the packet.

Gadgets: If you can't afford a car or don't have a beau who has a car and therefore have to walk to work, you need a "Button-up Rubber Stocking Protector" that hooks over the heel of your shoe and buttons up along the front. You can walk through muddy streets and when you arrive at the office you'll look as though you are rich enough to drive yourself to work.

Dance: "It": you have to have "It" of course, but if you show too much of "It" on the dance floor, then you need the "Buffer Belt" which you tie around your waist from where a series of ribbon-covered, flat-ended prongs stick out. That way your dance partner can't get too close. But don't forget, the Buffer Belt does not protect your rear.

fields.headline: 'I don't mind playing the little girl...'
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney meets the Catalan who has become one of France's most versatile actors
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney meets the Catalan who has become one of France's most versatile actors
fields.body:
They say Sergi Lopez is the new male sex symbol in European cinema, and the roles would seem to fit, up to a point. In the surprisingly non-raunchy Une Liaison Pornographique (An Intimate Affair, as the subtitle discreetly puts it), he plays a man who regularly meets a woman in a Paris hotel room to indulge some unspecified sexual peccadillo. A prominent still from the thriller Harry, A Friend Who Wishes You Well, recently in Cannes, has Lopez in the ultimate sensitive-macho pose - bare-chested and hirsute, gazing longingly at an egg (his rule is: one to be taken directly after sex).

Hunky, maybe, but creepy and not a little ridiculous - these are the parts that Lopez is making his speciality. Harry, in Dominik Moll's thriller, is an amiable maniac who attaches himself, like Mr Ripley, to a hapless young couple, then starts "solving" their domestic problems. In Britain, Lopez is best known for Western, a small but delectable comedy by Manuel Poirier, in which he plays a weary, jowly Lothario, a shoe salesman who ends up schlepping round Breton back roads with a Russian drifter.

This year was Lopez's second stint at Cannes, and the first time he has been there as a known face. But he's not yet jaded enough to just turn up and do the job. The words tumble out in French heavily laced with his Catalan accent and the odd comic sound effect, as he lights cigarette after cigarette, hands weaving in the air, heavy eyebrows flying up in shows of comic delight. Bulky but always on the verge of being carried aloft by his enthusiasm, Lopez seems the opposite of his sullenly chunky screen parts.

He grew up, and still lives, in a village 45km south of Barcelona. He kept re-taking years at school, and his father, who worked in the local Pirelli factory, didn't approve of his waywardness. Lopez recalls the day he announced he was going to act. "My father said, 'Make sure you're home by 10.' I came in at one. He was sitting there..." He crosses his arms, the statue of an angry patriarch. "His leg was shaking" - he demonstrates a furious St Vitus Dance - "which meant he was - wahhh! - set to explode! 'Where have you been?' I said, 'Look, I've just decided - I'm going to be an actor.' He was really - whpp!" - an invisible lid flies off. "His leg goes - hop!" - the leg flies up - "and he calms down. 'Acting? Fair enough. Go ahead.' "

Lopez went to Paris to the famous Lecoq stage school, with just enough French to pick up his room keys. Eventually he went to a casting session for a film, even though he'd never given cinema a second thought. The audition was for director Manuel Poirier, and they ended up making five films together, the fifth of which was Western.

Western is one of those rare films that appears to have just happened of its own accord - the right pair of actors (Lopez, and wispy, poker-faced Sacha Bourdo) just drifting from event to event. That's partly the result of Poirier's insistence on shooting chronologically. "Usually, it's 'OK, you've just done something we haven't shot yet, and you're going somewhere we haven't seen yet.' "

Surprisingly, hardly anything in Western was improvised. That's the point, says Lopez. "What you try and do when you act is make people think you're improvising - that there's no script, no direction, that you're just living it." All being well, this trick will come again in his sixth film with Poirier, recently shot in Peru, in which he has a small role as a pianist. "I've never played the piano in my life. I probably never will. But I play a pianist." He gives a big "go figure" shrug.

Harry... is a whole other story, where Lopez is expansive, hail-fellow-well-met, but a well-wisher to leave you feeling faintly ill. Dominik Moll originally offered him the role not of the killer, but the husband. "I said, 'OK, I could play the husband. Or the wife, or the girlfriend, or the little girl. I don't mind playing the little girl.' " He does a little mumble, in character as the director. 'Yeah, I don't know, er... what about Harry?' 'Oh, yes! Yes, please!' "

Harry works so well as a character because he's unsettlingly repellent, even while seeming a terribly, terribly nice man. "People often say I have a nice face," says Lopez. "I tend to play positive, well-balanced people. But just because you've got a nice face doesn't mean you can't play a villain. If you put your hand behind your back, you could be holding a knife or you could be holding a flower. The face doesn't change either way."

Lopez prefers to approach his characters on a need-to-know basis, and to hell with their back story. "Not interested. I don't like to knock myself out. It doesn't help me to have too much information in my head." This blank approach reaches an extreme in Une Affaire Pornographique, where Lopez simply plays "Him" to Nathalie Baye's "Her". Not only do we never learn what the couple get up to behind hotel doors, we never get the basic facts about their private lives either. They just simmer gently, no questions asked. Lopez has turned his own natural volume down close to zero. "The point was not to give him any distinguishing features. His main distinguishing feature is his accent - which happens to be my accent anyway."

Nor is he willing to speculate on the couple's fetish. "We thought, 'Should we decide among ourselves what they do, and then we'll know and no one else will?' Then we said, OK, I'll think of something but then if I tell you what it is, you might go, 'Oh, that's your fantasy? But I do it every Wednesday.' "

Currently stacking up high-profile projects in France and Spain, Lopez is new enough to the game to still be bemused by the attention. "When you come to a place like this," he says, gesturing round the hotel lobby, "everyone flatters you, and it's all a bit... surrealistic. You meet people from Brazil or Austria and you have no idea who they are, but they know you."

He gets a sense of its arbitrariness from his four-year-old daughter and two-year-old son, who once spotted their dad in the paper, and now keep pointing to photos of other men, convinced they are him. They also find pictures of women who they think are their mother - "and she's nothing to do with cinema, she does a normal nine-to-five job." As for the angry patriarch, his leg stopped shaking long ago. "He photocopies all the articles about me and goes round the village bars, showing them to his friends."

 Une Liaison Pornographique is released next Friday. Harry, A Friend Who Wishes You Well will be released here in November.

fields.headline: A girl's best friend
fields.standfirst: Julia Roberts's pal Rupert Everett is back as Madonna's chum
fields.trailText: Julia Roberts's pal Rupert Everett is back as Madonna's chum
fields.body:
Rupert Everett is in reckless mood. "Make me say something outrageous. I don't want to sound bland or boring," he calls after me as I leave his hotel suite. Having talked to me for over an hour from a horizontal position on his bed, he has grown sick of the sound of his own voice.

Everett is in London to promote his new film, The Next Best Thing, in which he plays another gay best friend, this time Madonna's. Since Hollywood likes to repeat an actor's success, he was cast on the strength of his performance in My Best Friend's Wedding, in which he played alongside Julia Roberts. This film, however, is significantly darker. The plot revolves around a one-night stand, a baby and a paternity lawsuit and Everett's involvement has been such that at one point he was also producing.

"But then I was fired because they wanted to control me," he says. I ask if his ego took a battering. "No," he shrugs. "You can't be too proud in show business. You have to always be prepared to stand down."

Everett doesn't go out of his way to make you like him, and it's an appealing trait. It's rare to meet an actor so comfortable with imperfection and so disarmingly frank. Part of him, he says, is "a huge, momentous, attention-grabbing opportunist" - which is what catapulted him into acting in the first place.

He enjoys complaining. "All actors like to complain as it's a way of letting off steam." And he doesn't mind being bored either, which is why he likes sitting round on film sets all day. He says he is lazy but has enough of the catholic upper-class upbringing (he was educated at Ampleforth) to prevent him sinking into sloth.

He'd like to be less selfish but it doesn't come naturally. "Living is quite difficult," he confesses. "You're constantly worrying about how to keep going and get on to the next step. Your career takes over and you close down and focus on yourself and your survival."

Friendship is important to him and he keeps in touch with the people from the troughs as well as the highs. Everett's career has progressed in fits and starts. The huge success of Another Country in the mid-80s thrust him into prominence. But after its successor, Dance With a Stranger, he lost his way in an ill-fated attempt to become a rock star and the famously dreadful rock 'n' roll movie Hearts of Fire, co-starring Bob Dylan. Britain turned nasty on him for a time and he retreated to Paris to lick his wounds.

His novels (most recently Hello Darling, Are You Working) have also been slated but he says people miss the point - they're meant to be trash. Besides, his writing skills are now in huge demand: he has two film scripts on the go. But he re-emerged splendidly in 1995 in The Madness of King George as a fat Prince of Wales. Suddenly, critics were won over again.

In the last three years, Everett's reputation has risen again following the success of My Best Friend's Wedding, in which he was famously written into the final scene when test audiences insisted he had a bigger bite of the cherry. Since then he has become one of the very few "out" gay actors in America. He doesn't particularly like being Hollywood's "token queer" because his sexuality has never been an issue for him, but now, if he's typecast, he says it's more for his Englishness than sexual orientation.

His films make big bucks. But he frowns at any suggestion that he's had superstar status bestowed on him: "I'm absolutely not that huge," he insists. While America can't get enough of him, he's not sure how he's regarded in Britain, or indeed whether he has ever got over earlier perceptions of him as a hooray Henry.

People tend to forget that Everett is also a fine and versatile stage actor. His portrayal of a "queen" with dementia in Tennessee Williams's The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Any More received widespread acclaim and, more recently, a performance of The Importance of Being Earnest in Paris had audiences queuing round the block.

But possibly the single film which has affected him most is And Quiet Flows the Don, which he filmed in Russia in 1991. During the 18 months of filming there were four deaths - on the first week the man running the wind machine (an old aeroplane propeller) was decapitated in front of his eyes. "It was such a harsh world but an amazing experience which made me realise how much complaining and whingeing I'd done all my life. I was 30 and it was good for me to be taken away from my London club scene of boys and sex."

Now 40, he says he feels more content with the past, and also more restless. For a year he has been planning to go with Oxfam to Africa but back-to-back filming has ruled out taking even a week out of schedule. The planned trip is part of a growing desire to do something more with his life. "I see my family getting older and then I see myself getting older and it makes me realise we're all future corpses," he says. "That thought colours everything for me at the moment."

He is modest about his skills as an actor too. "Rather in the same way that we as human beings have this pride in ourselves because we've decided we're modelled in the image of God, I think actors as artistes are a little bit jumped up as well because all we really are are artisans. It's actually much easier to do the job if you keep that at the back of your mind."

He has strong views on love and blames the way it's treated on the silver screen for people's false perceptions of relationships. "In my view, love in the cinema is far more dangerous than violence in the cinema because it's so idealistic and charged. It's rare to meet an actor so comfortable with imperfection and so disarmingly frank. Part of him, he says, is "a huge, momentous, attention-grabbing opportunist" - which is what catapulted him into acting in the first place. He enjoys complaining. fields.headline: The Barber of Siberia
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Surely a contender for the Most Boring Film Of All Time award... this is a very long haul with nothing to sustain you for the journey
fields.body:
Life is too short by a long way for Nikita Mikhalkov's three-and-a-quarter-hour The Barber of Siberia: surely a contender for the Most Boring Film Of All Time award. Richard Harris is an eccentric American inventor who journeys to 19th-century Moscow with his beautiful stepdaughter Jane (Julia Ormond) to promote a bizarre new machine which will cut down trees as easily as a barber cuts hair. Jane falls in love with a mercurial military cadet Andrei Tolstoy (Oleg Menshikov) and their affair, like the film, is calamitous.

Conceived at a time when Mikhalkov nursed ambitions to be President of Russia - he unblushingly awards himself a cameo as Tsar Alexander - this is a very long haul with nothing to sustain you for the journey.

fields.headline: Drive Me Crazy
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Chugs along reasonably enough, but lacks the brightness and flair that this genre often surprises us with
fields.body:
Another week, another US high school teen picture. This one is Drive Me Crazy, with the same Pygmalion-ish concept as She's the One: punky rebel Chase (Adrian Grenier), gets a preppy makeover from the clean-cut girl next door Nicole (Melissa Joan Hart - she of Sabrina the Teenage Witch) and they pretend to be an item to intrigue and attract respective target dates.

This does not have the raunchy emphasis on sex and virginity of American Pie, neither unfortunately does it have the witty literary spin of Clueless or Ten Things I Hate About You. (Oddly, one film it does resemble is American Beauty, with its nerd recording everything with a DV camera and a choreographed sequence at a school basketball game.) This film chugs along reasonably enough, but lacks the brightness and flair that this genre often surprises us with.

fields.headline: The Underground Orchestra
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Honigman's camera captures the voices and poetry of exile, a deeply compassionate and literate form of world cinema
fields.body:
The Underground Orchestra is an excellent documentary by the Dutch director Heddy Honigman, composed of interviews with street musicians on the Paris Metro, and snatched video footage of them plying their trade in carriages and on platforms.

Musicians from Venezuela, Algeria, Argentina, Iran, Romania and Africa produce some stunningly beautiful music and maintain their dignity and self-belief in extraordinarily tough conditions.

Honigman's camera captures the voices and poetry of exile, a deeply compassionate and literate form of world cinema. Were it not for the fact that wariness of exploitation is such a part of the film, it could have every possibility of expanding itself into a Buena Vista Social Club-type phenomenon.

fields.headline: Return To Me
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It might have been fun, but there's no spark between the two lovers... and Duchovny's presence is purest teak
fields.body:
Anyone who's seen David Duchovny express his gay yearnings for Larry Sanders will know he has a gift for expressing infatuation with comic lightness. Sadly, this gift entirely deserts him in Return To Me , a dull romantic comedy with David as a guy whose wife (Joely Richardson) tragically dies, her heart getting donated to young waitress Grace (Minnie Driver), and there's no prizes for guessing who she then happens to fall in love with. As Mr Harry Hill would say: "What are the chances of that?"

There is a touch of Sleepless in Seattle here, but David plays not merely an architect like Tom Hanks ,but someone who has an all-in-one "design and construction" business, so he gets to be brainy and wear the Village People helmet. It might have been fun, but there's no spark between the two lovers; the only decent performance (Richardson) is killed off in the first reel and Duchovny's presence is purest teak.

fields.headline: Sweet and Lowdown
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Another eccentric indulgence for the director, a minor work which does not feel as if The Master has lavished much on it, either in feeling or craftsmanship...
fields.body:
With the latest Woody Allen movie, Small Time Crooks, currently playing in American cinemas, the time has arrived for his second-latest, Sweet and Lowdown to be distributed here, one of Allen's fictional mocu-dramas about an imagined jazz-era musician called Emmet Ray (Sean Penn): drinker, womaniser and brilliant guitarist. The action is tricked out with the kind of authenticating furniture familiar from Zelig: talking-head contributions from experts, both spoof and real - Allen among them here - and their job is to keep telling us what a "genius" Ray was, how fascinating, how unreliable, and the succeeding dramatic scenes have an odd sort of corroborative function. But as Emmet Ray is fiction not fact, it is impossible not to become uncomfortable from the outset with our hero's un-earned legendary status.

Be that as it may, Sean Penn gives a very strong performance, with his signature flourishes of coiled anger and negligent sexual charisma. Indolent and predatory, his thin pencil moustache emphasising a seedy yet sinuous line to the mouth, Penn cruises around looking for women - always making it clear that his real caresses are reserved for his guitar.

One of the women who falls for his nervy, seductive banter is Hattie, who has been rendered mute by a youthful fever, and occasionally scribbles on a little pad, Holly Hunter-style; in this role, Samantha Morton won an Oscar nomination. With her roles in Under the Skin and Dreaming of Joseph Lees, Morton has unquestionably established herself as a brilliant screen actress and here she plays the smiling and nodding Hattie with unassuming charm. But Allen obviously does not conceive of any great or complex struggle within her muteness, nor any profound sense of communication stifled or transformed. At the risk of sounding churlish, the extravagant response to this role is at least partly a testament to the fact that impersonating a disability will always win Oscar plaudits - but Morton certainly endows this under-directed, under- written part with sweetness and vulnerability.

Woody Allen is the only film director in 2000 who would make a sentimental film about a jazz age musician, and contrive to make him a white musician. (Great American jazz guitarists of the period like Lonnie Johnson and Charlie Christian were black; Eddie Lang was born of Italian parents, but re-invented himself as "Blind Willie Dunn" in an emphatically black tradition.) Sweet and Lowdown is another eccentric indulgence for the director, a minor work which does not feel as if The Master has lavished much on it, either in feeling or craftsmanship, and everything in it - the music, the settings, the farcical comedy of love and loss - has been done better and more lovingly in his other films. It's entertaining, and his fan-base will enjoy it, but for the first time, it looks as if Woody Allen is beginning to treat us with something approaching negligence.

fields.headline: Gangster No 1
fields.standfirst: After wide-boy chic and lottery losers, at last there's a real British gangster movie that doesn't pull its punches, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Scorchingly violent, sinister, with a strange undertow of melodrama and self-loathing... This is a powerful and serious film
fields.body:
Gangster No 1

Can it really be true that a halfway decent new British film has been released? And one about gangsters as well, a genre which has exposed like no other the fatuity, cluelessness and onanism of our bright young British movie stars? Incredibly, yes it can. Just when the talentless lottery gangster film has pretty well become a contemporary cultural crisis, director Paul McGuigan comes along with Gangster No 1, a tough 60s-set thriller: plausible and sure-footed, a film with a canny yet appalled sense of the repulsive realities of crime and the unlovely, unfunny people involved in it. It is scorchingly violent, sinister, with a strange undertow of melodrama and self-loathing.

Malcolm McDowell is an ageing mobster and sociopathically nasty piece of work glimpsed first at a gruesome black-tie boxing event; he hears that an old business associate, one Freddie Mays, is to be released from prison after nearly 30 years. This leads to a long flashback of his and Freddie's early days in the bi-polar gangland of 60s London: the twin turfs of the East End and Soho. David Thewlis is the fastidious, dandyish Mays and Paul Bettany is McDowell's younger self, clean-cut, sinisterly handsome, turned out with fanatical care, and impressively resembling the young Michael Caine in his fiercely serious mode - checking out his reflection in the mirrors of tallboys and the backs of ashtrays.

"Gangster lean" is an evocative New York phrase noted by Susanna Moore in her novel In the Cut, meaning a special wiseguy way of leaning or lounging in a car; the principals and supporting cast alike are giving it plenty of lean here; the phrase came into my head watching them leaning in their clubs and bars, their Dolomites, Rovers and E-types.

Gangster No 1 has a strong sense of the geography and furnishings of this period: the occult markings of London transcribed by writers like Iain Sinclair and Jake Arnott. Freddie himself lives in an outrageously fancy 60s apartment - impressively reconstructed - in which he is wont to relax with a drink from the sideboard and Matt Monro on the turntable. But we are never invited to luxuriate in retro naff: what is important is shabbiness, and sadness.

Even people who profess to be gangster cognoscenti are sometimes vague about what real gangsters actually do on a day-by-day, hour-by-hour basis to get their money. (In his Adventures In The Screen Trade, William Goldman famously denounced "cute Mafia chieftains" in supposedly realistic dramas like The Godfather: "Try asking a major star to play a real Mafia head, a man who makes his living off whores and child pornography, heroin and blood.") There is some residual cuteness in Gangster No 1, but Paul McGuigan certainly jettisons the tiresome Lock, Stock sense that gangsters are adorable stand-up comedy merchants with the gift of the gab.

As the young gangster, Paul Bettany is an unpleasant inadequate: convulsed with envy for what he imagines is Mays' mastery of the good life, neurotically concerned with imitating his boss's snappy suits, and ferociously unpleasant to Mays' fiancée Karen (Saffron Burrows) - thus sublimating homoerotic impulses into weirdly impotent nastiness. All the bigotry and sheer ugliness of gangsterism that was airbrushed away in inanities like Love, Honour and Obey are here in abundance.

McGuigan's central scene is the young gangster's orgy of sadistic violence against a rival boss, meted out with an ironmonger's tools. No Tarantinoesque slant of comedy: it is just claustrophobic and disgusting. It is at these moments where Paul McGuigan appears persuasively to suggest that the gangster film works not as a type of action movie, or black comedy, but as a species of horror film.

Gangster No 1 is not for everyone; there is something in the world it conjures up - at once banal and excessive - which may not appeal. It consciously (and laudably) refuses the confectionery of comedy and farce, and it can be unsubtle. McDowell sneers at the camera: "What d'you take me for - a CUNT?" (the answer is yes, yes, a thousand times yes, incidentally) but that c-word at least shows a candid grasp of real gangster idiom primly avoided by, say, All Saints and David A Stewart.

Let's give thanks for a film that isn't just a bunch of actors who hang out with their cocaine dealers and think they know what criminals are like. This is a powerful and serious film, with shrewdly discovered London locations and interior sets constructed in Berlin's Babelsberg Studios: a miasma of hysteria and anxiety - a real addition to the British crime canon.

fields.headline: When the chips are down
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodges' Croupier was made in Britain and died in Britain: now, in the US, it has become a surprise cult hit
fields.trailText: Mike Hodges' Croupier was made in Britain and died in Britain: now, in the US, it has become a surprise cult hit
fields.body:
Mike Hodges is talking as though he were a character in one of his movies, though in a tone much more amiable than that employed by Michael Caine in Get Carter - or Clive Owen in Croupier. Croupier? You almost certainly will not have seen that one; made three years ago, a muted critical success and given tiny distribution, it never had a hope in the UK.

There's nothing unusual about homegrown films being pushed out by formulaic product from the US. But this is a rare case of a film abandoned at home and rescued in LA.

Even though the morally equivocal thriller falls outside the normal framework for the success of a British movie in the US - no twits, no costumes and no salt of the earth types triumphing over adversity - it has become a sleeper hit in America and is among the most successful independent films currently on release. "I'm hoping they will reconsider it in the UK," says 67-year-old Hodges, "but they would have to eat shit and people in this industry aren't used to doing that."

Croupier, which is showing in more than 20 theatres across the US - eight in the greater New York area and is returning to bigger screens in five or six more, is being treated as a new movie. "It's a film-maker's fairy tale. The reviews have been overwhelming but not one person here has contacted me," says Hodges at home in Dorset. "I'm not whining, but maybe they're ashamed."

The movie, commissioned by Channel 4's film arm and made for £3m, has Clive Owen as a struggling writer within whom attachment and detachment do battle when he takes a job in a London casino. "They really didn't like it," says Hodges. "David Aukin [then head of FilmFour] said when he saw it: 'The only thing I like about this film is the credits at the end.' I haven't spoken to him since. They didn't think there was a market for it. At least they were courteous enough to leave the film the way I made it."

Aukin, who says he is delighted by Croupier's success in America, does not quite agree with Hodges's recollections. "I had left Channel 4 at the time it was distributed here but I recall it had only a modest outing. It's easy to blame the distributor but the fact is the reviews, word of mouth, didn't bring in an audience. I did of course champion the film and am a great fan of the screenplay by Paul Mayersberg. It's fair to say I have mixed feelings about the final film but I'd be thrilled if the success of the film in the States encourages FilmFour to resdistribute it in the UK."

Paul Webster, who has Aukin's old job at FilmFour, agrees that Croupier represents a missed opportunity in the UK but says that it cannot be rereleased. "I'm not hiding behind anything but all this went down before I joined FilmFour," he says. "To rerelease a movie in this densely crowded, exhibitor driven market would be tantamount to impossible. I like the movie a lot. Yes, I think it could have been platformed more aggressively but it's thrilling that Mike Hodges has now got his just desserts."

"The new management weren't interested at all," said Hodges. "They put it in Berlin's film market, which is like putting it in the morgue. I don't think distributors were even aware that it existed."

The BFI was reissuing Get Carter and Hodges suggested that it might also distribute Croupier. "It got incredibly good reviews but it didn't help that they didn't have a trailer or a poster and there were only two prints. It had absolutely no chance." Croupier might have gone the way of other Hodges projects such as 1991's Black Rainbow (straight to cable TV) or the IRA story from 1987, A Prayer for the Dying (chopped about by the Goldwyn Company). Then it was shown at a Hodges retrospective in LA and Michael Kaplan, a movie marketing strategist who has worked with films by Kubrick and Altman, drew it to the attention of the Shooting Gallery, a distributor based in Manhattan. It made more than $500,000 in its first month on release.

Meanwhile, Hodges is in Dorset working on treatments of the Thomas Mann story Mario and the Magician and a script of his own, Grist. And when might either of these go into production? "Oh, please. Just look at my CV. It's got holes in it like a Swiss cheese."

webTitle: Apocalyptic fundamentalists set to shove Harry Potter aside

fields.headline: Apocalyptic fundamentalists set to shove Harry Potter aside
fields.trailText: Move over Harry Potter. Forget John Grisham. Meet instead the two Christian fundamentalist science fiction novelists who are confidently expected to surge to the top of the US fiction bestsellers lists within days of the official publication of their new book.
fields.body:
Move over Harry Potter. Forget John Grisham. Meet instead the two Christian fundamentalist science fiction novelists who are confidently expected to surge to the top of the US fiction bestsellers lists within days of the official publication of their new book.

Tim LaHaye and Jerry Jenkins are an unlikely pair of blockbuster fiction writers. Mr LaHaye is a soft-spoken 74-year-old Christian evangelical minister from California and Mr Jenkins, 50, is a jobbing professional writer.

Yet the pair's latest novel, seventh instalment in the Left Behind series which they first started writing in 1995, topped Amazon.com's bestseller list in April based on advance orders alone, and on Sunday it is expected to move straight to first place in the coveted New York Times fiction bestseller list, an unparalleled achievement for a genre novel of this kind.

The new book, The Indwelling: The Beast Takes Possession, combines science fiction with an apocalyptic fundamentalism of which Americans seemingly cannot get enough.

The conservative slant of the two authors is underscored by the fact that the villain of the new book, an incarnation of the Antichrist, turns out to be a former secretary general of the United Nations, an organisation which many American conservatives believe is at the centre of an international conspiracy to overthrow the US constitution and establish a world government which would ban the private ownership of firearms and establish a global single currency.

In the new novel, the hero of the series, Rayford Steele, falls under suspicion of assassinating the Antichrist. Another hero is a converted Jew, who has accepted Christ as the messiah. Mr LaHaye is among many conservative fundamentalists who insist that Jews must be converted to Christianity as part of the millenarian process.

The Left Behind series has sold 17m copies in the US over the past five years, only about 3m fewer than the total American sales of JK Rowling's Harry Potter series, which have commanded the charts on both sides of the Atlantic for most of the past year.

The Indwelling has already sold 1.9m copies and the specialist Christian publishers, Tyndale House, has had to built new warehouses at its printworks in Illinois to cope with demand.

The success of the new book is all the more remarkable because many publishers and trade specialists had assumed that the success of the earlier novels in the series had been part of conservative America's mounting excitement over the approach of the millennium, when some enthusiasts believed that the world would end and the kingdom of Christ - US style - would be ushered in.

Yet the anticlimax of the start of the new millennium has done nothing to dampen enthusiasm for the series.

In interviews, Mr LaHaye appears to be the more driven member of the successful duo, saying that the books' message "is the greatest message of hope in the world".

Mr Jenkins, by contrast, seems more worldly. "There are some times when I think I was born for this project," he said recently. "Other times I think I was born to play golf."
