webTitle: Impassioned voice of Roman woman poet to be heard after 2,000 years

fields.headline: Impassioned voice of Roman woman poet to be heard after 2,000 years
fields.trailText: A virtually undiscovered poet, her work long buried among a man's less talented verses, will next month make her debut in English letters in her own right.
fields.body:
A virtually undiscovered poet, her work long buried among a man's less talented verses, will next month make her debut in English letters in her own right.

Take a bow, Sulpicia. The recognition has come slightly late for her. Yet her voice is unmistakably modern: direct, impassioned and unstaunchably erotic as she tries to talk her lover into bed:

Let each of us be bound with a tight bond

No future day shall break. The young man wishes

The same things I do, but doesn't want to

Blurt it out too openly.

And she berates her uncle Messala for coming between them.

Messala is much better known than his niece. GCSE students will recognise him as the character in Julius Caesar who tells Brutus of Cassius's death.

Even in Shakespeare's time, he was antique. He fought at the battle of Philippi in 42BC, surviving to become a literary patron in the reign of the emperor Augustus.

Sulpicia's poems have lain almost hidden to a general readership for more than 2,000 years. Now they are to be published together, for the first time in Britain, as the only works by a woman to have survived from all the literature of ancient Rome.

She was born before Jesus Christ, in the same generation and private literary circle as male poets Ovid, Catullus, Horace whose names lived down the ages.

No known image or biography of her exists. All we have is her father's first name, Servius. She is known only through eight love elegies incorporated, without definite attribution, in four volumes left by a male elegiac poet from her circle, Tibullus. Six poems are now regarded as hers and two more as possibles.

The 19th century German and English scholars who established the texts of classical literature "thought Tibullus wrote them for her", John Heath-Stubbs, the English classical poet who has done the new translation, said yesterday.

"They knew little, one feels, about women. They were reluctant to believe that any woman could - or should - write poems as passionately outspoken as these are," he said. "They would have preferred her to be cosy like Elizabeth Barrett Browning."

These were the years, Heath-Stubbs added, in which inhibited dons insisted the Greek lesbian poet Sappho "was simply the headmistress of a select finishing school for well-connected young ladies on the isle of Lesbos".

Even so, the 19th century German scholar CG Heyne called Sulpicia's fragments within the Tibullus "a marvel - the most beautiful relic of the whole of Latinity". Another, Emil Bahrens, noted the difference in style from Tibullus, concluding the sections "could only have been written by a poet of the first rank".

Tibullus's reputation waned, with only two British translations of his work in the 20th century. But Sulpicia's star has begun to rise, with most scholars and classical societies accepting that her poems are separate and distinctive.

"It's wonderful stuff," Denis Feeney, tutor in classical language and literature at New College, Oxford, said yesterday. "People are always very surprised and knocked back to find that there is somebody writing as she does, although she still gets scooped into modern editions of Tibullus. The more general readers she gets, the better."

Oliver Lyne, professor of classical languages and literature at Oxford, said: "The poems which we most plausibly attribute to her are very affecting and, I think, convincing. More and more people are writing about her."

In the new volume, to be published on July 1, Heath-Stubbs has included one poem which he is convinced was written either by Sulpicia or by Ovid. In it, she imagines interrupting a wild boar hunt, a distraction of her Greek lover, Cerinthus:

I'd lain in your arms beside the tackle,

Then let the boar come up to the nets indeed -

He can go scot-free if he doesn't disturb our lovemaking.

But without me, forget about sex.

The new book leaves one paradox unsolved. A century after Sulpicia, the Roman author Martial praised a woman of that name and period as having been a model, docile wife.

"There may therefore have been two Sulpicias", Heath-Stubbs writes in his preface. "Or - a rather depressing thought - Tibullus's friend may have dwindled into respectability in her later years."

Love has come at last. The very idea

That I'd hide it makes me more ashamed

Than openly confessing. Won over

By my Muse's supplication, Cythera's Goddess

Has brought him to me, placed him in my arms.

What Venus promised, she has fulfilled.

Let them tattle who have missed their chance.

I'll not entrust the news to a sealed letter

That none may read of it before my lover does.

I loathe to wear a mask in deference

To what the world may say. Let everyone hear

That we have come together - each of us

Deserving the other.

Sulpicia

 Poems of Sulpicia. Hearing Eye, 99 Torriano Avenue, London NW5 2RX (£6 plus postage).

fields.headline: Whispers of Betrayal by Michael Dobbs
fields.standfirst:
(HarperCollins, £9.99) Digested in the style of the original by John Crace
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: "Bugger Britain," said Colonel Peter Amadeus, the country's bravest man. "Bugger the government desk jockeys who've put me and other heroes on civvy street. I'm going to write a letter to the Daily Telegraph."
fields.body:
"Bugger Britain," said Colonel Peter Amadeus, the country's bravest man. "Bugger the government desk jockeys who've put me and other heroes on civvy street. I'm going to write a letter to the Daily Telegraph."

Tom Goodfellowe MP missed a Commons vote. "What are we going to do with you?" said the chief whip sadly. "A ministerial position?"

"Right," said Amadeus to Mary Wetherell, Andrew McKenzie, Albert Scully and Freddie Payne, his four trusted military discards. "The government has ignored my letter. From now on, as Clausewitz might say, it's war."

"Aaagh," said Jonathan Bendall, the PM who bore absolutely no resemblance to Tony Blair, as the taps at No 10 poured out a horrid orange liquid. "This is a national emergency. I want the best team on it. Recommend anyone, chief whip?" Tom Goodfellowe? "Bit of a maverick. Call him in."

The atmosphere in the Cabinet Office Briefing Room, codenamed Cobra, was muted. The water outrage had been followed by a 12-hour telephone outrage where all 0207 numbers had been misrouted. The finest political and anti-terrorist brains were stumped. All they had to go on was a misspelt letter.

"You could try looking at who made money when the water shares slumped temporarily," Goodfellowe chipped in. Ten seconds later, Payne was arrested.

"It's time, as Clausewitz might say, to remember that war is not an isolated act," said Amadeus. For no obvious reason, Amadeus and his three remaining trusted rejects decided to blow up Battersea power station's chimneys. By coincidence, anti-terrorist officers were there at the same moment. Scully, who had lost a leg in Bosnia, was caught by a marksman.

Later, Col Abel Gittings was caught in bed with his mistress after an anonymous tip-off. "Sounds like the work of a woman," Goodfellowe suggested at the Cobra meeting. Then police stormed Wetherell and McKenzie's flat. "That's the lot," said the PM. "Good work, Tom. Expect promotion."

"We've got a problem," said the press secretary, who bore no resemblance to Alastair Campbell. "We've had an ultimatum. Either you resign or the City gets it." "You idiot, Tom," said the PM. "Your job's on the line." Goodfellowe then recalled his old friend Peter Amadeus was dyslexic. It's him, he thought. "Don't do it," said Goodfellowe. "OK," said Amadeus.

And if you really are pressed - the digested read, digested: Old-fashioned values take on New Labour cynicism? You might think that, I couldn't possibly comment

webTitle: Scientists launch telling debate on CJD

fields.headline: Scientists launch telling debate on CJD
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Scientists are preparing to launch a national debate on whether people infected with the human form of BSE without their knowledge should be told they have the incurable disease.
fields.body:
Scientists are preparing to launch a national debate on whether people infected with the human form of BSE without their knowledge should be told they have the incurable disease.

Government advisers say ethical decisions will have to be made before the introduction of blood tests which may detect signs of the fatal condition before victims display symptoms.

Counsellors have helped some women who wished to be told whether surgical instruments used in caesarian operations had been used on a mother who developed variant CJD, as the condition is known. So far 60 people are believed to have died and 11 others probably have the disease.

Tests are considered a high priority for people such as potential blood donors. Early evidence of the disease, for which cures are far away, would have a devastating impact on families as well as having legal and employment consequences.

fields.headline: Drugs case errors condemned
fields.standfirst:
Customs may be stripped of its power to prosecute after two cleared

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Customs and excise could be stripped of its power to prosecute after the official inquiry report into the collapse of Britain's biggest drugs case uncovered a litany of incompetence and chaos that led to "two of Britain's biggest gangsters" walking free.
fields.body:
Customs and excise could be stripped of its power to prosecute after the official inquiry report into the collapse of Britain's biggest drugs case uncovered a litany of incompetence and chaos that led to "two of Britain's biggest gangsters" walking free.

Although the retired judge, Gerald Butler, who carried out the inquiry, said that almost everybody involved had some input into what went wrong, his recommendations made clear that the judge who threw out the case against both men had been mistaken.

His report cleared the customs officers involved of accusations that they acted illegally in their undercover bugging operations, faked evidence or lied under oath in court.

But the report, published yesterday, identified incompetence in the customs prosecution, and said the official authority for their bugging operations were based on "hopelessly defective documentation" and that the records on all their bugging operations at the time were chaotic.

The collapse of the case left the taxpayer with a £50m bill. Brian Doran, a Glasgwegian with a degree in Latin American studies, known as "the professor" and his lieutenant, Kenneth Togher, were cleared of smuggling £34m worth of cocaine into Britain.

At the time of their arrest in 1995, customs hailed their spectacular raid on the yacht, The Frugal, at Pevensey Bay, East Sussex, as part of Operation Stealer, as "the best knock ever".

The two ringleaders were jailed for 24 years each.

But the case turned sour when the appeal court judge, Mr Justice Turner, threw it out on the grounds that the prosecution had wrongly withheld the information that the suspects' hotel rooms had been bugged without official authority.

fields.headline: Loyalist parade rerouted
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The parades commission has ordered a major loyalist parade to be rerouted away from Catholic areas of north Belfast next week. About 2,000 Orangemen and bands are due to take part in the Tour of the North march on Friday, marking the start of the marching season in the city.
fields.body:
The parades commission has ordered a major loyalist parade to be rerouted away from Catholic areas of north Belfast next week. About 2,000 Orangemen and bands are due to take part in the Tour of the North march on Friday, marking the start of the marching season in the city.

Restricting the march, which takes place every two years, the Northern Ireland parades commission noted "the very serious civil disturbances" which accompanied it in 1996, "with violent confrontation, extensive damage to property and serious intimidation causing sustained damage to community relations". Similar restrictions were imposed in 1998.

It heard evidence from Protestants, who described "feelings of isolation and vulnerability" and regarded the parade as an opportunity to celebrate their identity. However, nationalists said allowing the parade to enter contested areas "would be an expression of sectarian triumphalism".

fields.headline: Farmer cleared after shooting poacher
fields.trailText: A farmer who shot an intruder on his land walked free from court yesterday after Judge Jonathan Teare directed a jury at Lincoln crown court to clear him of unlawful wounding.
fields.body:
A farmer who shot an intruder on his land walked free from court yesterday after Judge Jonathan Teare directed a jury at Lincoln crown court to clear him of unlawful wounding.

Brian Ward, 48, of Louth, Lincolnshire, fired a shot that shattered the hand of Nicky Westerman, 18, one of a group of five poachers who had woken him at night.

The farmer said he had simply fired a warning shot across the darkened field and had no idea the man was in his range.

The acquittal follows the controversy over the trial of Norfolk farmer Tony Martin, who was jailed for life for shooting dead a 16-year-old burglar at his farm.

Judge Teare said Mr Ward's behaviour was "extremely stupid" but accepted he did not know the teenager was present.

Unlawful wounding normally carries a jail sentence but the judge said Mr Ward could not have predicted what happened.

fields.headline: Minister admits GM crop failings
fields.standfirst:
Parliament: special report
GM debate: special report
fields.trailText: Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, last night apologised to MPs for failing to tell Scottish and Welsh ministers about the illegal commercial planting of GM contaminated rape seed, as a row broke out in Parliament over the disclosure that Whitehall tried to cover up the scandal.
fields.byline: David Hencke, Patrick Wintour and James Meikle
fields.body:
Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, last night apologised to MPs for failing to tell Scottish and Welsh ministers about the illegal commercial planting of GM contaminated rape seed, as a row broke out in Parliament over the disclosure that Whitehall tried to cover up the scandal.

The minister was pushed on to the defensive as the Tory agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo, accused him of "dither, confusion and panic" over the scandal. Advanta Seeds faces having to pay out huge compensation to farmers who sowed the contaminated crops.

The debate was made more dramatic by the announcement of an emergency EU payment package which will allow farmers who rip up the crops still to get subsidies from Brussels.

The deal was being negotiated as Mr Brown was trying to head off allegations from the firm that it had been initially told by officials at the Department of Environment and Ministry of Agriculture "not to worry" about it and was advised not to tell anybody about it until Whitehall had conducted its own tests.

It was also revealed yesterday that Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister formally responsible for overall government policy on GM issues, was kept in the dark for six weeks by the Ministry of Agriculture over the unlawful spread of GM into crops.

Cabinet office sources said the Ministry of Agriculture had not only failed to inform the agriculture departments in Scotland and Wales, but also failed to keep Ms Mowlam abreast of developments.

One Cabinet Office source said: "It is extraordinary and calls into question whether we really are co-ordinating this policy, or letting agriculture carry on in its old secret ways."

Opening the debate, Mr Yeo said Advanta had told him that they would have liked to warn their customers about the contaminated oilseed rape.

"The only reason they did not do so is that they were asked by Ministry of Agriculture officials to keep the whole matter secret," he said.

Mr Yeo said: "When Advanta went to the government to make a clean breast of their blunder, they were asked not to say a word about it to anyone else.

"It was the Ministry of Agriculture's advice to Advanta and nothing else which ensured farmers were kept in the dark...and allowed farmers to go on planting GM seeds in Britain after April 17." Mr Brown intervened, insisting: "There is a clear obligation on Advanta to tell their customers that they had sold them a defective product as soon as they knew they had done so. They had no advice from government not to tell their customers what had happened."

Mr Yeo accused agriculture ministers of "dither, confusion and panic" as he questioned why it had taken the ministry four weeks to make public news of the contamination of conventional seeds.

It also emerged that the government is reconsidering the size of buffer zones between GM and organic or conventional crops after the contaminated seeds fiasco.

Separation distances of up to 600 metres are at present used under voluntary guidelines drawn up by the biotech industry but critics say these are not nearly enough, given the potential for GM pollen to travel on the wind or bees.

Ministers have ordered scientists to review the current arrangements and are consulting farmers and all parties involved in GM issues whether further "more onerous" safeguards are needed. They also want to know what minimum levels of GM content in non-GM crops can "realistically be aimed for".

webTitle: US and Egypt split on fatal plane crash

fields.headline: US and Egypt split on fatal plane crash
fields.standfirst:
Suicidal pilot brought down flight 990 killing 217 people, insist NTSB sources, not a mechanical fault in the plane

EgyptAir flight 990 crash: special report
fields.trailText: American investigators of a plane crash that killed 217 people last year are wrapping up their inquiry and may approve their conclusions without public hearings for fear of exacerbating strained relations with Egypt.
fields.body:
American investigators of a plane crash that killed 217 people last year are wrapping up their inquiry and may approve their conclusions without public hearings for fear of exacerbating strained relations with Egypt.

According to the New York Times, experts at the National Transportation Safety Board are more convinced than ever that a suicidal pilot caused the crash of EgyptAir 990 after it left New York last October.

But the Egyptian government is pressing the theory that the plane, a Boeing 767, developed a mechanical fault in its tail.

According to the paper, some of the US investigators are frustrated that the inquiry, which the Egyptian government delegated to the US, has not been completed. One said that in investigations of domestic crashes, each party has a "constituency" because each represents the airline, or the plane manufacturer, but, he added, "usually you want to solve it".

The investigators still believe that the words of the plane's 59-year-old co-pilot on the cockpit voice recorder were those of a man saying a farewell prayer. As the aircraft was heading for the Atlantic, 50 miles off Nantucket Island, Gamil al-Batouti said: "Tawakilt ala Allah" or "I put my faith in God". Then the captain, Ahmed al-Habashi, who is thought to have left the cockpit, returned to say "pull up" or "help me".

Egyptians say that the Americans misunderstood the co-pilot's words, a Muslim prayer. "This prayer would never be said in times of crisis," said a spokesman for the Egyptian government. "It's definitely not to be said by someone who is going to commit suicide because suicide is against Islam."

Frank Wisner, the former US ambassador to Cairo, said: "Egypt has one of the lowest suicide rates in the world. They are not a suicidal people. Egyptian expressions are constantly interposed with communications to the almighty."

But investigators say there is more to support suicide as a motive: the flight data recorder does not suggest mechanical failure; during the plane's dive someone turned off the engines contrary to any emergency routines; and at the end of the dive the plane's elevators were pointing in opposite directions, as though the pilot and co-pilot were struggling with each other for control.

The NTSB investigators are thought to have informally rejected the Egyptian theory of mechanical failure. Egyptians "don't care about solving it, they want to cover themselves", said one.

The Federal Aviation Authority has not yet decided on a request from the Egyptian Civil Aviation Authority to examine a suspect tail part. The Egyptians are working with a team of experts who once worked for the FAA and the safety board.

They say that the disaster might have been caused by a fault in the elevator panels mounted on the Boeing's tail and which point the nose up or down. The panels are controlled by six actuators, four of which have been recovered from the sea.

One of these shows signs of malfunction. If another be haved in the same way, the aircraft's nose would have gone down, say the Egyptians.

But the Americans contend that the marks of failure could have been caused by impact with the ocean and that, in any case, the crew could have rescued the plane even if two actuators did fail.

webTitle: Vote tests Milosevic support in Montenegro

fields.headline: Vote tests Milosevic support in Montenegro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Montenegro's fiercely anti-Milosevic government faces a crucial test on Sunday when voters go to the polls in the capital city, Podgorica, and the coastal town of Herceg Novi.
fields.body:
Montenegro's fiercely anti-Milosevic government faces a crucial test on Sunday when voters go to the polls in the capital city, Podgorica, and the coastal town of Herceg Novi.

Though only local elections, they are the first in the small republic since Nato's air strikes sharpened the conflict between President Milo Djukanovic and the government in Belgrade.

Opinion polls show a gradual increase in support for inde pendence and although Sunday's voters also face local issues, their decision will be the best barometer of the mood short of a referendum.

The main opposition party, the SNP, has joined forces with the JUL movement run by Mr Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic, as well as the extreme right Radical party of Vojislav Seselj. It is calling its candidates the "Yugoslav coalition" in the hope that voters will have tired of Mr Djukanovic's pro-western line.

Mr Djukanovic, who has been widely courted by the US and the EU, barely recognises the Yugoslav Federation, which links Montenegro with Serbia.

Last week his security adviser, Goran Zugic, was gunned down in Podgorica by an unknown assailant. This week, the Yugoslav information minister, Goran Matic, said the murder was stage-managed by the CIA to blame Mr Milosevic. "The CIA stands behind this terrorist act," Mr Matic said. "Zugic was just a figure on [the] CIA's chess table."

Mr Djukanovic shelved a plan to hold a referendum on secession this autumn under US pressure not to provoke Belgrade. But he is unhappy with the latest advice from the west that he should take part in the elections to the federal Yugoslav parliament which Mr Milosevic has announced.

Miodrag Vukovic, the president's legal adviser, said: "The federal elections are just another of Milosevic's manipulations. If we reject them, he will accuse us of being separatists. If we take part, we will be repudiating all our previous statements."

But Mr Djukanovic is also being challenged by those who want independence now.

Zarko Rakcevic, who leads the opposition Social Democratic party, told the Guardian: "We cannot accept Montenegro being an instrument of western pressure on Milosevic.

"As long as you have Montenegro in the federation, the idea of [a] 'Greater Serbia' survives. Without Montenegro, they must start on the road of de-Nazification."

webTitle: Kaufman's revenge is all Greek to the visitors

fields.headline: Kaufman's revenge is all Greek to the visitors
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Committee room 15 was full of Greek reporters (Greek shorthand looks really fun), desperately hoping that the arts minister would announce that yes, we are finally going to send the Elgin Marbles home.
fields.body:
Committee room 15 was full of Greek reporters (Greek shorthand looks really fun), desperately hoping that the arts minister would announce that yes, we are finally going to send the Elgin Marbles home.

(No Briton in their right mind cares about this. The Greeks, however, care passionately. So why don't we send them back - which was Labour policy up to 1992? I guess it's a macho thing; New Labour is terrified the dockers would march, perhaps confused by the concept of a pay frieze. Or the WI - now known to Mr Blair as "the forces of conserves" - would get really angry this time.)

But there was a subtext. Gerald Kaufman, who chairs the committee on culture, media and sport, does not appear to care for Alan Howarth, the arts minister.

Mr Howarth spent most of his career as a Tory, switched to Labour before the last election, and was found a safe seat. He now does a job which Mr Kaufman might feel he would have performed rather better himself. What's more, Mr Howarth has recently set up a panel to advise on looted works of art - the task which the committee is supposed to do. So this was a clear case of lese-Kaufman, and could neither be ignored nor forgiven.

Mr Kaufman runs the committee rather as if it were a chat show. But he is the opposite of Michael Parkinson. His job is to receive guests and make them feel ill at ease.

He wondered why the panel had been set up to offer "good and practical" advice. Why did Mr Howarth and his colleagues refuse to accept the committee's good and practical advice?

"Oh, no, no, not at all," Mr Howarth anguished. "We give the greatest weight to your recommendations!"

"Well, we're thrilled by that," said Mr Kaufman, his voice sticky with sarcasm.

Soon afterwards he inquired which committee recommendations the department of culture, media and sport had put into action. Mr Howarth flannelled. "I, er, can't pluck a particular recommendation out of thin air. My powers of, hmm, recall are not focused as much as they, er, might be."

In other words, nothing. Everything Gerald had done had been totally ignored. He sat glowering at Mr Howarth, with angry, hooded eyes.

It must have been confusing for the Greeks. They might have been cheered up for a moment when Mr Howarth -who decided that the best form of defence was painful politeness - told us how unbounded was his admiration for Greece. "I say this in a spirit of the utmost friendship for the Greek people!" he carolled.

We Brits knew what this meant: "We're keeping the marbles. It's not only our right; it's a legal obligation."

Claire Ward wondered if the law might not be changed. "Possibly," said Mr Howarth before going on to add, in effect, "but not before I am as cold and dead as the marbles themselves."

"I speak, however, with the deepest respect for the Greek people and their love of democracy." A Greek person next to me sighed, deeply.

Later, in the chamber, Ms Ward gave way in the pensions debate to Desmond Swayne, the caddish-looking Tory. He tried condescension. "The honourable lady is young, intelligent, articulate. There are many other compliments I would like to pay."

Big mistake. "I am grateful for any compliments," she replied, "even from him. But I am not yet desperate."

Mr Swayne, his clumping gallantry having been rejected, looked rather as if a jar of WI conserves had been lobbed onto his head.

Later, in the chamber, Ms Ward gave way in the pensions debate to Desmond Swayne, the caddish-looking Tory. He tried condescension. "The honourable lady is young, intelligent, articulate. There are many other compliments I would like to pay." Big mistake. "I am grateful for any compliments," she replied, "even from him. But I am not yet desperate." Mr Swayne, his clumping gallantry having been rejected, looked rather as if a jar of WI conserves had been lobbed onto his head.

webTitle: PlayStation joins hand to hand fight

fields.headline: PlayStation joins hand to hand fight
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sony played catch-up yesterday in the fast-moving mobile entertainment market with the announcement of a portable version of its top selling PlayStation game console.
fields.body:
Sony played catch-up yesterday in the fast-moving mobile entertainment market with the announcement of a portable version of its top selling PlayStation game console.

Sony Computer Entertainment, the group's game-making unit, said the new machine - the PSone - will connect to mobile phones, allowing players to exchange messages and download software.

It is priced at about £90 and based on the original 32-bit PlayStation console which has sold more than 70m worldwide. It will be launched in Japan on July 7. Sales in the United States and Europe will start in the autumn.

PSone represents a shift in thinking at Sony, which has come to rely heavily on the PlayStation for profits.

The company has staked its future on the success of the new-generation 128-bit PlayStation 2, which was launched in March, but plans to put this machine at the centre of a wired world of games, film and other media have been threatened by the dramatic expansion of machines offering mobile internet access.

The PSone, which will gradually replace the old PlayStation, helps to fill this gap along with new palmtop terminals that Sony plans to launch later this summer. However, the dominance of Gameboy may not be challenged because PSone is not battery operated so is less mobile.

webTitle: Milburn looks for new health overlord

fields.headline: Milburn looks for new health overlord
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, yesterday laid the groundwork for a management overhaul at the top of the health service by creating a new position for an overlord to run the NHS, public health and social services.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, yesterday laid the groundwork for a management overhaul at the top of the health service by creating a new position for an overlord to run the NHS, public health and social services.

The job will combine the responsibilities of chief executive of the NHS executive and permanent secretary of the department of health. It will be advertised shortly at a six-figure salary and headhunters are expected to seek out private sector managers for interview alongside internal candidates who have come via the traditional civil service route.

Mr Milburn said the position would be "probably the biggest and most exciting in the public sector".

It would be "at the cutting edge of health and social care reform. The task is to drive through a modernisation programme to create 21st century health and social care for the people of this country." The move follows a decision by Alan Langlands, NHS chief executive to step down in July. Health department officials said Chris Kelly, their permanent secretary proposed the merger of the two jobs, but indicated that he would not be a candidate.

For 15 years Conservative and Labour governments supported the devolution of operational control of the NHS to an executive, supposedly at arms length from ministers.

But yesterday a department source said there had been concern for some time about problems caused by splitting NHS management from public health and social care. During the winter flu crisis, different sets of officials were responsible for vaccines, social care and hospital admissions, complicating the government's response.

"Chris Kelly has acknowledged that the relationship was highly dysfunctional, involving turf warfare. He said the job should be merged so one person has responsibility across the health agenda," the source said.

webTitle: Victor of Kosovo retreats to Wall Street

fields.headline: Victor of Kosovo retreats to Wall Street
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: A year after the Kosovo war ended, the general who won the conflict for Nato without a single combat casualty is quietly emptying his desk and looking for work in the unfamiliar world of investment banks and management consultancies.
fields.body:
A year after the Kosovo war ended, the general who won the conflict for Nato without a single combat casualty is quietly emptying his desk and looking for work in the unfamiliar world of investment banks and management consultancies.

This is not the way the US normally treats its victorious warriors. The commanders of Desert Storm were hailed as conquering heroes - and even urged to run for the presidency - when they returned from the Gulf. But Washington has given General Wesley Clark the cold shoulder.

He was pushed into retiring early from his position as Nato's supreme allied commander for Europe last month, and in less than two weeks he will leave the army, which has been his home since 1968, the year he completed his Rhodes Scholarship in Oxford.

In all those years, Gen Clark, 55, says he only had two bad days: when he was wounded in Vietnam, and then when he was called away from a formal dinner in Lithuania last year and told he would be leaving his command early to make room for his successor. The press had already been informed, in case he tried to get the decision overturned.

Gen Clark still winces when the subject is raised. In an interview on one of his last days at the Pentagon he clenched his jaw and fell silent for a moment as he pondered the motives behind his ousting.

"I'm sure there were many reasons," he said tersely. "I'm very satisfied with what I did. I did the right thing."

What Gen Clark did was to try to drag a reluctant Pentagon into the post-cold war era as he saw it. It is a world in which nation states are crumbling and conflicts erupting like fierce brush fires along the cracks, sometimes killing hundreds of thousands of people.

The general's message is that the west must be ready to intervene militarily in this new era even when its strategic interests are not directly threatened - to stop genocide for example. He believes such "humanitarian wars" are an inevitable consequence of democracy, television and the world wide web.

"The modern technology has made those of us in the west increasingly intolerant of the kinds of inhumanity that may have occurred in many cases in an earlier age. It's become simply intolerable," he said.

Part two of the Clark doctrine is that the west's interventions must be decisive.

It is the manifesto of the "hu manitarian hawks", of whom Gen Clark is the undisputed patron saint.

"During the cold war, where you had two adversaries both capable of destroying the other locked in an ideological struggle, any breach threatened a tit-for-tat escalation which could have resulted in nuclear catastrophe. Therefore the presence of strategic nuclear arsenals served as a dampening impact," he said.

As a result, his argument runs, western leaders dealt with crises and confrontations with a policy of incremental escalation, gradually sending forces to the battlefield. The policy minimised the risk of panicking the other side into going nuclear, and it gave time for cooler heads to prevail.

"In the post-cold war era the dampening effect of strategic nuclear arsenals isn't operative. In these kinds of regional operations, the use of force has to stand on its own. If it can't be decisive in and of itself then local authorities will be tempted to endure it and put up with the pain," he said.

In other words, the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, knew that Nato was not going to drop a nuclear bomb on him during the Bosnian and Kosovo conflicts, and was also aware that the west was highly reluctant to send in ground troops. He therefore thought he could win.

Mr Milosevic agreed to Nato terms only after Nato leaders had reconciled themselves to a ground invasion, Gen Clark argues. He saw "the hammer shaping up" in Macedonia and Albania. "It was inevitable and he knew it," he said.

But the general believes it took far too long for the Nato hammer to take shape, and his impatience earned him too many enemies in Washington for the good of his own career. He fumed to journalists over the slow deployment of hi-tech Apache helicopter gunships which might have been able to track down the Serb paramilitaries who were committing most of the atrocities against Kosovan civilians.

Despite his early departure the Clark doctrine of decisive force is at least gaining lip service in the corridors of the Pentagon, but the fear of casualties is likely to remain a paralysing influence when the bullets begin to fly.

The principle of humanitarian intervention is also in limbo. A victory for George W Bush in November is likely to send it back into retreat. If the Rwanda genocide were to happen tomorrow, Gen Clark was unsure whether the outside world would react any differently.

He is wearing a business suit as he does the rounds of Wall Street investment houses and hi-tech venture capital firms. Meanwhile he is putting the Clark doctrine in a book. The lessons of Kosovo are still being learned.

"It's a profound change," Gen Clark said. "It's akin to throwing a pebble in a pond and the ripples from that stone will go on for some time."

webTitle: Cabinet agrees bill to ban fox hunting

fields.headline: Cabinet agrees bill to ban fox hunting
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to undertake a dramatic volte face over fox hunting by announcing on Monday that the government will table its own bill, with a number of options including an outright ban on hunting with hounds.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to undertake a dramatic volte face over fox hunting by announcing on Monday that the government will table its own bill, with a number of options including an outright ban on hunting with hounds.

The plan was agreed in outline at yesterday's cabinet meeting, in advance of ministers today formally receiving a copy of the offical Burns inquiry into the impact of fox hunting on the countryside.

The decision to table a government bill increases its chance of reaching the statute book - or, at least, the chance of a morale boosting confrontation with the partially-reformed Lords in the next session, likely to be the last before the general election.

Mr Straw will make a statement to MPs on Monday. His aides have told MPs closely involved in the issue that he will suggest that a bill is tabled early in the next session with MPs given a free vote.

The bill, says the aides, will be passed overwhelmingly in the Commons, and then face fierce resistance in the Lords. Ministers will stress that if the bill is rejected in the Lords, they will make it a manifesto commitment for the next general election.

Until recent weeks Mr Straw has been holding out against a government bill, preferring to give government time to a private member's bill or simply delaying the measure altogether until after the election.

Ministers now expect the fox hunting inquiry, chaired by the former treasury permanent secretary Lords Burns, to make it clear that a ban on fox hunting will not destroy the rural economy, except in parts of south-west England.

Nor would a ban lead to a massive surge in the fox population, it will say. The inquiry's official research shows that fox hunting is one of the least efficient ways of reducing the fox population.

The report will, however, concede that fox hunting is popular in the countryside and plays a special cultural role.

Mr Straw's change of tack also reflects the increasing pressure from Labour backbenchers to stick by the manifesto commitment to provide time to ban fox hunting. As many as 102 backbenchers were planning to support a rebellion if Mr Straw did not make a clear commitment to a government bill.

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy yesterday expressed scepticism about a government move, saying: "I don't think at the top of government they want to re-open this particular issue, if they can possibly avoid it, despite what the prime minister said a few months back."

fields.headline: Putin signals Chechen long haul
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin made it plain yesterday that he was opting for long-term military occupation of Chechnya when he declared direct presidential rule of the separatist republic for what his aides said would be a period of up to three years.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin made it plain yesterday that he was opting for long-term military occupation of Chechnya when he declared direct presidential rule of the separatist republic for what his aides said would be a period of up to three years.

As the Russian government's special representative in Chechnya complained that he was "literally bound hand and foot" when it came to obtaining money for Chechnya reconstruction, Sergei Ivanov, head of the Kremlin's national security council, suggested that the Chechen conflict could drag on for decades.

His admission was a far cry from routine Russian claims earlier this year that the war would be over in a matter of weeks.

Officially, the Russian casualty rate in nine months of war was put at more than 9,000 dead or wounded. The toll rises inexorably as the rebels spring booby-traps all over Chechnya on a daily basis.

The Putin decree establishing direct rule over Chechnya, and an accompanying bill sent to parliament means that Chechens will not be able to elect local councils, a republican parliament, or a president in future and that Chechnya will be run by General Viktor Kazantsev, the officer who has commanded the war.

Nikolay Koshman, the Russian vice-premier in charge of Chechnya, voiced his exasperation at the lack of progress in subduing the republic and the failure to win Chechen hearts and minds, complaining that Moscow was strangling every effort he undertook.

webTitle: A feeble state, a disobedient UN and criminal neighbours

fields.headline: A feeble state, a disobedient UN and criminal neighbours
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone's troubles are a long way from over

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone's troubles are a long way from over
fields.body:
It was President Clinton who, after Somalia, brought in the idea that the most important part of any intervention abroad was the "exit strategy". In Sierra Leone Britain has, by contrast, arrived at "a re-entry strategy". Although the bulk of the British force is leaving soon, we are undoubtedly morally committed to return if the war should again go badly for the government and the United Nations proves unable to cope.

As Robin Cook enjoys the plaudits of the people of Freetown, it is worth reflecting both on the almost accidental way in which this commitment emerged, and on how fragile are the political forces with which we are now allied. The Sierra Leone operation was a product of the restructured British military readiness system (of which it has been the first serious test), of luck and of judicious opportunism.

The system efficiently delivered the rapid reaction force it was designed to produce. The luck came in the timing, in the chance that an amphibious force was at hand in the Mediterranean, and in the fact that the British were already involved in advising the Sierra Leone military. The opportunism came when those in charge of what began as an evacuation realised that the war in Sierra Leone was such a flimsy and chaotic affair that it could probably be turned around by a mixture of exhortation, forceful advice, and showmanship.

The chutzpah of our military men has been rather amazing. But what can be turned once can be turned again. That means not only that British forces might have to return to Sierra Leone, but that British diplomacy has new and difficult tasks. Britain is now involved far more than it was before in the complex and dangerous regional politics of west Africa, and in a problem that almost certainly cannot be solved until Charles Taylor, the ruler of neighbouring Liberia, is overthrown. It is not only Sierra Leone that is threatened. The potentially lethal combination of bad or inadequate government, disappointed rural people, and valuable resources for the taking exists in other countries in the region. A diamond boycott, if properly managed - which is a big if - will help, but there will have to be more to policy than that.

The grave weakness of Sierra Leone can hardly be overestimated. The country has just one month's supply of rice and fuel. Most of its meagre income comes from donors. Rice-planting has been disrupted by the resumed hostilities, which means worse scarcity is ahead. Refugees are once again heading in large numbers for Freetown and other centres. But the more fundamental difficulty is that the institutional infrastructure of Sierra Leone was fecklessly destroyed long before any rebels came on the scene. Earlier leaders, above all Siaka Stevens, who ruled from 1968 to 1985, eviscerated the country's institu tions, from the civil service and the judiciary to the army. The middle class either colluded or went abroad in disgust. In this "shadow state", as one academic has called it, real power was exercised, the real deals were struck, and the real money was made outside of the formal institutions, which became mere shades of what they had been. Expertise was dissipated, professional standards dropped. When the foreign ministry, for example, was recently asked for copies of treaties to which Sierra Leone is party, it discovered it had lost them.

The incompetence and lack of control of the Sierra Leonean state after Stevens had finished with it is the main reason it fell victim to an extraordinary act of international larceny. Charles Taylor, in alliance with the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), simply seized Sierra Leone's diamonds to finance his struggle to dominate Liberia. Taylor's capacity to manipulate the war has been amply demonstrated in the past month, during which he has restrained RUF units in the east of the country and been instrumental in the release of UN hostages. But since his aim is to continue to control the diamond areas by proxy, he will choose aggressive or "peaceable" tactics according to need.

The government of Ahmed Tejan Kabbah is an uneasy coalition of academics and professionals shackled with militia leaders and former coup-makers. Kabbah is reasonably popular but not a commanding figure, and his popularity rests in part on his capacity to deliver foreign military and financial help. The forces the government has - it would be too much to say it controls them - are a congery of half-trained new soldiers and irregulars, including ex-rebels and some who were little more than bandits before they rallied to the cause. The British military claim they are getting better and that British training will effect further improvements. But that is from a very low base indeed.

The weakness of the government is paralleled by the weakness of the UN force which has unavoidably become the government's not very stable prop since fighting began again last month. The force is hampered not so much by its mandate as by the reluctance of its contingents to obey orders. In spite of the fact that the UN mission is headed by a Nigerian diplomat and the deputy commander of the force is also Nigerian, one of the Nigerian battalions, for example, refused orders to reoccupy a strategic junction last week. Apart from such problems, the force remains vulnerable to hostage-taking.

It is true that Sierra Leone displays a sort of competition in fragility. If the government barely has a grip, the UN is tentative, and the British are trying to make a difference with a riskily small outlay of resources, the RUF is not by international standards a formidable force. It may have no more than a couple of thousand fighters; its government of the regions it controls is both harsh and ineffective; and its ideological appeal has faded. To deny that it has any social base would be foolish, and it may still focus feelings of hostility toward Freetown, toward southern ethnic groups, and against Nigeria. But a living popular revolutionary movement it is not. Yet the question in Sierra Leone is not who is strong - nobody is - but who is least weak.

The Sierra Leone government lost its diamonds and much of its country because it was enfeebled and in the process it became more enfeebled still. It will be hard for it to defeat the RUF in any final way, or to prevail politically in the kind of neither-peace-nor-war situation which may come about if a ceasefire is patched up between the two sides, unless the problem represented by Charles Taylor can be solved. Siaka Stevens brought Sierra Leone down, and Charles Taylor keeps it down. Britain may find it is back in West Africa for a longer haul than anyone contemplated when the joint headquarters at Northwood went on alert a month ago.

The incompetence and lack of control of the Sierra Leonean state after Stevens had finished with it is the main reason it fell victim to an extraordinary act of international larceny. Charles Taylor, in alliance with the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), simply seized Sierra Leone's diamonds to finance his struggle to dominate Liberia. Taylor's capacity to manipulate the war has been amply demonstrated in the past month, during which he has restrained RUF units in the east of the country and been instrumental in the release of UN hostages. But since his aim is to continue to control the diamond areas by proxy, he will choose aggressive or "peaceable" tactics according to need. The government of Ahmed Tejan Kabbah is an uneasy coalition of academics and professionals shackled with militia leaders and former coup-makers. Kabbah is reasonably popular but not a commanding figure, and his popularity rests in part on his capacity to deliver foreign military and financial help. The forces the government has - it would be too much to say it controls them - are a congery of half-trained new soldiers and irregulars, including ex-rebels and some who were little more than bandits before they rallied to the cause. The British military claim they are getting better and that British training will effect further improvements. But that is from a very low base indeed. The weakness of the government is paralleled by the weakness of the UN force which has unavoidably become the government's not very stable prop since fighting began again last month. The force is hampered not so much by its mandate as by the reluctance of its contingents to obey orders. In spite of the fact that the UN mission is headed by a Nigerian diplomat and the deputy commander of the force is also Nigerian, one of the Nigerian battalions, for example, refused orders to reoccupy a strategic junction last week. Apart from such problems, the force remains vulnerable to hostage-taking. It is true that Sierra Leone displays a sort of competition in fragility. If the government barely has a grip, the UN is tentative, and the British are trying to make a difference with a riskily small outlay of resources, the RUF is not by international standards a formidable force. It may have no more than a couple of thousand fighters; its government of the regions it controls is both harsh and ineffective; and its ideological appeal has faded. To deny that it has any social base would be foolish, and it may still focus feelings of hostility toward Freetown, toward southern ethnic groups, and against Nigeria. But a living popular revolutionary movement it is not. Yet the question in Sierra Leone is not who is strong - nobody is - but who is least weak. The Sierra Leone government lost its diamonds and much of its country because it was enfeebled and in the process it became more enfeebled still. It will be hard for it to defeat the RUF in any final way, or to prevail politically in the kind of neither-peace-nor-war situation which may come about if a ceasefire is patched up between the two sides, unless the problem represented by Charles Taylor can be solved. Siaka Stevens brought Sierra Leone down, and Charles Taylor keeps it down. Britain may find it is back in West Africa for a longer haul than anyone contemplated when the joint headquarters at Northwood went on alert a month ago. martin.woollacott@theguardian.com

webTitle: We're not political, says WI; yes you are, says Downing Street

fields.headline: We're not political, says WI; yes you are, says Downing Street
fields.standfirst:
National Fed. Women's Institutes
Labour Party
fields.trailText: It is not often that the ladies of the women's institute at Watnall, on the outskirts of Nottingham, give themselves a pat on the back but yesterday they looked decidedly pleased with themselves.
fields.body:
It is not often that the ladies of the women's institute at Watnall, on the outskirts of Nottingham, give themselves a pat on the back but yesterday they looked decidedly pleased with themselves.

After all, the mild-mannered matrons of Britain's largest women's organisation found themselves on the front page of every national newspaper for humiliating the prime minister.

Joan, Joy, Sheila, Margaret and Mollie are delighted by the stand made by their fellow members. As they sit down to their coffee and biscuits at the Royal Moathouse hotel in Nottingham they look the epitome of middle class, middle-aged middle England.

They are, they admit, all a certain age, conservative with a small 'c' with a strong urge to sing Jerusalem at least once a month. Two of the five are Tory voters, one a Liberal Democrat, and two won't say. But none, they insist, has ever made jam.

The WI, as a registered charity, does not describe itself as a political organisation, seeing itself more as "a modern voice for women".

Downing Street was yesterday privately angry at such a claim, pointing out that the WI repeatedly lobbies government and openly espouses its views in clear political terms. Among the issues it has taken up are post office closures, nursery school provision, breast cancer screening and GM foods.

Ministers do not want to engage in an open war of words with the WI partly because there are few political benefits from doing so, but one minister said: "We are lobbied by the WI up to 30 times a year. They produce papers on how to lobby MPs and MEPs, how to deal with lobbying organisations, how parliament works and it has even in the past adopted a position on the future of the House of Lords."

At the time of the Budget, the WI issued lengthy press releases, dishing out praise and blame in equal measure over the chancellor's tax plans. It welcomed "the extra help, although limited, for mothers and working families on low incomes, for pensioners and for small businesses". It also welcomed an increase in child benefit and a commitment to tackle child poverty and expressed concern over rural transport the government's road safety strategy, the lack of action on the crisis in farming and the high value of the pound.

Tessa Jowell, the women's minister forging a relationship between Labour and the WI, said: "I have spoken to lots of WIs and they have been highly involved in our 'listen to women' road shows. It is a very important organisation and one that the government needs to take seriously."

The WI was set up in 1915 to help women in rural areas to support the war effort by bottling fruit and vegetables. Today, 85 years later, it has 250,000 members 8,000 institutes from villages, small towns and suburban districts.

Watnall WI - 56 members - has been vocal in support of the village's post office. Tony Blair should leave them alone, said member Margaret Smith, 68, a retired teacher who votes Tory.

But it was not a party political matter, insisted Mollie Houlton, 69, a retired teacher and Lib Dem supporter. "We'd be arguing against whichever government was in power."

webTitle: Visionary architect may join Livingstone team

fields.headline: Visionary architect may join Livingstone team
fields.standfirst:
Rogers talks of 'fantastic' chance to aid look of London
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Lord Rogers of Riverside is poised to test his architectural talents in a new arena by joining Ken Livingstone's mayoral cabinet and getting the "power of the people" behind a regeneration of London comparable to that of Barcelona.
fields.body:
Lord Rogers of Riverside is poised to test his architectural talents in a new arena by joining Ken Livingstone's mayoral cabinet and getting the "power of the people" behind a regeneration of London comparable to that of Barcelona.

Asked whether the newly elected London mayor will have the power or the cash to make much difference, the designer of some of the world's most famous modernist buildings - as well as the Millennium Dome - said: "I don't know yet, we've got to explore it."

He added: "But the mayor's got a big responsibility for the environment and traffic. The power here is not the written power, it's the power of the people behind you."

Last night he called it a fantastic opportunity and said that his twin objectives in such a post would be the redevelopment of the Thames, as "a connector, not a divider", and the creation of neighbourhood squares.

Long a champion of revitalising the Thames, he called the South Bank, from London Bridge to the London Eye, and the prospects for redevelopment of east London's Thames gateway "the most important, accessible regeneration in urban England."

It could be transformed as Barcelona's old harbour had been, with his help, to become what he called the leading example of such redevelopment.

Lord Rogers has yet to make up his mind whether, at 66, he would accept Mr Livingstone's offer to join his team and manage the built environment programme in a capital which he has warned is "rotting".

If he says yes within the next seven days Lord Rogers may need to create up to 1m new homes, mainly on existing "brownfield" sites, using his long-advocated mixed communities, where people "live, work and have leisure within walking distance".

After news that Mr Livingstone had approached him two weeks ago leaked yesterday - and "caught me on the hop" - Lord Rogers admitted that he barely knew the former GLC leader, with whom he has had two working meetings.

Nikki Gavron, Mr Livingstone's deputy, a veteran of London environmental politics, had brought them together, he said.

"Nikki was the facilitator, she has a very good understanding of urban questions."

Lord Rogers, who is close to ministers, chairs the government's urban taskforce, working closely with John Prescott, whom he yesterday described as "an amazing man, who has a hell of a battle, mostly outside his department".

Despite recent complaints, in which he urged ministers to move further and faster on urban regeneration, Lord Rogers insisted that he had not fallen out with Tony Blair, and that his willingness to work with Mr Livingstone was not a sign of disaffection.

He has criticised the con tents of the dome - "There are many good things, but it could be better" - and, like Mr Livingstone, is keen to curb cars in the city.

But one point of contention with the mayor is over his old partner, Lord (Norman) Foster's plan for a new riverside home for the greater London authority, a glass "headlamp" on the south bank of the Thames.

"It's an amazing design by one of the world's great architects, a great symbol of pride," he said.

"Why should the GLA move into a 100-year-old building?" he asked.

In his 1995 Reith lecture, Lord Rogers declared: "London must not be abandoned to the mercy of the market - to cars, pollution and poverty. London offers every opportunity to create a cultured, balanced and sustainable city. But to achieve this Londoners must be empowered" - by getting an elected mayor.

webTitle: No 'navel gazing' after Blair WI fiasco

fields.headline: No 'navel gazing' after Blair WI fiasco
fields.standfirst:
The inquest No 10 to 'come out fighting' as pressure grows on spin regime
National Fed. Women's Institutes
Labour Party
fields.trailText: Downing Street insisted yesterday that it did not see the fiasco over Tony Blair's derided speech to the Women's Institute, as marking a defining moment when Middle England abandoned the government.
fields.body:
Downing Street insisted yesterday that it did not see the fiasco over Tony Blair's derided speech to the Women's Institute, as marking a defining moment when Middle England abandoned the government.

Cabinet ministers insisted it was merely a case of the right speech delivered to the wrong audience, suggesting only that communications between the Women's Institute and No 10 must have broken down.

However, as the inquest developed on the prime minister's most uncomfortable moment since the general election, the home secretary Jack Straw accepted that it showed normal politics was returning after three years in which Tony Blair has been seen as above the fray.

Mr Straw said: "It obviously spells thoughtfulness and a need for reflection." But even loyal backbenchers said they hoped the episode marked the decline of the Blairite spin machine, adding that ministers now needed to give themselves sharper definition by being willing to risk making enemies.

Lord Hattersley called for Alastair Campbell, the Downing Street press secretary, to be kicked around the office by Mr Blair in the wake of the disaster, but Mr Campbell was unrepentant, saying he would not indulge in a war of words with the WI and insisting that the broad content of the speech had been agreed with the WI.

The WI, enjoying more publicity than it has for a generation, tried to cool the temperature by issuing a statement saying it was delighted that Mr Blair had attended its rally. However, the WI again refused to agree with Downing Street that it had first issued the invitation.

William Hague, hoping to be a beneficiary of Labour's travails with a speech in Wales this morning, said last night that the incident proved that people "really are now fed up with the endless talk of the government. They have had all talk and no delivery and people are really fed up with it."

Mr Campbell said he and his team would not indulge in a period of navel gazing or introspection, but would instead come out fighting. He denied he had been instrumental to the debacle by briefing on the speech the night before so that WI members felt they were being set up to be part of a political relaunch by the prime minister.

He insisted there had been no briefing on the speech from Downing Street prior to the night before and if he had not given a briefing, his office would have been inundated by calls from what he described as the 24 hour new media and its "babbleology".

He said: "The government has an agenda and is delivering on that agenda and it is far more important than the activity and behaviour of a number of women at a big gathering. What we do not do is sit around wallowing and navel gazing. What you do is come out fighting and make your case."

At his morning briefing he attacked the media saying that all the questions he was being asked revealed the media's view that the briefings they were given daily contained only spin. He insisted he gave the media facts .

webTitle: They say that breaking up is hard to do

fields.headline: They say that breaking up is hard to do
fields.standfirst:
Notebook Judge delivers swift justice
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: The words of American Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in his memorandum, order and final judgment that Microsoft, perhaps the most extraordinary business success story of recent times, should be broken up are quite astonishing in their bluntness and aggression.
fields.body:
The words of American Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in his memorandum, order and final judgment that Microsoft, perhaps the most extraordinary business success story of recent times, should be broken up are quite astonishing in their bluntness and aggression.

Having listened for two years, he quite clearly believes that the company's officers lie and that as an organisation it is untrustworthy. The judge is also convinced that Microsoft, in turn convinced of its own innocence, continues the types of business practice which got it up in front of the US district court bench in the first place - using its monopoly in desktop operating systems to bully smaller competitors making PC applications.

Having unfairly swiped the internet browser market, the judge's view is that there is a real risk Microsoft will go and destroy the competition in other sectors. So much so that he has effectively ruled that while the appeal goes through, the business should to a large extent be frozen.

So it will be interesting to see what Microsoft unveils in a fortnight's time, when it is due to give us all a peek of what the next generation of Windows software, powered for the internet age, will look like.

The slide show, which has already been delayed by the trial developments, might be rather shorter than first envisaged.

Meanwhile, with the legal brawling over the anti-monopoly case likely to go on for at least another year as the software company appeals both the verdict and sentence, it has become increasingly fashionable on the other side of the Atlantic to criticise the US state department for destroying shareholder value.

Microsoft stock is 40% off its peak and, so the argument goes, since this ranks as one of the world's biggest quoted enterprises that price drop impacts on the savings and pension of many millions of investors. Mr Gates, with 15% of the company, has seen his paper personal wealth shrink by about £25bn and other shareholders have seen almost £200bn disappear.

But this is very narrow thinking. The state department brought its case against Microsoft because the company was alleged to be exploiting its monopoly to strangle existing competition and ward off future competitors. And Judge Jackson has found the company guilty and ordered that it be split up.

That verdict and sentence says Microsoft has been restricting enterprise - destroying shareholder value elsewhere or doing its best to make sure that non-Microsoft value is not created. Having first given computing to the masses, it has then restricted the use and development of the technology.

There is little doubt that over the past couple of years as the prospect of the Microsoft machine being tamed has increased so has the confidence of many thousands of companies who have been potential competitors to the software monolith. There is real value in this. It is the stuff of long-term economic prosperity, and investors and pensioners the world over should thank Judge Jackson for that.

No comparison

The give growth a chance school of central banking has not taken root in Frankfurt. Yesterday's show of machismo by the European Central Bank is an indication that Wim Duisenberg is no Alan Greenspan.

America's record-breaking run of economic growth would not have reached its 10th year had Mr Duisenberg been in charge. He made it clear yesterday that the ECB was starting to get the heebie-jeebies about rising prices in euroland, even though inflation - affected by higher oil prices - is running only a smidgen above the bank's 2% ceiling. Of course euroland still has a massive overhang of unemployment - the baleful legacy of two decades of deflationary economic policies.

In essence, the ECB believes that much of this unemployment is structural and will not disappear even with strong growth. Instead, it sees supply-side reforms and a good solid dose of market liberalisation as the way forward. The bank has certainly put its money where its mouth is by moving from a fixed-rate refinancing system for a more variable-rate regime. This gives the markets a bigger role in dictating monetary policy.

But the fear must be that the bank is still fighting the last war. Inflation is low around the world, and the experience of the anglo-saxon economies in the past decade is that a sustained period of strong demand is crucial not just to bringing down unemployment but to smoothing the passage of economic reform. By moving rates upwards too early, the ECB risks choking off the recovery. And if that happens, the euro will go down not up.

webTitle: Aids 'began with virus from a chimp'

fields.headline: Aids 'began with virus from a chimp'
fields.trailText: The world Aids epidemic began in Africa with the accidental infection of a human from a chimpanzee between 1915 and 1941, a US-based scientific team has claimed.
fields.body:
The world Aids epidemic began in Africa with the accidental infection of a human from a chimpanzee between 1915 and 1941, a US-based scientific team has claimed.

The claim, made in the latest issue of the journal Science, adds to the growing controversy over the origin of Aids, reignited by British journalist Ed Hooper in his book The River.

Mr Hooper argued that HIV-1, the main virus causing Aids, was first introduced accidentally into humans in the then Belgian Congo in the 1950s, as the result of trials of an experimental polio vaccine.

But the US researchers, led by Bette Korber of the Los Alamos laboratory in New Mexico, said that HIV-1 must have appeared before the vaccine trials.

The battle lines are now drawn before a showdown in London in September, when proponents of the conflicting theories will air their views at a Royal Society conference.

The Korber group used computers to analyse the recent rate of mutation of the most pernicious strain of HIV, HIV-1 M, which has infected 50m people and left 16m dead.

Working on the assumption that the original virus mutated into different versions at a steady rate over time, they tracked its first appearance in humans back to a point earlier than 1941 and later than 1915, most likely in 1931.

The experimental polio vaccine was given to hundreds of thousands of people in Central Africa between 1957 and 1960.

It is generally accepted that the first known case of HIV infection, retrospectively diagnosed, was from 1959, in Leopoldville, now Kinshasa

"Our analyses suggest that the HIV-1 M group ancestral sequence occurred decades before the vaccination programmes," said the group's Science paper. "We find it unlikely that oral polio vaccine was the source of HIV-1 transmission to humans."

The Hooper scenario proposes that western scientists used the kidneys of chimpanzees, known to have been kept at a lab close to the city of Kisangani, to prepare the experimental vaccine, known as CHAT.

According to this theory, the kidneys contained a simian version of the HIV virus, SIV, which passed into some of those vaccinated. Cases of other viruses spreading via other polio vaccines are well documented.

Surviving members of the CHAT research team have said other primate kidneys, not organs from chimps, were used, but no paper evidence exists to say what exactly was done with the Kisangani chimps.

The Korber team acknowledged that they had not disproved the Hooper scenario, but said that to make their calculations wrong, the CHAT vaccine would have to have introduced nine genetically distinct versions of the HIV-1 virus into humans.

Mr Hooper said yesterday that he believed this was what had happened.

He pointed out that one key reference in the Korber paper, to one of the few surviving lab records from Kisangani, wrongly stated that the lab held only juvenile chimps, which would be less likely to harbour different types of SIV.

In fact the document, which is now in Mr Hooper's hands and has been seen by the Guardian, records that at least one chimp was an adult.

Mr Hooper argued that HIV-1, the main virus causing Aids, was first introduced accidentally into humans in the then Belgian Congo in the 1950s, as the result of trials of an experimental polio vaccine. But the US researchers, led by Bette Korber of the Los Alamos laboratory in New Mexico, said that HIV-1 must have appeared before the vaccine trials. The battle lines are now drawn before a showdown in London in September, when proponents of the conflicting theories will air their views at a Royal Society conference. The Korber group used computers to analyse the recent rate of mutation of the most pernicious strain of HIV, HIV-1 M, which has infected 50m people and left 16m dead. Working on the assumption that the original virus mutated into different versions at a steady rate over time, they tracked its first appearance in humans back to a point earlier than 1941 and later than 1915, most likely in 1931. The experimental polio vaccine was given to hundreds of thousands of people in Central Africa between 1957 and 1960. It is generally accepted that the first known case of HIV infection, retrospectively diagnosed, was from 1959, in Leopoldville, now Kinshasa "Our analyses suggest that the HIV-1 M group ancestral sequence occurred decades before the vaccination programmes," said the group's Science paper. "We find it unlikely that oral polio vaccine was the source of HIV-1 transmission to humans." Cases of other viruses spreading via other polio vaccines are well documented. webTitle: Warning shot may help to heal wounds

fields.headline: Warning shot may help to heal wounds
fields.standfirst:
Wembley blow highlights need for action and results
National Fed. Women's Institutes
Labour Party
fields.trailText: Some good may well come from Tony Blair's brush with the Women's Institute. In private, the prime minister sometimes talks as if he has endured three years of hell since 1997. He hasn't.
fields.body:
Some good may well come from Tony Blair's brush with the Women's Institute. In private, the prime minister sometimes talks as if he has endured three years of hell since 1997. He hasn't.

So the past 24 hours has been both a novel and an unwelcome experience for him, though potentially not unhelpful. "Let's learn from our mistakes," Labour MPs were saying yesterday.

Margaret Thatcher, whose first term Mr Blair directly compares with his own, had to grapple with strikes, rising unemployment, hyper-inflation and Argentine juntas. If he can get through a first term with nothing worse than a disastrously misjudged speech to the WI, Mr Blair will be lucky indeed.

So the Wembley debacle was a test of New Labour's character, its resilience in adversity. Half of Fleet Street - and a sizeable chunk of the parliamentary Labour party - had been waiting for the slick Downing Street publicity juggernaut to hit a pothole.

Yesterday their joy was unconfined. Downing Street rolled with the punch. After initially saying he had no quarrel with the WI, the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, showed signs of suggesting that the boss had been the victim of a calculated ambush. Wisely, he refrained from pressing the theory. Mr Blair and his team of speechwriters agreed that no one would be blamed.

"It was an absurd choice of venue for that sort of speech and showed inexperience. You stay clear of the WI," said one loyal ex-minister of many years standing.

"But it's a good thing it happened now. Blair believes in the Big Tent theory of politics. It may help him understand who his friends are."

Roy Hattersley, another candid veteran, put it more robustly. "Saying 'please believe me, I am yours, whatever you want me to be' won't win middle England. He has to return to what he was three years ago," he said.

But are the doomsayers right when they predict that Mr Blair's pitch to the WI - his attempt to weld his modernisation agenda to "the best of old British values" - was final proof that he has lost the magic touch that has sustained New Labour since he succeeded John Smith in 1994?

Or even that he is in danger if losing next year's general election to a resurgent William Hague? That remains unlikely. It would take the Tories a swing of 6.5 % to reverse the historic Blair landslide of 1997 with its 179-seat Commons majority and 44% to 31% popular lead.

Mr Hague privately tells his MPs he does not expect to do it in one bound. But he needs to do well enough to neutralise the Portillo/Widdecombe threat after the election and get within striking distance of victory.

It is not as if Labour has been complacent. If anything it has been the reverse.

As Mr Campbell said in a waspish Blair profile for the US magazine, Vanity Fair, this week: "There's two people, me and him, who wake up every day thinking 'Right, how can we lose [the election]'?"

But that laudable preoccupation has produced what Labour policy wonks would call perverse results. Even its radicalism - serious and long-term efforts to tackle poverty, school standards and the skills shortages - has been underplayed for fear of upsetting the Daily Mail.

The fact that the Mail's editorial yesterday said it could agree "with almost every word" of Mr Blair's text is a reminder of Downing Street's relentless effort to reconcile its radicalism with what it takes to be the electorate's conservatism. Leftwingers hated the speech.

More to the point, it was the desire to stoke the feelings, aspirations and prejudices of Labour's neglected core vote which may have prompted Gordon Brown's "old school tie" assault on Oxbridge.

Hence Mr Blair's attempt to re-adjust the tone without re pudiating his chancellor's main charge with which he happens to agree. No wonder the order of the day is "no blame," because they are all to blame - cautious policymakers, cash-conscious Treasury ministers and spin doctors

The latter were the obvious easy target for Labour MPs' ire and any row which makes Mr Blair and his intimates concentrate on substance more than presentation is progress, backbenchers agree.

There is still a year or more before the election, in which to make amends - especially as Mr Brown's belated largesse to health, education and transport, starts to yield results.

But Mr Campbell and the other courtiers around the Blair throne - pragmatic, hard-working, instinctively illiberal - are symptoms of the regime's strengths and weaknesses, not its causes.

There was some talk yesterday that the Wembley experience will prompt Mr Blair to recall Peter Mandelson to his side from Belfast. Either way it is action and results by which voters want to judge Mr Blair's first term, not smart PR - or better Wembley speeches.
