webTitle: MPs seek more cash to meet office debts

fields.headline: MPs seek more cash to meet office debts
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Almost 200 MPs have gone thousands of pounds into debt after overspending their office costs budget, according to figures released today. Some MPs have paid out as much as £15,000 above their £50,000 annual allowance for staff, office rent and equipment.
fields.body:
Almost 200 MPs have gone thousands of pounds into debt after overspending their office costs budget, according to figures released today. Some MPs have paid out as much as £15,000 above their £50,000 annual allowance for staff, office rent and equipment.

A hundred Labour and Liberal Democrat MPs are calling on the Commons authorities for an independent review of their allowances. They say they are willing to relinquish personal control of the cash, allowing the Commons authorities to pay MPs' staff directly on formal civil service salary scales.

The proposal is being resisted by whips and ministers amid concern that the call will be interpreted by voters as a demand for more personal cash by "fatcat MPs".

A total of 182 MPs overspent the last financial year's allowance by an average of £2,500, according to the Commons fees office, which administers the office costs budget. Peter Bradley, the Labour MP for the Wrekin who put down the Commons motion calling for a review and uprating of the allowance, last year spent £6,000 above budget, mainly on salaries for one full-time and two part-time staff.

He said: "MPs' workloads have increased enormously as constituents rightly expect a prompt and professional response to the issues they face."

Martin Salter, Labour MP for Reading West, said he had personally subsidised last year's allowance by over £3,000 from his own salary, on which he had already paid tax.

Some MPs were abusing the allowance in the way they employed family members, or were taking on staff on exceptionally low salaries, he said. Others sacked their staff at the start of the summer recess.

Mr Bradley said: "I can think of no other democratic legislature which places so many obstacles in the way of MPs trying to represent their constituents. US congressmen routinely employ a staff of 30 - as far as I am concerned, three would be nice."

fields.headline: Rebels thwart warm homes bill
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: A shadow cabinet plan to establish a new green agenda for the Tories by backing an all-party measure to cut pensioner deaths caused by fuel poverty is set be wrecked today by two Conservative ex-ministers, David Maclean and Eric Forth.
fields.body:
A shadow cabinet plan to establish a new green agenda for the Tories by backing an all-party measure to cut pensioner deaths caused by fuel poverty is set be wrecked today by two Conservative ex-ministers, David Maclean and Eric Forth.

The bill - put forward by David Amess, Conservative MP for Southend West, with backing of Tory environment spokesman Damian Green - would have committed the government to setting up a national strategy to combat fuel poverty. It was due to pass all its stages in the Commons today. But yesterday morning some 70 amendments were tabled by the two backbenchers without consulting Mr Amess, the shadow cabinet, or the Tory chief whip, James Arbuthnot.

The Guardian revealed last month how Mr Maclean helped wreck a firework safety bill. In letters he had said that the blocking of that bill had been punishment for Labour's stance on hunting.

The shadow cabinet is understood to be furious at the MPs' action. Three months ago Mr Green issued a press release saying: "The new Conservative blue-green agenda means that we welcome the principles behind this bill because it will lead to a saving of energy.

"We also welcome it as a practical way of improving the lot of pensioners. A Conservative government would use private funding methods to meet the programme of improvements," he added.

Last night Mr Forth said: "The bill as it stands is all motherhood and apple pie and will raise false expectations because there is no money attached to it. In our view it was emasculated when it had a second reading in the Commons - and a lot of specific provisions were taken out."

When it was put to him that it was Tory party policy to support it and find the money from private sources, he retorted: "You don't need a bill to do that." He also criticised Mr Green for sticking to his support for the measure after it had been changed.

He dismissed criticism from Tom Brake, the Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, who claimed that 230 pensioners had died unnecessarily from badly heated homes, as "meaningless".

Mr Forth said the figures were out of date and failed to take into account the excellent social services provision and the recent cuts in fuel prices.

The two MPs' decision to effectively wreck the bill, which will run out of time today, was also condemned yesterday by Friends of the Earth, Help the Aged and Age Concern.

Mike Lake, director general of Help the Aged, said: "This bill is desperately needed to prevent thousands of people dying unnecessarily each year."

fields.trailText:
Declaration of day
A second Jones has entered the running to succeed Dafydd Wigley as leader of Plaid Cymru. Helen Mary Jones, the leftwinger who snatched Llanelli from under Labour's noses in last year's national assembly elections, confirmed yesterday that she is to challenge frontrunner Ieuan Wyn Jones for the party presidency.

Declaration of day
A second Jones has entered the running to succeed Dafydd Wigley as leader of Plaid Cymru. Helen Mary Jones, the leftwinger who snatched Llanelli from under Labour's noses in last year's national assembly elections, confirmed yesterday that she is to challenge frontrunner Ieuan Wyn Jones for the party presidency.

Bad day
Junior employment minister Margaret Hodge became the latest to be caught wearing foreign clothes. During question time Mrs Hodge was berated for wearing a French suit, although she insisted: "My fundamentals are well and truly British." The previous day Stephen Byers wore a South African suit while launching a textile industry aid package.

Hero of day
Home office minister Lord Bassam told peers how he once arrested a burglar in his home, saying: "We are all subject to this problem of time that it takes to get the police round to an incident. I well remember having exactly that same problem myself when I was burgled for the fourth and final time in an 18-month period ... I was obliged to apprehend the burglar myself." But he made clear the government would not change the law of self-defence following the recent murder conviction of farmer Tony Martin.

Today
Commons: Licensing (young persons) bill, third reading. Warm homes and energy conservation bill, report. Recycled newsprint bill, report. Medical treatment (prevention of euthanasia) bill, report. Lords: Not sitting.

fields.headline: Circumcision may ward off HIV
fields.trailText: Circumcision may protect men against contracting the HIV infection, according to evidence compiled by two scientists who argue that the practice ought to be promoted in countries where Aids is rife.
fields.body:
Circumcision may protect men against contracting the HIV infection, according to evidence compiled by two scientists who argue that the practice ought to be promoted in countries where Aids is rife.

The two Australian researchers have analysed 40 published studies and found that the weight of evidence is heavily in favour of circumcision reducing the risks of infection. Writing in the British Medical Journal today, they suggest that the virus targets specific cells found on the inner surface of the foreskin which possess HIV receptors. These cells, they say, are likely to be the primary point of viral entry into the penis of an uncircumcised man.

The most dramatic evidence of this theory comes from a new study of couples in Uganda, they say, where the woman was HIV positive but the man was not. In 30 months, none of the 50 circumcised men became infected, but 40 out of 137 uncircumcised men did. Both groups had free access to HIV testing, free condoms, advice and information, but 89% of the men never used condoms.

The authors, Roger Short, a professor of obstetrics and gynaecology at the University of Melbourne, and Robert Szabo from the faculty of medicine at Monash University also in Melbourne, say they accept that there are deeply held religious and cultural reservations in parts of the world against circumcision, but none the less, promotion of the practice should be considered.

"Although condoms must remain the first choice for preventing the sexual transmission of HIV, they are often not used consistently or correctly and there may be strong cultural and aesthetic objections to using them.

"Cultural and religious attitudes towards male circumcision are even more deeply held, but in the light of the evidence presented here circumcising males seems highly desirable, especially in countries with a high prevalence of HIV infection," they continue.

Circumcision for baby boys is relatively easy and has few complications, they say, but such a programme would not show results for 15-20 years in HIV transmission rates. They advocate circumcision at puberty before young males become sexually active as "the most immediate effective intervention".

webTitle: Double jeopardy rule may be axed

fields.headline: Double jeopardy rule may be axed
fields.trailText: The case to scrap the double jeopardy rule which prevents an acquitted defendant being tried again if compelling new evidence is produced receives a boost today with the publication of a report by the Commons home affairs committee backing its abolition.
fields.body:
The case to scrap the double jeopardy rule which prevents an acquitted defendant being tried again if compelling new evidence is produced receives a boost today with the publication of a report by the Commons home affairs committee backing its abolition.

The MPs endorse the recommendation of the official inquiry into the death of Stephen Lawrence and say that the rule should be relaxed for offences which are so serious they carry a life sentence and when there is new evidence that makes the previous acquittal unsafe.

They also recommend that there the relaxation of the "double jeopardy" rule should be retrospective with no time limit on older cases being reopened.

Advances in forensic science techniques should also be used to solve older cases. But the home affairs committee says that retrial should not be ordered on the basis of evidence that was available at the time of the original trial but was ruled inadmissible.

Ministers are waiting for a report from the law commission before deciding whether to act on the Lawrence recommendation to scrap the double jeopardy rule which was originally suggested by Michael Mansfield QC, and Imran Khan, the lawyers involved in the Stephen Lawrence case. "We fully accept that the public interest in convicting and punishing the guilty fully justifies a re-examination of the double jeopardy rule," the MPs' report concludes.

The MPs want the director of public prosecutions to be given the power to determine whether or not it is in the public interest to apply to the high court for the original acquittal to be quashed.

They believe that scrapping the double jeopardy rule in cases such as murder would not affect the quality of police investigations. The Law Society had warned the MPs that such a change would allow a police force a second chance and they would go ahead with the first trial after an incomplete investigation believing that if they did not get a conviction they could return to court with further evidence.

But the home affairs committee report says that they agreed with the DPP that in such situations no judge would allow the prosecution a second chance to make up for police incompetence at the first trial.

If ministers support the change, it could be contained in a crime bill this autumn.

fields.headline: Wrongly convicted soldier gets £1m
fields.trailText: A former soldier wrongly convicted at 17 of the murder of a schoolgirl was yesterday awarded £750,000 by the Home Office, bringing his total compensation to almost £1m.
fields.body:
A former soldier wrongly convicted at 17 of the murder of a schoolgirl was yesterday awarded £750,000 by the Home Office, bringing his total compensation to almost £1m.

Andrew Evans spent 25 years in jail for the murder of 14-year-old Judith Roberts before being freed by appeal court judges in 1997, the longest period served by a wrongly convicted person.

In the absence of scientific or eyewitness evidence, he was convicted through answers obtained using a so-called truth drug, brietal, which has since been discredited for inducing false memories.

Under today's rules of evidence, his confession would have been inadmissible, and there were also doubts raised about psychiatric evidence.

Yesterday's award will add up to almost £1m with interim payments, and is thought to be a record.

The highest award known to have been offered in such a case is £550,000 to Gerry Hunter, who spent more than 16 years in prison over the 1974 Birmingham pub bombings. The group dubbed the Birmingham Six had previously rejected an offer of £400,000 each.

Mr Evans, now 45, said that yesterday marked the last day of his false imprisonment and the first day of his life.

"For the past two and a half years we have been fighting for this money and at last it has been sorted. I am relieved.

"I will never be fully free - every time I lock a door I have flashbacks to being in prison."

His solicitor, Dragan Plavsic, said: "With interim payments, Mr Evans's award is closer to £1m. I believe it may be the largest award of its type ever given because he is probably the person who has been locked away for the longest time.

"I think this was a reasonable settlement - the whole point is to try to repay the horror he has been through for the last 25 years."

Mr Evans was a soldier serving at Whittington barracks just outside Lichfield in June 1972 when the girl's body was found in a field six miles away.

The nervous and socially in adequate teenager, who was taking a prescription drug for depression, went to see police in October that year because he had dreamed of a girl's face.

Sobbing hysterically, he stumbled into a police station and asked to see a photograph of Judith Roberts.

Detectives initially dismissed him as a fantasist but over three days of questioning, began to accept his belief that he was the killer.

When officers asked him if he had murdered Judith, he said: "This is it - I don't know. Show me a picture and I will tell you if I've seen her."

Police said he recalled details that could have been known only by Judith's killer.

As the trial approached, he retracted his confession and lawyers on both sides agreed the use of a truth drug. He was sentenced to life in 1973.

In 1994 Mr Evans began a campaign to prove his innocence and contacted the human rights group Justice.

Mr Evans, who now lives in Nottingham and last month married Sue, 43, said: "I have lost most of my life. Now I have married and we are going to buy a house and settle down properly."

A spokeswoman for Justice said: "We are delighted to hear he has won his compensation battle."

A Home Office spokesman confirmed the payout had been made, but refused to comment on the amount.

webTitle: Labour losing support of women over 55

fields.headline: Labour losing support of women over 55
fields.standfirst:
National Fed. Women's Institutes
Labour Party
fields.trailText: WI woman, with her no-nonsense slapdown for the prime minister who won middle England for Labour, reflects a general slide in the party's standing among older women voters, according to new polling figures.
fields.body:
WI woman, with her no-nonsense slapdown for the prime minister who won middle England for Labour, reflects a general slide in the party's standing among older women voters, according to new polling figures.

A Mori poll of voting intentions conducted for the Fawcett Society indicates a Tory lead of 18 points over Labour among middle class women over 55. The findings, conducted in the first quarter of this year and the most up-to-date available, compare with a 14% lead for the Conservatives among women in the higher social classes in 1998. The figures also coincide with new research showing that women's level of satisfaction with the government has fallen far further than men's, leaving a gap of 13 points.

The slippage will be particularly worrying for Labour because older women are the most likely to turn out at the polling booths. It will be small comfort to the party's strategists that the Fawcett research shows a 30-point lead for Labour among ABC1 women under 25, since the young are the most reluctant voters.

The sense that WI woman is losing faith in New Labour is doubly galling for the party since it has continued to suggest that the closing of the gender gap it achieved - with some effort - at the last election has remained since it took office.

In 1997, Labour managed to whittle the "gender gap" - the difference between its support from men and from women - down to just 2% from as wide as 12% in the 1980s, when women became most disillusioned with the party.

That gap, which is small enough to be negligible in polling terms, remains the same overall.

Fawcett Society director Mary-Ann Stephenson called the slump in older women's support "extremely significant". She said: "There has been as assumption that it is middle England voters turning against Tony Blair, when it is actually about women. Labour has a real problem with women over 55."

Many older women were concerned about pension provision and believed people were being penalised for saving, she suggested. "These women were wooed and, having been won, they are feeling a bit ignored.

"All the parties have to remember that women are much more likely to switch their support than men are. They don't have a tribal approach to politics and if they aren't happy they won't vote for you."

fields.headline: No: 1653
fields.standfirst: Dr WG Grace
fields.trailText: Dr WG Grace
fields.body:
Full name:
William Gilbert Grace.

Age:
Died in 1915 aged 67, but immortal in cricket lovers' hearts.

Appearance:
Huge man with a vast, bushy beard. Not in the least bit camp, unless you count the undersized cap he liked to sport.

Status:
The greatest player and personality the game has known.

Why so great?
His first-class career spanned 43 years; he scored more than 50,000 runs, including 124 centuries; took almost 3,000 wickets; recorded England's first Test century; hit the first triple-century in first-class cricket; was the first player to do the double of 1,000 runs and 100 wickets in a season; was the first . . .

Yes, thanks, I get the picture: he could play a bit, natch. What about the personality part?
He was, in every respect, bigger than the game. "Admission threepence, when WG plays sixpence," as the signs used to say. He came to symbolise Victorian England and was as well known as the Queen.

Fascinating. Why is he back in the news? Selected for the series against West Indies?
If only. We're stuck with Flintoff, I'm afraid. WG's descendants are cutting up rough over a gay cricket team which has appropriated his name.

Disgraceful:
That's what they reckon. "I and my family are horrified they should have called this team The Graces without asking us first," says Morny Grace, widow of WG's great-grandson.

Sounds like homophobia.
"We are not gay-bashers, but we object to them using our family name."

Are The Graces worried?
The captain, Ian Crossland, couldn't give a toss. "He was a pioneering figure in his time, just as we are. It is amazing people take such a pathetic stance."

Not to be confused with:
Cricket-playing brothers EM, GF and Henry; sons WG Jr and CB; nephews AH and NV; Grace Kelly (no relation but bowled a mean googly, apparently).

Do say:
"I think he swings it both ways."

Don't say (at least in the presence of a Grace):
"I think he swings both ways."

webTitle: Branson says he'll buy - so Airbus will build A3XX

fields.headline: Branson says he'll buy - so Airbus will build A3XX
fields.trailText: Airbus is to announce that it will build the world's largest super-jumbo, the A3XX, with capacity for up to 900 passengers, sources at the consortium confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Airbus is to announce that it will build the world's largest super-jumbo, the A3XX, with capacity for up to 900 passengers, sources at the consortium confirmed last night.

They said that the European aircraft manufacturer had reached "an authorisation to offer" stage with six different customers and that the project was "unstoppable".

This stage means potential customers have told Airbus they are ready to proceed and are waiting for final confirmation from the consortium.

Although the company would not officially comment, the balance appears to have swung in the project's direction after a declaration from Sir Richard Branson yesterday that he wants 12 aircraft for his Virgin Atlantic airline.

"The A3XX will provide a quantum leap in passenger service as well as provide a cost effective solution to the increasing problems of capacity constraints at the key airports served by the airline," Sir Richard said, adding that Virgin would look to provide beauty treatment areas and bars for economy class passengers on its A3XX class.

Airbus will give no figures but clearly feels confident it has now reached the minimum figure of between 40 to 50 orders specified by John Leahy, its senior vice-president in charge of sales.

Although there has been some delay in an official announcement by Airbus' supervisory board, company sources stressed that it was on track to launch the new flagship of the world's airlines by the end of the year. The first A3XX will fly in 2004 and operate commercially one year later.

Company sources said that it plans to produce 1,200 passenger aircraft and 300 freighters between 2005-2018. The sources said that airline traffic was forecast to double in the next 15 years and triple in the next 32 years, and the A3XX was the most practical way of meeting this growth.

Among the committed airlines are Emirates, Air France, Singapore plus the International Leasing Finance Corporation. Airbus believes the involvement of a leasing company is significant because it would not declare an interest unless it thought there was a market.

The price of the A3XX works out at around $230m (£152m), compared with $180m for the Boeing 747. Airbus sources said that apart from larger capacity than the 747, the A3XX was a less noisy aircraft and took off and landed over a shorter distance.

BAe Systems, which has a 20 per cent stake in Airbus, will manufacture the wings, creating up to 20,000 jobs in the UK.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: I'm All Right Jack | Local Hero | Close Encounters Of The Third Kind (Special Edition) | Dawn Of The Dead
fields.body:
I'm All Right Jack

(John Boulting, 1959)

9am, Carlton Cinema

The Boulting brothers' attack on big business and the unions - in the days when unions wielded power. Ian Carmichael plays a young twit embroiled by devious Dennis Price and Richard Attenborough in a scheme to spark a strike at the latter's munitions factory - where Peter Sellers reigns as shop steward.

Local Hero

(Bill Forsyth, 1983)

8pm, FilmFour

The enchanting tale of a clash of cultures in a small Scottish village, as Texan oil exec Peter Riegert arrives to buy up the place lock, stock and barrel, working out a deal with local lawyer Denis Lawson. Forsyth attracted Burt Lancaster at a cut price with his wistful, comic script: he plays the corporation's star-gazing boss, a twinkling presence in a film that sparkles like the Aurora Borealis.

Close Encounters Of The Third Kind (Special Edition)

(Steven Spielberg, 1977)

10pm, FilmFour

Featuring the aliens with the five-note musical calling card: and curiously, since this is Spielberg's homage to 50s sci-fi,not a ray-gun in sight. He blew the $20m mega-budget on dazzling special effects, with Douglas Trumbull's team creating alien craft of astonishing size and power, and on clever smaller tricks too - such as little Cary Guffey's toys going bonkers when the aliens arrive (pictured). An exercise in wide-eyed wonder.

Dawn Of The Dead
(George A Romero, 1979)

12.30am, FilmFour

George A Romero's zombie trilogy is up there with Citizen Kane as far as gorehounds are concerned, and it's a film that's celebrated for combining what's almost socialist political comment with a story about braindead denizens of the grave. This, the second in the series, is the most downbeat and morbidly humorous. A classic.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Jazz Legends | Performance On 3
fields.body:
Julian Joseph's spotlight falls on Jelly Roll Morton as one of the last century's Jazz Legends (4pm, Radio 3). Those who have heard Morton's famous reminiscences for the Library of Congress will realise how baffled he would have been by the programme's title. Since he invented the art, how could there possibly be any other legends? But he was a splendid craftsman who took infinite pains to achieve what he wanted in the music. He did, in truth, have a lot to be immodest about.

Joshua Rifkin eschews his interpretation of Scott Joplin's ragtime classics to play fast and loose with JS Bach in Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3). Appearing in his eminent Bach scholar mode, he and his Bach Ensemble offer the composer's original version of the Orchestral Suites in B Minor. This reconstruction features a violin instead of the later version's solo flute. There's also a rare performance of the Triple Concerto (BWV 1044).

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
They're all at it. Putting pen to paper - or finger to keyboard, that is. News emerged this week that erstwhile EastEnders star Ross Kemp is taking his undoubted talents to Dickensian heights. Yes, the London bad boy with the bad expression has penned a script based on our mutual friend's A Christmas Carol.

The show is only in development and thought to have been rejected by the BBC already, leaving Kemp's new producers, LWT, hoping to secure an ITV slot for the masterpiece.

But surely Kemp isn't thinking of chucking in the acting game so early in his on-screen career? By doing so, he'd kill off one of the best-loved televisual mono-expressions since Pierce Brosnan followed Roger Moore so ably into the shoes of one James Bond.

Talking of killing off, we chanced this week upon an unusual query in our bulging postbag. "In theory, if a person writes to an editor of a media journal, seeking information on a TV soap, he should get out more," writes our correspondent. "With ER, my excuse is that it's reasonably well written. What I really need to know is, why did they kill off Lucy recently? I assume the actress wanted out, and hope they didn't push her. She was the loose cannon, she was great! Many thanks!" For what, Mr Jeffrey? Sadly I'm unable to answer your query. I assume, as do you, that Lucy - or Kellie Martin to give her her behind-the-screen name - "wanted out". Her ambition is to open a photography gallery in New York, apparently.

But your diligent attention to detail could shed light on Mr Kemp's situation. Should he pursue a career in the hit US medical drama while sustaining his period writing efforts closer to home? One can only imagine how the dialogue might pan out. "By Jingo, Dactor Ross-Kemp, 'is BP's 100 over eazy. Blinkin' 'ell, guv, 120 mils saline up his trademan's, don'tcha know."

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the bodyform ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the bodyform ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
Two girls are sitting looking out of a cafe, bored. A giant panty liner (yes, that's right) walks past and waves at them. They take no notice. Panty Liner Woman pulls a silly face, does a dance and some juggling - all to no avail. Eventually the girls get up to leave. She follows, then jumps out at them from behind a tree, falling spectacularly on her face. Not a flicker. She then flings herself onto the bonnet of their car, bashing the windscreen with her fists as they drive off. "Bodyform. You'll hardly notice it", reads the endline.

The jargon:
Swedish sanpro giant SCA Hygiene Products evidently felt that sanpro advertising had become cliched and patronising, relying too heavily on women in tight white jeans. They decided to buck the trend of such "subtle", "discreet" communication by, well, being unsubtle - an interesting development from the same people who brought us the roller-skating girl on the beach and the "Oooooo, Bodyformed for yooo " jingle.

Personality:
You are, er, female, aged 20-45, and you live anywhere in Europe (the ad is airing right across the continent). You also have a sense of humour and are probably fairly youngish, able to laugh at the idea rather than be embarrassed at the fact that Mother Nature acts the way she does.

Financial status:
Social demographics, financial status and income aren't as important here as the "psychographics" of what sort of woman you are.

Telling lifestyle detail:
If you live in Italy you probably love the ad (it's going down very well there, apparently) while the UK response has been rather more subdued, many British women finding embarrassing enough the fact that sanpro advertising is allowed on telly at all.

Other relevant data:
The 45-second commercial was made by a Swedish agency, directed by British director Ashley King and shot in South Africa. Rather strangely, numerous requests to hire the panty liner costume for hen nights have been made by Scandinavian women.

fields.headline: The plot thickens
fields.standfirst: If you've ever visited a soap opera's official website and left a comment, you might be surprised who read it. Programme makers are turning to the internet to find out what fans really want.
fields.trailText: If you've ever visited a soap opera's official website and left a comment, you might be surprised who read it. Programme makers are turning to the internet to find out what fans really want.
fields.body:
Ever wondered how top soap opera executives spend their time? Well, they surf the internet. Or, more specifically, they log on to the websites devoted to their own shows. Take John Yorke, executive producer of EastEnders. "I tend to log on to the EastEnders message board two or three times a week to see what's going on," he says. "In a sense, the website's a large school playground. We can see what's exciting, what makes people happy."

For soap opera bosses, the internet explosion's been the best thing since Dirty Den gave his daughter's best mate an impromptu seminar on what the birds and bees do down in Albert Square. Official websites devoted to soaps mean that TV execs can now get direct and unfiltered access to information about what you, the viewer, think about their storylines and characters. In the last year, the rollercoaster proliferation of websites and chatrooms devoted to soaps means we can all chip in with our expert opinion about the latest developments. And, importantly for the programme-makers, all they need to do is log on, download and away they go. No need to venture anywhere near an East End market stall or Manchester backstreet to find out whether people think Todd Carty is boring or not.

When you think about what a huge place soap operas have in so many people's lives, it's no big surprise that chatrooms and message boards are so popular. And, in true net style, users aren't afraid to open up to strangers. On my first visit to one popular soap message board, I got a date, planned a shopping trip and discovered how unemployed school-leavers spend their morning. Doesn't take much imagination to guess what market researchers are getting out of it, does it?

Crucially, the sites also give programme-makers a chance to keep in contact with fans. On the official Hollyoaks website, there's a letter from creator Phil Redmond thanking fans for responding to an online questionnaire about a proposed Hollyoaks video. So now Redmond knows which characters should take centre stage, whether celebrity cameos should become a regular event - such as Linda Lusardi's appearance on Hollyoaks - and which ones should head off down the Dog In The Pond to drown their sorrows. Of course the real lure of all this web-gleaned information is that it's bang up-to-date. Traditional market research tends to lag somewhere behind the nation's current water-cooler obsession.

BBC Online recently conducted a survey to find people for an offline group discussion looking at soap-viewing habits. And users' enthusiasm for answering questions online has obviously made Channel 4 New Media department's day - the Hollyoaks website boasts a general lifestyle questionnaire. But surely this is just the tip of the proverbial: as technology develops, producers will be able to get more and more information from and about viewers. Channel 4 is looking into tracking where we go online and correlating this with our viewing habits (oooh, and see those advertisers' mouths water).

The question is, where will it stop? At the moment, it's logistically impossible for, say, BBC Online to collect intricate data about thousands of users. But, with computers and communications devices becoming ever more sophisticated, you'd be hard pushed to convince anyone that things won't change pretty quickly.

And that's not the half of it. Where it all starts getting really tricky is with the ethics of online marketing, especially when you consider that children are heavy chatroom users. Kids' channel Nickelodeon doesn't run a "real time" message board - mainly because it doesn't want undesirables lurking around, but it's also had to see off companies trying to market mobile phones. The site features a list of do's and don'ts, in child-friendly language, in an attempt to stop children giving out personal information.

It's an issue that the terrestrial channels, too, will increasingly be forced to deal with. Of course, the big problem will always be with sites where you can chat in real time, because it's impossible to filter everything. Experimenting with T4, Channel 4's Kids' strand message board, I managed to get a user's private email address and do a spot of name-dropping for NikeTown. (My swearword was caught before being posted on to the group - it was changed to "FISHing", since you ask.)

Over in America, there are glimpses of a more serious attitude to new media and children, as witnessed by the first federal internet privacy law, which establishes a set of rules for marketing to children on the web. Over here, though, we're still playing catch-up.

So just fill in that all-important "questionnaire" for Channel 4, and they'll be more than happy to send you a freebie video for your pains. Me? I'm going FISHing.

fields.headline: Bacterium link to 'rogue' heroin
fields.standfirst:
Germ from soil could have led to 30 deaths

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Scientists investigating a spate of deaths among drug addicts across Britain and Ireland believe at least 30 fatalities may be linked to a rogue batch of heroin infected with a bacterium found in soil.
fields.body:
Scientists investigating a spate of deaths among drug addicts across Britain and Ireland believe at least 30 fatalities may be linked to a rogue batch of heroin infected with a bacterium found in soil.

Intensive analysis in Britain and the United States has connected the deaths of 15 addicts in Glasgow, one in Aberdeen, eight in Dublin and at least seven in England and Wales to a toxin produced by a bacterium which may have been inadvertently mixed with the opiate.

As health authorities complete their investigations of heroin-related deaths over the past month, the number of cases where heroin users have exhibited similar symptoms is rising dramatically.

Yesterday health authorities in the north-west confirmed nine cases in Manchester and Liverpool, involving five deaths. Many more heroin addicts across Britain and Ireland are seriously ill with the condition, which could claim the greatest number of deaths in Britain caused by a rogue narcotic.

The outbreak was first identified in early May when heroin addicts in Glasgow began turning up at hospital casualty departments with huge abscesses up to 12 inches in diameter.

The addicts, mainly women, were given antibiotics, but developed an illness similar to septicaemia. Many suffered multiple organ failure and died.

When the spate of heroin deaths was first spotted in Glasgow public health officials, led by Laurence Gruer, began a nationwide search for the cause.

Dr Gruer, a senior public health consultant with Greater Glasgow health board, called on the help of specialists from the centres for disease control and prevention in Atlanta. British and American scientists now agree the deaths have been caused by a bacterium found in soil never before associated with the deaths of drug addicts.

All those affected have been intravenous heroin users, but it is women, more than men, who have been dying. Scientists believe this is because women, who have a larger fat covering on their body, are more likely to miss veins and inject directly into their muscles, where scientists believe the bacterium thrives in the acid used to dissolve the heroin. The bacterium would quickly be diluted by blood if injected in the veins.

Doctors can give antibiotics to kill the bacterium, but have no way of tackling the toxin. This explains why so many addicts have died despite receiving hospital treatment.

Initially the anthrax bacterium used in chemical weapons was suspected as a possible cause following a tip-off from a Norwegian doctor and tests carried out at the Porton Down laboratory, Wiltshire, which confirmed blood samples from two Scottish victims contained antibodies to anthrax.

However the tests were inconclusive and anthrax was ruled out.

Public health officials across the country yesterday reiterated their plea to heroin addicts to stop injecting the drug and begin smoking it. But, since smoking heroin is far less effective and much more expensive than injecting, it is likely their pleas will fall on deaf ears.

Dr Gruer has called on the government to consider adopting the scheme already used with some success in Switzerland and begin offering heroin to long-term addicts under strict supervision.

Roseanna Cunningham, shadow justice and equality minister in the Scottish executive, yesterday called for a government inquiry into the deaths.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: A strong early advance, which threatened to take the FTSE 100 through 6,600 points had all but disappeared by lunch, with markets across Europe unsettled by the euroland rate rise.
fields.body:
A strong early advance, which threatened to take the FTSE 100 through 6,600 points had all but disappeared by lunch, with markets across Europe unsettled by the euroland rate rise.

Dealers said business was lacklustre and trading volume said as much, with about 1.3bn shares changing hands. The FTSE 100 closed down 7.2 points at 6,496.6.

The switchback was well illustrated by Vodafone AirTouch, which moved from 323.5p to 334p in the morning and then proceeded to drift all the way back to 316p.

Among those stocks leaving the Footsie, security software specialist Baltimore Technologies managed an advance from 576p to 595p and telecoms group Thus was up 14p at 348p - a move of more than 4%. Rival telecoms firm Kingston Communications jumped from 661p to 700p, a move of almost 6%, while portable computing group Psion looked a relative laggard, up just 5p at 629p.

Among the Footsie newcomers, Bookham Technology, which makes kit for fibreoptic cables, slumped 237.5p to £37.37, and building materials group Hanson was down 12p at 476p. Ocean, the transport firm, slipped 5p to £11.84, while Scottish & Newcastle added 7p to 543p.

Elsewhere, engineering group Invensys, which is trying to turn itself into a hi-tech concern and recently emerged as the rescue bidder for Dutch software group Baan, shed 15.5p to 235p. Followers blamed a downgrade by US investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which has slapped an "underperform" rating on the stock.

The pressure on BSkyB continued after this week's partial stake sale by Germany's Kirch and the prospect of further stock coming on to the market from France's Vivendi. The shares fell a further 66p to £11.45.

Venture capital group 3i gained 92p to £13.75 as chief executive Brian Larcombe exercised options over 60,000 shares. Crucially, the accompanying statement indicated he was hanging on to the stock, but the low exercise price on the options means Mr Larcombe has an extra bundle of shares worth £700,000.

Chemex, a firm which was touted as a shell company for many years, but which is now working to develop its environmental chemistry business, slipped 1.25p to 7.75p after chairman Reg Pomphrett revealed that tough trading conditions had thrown the firm into the red during the first half of the year.

Financial services group Christie had to warn that profits will be no better this year than last. The shares slumped from 165p to 130p.

fields.headline: Mugabe's reign of terror
fields.standfirst:
The Conservative frontbencher wants international monitors to protect Zimbabwe's voters

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservative frontbencher wants international monitors to protect Zimbabwe's voters
fields.body:
Last weekend, in Matabeleland, southern Zimbabwe, I came across some of the most pitiful people I am ever likely to meet. They were Zimbabwe's "war veterans" - in reality members of the rural poor who have been whipped up into a state of greed and anger by Robert Mugabe's promises of free land and his tales of traitors, black and white, who are selling Zimbabwe out.

Those "veterans" spend their time hacking down trees in a vain attempt to carve out a smallholding on land so barren that no crops will grow on it. They own nothing more than the ragged shirts on their backs. Without schooling, employment or hope, they are the real victims of Mugabe's bankrupt regime.

Two things became clear in the two days I spent in Zimbabwe. First, it is obvious that the general election later this month will not be free or fair. It is being rigged. Any pretence to the contrary is misleading and self-serving. And second, most importantly for the immediate future, people from all walks of life opposed to Mugabe are in danger from violence after - as well as before - the election.

Voters in many parts of the country have already been cowed by Mugabe's state terrorism. His thugs have kidnapped, tortured and murdered opponents from the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), the main opposition party. And these intense and sudden bouts of violence have served as a warning to others.

Whites and blacks told us how units of Zanu-PF thugs have toured the country setting up mobile re-education units, where peasant farmers are corralled and then bullied or beaten into submission. People made it clear that this violence has been planned and controlled by Mugabe personally.

Although the heavies have done most of their dirty work already, there is a real danger that the violence will return, and a specific fear about the safety of opposition candidates and voters in about 10 key constituencies where Mugabe's most powerful cronies are standing. I gave a list of these seats to Robin Cook when I met him this week.

What is more, Zimbabwe's electoral rolls are works of fiction. Tens of thousands of younger voters have been removed because so many are fiercely determined to reclaim their country from Mugabe's vicious grip.

The real question remain ing is whether Zanu-PF's rigging the election will work.

Despite the naked abuse of power by Mugabe, the MDC still believes that it can win enough seats to provide a significant nucleus of opposition. The MDC's members are brave and resolute people, who risk their lives every day by speaking up for their beliefs.

So what can we do? Above all, I was repeatedly told that if Britain and other nations can ensure that election monitors will stay on after the election, people will be reassured that they can cast their votes without fear of reprisals.

Mugabe is hated, but Zimbabwean observers worry that the biggest block to a mass anti-Mugabe vote is fear that after the election he will unleash violence on his own people, as he did in 1985.

Members of the army's notorious fifth brigade, which carried out massacres in Matabeleland in the 80s, have already made public visits to towns and villages where support for the opposition is strongest. The message is chilling and clear. Areas that do not vote for Zanu-PF will be targeted for reprisals.

Britain should quietly co-ordinate a coalition of states and organisations - South Africa, the Commonwealth, the EU, and the US - to press for monitors to stay in the country for several weeks after the elections. In all likelihood, lives - perhaps the lives of Zimbabwe's new generation of leaders - depend on this.

Mugabe himself is immune to influence and diplomacy. But there are things that can be done. Only this week, the MDC has asked the outside world to freeze overseas assets of Mugabe and his cronies. I strongly agree. The world could also target senior members of Zimbabwe's regime with travel bans. They, including Mugabe himself, should be international pariahs if they continue in their present course.

There is also the question of what to do after the election. If Zanu-PF wins the election, and it is clear that the will of the people has been flouted, the Common wealth must move to suspend Zimbabwe forthwith.

Zimbabwe is not all gloom. The country is a success story waiting to happen. One woman I talked to reminded me that both blacks and whites were being struck off the electoral roll in equal numbers because both share a common view of the future, a future without Mugabe.

Africa's generation of Marxist nationalists is giving way. Some, like Mugabe, will not go quietly. The new world that is emerging - both in Africa and Europe - is a world of universal values of democracy, open economies and the rule of law. We need to do our bit to make sure that Zimbabwe can become part of this new world. So far, we have let it down.

 Francis Maude is shadow foreign secretary.

fields.headline: Opec
fields.trailText: Eurosceptics seeking a model of intergovernmental co-operation free of any hint of supranational infection could do worse than look at the 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Opec, as it approaches a crunch summit on June 21.
fields.body:
Eurosceptics seeking a model of intergovernmental co-operation free of any hint of supranational infection could do worse than look at the 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Opec, as it approaches a crunch summit on June 21.

If you can imagine an EU in which Germany hints it will pull out of a key piece of union strategy - say, the single currency - while the member state responsible for drafting the plan - France, for instance - breezily concurs, suggesting there is nothing automatic about the transition to the euro, then you have a rough idea of how Opec operates.

To be fair, Opec is a single issue outfit - and that has certain advantages, in that members can hate each other or even go to war with one another without being kicked out. But it works also in reverse, in that all differences tend to become oil differences.

The story so far: by January 1999, the price per barrel sank below $10. The cartel thrashed out a cuts package that worked. Last night, the price was above $27 and it regularly bobs above the $28 Opec ceiling, when an EU-style "thermostat" mechanism is supposed to raise quotas.

Except that it does not. The "swing" producer Saudi Arabia is sceptical of the whole concept of putting quotas on automatic pilot, and Venezuela - author of the scheme - has weighed in with the intriguing notion that the automatic pilot is not necessarily automatic.

So their excellencies the Opec energy ministers will meet in Vienna to decide whether the present healthy price is robust enough to take the sort of quota increase that will please the profligate United States, or is merely speculative froth that will be blown away once the taps are turned on.

The gloomiest view, that of analyst David Fleming, is that, given Opec's growing share of finite oil supplies, it does not matter much anyway. All Opec has to do is "chunter along", he said, and prices will rise. The reason is simple. "There are no more Alaskas, there are no more North Seas."

If you can imagine an EU in which Germany hints it will pull out of a key piece of union strategy - say, the single currency - while the member state responsible for drafting the plan - France, for instance - breezily concurs, suggesting there is nothing automatic about the transition to the euro, then you have a rough idea of how Opec operates. The cartel thrashed out a cuts package that worked. The "swing" producer Saudi Arabia is sceptical of the whole concept of putting quotas on automatic pilot, and Venezuela - author of the scheme - has weighed in with the intriguing notion that the automatic pilot is not necessarily automatic. webTitle: Tate & Lyle profits fail to sugar pill

fields.headline: Tate & Lyle profits fail to sugar pill
fields.trailText: Tate & Lyle, the sugar and starches group, yesterday gave its shareholders a bittersweet package to chew over.
fields.body:
Tate & Lyle, the sugar and starches group, yesterday gave its shareholders a bittersweet package to chew over.

On the positive side, profits were up, minority interests in two key subsidiaries have been acquired, and a way out of the disappointing Queensland sugar business has been found.

But the big negative was the news that there was no sign of an improvement in market conditions, especially in America where over-capacity in the sugar industry continues.

Group pre-tax profits rose 3.8% to £191m for the year to March 25. However underlying profits, before tax, reorganisation costs and exceptional items, were 30% ahead at £225m.

Larry Pillard, Tate & Lyle's group chief executive, said he believed significant efficiences would be achieved by buying out the minority interests in Amylum and Staley, the group's European and US starch businesses.

The group is paying £274m for the outstanding 36.7% of Amylum and 10% of Staley, both owned by CIP, a private investment company based in Luxembourg. The cash and shares deal will leave CIP owning 5% of Tate & Lyle.

Amylum, one of Europe's leading producers of cereal sweeteners and starch, operates mainly in France, Belgium, Britain, Spain, Holland, Italy and Greece. Tate & Lyle bought a third of the business in 1976 and effectively doubled its holding when it took control of Staley in 1988.

The British group has also agreed to sell Tate & Lyle Bundaberg, its wholly owned Australian sugar business. Mr Pillard said Bundaberg had been bought in 1991 in the expectation that deregulation of the Queensland sugar industry would enable it to be integrated into other group operations.

However recently introduced legislation meant that it was unlikely that enhanced returns from vertical integration would be available in the near future, he said.

With overall market conditions unlikely to improve, Tate & Lyle is relying on improved efficiency and reduction in costs to boost profits. Investors, however, remain unconvinced. The shares closed unchanged at 268p.

webTitle: Britain heads off EU blank tape tax

fields.headline: Britain heads off EU blank tape tax
fields.trailText: Plans to increase the price of blank video cassettes to compensate producers for lost revenue when people record films instead of buying them have been shelved, European Union diplomats said yesterday.
fields.body:
Plans to increase the price of blank video cassettes to compensate producers for lost revenue when people record films instead of buying them have been shelved, European Union diplomats said yesterday.

Britain was one of the fiercest opponents of the scheme pushed by France, Belgium and Italy as the best way of safeguarding film and programme makers' rights.

The proposal was part of a new EU copyright directive that is in the process of being finalised. But EU governments were reported to have struck a political deal yesterday on the legislation and to have agreed that Britain and others do not have to levy the tax.

"The odds are that this [deal] will go through," one official said. "The UK copyright regime will not need to be changed at all, and there will be no tape levies."

Diplomats said Britain had managed to persuade France and others that producers are already paid for their efforts by broadcasters such as the BBC, and that British consumers are making a contribution through the licence fee.

The fact that a consumer might build a collection of high quality recordings was irrelevant, Britain argued, because the originals still offered extra features. "This does not cause economic damage for the rights holder and this agreement is a real breakthrough," the EU official said.

fields.headline: Doctors condemn unrepentant Ledward
fields.standfirst:
Second consultant faces GMC inquiry

The General Medical Council
fields.trailText: The disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward was attacked by doctors and managers yesterday for a "breathtakingly disgraceful" defence of his years of botched surgery in which he claimed the NHS had lost in him a "first-class consultant".
fields.body:
The disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward was attacked by doctors and managers yesterday for a "breathtakingly disgraceful" defence of his years of botched surgery in which he claimed the NHS had lost in him a "first-class consultant".

His remarks, universally condemned as arrogant beyond belief, raise the temperature just days before Richard Neale, a second gynaecologist, is due to face the General Medical Council, charged with a catalogue of botched operations, sub-standard treatment and falsification of documents.

The Neale case raises very similar questions to the Ledward case about hospital managers' handling of suspect doctors. Mr Neale had his licence revoked by the Canadian authorities in 1985, yet went on to practise in the UK until he was suspended by the GMC last year.

In 1995 he was paid £100,000 by a hospital trust to leave and given a clean reference that enabled him to get work elsewhere.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, reacted with horror to the remarks of Mr Ledward, who was clearly unabashed by the damning report into his practice in Kent published last week by Jean Ritchie QC. Dr Bogle said he felt sorry for any of Mr Ledward's former patients or their relatives who were listening.

"It was arrogant, conceited and deluded, and it missed out the one thing that should have started that off - 'I'm sorry'," said Dr Bogle.

Andrew Foster, a director of the NHS Confederation, which represents hospital managers, said: "I did find that a quite breathtaking interview. But unfortunately one of the characteristics of seriously poorly performing doctors is that they do lack insight into their own performance - and then you get a very offensive interview like that."

The Ritchie report condemned hospital managers and medical staff for doing nothing to stop Mr Ledward practising when there were clear questions over his competence.

Clear parallels can be seen with Mr Neale's case. There have already been questions asked about the conduct of managers at the Friarage hospital in Northallerton, North Yorkshire, where Mr Neale worked for 10 years. The case is also likely to lead to more attacks on the embattled GMC, with questions over how much its officers knew about Mr Neale's Canadian history, and when they knew it.

Last night the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Ontario, which revoked Mr Neale's licence, told the Guardian that the GMC was informed by letter of the revocation at the time. "At the time, the process was that we informed the Medical Council of Canada and a notice was sent to all jurisdictions," said Jill Hefley of the college.

She said they received confirmation from the council that the letter had gone out to relevant authorities abroad, one of which would have been the GMC.

The GMC is expected to say it has no record of receiving such a letter. While its critics will make capital of the fact that it knew Mr Neale had been found unfit to be a doctor and did nothing, GMC officers are likely to say that they cannnot act on the basis of the findings of a tribunal abroad. A doctor's incompetence has to be proved in the UK before it can strike him off the register.

Mr Neale's licence was revoked in Canada after one of his patients died during an induced termination. She was 40 and high risk. He was found to have given her inappropriate drugs, one of which was not allowed in the hospital, and to have altered the medical record to show a dose 10 times less than the one he actually gave.

The Friarage hospital did not know of the Canadian verdict before Mr Neale was taken on, but it was told not long after. By 1993 there was unhappiness about the gynaecologist's work. It is understood the trust convened a panel to investigate and ended by demoting him. In 1995, Mr Neale was suspended. The trust wanted rid of him and gave him a payoff of £100,000 and a good reference.

Mr Neale went to work in Leicester as a locum, where he lasted only a matter of months, and then moved to the Isle of Wight.

It was one of his patients there who made the first official complaint against him to the GMC in February 1998.

Partly because of the publicity, including a Panorama programme, complaints began to flood in to the GMC: it is understood there have been 62, of which 14 were sufficiently robust to be heard in the hearings that will last at least four weeks.

Because of the large number of complaints, the investigation into Mr Neale has taken longer than usual. His suspension last September was only possible once the complaints had been approved by a prelimnary committee to go forward to the professional conduct committee.

Yesterday Mr Neale said: "From Monday, my future as a doctor is on the line. I have always maintained that I am a caring and competent surgeon.

"I have also never failed to express my regret for the distress and inconvenience suffered by those of any patients who experienced post-operative complications."

The GMC, which has embarked on a modernisation programme, may well attract flak for failing to investigate Mr Neale earlier.

In the past 10 years, it has struck off six doctors from Canada and the US whose licences were revoked abroad - in each case after carrying out an investigation in the UK.

webTitle: Avesco hits jackpot with stake in Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?

fields.headline: Avesco hits jackpot with stake in Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?
fields.trailText: At last there has been a homegrown jackpot winner on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?. Avesco, which has a half share in the company behind the hit television gameshow, yesterday said it had generated £1.9m in profit last year, and forecast substantial growth in the coming months.
fields.body:
At last there has been a homegrown jackpot winner on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?. Avesco, which has a half share in the company behind the hit television gameshow, yesterday said it had generated £1.9m in profit last year, and forecast substantial growth in the coming months.

The company's broker, Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, predicts the programme will throw off some £7m in profit this year for the group.

David Nicholson, Avesco's chief executive, said the company had only begun to scratch the surface of the po tential for merchandising.

The show has been an enormous success in virtually every market in which it has been launched and is regularly the top-rated show in the US.

It has been screened under licence in 26 countries including Spain, Australia, South Africa and Russia and options have been granted in a further 60 territories. A CD-ROM, produced and marketed in the US under licence to Disney Interactive, sold 1m copies in December alone.

In Britain, the first edition of the Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? book was top of the best-seller list for several weeks; the boardgame was completely sold out over the Christmas period; and more than 1,000 video games have been shipped to pubs and clubs. PC, PlayStation and Dreamcast versions will be launched in the autumn.

"We've hardly launched any merchandising outside Britain and the US, and the potential is phenomenal," Mr Nicholson said.

The success of the show has not been lost on the City - which has marked up Avesco shares threefold since the start of the year. Yesterday they closed 45p lower at 990p.

Avesco's interest in the show is held through a 49% stake in Complete Communications which owns Celador, the production company behind Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?.

Avesco paid only £713,000 for the stakeholding three years ago. "It was quite a bargain, with hindsight," Mr Nicholson said.

At a group level, Avesco reported pre-tax profits of £6.5m for the year to April compared with £5.2m during the previous 12 months. Revenues climbed from £42.3m to £57.6m. Avesco's other interests include corporate presentations, advertising screens and television studios - which led to the fortuitous meeting with Complete.

webTitle: Couple face trial for $1.5m mail scam

fields.headline: Couple face trial for $1.5m mail scam
fields.trailText: With pay of up to $600 (£395) a day, a job with the Irizarry alternative mail service had more going for it than carefree strolling from house to house taking in the fresh air.
fields.body:
With pay of up to $600 (£395) a day, a job with the Irizarry alternative mail service had more going for it than carefree strolling from house to house taking in the fresh air.

In fact, fresh air was the least of what the 16 operatives were taking in: it was their task to loot New York city mailboxes, a project that brought in more than $1.5m, according to prosecutors.

Ismael and Luisa Irizarry are accused of grand larceny, possessing forged cheques, falsifying business records, scheming to defraud and possession of stolen property - charges that could put the couple in jail for 15 years if they are found guilty.

"The brashness and high degree of organisation exhibited by the defendants was both unusual and alarming," said the district attorney for Queens, Richard Brown.

"They made use of everything," said a police source. "If they got a cheque, they cashed it. If it was a credit card application, they had their runners fill it out. And if it was just your mortgage bill, they put it into an identity database so they could use it later for an identity takeover - to apply for a credit card or open a bank account in a person's name."

Mr Irizarry, 28, and his 27-year-old wife would send their 16 employees out in pairs, targeting homes in the New York borough of Queens and affluent and middle-class neighbourhoods in nearby Long Island.

Their takings allegedly were spent on cars and homes in the Dominican Republic and Florida. But the scheme started to unravel when one of about 2,000 victims became suspicious.

Nicole Mercado Morton, 29, said that the first indication that anything was wrong came when she received a call from a bank. "They said 'We want to know if you tried to open an account with us a couple of weeks ago and can you verify your social security number'."

"The more I found out, the worse it got. You name it, it was being opened in my name."

Salvador Cheda, a lawyer representing Mr Irizarry, said: "The evidence against him would appear to be circumstantial at best."

fields.headline: Bangs per buck
fields.standfirst:
Plans for a European intervention force have been agreed in prinicple but voters don't like the idea of increased defence spending

The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Plans for a European intervention force have been agreed in prinicple but voters don't like the idea of increased defence spending
fields.body:
What do Eurosceptics, American Republicans and Nato general secretary George Robertson (speaking out yesterday in Brussels) have in common? They all believe in "Europe". Either it is a juggernaut bearing down on them or a thing with a mind of its own, attending, say, to collective defence. In fact national perspectives rule OK, especially when it comes to soldiers and the foreign policies they serve.

Defence and security show most clearly how fragile European aspirations can be. Despite the trappings - Javier Solana's appointment as high representative, the promise at last year's Helsinki summit to create a European intervention force - a common "identity" is painfully slow in being born.

The other day George W Bush's shadow national security adviser anticipated Robertson's speech to Nato defence ministers. Spending by European countries on defence had to rise, she said - Europe had to become more autonomous in security matters. (Neither spelled out "or else".) Backsliders will be driven - says Solana, Nato general secretary - by peer review: you show me yours and I will show you mine. "Member states would discuss collectively their contributions to the headline goal and debate how to make up any shortfalls."

That implies the existence of a common will not just to defend Europe (which Nato membership affirms) but to project force elsewhere.

Some countries believe it - the Dutch say arresting the decline in their defence spending shows their Europeanness. Elsewhere the European security picture cuts little ice with voters and politicians.

EU members signed up in Helsinki to a corps capable of speedy movement and intervention. By 2003 a force 180,000-strong, allowing 60,000 warriors to be mobilised at any one time, could deploy within 60 days; any given operation would be sustainable for at least a year. Rapid reaction units already exist in France, the UK and Germany. The problems surround the transformation of their defence posture to allow the Helsinki commitment to be met alongside Nato and other obligations.

The big European players have the men, as the chart shows. The problem is their quality, how they are armed, moved and supplied. The German Social Democrat - Green coalition pledged to cut defence. But defence minister Rudolf Scharping admitted to SPD members of the Bundestag that Germany's armed forces are not capable of serving Nato nor Europe in their present state. His solution is a big cut in manpower (though the Schröder government has just agreed women can take frontline roles), freeing up money for equipment. About 13% of German defence spending goes on weapons, compared with 27.5% in the United Kingdom and 24.4% in the US. German forces are, as a result, badly equipped. They have more soldiers - 60.1% of German defence spending goes on manpower compared with 39.2% in the UK. But many are conscripts who do not fight. (The last British conscript was recruited in 1960 and selective service was abolished in the US in 1973; France, the Netherlands, Spain, Italy and Belgium have recently de cided to end compulsory service.)

Privately, many Germans agree.

Solana has taken some tentative steps towards creating a Brussels version of the Cabinet Office's joint intelligence committee. Charles Grant's recent pamphlet, Intimate Relations (www.cer.org.uk), wondered if Whitehall could build "firewalls" to stop European allies gaining access to American intelligence. fields.headline: Driving ambitions
fields.trailText: Foot in the Door | Under The Sun: Taxi Dreams
fields.body:
Last night's Foot in the Door (BBC2) seems to be based on the story of the three little pigs. Only one little pig will make it.

Juliette, Rick and Eliot were competing for a job in advertising. The trial assignment was to publicise the New York lottery, and a trip to New York was thrown in.

Tim, the creative director, huffed and puffed and blew their first effort away ("It's crap"). In New York they still had nothing to show. Tim made throat-cutting noises. "It's a hatful of crabs at the moment. I'm buggered, basically. Why don't you get yourselves together and work on your own?" I had the greatest difficulty understanding anything Tim said, but that's creative people for you.

Juliette went out to solicit some vox pops. What would you do with 40 million dollars? A whiskery drifter, who looked (as Mr Connolly said during Billy's hippy phase) like a tramp keeking out of a hay loft, said "I would like to devote more time to my passion, paranormal exploration. I'd devote my time to exploring the borderlines of reality." An elderly man, asked the same question, said "Look, I have a son who just came into 100 million dollars."

I tell you, they're all out there on the sidewalks of New York and it's hard to say which is the sane one.

Rick, to whom I became increasingly attached, ordered a shop's entire stock of tinned tuna ("I'll have 'em all!") on the Woosterish grounds that fish is good for the brain. Bertie believed that Jeeves' brilliance was due to his seafood diet during shrimping holidays at Frinton, and it certainly seemed to work for Rick. Despite Tim's vibrant urging to steep himself in the city, he liked to watch TV. Which gave him the idea for a dot matrix basketball sign, apologising for the absence of a lottery winner who had gone to see his mother. "He should get here about five-ish. Sorry for any inconvenience." That is very English humour. Particularly the ish.

Juliette based her pitch on Jimi Hendrix's "Anything Is Possible" - which is very American. She is also a good-looking girl. She got the job.

At the Creative Circle Awards, Tim seemed on the brink of tears, as people often are at awards. "She has taken the first step through the door on, hopefully, the ladder of success." I shall never understand a word that man says.

It was hardly worthwhile coming home, as Under The Sun: Taxi Dreams (BBC2), which followed, was about New York's yellow cab drivers. In Jack Rosenthal's The Knowledge, a play about learning to be a London taxi driver, Nigel Hawthorne gave such a dazzling display of rage as the examiner, that he seemed to rise a foot above the floor, shooting flames from his feet. It was the sort of performance you remember half your life. If you'd seen it when you were born, you'd remember it all your life.

Becoming a cabbie in New York is much less strenuous. Sumon comes from Bangladesh. His driving is bad, but better than his sense of direction. As a grimly humorous passenger said after an eventful trip with Sumon: "You've got a way's to go, honey, but, first day on the job, you got me home. Good luck, Good luck to you especially," she added, looking hard at the cameraman, as if she didn't expect to see him again. Sumon's first day was also his last. The cab cost him 20 dollars more than he earned in fares. Though, in my opinion, his passengers offered a good 20 dollars-worth of entertainment value from the singing schoolgirls ("I am 16 going on 17") to the laconic men from cowboy country ("We're from Arizona. This is kinda strange to us." "Most definitely.") Passengers in yellow cabs are not a bit shy.

The cabbies are mostly immigrants taking the first step through the door on, hopefully, the ladder of success, as Tim would say. It was Christmas and their breath came white like ectoplasm. Rafik from Tajikistan with the face of a thousand progroms. Kwame, who, after 14 years, could afford to bring his family over from Ghana. You should have seen his beautiful wife's suddenly stricken face when she saw the Bronx. From their earnings Kwame supports an extended family in Ghana and Sharma funds a girls' school in North India.

Rafik took his family to Coney Island. He said: "To be successful you must forget. We have a lot of opportunities here. I see it now." The whole glittering fairground lay below. The Wonder Wheel went round.

fields.headline: DMGT freesheet steams into profit
fields.trailText: Metro, the free newspaper which has made a deep impression on the reading habits of commuters in London, has broken into profit nine months ahead of its target.
fields.body:
Metro, the free newspaper which has made a deep impression on the reading habits of commuters in London, has broken into profit nine months ahead of its target.

Daily Mail and General Trust, which has invested £20m in the launch of the freesheet in five cities, yesterday said the London edition moved into the black in February. Metro had attracted non-newspaper readers, said the publisher - although tellingly circulation of its paid-for London Evening Standard fell by 3% during the first half of its financial year.

"Metro has been a phenomenal success," said group finance director Peter Williams. "There are probably limits to the market for a Metro-style paper, but we haven't got any where near them yet." The London paper launched in April 1999 and Glasgow, Birmingham, Manchester and Edinburgh editions were added in November.

The non-London editions, along with continuing new media investment including the Charlotte Street website for women and This Is Money, proved a drag on half-year profits. A combined £36m was ploughed into them in the six months to the end of March.

The company, which publishes the Mail newspapers as well as a stable of regional papers, recorded a 16% drop in pre-tax profits to £72.4m. Revenues were 14.5% at £863.1m.

Mr Williams added the company would not be averse to a flotation of news provider ITN, in which it has a 20% stake. DMGT shares fell 6p to £10.74.

fields.headline: NTL buys £11.5m Leicester City stake
fields.trailText: The media industry's carving up of English football continued yesterday when cable company NTL took a 9.9% stake in Premier League club Leicester City.
fields.body:
The media industry's carving up of English football continued yesterday when cable company NTL took a 9.9% stake in Premier League club Leicester City.

NTL is paying £11.5m for the stake plus an additional £1m for the granting of rights over Leicester's media interests, including a potential pay-television channel and website.

The media group now has stakes in four clubs after negotiating similar deals with Aston Villa, Middlesbrough and Newcastle. The investment has been agreed just weeks ahead of the crunch decision to award broadcasting rights for the Premier League over the next three years.

The Premier League clubs were yesterday attending their annual meeting, where chief executive Richard Scudamore presented options for the next stage of the bidding process - sealed bids or an auction.

Geoffrey Hamilton-Fairley, chief executive of NTL subsidiary Premium TV, denied the deal had any bearing on the Premier League rights.

Officials, however, are sufficiently concerned to be considering a limit on any single investor holding a stake in more than six clubs, which would be enough to veto a League decision.

BSkyB, which began the trend and has the most to lose in the League negotiations, has stakes in five clubs. NTL is rumoured to have bid up to £1.75bn for the main package of 66 live games plus a second of 40 pay-per-view games.

fields.headline: Procter & Gamble chief quits
fields.trailText: Procter & Gamble, the biggest household products group in the US, yesterday issued its second profits warning this year and announced the retirement of its chief executive after only 17 months in the job.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble, the biggest household products group in the US, yesterday issued its second profits warning this year and announced the retirement of its chief executive after only 17 months in the job.

Durk Jager, P&G's president and chief executive, will stand down after 30 years with the group on July 1. The 57-year-old is thought likely to be awarded a significant retirement payout after receiving a pre-promotion package of $1.3m (£858,000) in 1998.

Wall Street analysts held Mr Jager responsible for aggressively pushing sales growth of P&G's top lines and attempting a rapid transformation of the sometimes lumbering group after his appointment as chief executive in January 1999.

He was also forced to terminate takeover talks with pharmaceuticals groups Warner Lambert and American Home Products earlier this year because of fears regarding the strategic direction of P&G, whose brands include Ariel soap powder, Pampers nappies and Crest toothpaste.

Mr Jager was criticised at the time for a lack of communication skills. On being appointed chief executive, he attempted a shake-up by calling for revenues to be doubled by 2005 to more than $70bn a year. As part of his attempt to revitalise the group he announced swingeing job cuts and the closure of 10 plants last year - at the same time spending heavily on new products.

P&G yesterday blamed the poor performance of some of those new products for lower than expected earnings and sales. It said that competitve pressures and "reduced marketing support" in key business divisions would lead to flat earnings in the fourth quarter to the end of June, compared with a year ago.

Analysts had expected an increase of between 15% and 17%. The company also down graded its outlook for next year, with core earnings expected to rise only 11% to 13% from a lower base.

In a statement yesterday Mr Jager said it had been a "personal decision" to step down. "It's unfortunate our progress in stepping up top line sales growth resulted in earnings disappointments," he added.

The group appointed Alan Lafley, head of its global beauty division as well as of north America, to replace Mr Jager with immediate effect.

Mr Lafley, 52, blamed the pace of change at P&G for the results - yesterday he said: "In hindsight it's clear we changed too much, too fast."
