fields.headline: Sir Peter Youens
fields.standfirst: Banda's colonial confidant in Malawi's freedom struggle
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Youens, who has died aged 84, was a senior colonial civil servant who occupied a crucial position in the turbulent years of increasing African nationalist activity in pre- and post-independence Nyasaland (now Malawi). He was secretary to the new country's first prime minister, Hastings Banda, and to his cabinet, having earlier been deputy chief secretary (1953-63).
fields.body:
Sir Peter Youens, who has died aged 84, was a senior colonial civil servant who occupied a crucial position in the turbulent years of increasing African nationalist activity in pre- and post-independence Nyasaland (now Malawi). He was secretary to the new country's first prime minister, Hastings Banda, and to his cabinet, having earlier been deputy chief secretary (1953-63).

In fact, for much of this time he was acting chief secretary, while the holder of the post was either on leave or acting as governor. It was in this capacity that his relationship with Banda was vital, for Youens was not only chief adviser to the British governor of Nyasaland, but the filter through which negotiations with Banda, who had returned home in 1958 after four decades away, were undertaken.

The discussions centred on internal self-government, cessation from the then Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, and independence, which took place in 1964. Banda came to value Youens's role and, even after stormy meetings, the two men invariably had tea and toast together and departed on good terms.

Two factors explain Banda's confidence in Youens. When, during the lawlessness following Banda's return, the British governor contemplated detaining nationalist leaders, Youens recommended that Banda himself should remain free. This far-seeing proposal was rejected, but it would have enabled the British to negotiate with Banda without extremist pressures from his colleagues.

Again, when Banda was released from detention in Southern Rhodesia in April 1960, it was Youens who secretly flew to the then capital, Salisbury, released him and accompanied him back to Nyasaland to meet the governor and Iain Macleod, the secretary of state for the colonies.

Banda never forgot this. Indeed, he asked for Youens to become chief secretary that November, but the governor preferred a colleague from Northern Rhodesia. However, as soon as Banda was in a position to get his own way, he had Youens appointed as his top civil servant.

Two examples illustrate the importance of their relationship. Firstly, when Banda was released, a dozen hardcore detainees remained in prison. Banda demanded their freedom, but the governor resisted, fearing that violence would escalate. Youens, then acting chief secretary, patiently pointed out to Banda that if he called on his followers to stop the violence, the detainees might be released. Indeed, when, shortly afterwards, the governor announced the releases, this was accompanied by an appeal for peace and calm from Banda.

On another occasion, only a few weeks after independence, Banda dismissed, or accepted the resignation of, all but one of his cabinet ministers. A period of violence followed, during which pro-Banda youths attacked Malawian civil servants, who were generally opposed to Banda. The civil servants in Zomba, the capital, then went on strike. Banda was away in the north of the country, rallying support, and none of his newly-appointed ministers dared be seen in Zomba.

As the violence escalated, and in the absence of any ministerial guidance, Youens went in person to persuade the civil servants to end the strike. His courageous step was successful; they returned to work the following morning.

Peter Youens was educated at King Edward VII's school, Sheffield, and Wadham College, Oxford, where he read law, played rugby and won a boxing blue. After graduating in 1938, he spent two years in the navy, before going to Sierra Leone, where he rose to become colony commissioner and a member of the legislative council. In 1951, he transferred to Nyasaland. He was knighted in 1965, and left Malawi the same year.

Back in Britain, Youens became an executive director of Lonrho for three years, and then a partner with the executive recruitment consultants, John Tyzack and Partners, work he deeply enjoyed. He returned to Lonrho in 1981 and stayed until retirement in 1994, after which he was able to indulge his love of opera, theatre, rugby and reading. His wife, Diana, died in 1990; he is survived by his daughters, Stephanie and Sarah.
Colin Baker

 Peter William Youens, colonial civil servant, born April 29 1916; died May 6 2000

On another occasion, only a few weeks after independence, Banda dismissed, or accepted the resignation of, all but one of his cabinet ministers. A period of violence followed, during which pro-Banda youths attacked Malawian civil servants, who were generally opposed to Banda. The civil servants in Zomba, the capital, then went on strike. Banda was away in the north of the country, rallying support, and none of his newly-appointed ministers dared be seen in Zomba. As the violence escalated, and in the absence of any ministerial guidance, Youens went in person to persuade the civil servants to end the strike. His courageous step was successful; they returned to work the following morning. Peter Youens was educated at King Edward VII's school, Sheffield, and Wadham College, Oxford, where he read law, played rugby and won a boxing blue. After graduating in 1938, he spent two years in the navy, before going to Sierra Leone, where he rose to become colony commissioner and a member of the legislative council. In 1951, he transferred to Nyasaland. He was knighted in 1965, and left Malawi the same year. Back in Britain, Youens became an executive director of Lonrho for three years, and then a partner with the executive recruitment consultants, John Tyzack and Partners, work he deeply enjoyed. He returned to Lonrho in 1981 and stayed until retirement in 1994, after which he was able to indulge his love of opera, theatre, rugby and reading. His wife, Diana, died in 1990; he is survived by his daughters, Stephanie and Sarah. Colin Baker  Peter William Youens, colonial civil servant, born April 29 1916; died May 6 2000

fields.headline: Nuclear dump plan for Russia
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: A controversial plan to use Russia, a country struggling to cope with the consequences of its ageing nuclear arsenal, as a storage depot for 10,000 tonnes of the globe's spent nuclear fuel is being actively developed in Washington and Moscow.
fields.body:
A controversial plan to use Russia, a country struggling to cope with the consequences of its ageing nuclear arsenal, as a storage depot for 10,000 tonnes of the globe's spent nuclear fuel is being actively developed in Washington and Moscow.

Five countries - Taiwan, South Korea, Mexico, the Netherlands and Switzerland - have expressed interest in sending the fuel to Russia to be placed in specially constructed stores where it would be kept safe and prevented from being used for nuclear weapons.

As part of the deal, the Russians would agree to halt plans to commercially reprocess spent fuel, assuring that it would make no more plutonium available for nuclear weapons.

Minatom, the Russian nuclear power agency, suggested in April a 20-year moratorium on reprocessing in exchange for the US helping Russia to build a dry store. Russia has the expertise to deal with spent fuel, but it has no money to build the storage facility.

The plan would generate an estimated $15bn (£10bn) in fees during the first 10 years. This foreign exchange would provide the funding to build enough space for the 10,000 tonnes of fuel and solve the problem of what to do with Russia's increasing stockpile of fuel from reactors - believed already to be 14,000 tonnes.

The idea has influential backers in the US and Russia, including endorsement from senior environmental figures such as Tom Cochran, the director of nuclear programmes at the National Resources Defence Council (NRDC), but some green groups are appalled by the idea.

"The world has huge problems with nuclear waste but sending it to Russia is not the answer," Michael Mariotte, the executive director of the Nuclear Information Resource Service, said. "The plan really represents the ultimate in 'not in my back yard' thinking."

Vladimir Slivyak, of Russia's Ecodefence, an umbrella group of 300 environmental organisations, said: "We are shocked by the proposals which have nothing in common with environmental principles and unethically promote the interests of western nuclear industry, whose main concern is to get rid of its nuclear waste."

Mr Slivyak said Yevgeny Adamov, Russia's minister for nuclear power, has included the building of 23 nuclear reactors in Russia as part of the programme.

"These reactors are dangerous and not needed. Energy-efficient technologies do not exist on an industrial scale in Russia," Mr Slivyak said. "Development of renewable sources of energy would provide Russia with a great amount of energy as well. But efficiency and renewables do not have great lobbyists as one of the richest corporations of the world - Minatom - has."

Still, the NRDC's Dr Cochran remains squarely behind the initiative. "It would stop reprocessing in Russia for at least a couple of decades; it would aid nuclear non-proliferation by removing fuel from countries like Taiwan. It would also solve storage problems for countries in earthquake zones. The income stream [it would create] could cure a lot of problems in Russia."

He said the five countries had expressed an interest in the scheme because it would solve their problems on what to do with spent nuclear fuel.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 In a desperate bid to avert any repeat of Wednesday's fiasco, we have been seeking professional help for Mr Tony Blair. "I heard about his trouble, and I'm willing to help," says Bernard Manning, a forthcoming subject of Channel 4's Heroes Of Comedy. "You'll never get on until you learn how to handle hecklers. If it's an elderly crowd like that, he could try: 'I advise you to take back your library books in the morning, madam, and don't buy the Christmas tree just yet'." I see. Anything else? "What about: 'Don't worry, love, I was like that after me first pint, you'll get used to it'?" From the opposite end of the stand-up spectrum, Mark Thomas offers his guidance. "It would be brilliant if he'd said: 'Why don't you f*** off back to your jam?' " Would that really be the best way to regain control of the situation? "No, but it would have been a lot funnier. Normally when you're losing a crowd, you admit it. You tell the truth. But Mr Tony can't do that, he's a politician." So what would you have done? "Acted like the German U-Boat captain in Dad's Army," Mark counsels, "pulled out a notebook and gone: 'Vot is your name?' "

 When my colleague Richard Adams calls Downing Street to discuss some tutorials for Mr T, an entirely new tactic is noted. "Just hold on," a press officer says . . . and 10 minutes later he is still holding on. How amazingly clever.

 In the wake of the ban on breastfeeding, further news of parliament's efforts to make women feel at home come to our attention. Yesterday lunchtime, my colleague Lucy Ward, who is expecting a baby next month, was waiting for an MP in the members' lobby. The several green leather benches are reserved for members, but with not an MP in sight, and after standing for 10 minutes, Lucy asked one of the buckle-shoed gumbies if she might sit down while she waited. Certainly not, came the answer. Please, said Lucy, I'm almost eight months pregnant. Absolutely not. But what if I faint? In that case, he replied, "I would take you outside".

 A boost for David Winnick as he chases the Stupidest MP 2000 title. A reader faxes a page from Lern Yerself Scouse, edited by Fritz Spiegl. "Winnuck or winnick," reads one entry, "daft or dotty."

 Startling medical news from Wapping: alopecian Sun editor David Yelland has been cloned. When we ring for a chat, his PA Lorna assured us that he (or rather a version of him) is not there, on account of "travelling back from New York". Meanwhile, Sun staff were convinced they had spotted what we presume to be the copy earlier. We wanted to talk to one of the Davids about the front page concerning a prone Lord Frederick Windsor, who had apparently crashed out at a party. Is it always fair game for ridicule, we hoped to ask, when someone visibly the worse for wear is prostrate on the floor? And if so, is it the responsible journalist's duty to expose it for public merriment? Perhaps we will return to this soon.

 The Times's Euro 2000 coverage gets off to a flier, with a large picture of four England players on page eight yesterday. "Shades of former glory," ran the caption above a story about squad members modelling suits worn by their 1966 counterparts, "Tony Adams, David Beckham, Alan Shearer and David Seaman in suits made by Burton . . ." Excellent work. Admittedly the four were, in order, Robbie Fowler, Phil Neville, David Beckham and Paul Ince. Still, Burton was right.

 Speaking of football, I pose this philosophical question. Which is morally preferable: England progressing to the quarter finals after beating Portugal and Romania but losing to Germany? Or - the Samson option - losing the other two games but beating the Germans, crashing out of the tournament but taking the Hun with us? Your theories are welcome.

fields.headline: Biblical message found in Pokemon
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Having taken over the lives of the nation's 10-year-olds, the Pokemon phenomenon now appears to be invading the portals of the Church of England.
fields.body:
Having taken over the lives of the nation's 10-year-olds, the Pokemon phenomenon now appears to be invading the portals of the Church of England.

Ceaseless in its quest for relevance, the church is planning to point up the Christian message lurking behind the stories of the little Japanese cartoon characters.

Anne Richards, theology secretary of the church's Board of Mission - responsible for spreading the gospel in the community - has written a paper extolling the morality of the likes of Ash and Mewtwo, characters from the recent Pokemon film which was panned by critics and is now being endured by parents nationwide.

"I had to ask myself whether this obsession with Pokemon could be used to speak into any of the stories and narratives the church holds dear," she explains. "At first I found this very difficult, since so much of Pokemon is concerned with fighting battles and outwitting opponents, but I have changed my mind after having seen the movie."

Now, where parents may see only a craze for buying and swapping cards showing the 150 varieties of pocket monsters which appear to exist only to kill each other, Dr Richards discerns a tale of Christian sacrifice and redemption.

Relating the film's tale of the wicked Mewtwo, who seeks to capture all human beings and to clone Pokemons and set them to fight each other, Dr Richards detects a parable about the pointlessness of force and the importance of the love relationship.

There is a familiarity too in the film's subplot involving Ash and his pet pokemon Pikachu. "The film highlights the love between them ... for him [Ash] there is only the one, original Pikachu, perfectly loved and known," said Dr Richards.

When Ash is killed trying to stop a fight involving Mewtwo, the theologian sees a further message. "Mewtwo is completely changed by Ash's sacrifice," she said. "All evil is gone from him and he is redeemed. The storm outside is calmed ... he flies off to start a new world. He has found new answers to the questions: 'Who am I?' and 'What am I for?'"

"My own children found obvious Christian parallels with all this. They were impressed by the death and resurrection sequence and the fact that at the heart of it all was love."

Dr Richards is not the only Christian to have embraced the Pokemon world. David Tate, a youth leader at a church in St Paul's Cray in Kent, has devised a "safe alternative" to the card game using biblical characters.

But Mark Greene, director of the Institute of Contemporary Christianity has warned against the church getting carried away with a "knee jerk reaction to something that is successful".

He told the Church Times: "Teaching children to deal with potentially addictive obsessions is always a good thing. There are limits, but it is parents that have to set them."

fields.headline: Joan Bourne
fields.standfirst: Labour stalwart who made policy and suffered prejudice
fields.trailText: Joan Bourne, who has died aged 90, was a behind-the-scenes socialist and unsung heroine of the labour movement, whose work and ideals helped to give successive Labour governments the policies that made them distinctive. She was also a pioneering feminist before it became fashionable.
fields.body:
Joan Bourne, who has died aged 90, was a behind-the-scenes socialist and unsung heroine of the labour movement, whose work and ideals helped to give successive Labour governments the policies that made them distinctive. She was also a pioneering feminist before it became fashionable.

Her principles were a mixture of nature and nurture. The daughter of a daffodil grower who became an Anglican vicar, she was born in an area of rural poverty in Simpson, Buckinghamshire. In 1921, her family moved to Reading, where she attended university, reading mathematics on a scholarship. She graduated in 1930, a year of rapidly increasing unemployment.

Joan's main interest was already in leftwing politics and, as an early member of the Labour Students' Federation, she met Arthur Greenwood, minister of health in the second Labour government, who became her friend, mentor and employer.

After two years' teaching, she moved to London to work in local government, and became a councillor in Hammersmith before getting a job in the then embryonic Labour party headquarters at Transport House. With the coming of the second world war, she was promoted to the key job of London women's organiser.

As the postwar election approached, the mobilisation of the female vote assumed a special importance, and Joan worked hard to ensure the maximum turn-out on polling day. She also encouraged women party members to make their voices heard, to gain the confidence to sit on committees, and to stand as councillors. Meanwhile, her friendship with Greenwood - who, as a member of the war cabinet, had commissioned the 1942 Beveridge report on social insurance - heightened her interest in developing Labour's welfare state programmes.

She also worked closely with Aneurin Bevan, Jennie Lee and Edith Summerskill, focusing especially on child benefit and maternity care. A natural sympathiser of the Labour left, she could sing all the verses of both The Red Flag and The Internationale, had an, at times, uncritical regard for the Soviet Union, and backed CND in its various phases.

In 1949, Joan's situation was dramatically altered when an affair with John Taylor, the Scottish Labour party organiser, led to the birth of an illegitimate daughter. There was no public scandal, and Taylor, who was married with two other children, went on to become MP for West Lothian. Joan, on the other hand, suffered the full weight of disapproval from a highly puritanical Labour party, at a time when unmarried mothers were a group stigmatised by society at large.

Some colleagues were supportive - Nye and Jennie, in particular - but others, including members of the women's committee, were the reverse, and Joan was forced to move from her cherished women's organiser job to a position in the research department. Here, she was given a Home Office brief, and worked in the 1950s and 1960s on a wide range of issues, from arts policy to prison reform.

The prevailing attitude at the time required that a respectable woman who fell from grace should not keep her baby. It was a mark of Joan's strength of character that she held out against this. Defying critics, she brought up her daughter Jenny (named after Jennie Lee) lovingly and successfully, while continuing to hold a political job. She also made single mothers her personal cause, working voluntarily for the National Council for the Unmarried Mother and her Child. In 1971, she published Pregnant And Alone, pressing for increased state support, and condemning the social and emotional pressure commonly used to force mothers to give up their babies for adoption.

Meanwhile, her Labour party work flourished. In 1963, she acted as secretary to the working party on crime prevention, chaired by Lord Longford, that led to the appointment of the Seebohm committee, and to a liberalisation of policy on crime later in the decade. In 1967, she became a temporary civil servant, working with Longford and other cabinet ministers in the Wilson government. After her retirement, she continued to follow Labour politics as a fervent grassroots activist.

Modest, passionate, humorous, serious-minded - but not in the least naive about the motivations of others - Joan had a gift for friendship and a dogged loyalty both to people and causes. In some ways, she belonged to a particular type of female trailblazer of her generation - an educated woman working in a man's world for what she believed in, who never allowed her fiercely-held convictions to be crushed by thoughtless male colleagues or by female ones who, too easily, accepted the status quo. There are many new-millennium women, enjoying a freedom they take for granted, who owe a debt to Joan Bourne and others like her.

She is survived by her daughter.
Ben Pimlott

fields.headline: Brigadier Stephen Saunders
fields.trailText: The shooting in Athens of Brigadier Stephen Saunders, at the age of 52, is the loss of a fine soldier, professionally able and intelligent, and a good family man. He was a natural leader and popular with the men under his command.
fields.body:
The shooting in Athens of Brigadier Stephen Saunders, at the age of 52, is the loss of a fine soldier, professionally able and intelligent, and a good family man. He was a natural leader and popular with the men under his command.

Saunders was born in Farnborough, Hampshire, the son of an army officer. He was educated at Peter Symonds school (Christ's Hospital) in Hampshire, and joined the army in 1965. After Sandhurst, he was commissioned into the Duke of Edinburgh's Royal Regiment (Berkshire & Wiltshire).

Shortly after joining his battalion in Germany, Saunders was selected for an in-service degree and read geography and economics at Bristol University, where, in 1970, he took part in an expedition sponsored by the Royal Geographic Society to a remote part of the Hindu Kush, travelling there and back overland. In 1993, he was made a fellow of the Royal Geographical Society.

Saunders served in Berlin, Cyprus, West Germany and Northern Ireland. In Londonderry, in 1979, he and his men came under fire from terrorists hidden in a nearby building. Despite short range, the gunmen missed. Following up the incident, Saunders's company recovered a rifle with ammunition. Later, he was mentioned in dispatches.

In 1981, Saunders went to staff college and then as a staff officer to HQ Northern Ireland. Returning to his battalion as a company commander, he served with the United Nations in Cyprus. He was promoted lieutenant-colonel on the staff in 1985, before commanding his battalion in Northern Ireland and Hong Kong. During this command, his humanitarian and travel interests were put to good use in arranging beneficial training exercises for his men in Malaysia, South Korea, Hawaii and Australia.

In 1990, he was part of a British military training team in Zimbabwe, on loan to the country's army, and responsible for training and operations. On promotion to colonel in 1992, he was again in Northern Ireland, this time as deputy commander headquarters 8th brigade, in Londonderry, where he was awarded the Queen's Commendation for valuable service. His tact, diplomacy and charm earned him a tour from 1993-96 in Australia, as military attaché with the British defence liaison team in Canberra, and as defence adviser to Papua New Guinea.

In March 1997, Saunders spent a year as military assistant to the force commander United Nations Iraq Kuwait Observer Mission (UNIKOM), during which time he travelled throughout Iraq and frequently visited Baghdad for discussions. In 1999, he was promoted brigadier, and appointed defence attaché to the British embassy in Athens.

Cheerful and enthusiastic, Stephen Saunders was an excellent communicator, perceptive and logical in argument, and endlessly patient. His fine sense of humour allowed him to make his point firmly and effectively in an acceptable manner. He loved sport, especially skiing and hockey, in which he regularly represented his battalion.

He is survived by his wife, Heather, and their two daughters.
IG Spence

He was educated at Peter Symonds school (Christ's Hospital) in Hampshire, and joined the army in 1965. After Sandhurst, he was commissioned into the Duke of Edinburgh's Royal Regiment (Berkshire & Wiltshire). Shortly after joining his battalion in Germany, Saunders was selected for an in-service degree and read geography and economics at Bristol University, where, in 1970, he took part in an expedition sponsored by the Royal Geographic Society to a remote part of the Hindu Kush, travelling there and back overland. In 1993, he was made a fellow of the Royal Geographical Society. Saunders served in Berlin, Cyprus, West Germany and Northern Ireland. In Londonderry, in 1979, he and his men came under fire from terrorists hidden in a nearby building. Despite short range, the gunmen missed. Following up the incident, Saunders's company recovered a rifle with ammunition. Later, he was mentioned in dispatches. In 1981, Saunders went to staff college and then as a staff officer to HQ Northern Ireland. Returning to his battalion as a company commander, he served with the United Nations in Cyprus. He was promoted lieutenant-colonel on the staff in 1985, before commanding his battalion in Northern Ireland and Hong Kong. During this command, his humanitarian and travel interests were put to good use in arranging beneficial training exercises for his men in Malaysia, South Korea, Hawaii and Australia. In 1990, he was part of a British military training team in Zimbabwe, on loan to the country's army, and responsible for training and operations. On promotion to colonel in 1992, he was again in Northern Ireland, this time as deputy commander headquarters 8th brigade, in Londonderry, where he was awarded the Queen's Commendation for valuable service. His tact, diplomacy and charm earned him a tour from 1993-96 in Australia, as military attaché with the British defence liaison team in Canberra, and as defence adviser to Papua New Guinea. In March 1997, Saunders spent a year as military assistant to the force commander United Nations Iraq Kuwait Observer Mission (UNIKOM), during which time he travelled throughout Iraq and frequently visited Baghdad for discussions. In 1999, he was promoted brigadier, and appointed defence attaché to the British embassy in Athens. Cheerful and enthusiastic, Stephen Saunders was an excellent communicator, perceptive and logical in argument, and endlessly patient. His fine sense of humour allowed him to make his point firmly and effectively in an acceptable manner. He loved sport, especially skiing and hockey, in which he regularly represented his battalion. He is survived by his wife, Heather, and their two daughters. IG Spence  Brigadier Stephen William John Saunders, soldier, born July 26 1947; died June 8 2000

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Maurice Plaskow writes: I was closely associated with the work of Dr Joan Tough (Obituary, June 3). When I was a curriculum officer at the Schools Council in the 1970s, her enthusiasm, energy and commitment were infectious, and motivated many hundreds of teachers.
fields.body:
Maurice Plaskow writes: I was closely associated with the work of Dr Joan Tough (Obituary, June 3). When I was a curriculum officer at the Schools Council in the 1970s, her enthusiasm, energy and commitment were infectious, and motivated many hundreds of teachers.

The insights and practical guidance, revealed through her close observation and reflection on how children learn and develop language, were exciting, especially when teachers recognised the effectiveness of her analysis and suggestions for helping children with not just literacy, but their ability to negotiate meaning.

We should not lose sight of the body of excellent work done in this field, not least through Schools Council projects of the 1970s.

webTitle: Cook sees legacy of the dirtiest of wars

fields.headline: Cook sees legacy of the dirtiest of wars
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, stood in heavy rain at the Murray Amputee and War Wounded camp in the Sierra Leone capital yesterday and shook his head.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, stood in heavy rain at the Murray Amputee and War Wounded camp in the Sierra Leone capital yesterday and shook his head.

Facing him were four men in T-shirt and shorts, sheltering under a single umbrella. They had only one hand between them with which to hold the handle. "I just can't understand it," Mr Cook said.

A walk through the camp, which holds 2,000 people who have fallen victim to the rebel practice of spreading fear by amputating limbs, provided Mr Cook with constant reminders of this grisly civil war in which Britain is heavily involved.

He bent down to talk to Aminate Koroma as she fed her eight-month-old daughter, Mariatu, who was wearing a pink hat and dress. Mariatu's left arm was missing, cut off by a Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels when she was three months old.

Mr Cook, the first British minister to visit Sierra Leone since British troops went in last month, said: "It beggars belief that anyone would deliberately chop off the limb of a child of only a few months. What purpose has been served by that?"

The overwhelming message he heard was that the people in the camp wanted British troops, scheduled to leave next Thursday, to stay.

One of the men under the umbrella was Hassam Bah, who said his son was killed by the RUF and stuffed down the toilet. He waved his stump round the camp saying: "All of these people want the British soldiers to stay. They are a proper army and we are afraid."

The same message was conveyed to Mr Cook elsewhere in Freetown. Members of his convoy spotted a woman drumming up signatures for a petition urging British soldiers to remain. The petition, which ran to tens of thousands, was presented to Mr Cook.

When Britain first sent troops to Sierra Leone, both the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence repeatedly stressed that it was a limited mission to get British and other European nationals out. Questions from journalists about "mission creep" were dismissed - British soldiers would be out by mid-June.

But yesterday Mr Cook, moved by his experience, said: "I'd like those who have spent the last three weeks moaning about mission creep to have visited that camp."

And the message he took to the Sierra Leone president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, when they met in Freetown was that Britain is in for the long haul.

It was Mr Kabbah who gave the clearest statement yet of British intentions. Asked how he felt about the pull-out next week, he replied: "The British are not going."

Two British ships will stay offshore, in sight of Freetown, and the 600 marines scheduled to leave next week will be replaced by around 200 military trainers from the Royal Anglian. But Mr Cook disclosed yesterday that only about a third of the 200 will be involved in training. The rest will have other duties.

A British official said these duties would be interpreted "imaginatively", continuing the pattern of the last month - bolstering the Sierra Leone army and the UN force.

The estimate of one British official was that the involvement would last for at least 18 months and very probably much longer unless there was an unexpected collapse in RUF morale. The objective was to help the Sierra Leone army and the UN win back the crucial diamond producing areas from the rebels.

As well as the 200 Royal Anglians, there will be 90 military advisers and 78 civilians, who occupy key posts in the police, judicial service and government departments.

Britain will also lead a behind-the-scenes drive to try to limit the damage being done by Sierra Leone's neighbour, Liberia, whose president, Charles Taylor, has been supporting the RUF, swapping arms for diamonds.

The British government yesterday sponsored a resolution at the UN for sanctions against illicit diamonds from Sierra Leone, most of which go through Liberia.

This is Mr Cook's chance to restore credibility to his battered ethical foreign policy as there is no strategic, economic or political interest for Britain in this engagement.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Longbridge report leaked

The taskforce appointed by the government to look at the future of Rover's Longbridge site warns today that 4,000 jobs will go despite the Phoenix takeover, a leaked copy of its study shows. The final report of the taskforce predicts difficult times ahead and recommends that the West Midlands seeks to diversify. The Birmingham complex is expected to shed 1,000 jobs with a further 3,000 lost among its suppliers. The total is a fraction of the 24,000 at risk if BMW had shut the plant but the wages of the workers hit are above average, and the taskforce predicts social problems for individuals and areas affected. Phoenix is urged to concentrate on higher income-yielding sports and executive cars in order to improve its survival prospects.
fields.body:
Longbridge report leaked

The taskforce appointed by the government to look at the future of Rover's Longbridge site warns today that 4,000 jobs will go despite the Phoenix takeover, a leaked copy of its study shows. The final report of the taskforce predicts difficult times ahead and recommends that the West Midlands seeks to diversify. The Birmingham complex is expected to shed 1,000 jobs with a further 3,000 lost among its suppliers. The total is a fraction of the 24,000 at risk if BMW had shut the plant but the wages of the workers hit are above average, and the taskforce predicts social problems for individuals and areas affected. Phoenix is urged to concentrate on higher income-yielding sports and executive cars in order to improve its survival prospects.

Wales makes Hyder appeal

The £464m bid from US group Western Power Distribution for Welsh multi-utility Hyder suffered a blow yesterday when the Welsh national assembly urged Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, to intervene and refer it to the competition commission.

The assembly's move, made after talks with WPD executives, followed an unusual intervention from Peter Hain, foreign office minister and Neath MP, urging Mr Byers to refer the WPD bid.

Mr Hain said the US bid would lead to a break up of the Hyder group.

Belgium phone auction hopes

The Belgian government will sell four third-generation mobile phone licences by auction this year in hopes of raising 40bn-60bn Belgian francs (£627.6m-£941.4m), compared with the British government's £22.5bn haul.

The government will use a consultant to determine the selection procedure in July for possible bidders.

The telecoms operators currently holding Belgian GSM licences - Belgacom's Proximus, France Telecom's Mobistar and KPN-Orange - have expressed concern that an auction would force them to overpay for the next generation licences.

Rolls-Royce in £1bn deal

Rolls-Royce yesterday said its joint venture Rolls-Royce Turbomeca will supply its RTM322 engines to up to 399 military NH90 transport helicopters in a contract worth £1bn. Rolls-Royce engines will power up to 219 helicopters for Germany, 160 for France and 20 for the Netherlands.

fields.headline: Bomber paused for survey
fields.trailText: David Copeland took part in a survey on policing as he waited in a park to plant a nail bomb in Brixton, the Old Bailey was told today.
fields.body:
David Copeland took part in a survey on policing as he waited in a park to plant a nail bomb in Brixton, the Old Bailey was told today.

As he clutched the live bomb in a sports bag, he answered questions about officers on the beat. Then, he told police in taped interviews, he walked to a spot near Brixton market in south London, and left the bomb close to a bus stop.

It exploded soon afterwards injuring 40 people.

On the tapes, which were played to the jury, Copeland said he found himself in Brixton 90 minutes early because he "messed up" the time.

He said he did some window shopping, went to a library to see if it had a lavatory and into a little park.

He added: "Someone came and gave me an interview about how good police were in the local area. I was just bored. I do not know if it was a police officer. It was like a questionnaire.

"He asked if there were enough bobbies on the beat. It was some sort of survey. He asked a lot of questions but I never signed anything."

Copeland said he targeted a predominately gay pub in Soho, central London, because he knew it would upset Tony Blair and other politicians.

Copeland, 24, an engineer working on the Jubilee Line underground extension, has admitted causing explosions in Soho, Brick Lane in east London, and Brixton during April last year, in which three people were killed and 129 injured.

He is being tried for murder after the prosecution refused to accept his pleas of guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

The trial continues today.

fields.headline: Steely look for Queen Mother
fields.trailText: A new portrait sculpture of the Queen Mother, aiming to show shrewd and steely qualities under the lines left on her face by nearly 100 years, was unveiled at St Paul's Cathedral last night by her granddaughter, the Princess Royal.
fields.body:
A new portrait sculpture of the Queen Mother, aiming to show shrewd and steely qualities under the lines left on her face by nearly 100 years, was unveiled at St Paul's Cathedral last night by her granddaughter, the Princess Royal.

The bronze is meant to honour her as one of the two great surviving public images of the second world war. She is renowned for her visits as queen to bombed cities all over Britain.

The other image is the cathedral itself, photographed during the war standing in smoke and flames while German bombs fall around it.

As the centenary of the Queen Mother's birth on August 2 approaches, the bust was financed by the Friends of St Paul's, whose patron she has been since 1952. The group grew out of the St Paul's wartime fire watch, formed by volunteers who saved Christopher Wren's building by patrolling its labyrinthine crannies to see that every stray spark was extinguished at once.

Yesterday the sculptor, Marin Jennings, who had seven sittings with her, said: "She is often represented in a slightly saccharine way but this does not reflect her true nature. There is gristle in her personality."

fields.headline: Madonna, queen of arts
fields.trailText: Of one thing we can be sure. Virginia Woolf - novelist, feminist, essayist, philosopher, diarist, icon - never starred in an even halfway decent rock video. But if she had, you can be pretty sure that she'd have donned a T-shirt and jeans, let her hair hang loose, sharpened up her dance routines and told her deadweight husband Leonard to pick up his tweed jacket and get the hell out of it. She would, in a nutshell, have looked and behaved exactly like Madonna in the landmark American Pie video.
fields.body:
Of one thing we can be sure. Virginia Woolf - novelist, feminist, essayist, philosopher, diarist, icon - never starred in an even halfway decent rock video. But if she had, you can be pretty sure that she'd have donned a T-shirt and jeans, let her hair hang loose, sharpened up her dance routines and told her deadweight husband Leonard to pick up his tweed jacket and get the hell out of it. She would, in a nutshell, have looked and behaved exactly like Madonna in the landmark American Pie video.

Sadly, Virginia Woolf never got to meet Madonna, never got to boogie on down like crazy all thru' the nite to such 20th-century classics as Holiday, Material Girl and Papa Don't Preach, never got to penetrate to the very heart and soul of Clinton's America. If only Woolf hadn't filled her pockets with stones that fateful December day and taken her final walk into the teeming currents of the River Ouse, she might have lived long enough to catch Madonna make her thrusting, dynamic debut with Like A Virgin on Top of the Pops.

Who exactly is Madonna and - perhaps more importantly - what does she signify? One thing she is most definitely not, and that's just another girly pop singer with a weak voice and nice tits. I mean - really! How can you say that? It's that attitude that makes me hopping mad. How can anyone possibly say that of her? How can you just sit there without bothering to check your facts or even think of the wider cultural implications and expect me to listen while you just slag off one of our major cultural icons of the past thousand years? I mean, really. I'm sorry, but if that's your bloody attitude, I'm leaving. I'm sorry but I am.

Let's deal in hard facts for a change. FACT: Madonna is born in 1958 in Rochester, Michigan. FACT: in 1984 she enjoys her first number one hit with Like A Virgin. FACT: within the space of a decade, she has become the key cultural icon of her time, a high-powered feminist intellectual capable of reinterpreting masculine sex-role fantasies in an ironic mode and thus empowering not only herself but all women into a complete reassessment of the feminist role from passive/submissive to active/dominant. FACT: in 1999, she wins a Grammy for best original song from a motion picture for her contribution to Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me, an iconic feminist movie that effectively re-examines and revolutionises the role of women in late 20th century on-screen entertainment.

With keynote number one hits like I Wanna [Shake My Butt] (1987), Look At Me - I Wear [No Panties] (1991) and F-F-Fellatio! (1995), hugely successful concert tours such as the Bosoms Out For The Boys World Tour (1987) and her 1988 major autobiographical work of feminist iconography, Madonna In The Nude From Funny Angles, Madonna was to prove conclusively that the great post-war feminist battle had been won - and from now on it would be possible for young women wearing the barest minimum of clothes to make it big in the male-dominated world of entertainment.

In Madonna, I see a woman in a continual state of development, both artistic and personal, a woman who has engaged in a lifetime study of the struggle between men and women; and has recently embarked on a far-reaching examination of fame and its effects. Her insights into fame are indeed extraordinary: she has taught us something about the meaning of fame that we would otherwise never have guessed - the sobering fact that to be famous means being well known to a very large number of people you may never have met.

And having played almost every role imaginable - from sex-goddess to vamp to femme fatale to goddess-of-sex - she is now astonishing us afresh by turning her back on fame. Two years ago she issued that most intensely personal statement, Mama, I Don't Wanna Be Famous No More [Disco Mix] in which she appeared on satellite in her new role as sex-goddess in front of more than 500,000,000 people worldwide and sang - exquisitely, painfully - these heartfelt lyrics that were to signal a new beginning:

"Mama, I don't wanna be
famous no more

So I'll take off all my

clothes

And lay my brassiere on

the floor

(Chorus) So let's do it right

here, baby, Right here on my bed!

Let's do it right here?

Can't get you outta my

head!"

With this statement, Madonna has become the Whole Woman. With these words, she is saying that she now stands independent of frankly sordid male fantasies, belonging not to the world, but to herself. If only Virginia were still alive, I swear she would be the first to applaud.

fields.headline: Assassination in Athens
fields.standfirst: Greece has failed to be tough on terrorism
fields.trailText: The pitiless, execution-style murder of Stephen Saunders, the British defence attaché based in Athens, raises broad questions about the safety of British diplomats posted overseas, the difficulty of rooting out small, ideologically driven groups which use violence to achieve their ends, and the commitment of successive Greek governments to combating terrorism at home and abroad.
fields.body:
The pitiless, execution-style murder of Stephen Saunders, the British defence attaché based in Athens, raises broad questions about the safety of British diplomats posted overseas, the difficulty of rooting out small, ideologically driven groups which use violence to achieve their ends, and the commitment of successive Greek governments to combating terrorism at home and abroad. But first and foremost, this is an awful human tragedy. Brigadier Saunders was a career diplomat and family man who had by all accounts served his country well. The widespread revulsion expressed yesterday, by the Greek prime minister Costas Simitis, by Tony Blair and by the Nato chief, George Robertson, among many others, will be of little consolation to his widow, Heather and to his teenage daughters, Nicola and Catherine. They will wonder, along with the rest of us, why their man had to die.

Was Brig Saunders an easy target, when compared for example with heavily guarded American diplomats? His white Rover car, although unmarked, would have been readily identifiable by the two men on a motorcycle who rode up alongside him on Kifissias Avenue and fired several times through the front passenger window. British diplomats, businessmen and even a Royal Navy warship have been targeted in previous attacks by November 17, the group held responsible for yesterday's atrocity. So why, on this occasion, was Brig Saunders so lethally vulnerable?

November 17, which became active in 1975 when it killed the CIA station chief in Athens and has since murdered 22 other people, is a known, well-established threat. Its crude anti-capitalist, anti-American jingoism is a twisted legacy of Greece's 1970s struggle against militarism and fascism. This alone could have led its equally warped members, thought to number a mere half dozen or so, to pick on Brig Saunders as a symbol of "foreign oppression". Perhaps the murder was timed to coincide with the climactic anniversary of Nato's Kosovo campaign (deeply unpopular in Greece); was in protest at Greece's growing EU integration (against which November 17 has issued regular polemics) or at the continued US and Nato military presence in Greece; or even was prompted by Britain's refusal, repeated this week, to return the Elgin Marbles, supposedly a great emblem of Greek nationhood.

But in truth, attempts at rational explanation are probably pointless. Sick killers such as these, steeped in their many, odious crimes, abandoned reason many years ago. This very political dysfunction, reinforced by obsessive secretiveness and clan-like personal ties, is perhaps the main reason why no member of November 17 has ever been caught, let alone convicted. This is not a problem unique to Greece. In any modern, urban society, the difficulties of snaring such fanatics are notorious.

All the same, the Greek record on fighting terrorism, whatever its origin or cause, is outstandingly pathetic. A US report this week accused the country of "not fully cooperating" with international attempts to defeat terrorism. The US state department recently identified Greece as "one of the weakest links in Europe's efforts against terrorism". Yesterday, the US repeated its call for a "tougher stance", while Geoffrey Hoon, the defence secretary, demanded that no effort be spared to find the killers of Brig Saunders. The Greeks say, as always, that they are doing all they can. But nobody believes them. If they really expect to host a safe, successful Olympics, they have a lot of work to do before 2004.

fields.headline: Off the ball
fields.trailText: You reiterate the allegation by Jack Straw that "maverick Tories and a pusillanimous Conservative front bench" blocked legislation to stop hooligans from travelling when it was introduced last year (Football hooligans put on notice, June 6). This is not true.
fields.body:
You reiterate the allegation by Jack Straw that "maverick Tories and a pusillanimous Conservative front bench" blocked legislation to stop hooligans from travelling when it was introduced last year (Football hooligans put on notice, June 6). This is not true.

The Football (Offences & Disorder) Act 1999 was a private members bill introduced by the Conservative MP Simon Burns. It allows passports to be removed from anyone made the subject of an international banning order by magistrates. Senior Labour backbenchers as well as Conservative members expressed reservations about extending restrictions to people without convictions for violence. Both government and opposition agreed that a private members bill was not the ideal vehicle.

However, I made it clear the Conservative party would support such a measure in a government bill in government time. The home secretary has had a year in which to bring forward legislation.
John Greenway MP

fields.headline: Plus ça change ...
fields.trailText: As Dr Michael Austin points out (Letters, June 8) the problem with increasing consultants' salaries to encourage them to work harder within the NHS is that it is likely to have the opposite effect; more time spent with families instead of in the operating theatre. The answer is to pay consultants more, but pay them per operation performed.
fields.body:
As Dr Michael Austin points out (Letters, June 8) the problem with increasing consultants' salaries to encourage them to work harder within the NHS is that it is likely to have the opposite effect; more time spent with families instead of in the operating theatre. The answer is to pay consultants more, but pay them per operation performed. This is the only way that we can correct the perverse incentives created by a public sector based on salaried employees existing alongside a private sector based on fees for service.
Prof Julian Le Grand
London School of Economics

One of the activities of the woman obsessed with hospital life (Report, June 7) involved finding empty beds in which to sleep. She should immediately apply for a job in the Department of Health.

London mwalker2@dircon.co.uk

Richard Corbett MEP (Letters, June 7) thinks God Save The Queen is a good anthem for Britain as a whole. Perhaps he finds the piece so tedious he never makes it through to the later anglocentric verses.

Banbury, Oxon philbloo@uk.packardbell.org

How about the theme from the Archers?
Darren Price
Sheffield

I see the New Order, (Guardian supplement on website use, June 8) is much like the Old Order. Every photo and advert contains a male image. Do you not have anyone with a responsibility for equal opportunities?
Helen Kay
Edinburgh hkay@kaycee.demon.co.uk

The ice-cream kiosk by Greenwich pier has no problem with apostrophes (Letters, June 7) in its warning to "Beware of bag knickers".

fields.headline: Scotland's sound and fury
fields.trailText: Trevor Royle (Wreckers of democracy, June 8) seems to have a misconceived notion of democracy...If defenders of gay rights in Scotland will just get off their backsides and make their numbers felt, the Scottish politicians (like all politicians) will respond to the pressure.
fields.body:
Trevor Royle (Wreckers of democracy, June 8) seems to have a misconceived notion of democracy. Like many Europeans, it appears he's come to believe that democracy is a system in which people and their representatives do wonderful, progressive things and nothing else. Democracy is about means and processes, not ends and legislation. The majority may well favour wicked ends, as appears to be the case with Section 28 in Scotland. That is not the wrecking of democracy - merely the triumph of wrong over right. If defenders of gay rights in Scotland will just get off their backsides and make their numbers felt, the Scottish politicians (like all politicians) will respond to the pressure.

Royle gives credence to that old canard that the left is helpless if the right spends more money. If that were true, left-of-centre causes would never win. Supporters of repeal obviously weren't ready for the pro-Section 28 campaign and they are lazily blaming anyone but themselves. Now that Brian Souter, Cardinal Winning et al have revealed their hands, it's time for their opponents to get out and do some work - and mere complaining does not qualify as work.
Andrew Hirsch
Bainbridge Island, Washington, USA andrewhirsch@uswest.net

Three cheers to Trevor Royle. Having moved down from Scotland five years ago to work in London, I'm increasingly embarrassed by the loudness of its small-minded minority. If it's not the bigoted nonsense of Souter (shame on you too, Cardinal) then it's Margot "Where are the columns?" MacDonald on how pressing on with the wonderful new parliament building will bring an end to life as we know it. Come on Scotland - start talking sense. As a protest, I might even support England in the football next week.
Tim Findlay-Coulson
London

webTitle: Plea for the forgotten army of carers

fields.headline: Plea for the forgotten army of carers
fields.trailText: My mother was diagnosed with MS in 1986. After my father died suddenly in 1991, my mother's illness worsened and she began a slow decline. My sister was 15 and I was 18. We looked after our mother for the best part of nine years, as friends and family turned their backs on us. Apart from a brief spell in respite every three months, we had no help at all .
fields.body:
My mother was diagnosed with MS in 1986. After my father died suddenly in 1991, my mother's illness worsened and she began a slow decline. My sister was 15 and I was 18. We looked after our mother for the best part of nine years, as friends and family turned their backs on us. Apart from a brief spell in respite every three months, we had no help at all .

Eventually it became too much and social services took over. They brought in a private agency of carers. Most of them had very little training and had to be shown by us how to use the hoist, manage the catheter, etc. When they did bother to turn up things would go missing. Even the batteries in the door-bell went walkies. My mother was often discovered sitting in the lounge, in total darkness, waiting for someone to put her to bed.

I am not condoning Raymond Bouldstridge's actions, but I understand the horror of his circumstances (He only wanted to end his wife's pain, June 7). Anybody can walk off the street and become an agency carer. I am convinced that my mother's appalling treatment shortened her life. The army of forgotten carers save the government millions each year, and they are taken for granted. It is disgraceful that Mr Bouldsridge was treated in such a way.
Richard Berger
Bournemouth Rberger@bournemouth.ac.uk

I don't think Raymond Bouldstridge should not have been prosecuted for trying to end his wife's life. However, there's clearly more to this story. Health and safety guidelines now prohibit employed carers from lifting someone's full body weight without the aid of a hoist. This is because there have been so many disabling back injuries. Social services have to balance their responsibilities to their clients with those to their employees.

One factor in Mr Bouldstridge's refusal to have a hoist installed may be that government funding for social services anticipates that councils will charge for services. But, whether for financial or other reasons, he would not have a hoist installed, the service was suspended and the social worker is now being made to seem a monster. Is it any wonder that it is so difficult to recruit social workers?
Lesley Misrahi
London

fields.headline: Sad song
fields.trailText: In her relief at the release of her daughter (Letters, June 7) Mrs Goldwyn should have remembered that no decent government would ever have imprisoned Rachel in the first place just for singing a well-known song. Instead, her letter reads very much like a plea on behalf of the junta.
fields.body:
In her relief at the release of her daughter (Letters, June 7) Mrs Goldwyn should have remembered that no decent government would ever have imprisoned Rachel in the first place just for singing a well-known song. Instead, her letter reads very much like a plea on behalf of the junta.

In the context of such a regime, her phrase "ethical involvement" is a contradiction in terms. One wonders what "ethical involvement" with Hitler might have meant. She speaks of "the poor people who rely on the tourist industry" as if the whole country were a mere holiday destination. Above all she assumes that she, rather than Aung San Suu Kyi, knows what is good for Burma. I hope to see an answer from Rachel.
Gerry Abbott
Manchester

webTitle: Blair's political jam with the WI

fields.headline: Blair's political jam with the WI
fields.trailText: I was a delegate at the Women's Institute meeting at Wembley (Heckled, jeered, booed, June 8). The problem started because the acoustics were very poor making it hard to hear what Tony Blair was saying. He should have been warned to make a shorter speech, but this does not excuse the behaviour of some of the audience. The WI claims to be non-political but discusses and votes every year on three resolutions which start "We urge the government to ..."
fields.body:
I was a delegate at the Women's Institute meeting at Wembley (Heckled, jeered, booed, June 8). The problem started because the acoustics were very poor making it hard to hear what Tony Blair was saying. He should have been warned to make a shorter speech, but this does not excuse the behaviour of some of the audience. The WI claims to be non-political but discusses and votes every year on three resolutions which start "We urge the government to ..."

I was ashamed to be a WI member when in the afternoon the same women who had been so rude to the prime minister laughed and applauded Gyles Brandreth for a saucy and slightly amusing act of pure trivia.
Jean Wood
Hitchin, Herts wood1@which.net

I cannot understand why an organisation like the WI, that has always been apolitical, should consider inviting a prime minister to address its members, especially when, on the whole, they are Tory-biased. As a keen member of the WI for many years, I was very proud of its campaigning history. Yesterday I was disgusted at its loutish behaviour. It would surely have been more telling and dignified to receive the speech in stony silence.
Helen Keating
Gatehouse of Fleet, Kirkudbrightshire

Were they hoping for a talk on caring for baby?
Jean Machell
Stockton-on-Tees

It's a safe bet that any organisation which describes itself as "apolitical" is stuffed full of Tories. WI branches are often little more than the jam-making section of the local Conservative Association. A slow handclap and the odd heckles hould be viewed in contrast with the divisive politics of successive Conservative governments. I recall, inner-city riots, violent and costly industrial disputes and frequent protest marches.

In common with many other lifelong Labour supporters, I have nagging doubts about the big tent-style of politics, but things should be kept in proportion. The government continues to be seen as both competent and popular and it will take more than a slow handclap from our natural opponents to derail the New Labour project.
Andrew Furlong
Kirkby Mallory, Leics
afurlong@icheme.org.uk

It is a sign of our strange times that a "respectable" women's organisation heckles and jeers a politician it has invited to address it and then it is the politician who is widely held to blame. But perhaps nothing has really changed and the WI, like the rest of Middle Britain, is what it always has been beneath the surface - intolerant, bad-mannered and provincial.
Tim Shelton-Jones
Brighton, E Sussex

When the WI heckle and walk out they are respectable pillars of the middle class. When teachers do the same ...
Mark Hellen
London
m.hellen@euroseek.com

It is New Labour's mindset, seen in its unwillingness to respond positively and forcefully to Hague's racist rabble-rousing over asylum seekers that has led to Tony Blair's humiliation. New Labour must understand that speeches based on focus-group findings are insufficient, that they must refuse to be held hostage by the cheap populism of Hague, the Mail and the Sun, and that in the end a political leader must lead politically.
Peter Nicklin
Newcastle upon Tyne
peter.nicklin@newcastle.ac.uk

Mr Blair and his spinners got what they deserved. But didn't Downing Street realise there would be more Tory women at Wembley than at the Tory party conference?
Joe Hennessy
London

Having watched, with great admiration, the Guardian's successful attempts to discredit the Tories and help to rid the country of their sleaze and incompetence, I am now bemused as to why you are doing your best to get them back in power again? I know many other readers are equally baffled by the almost incessant attack on the government, such as your headline on the WI, playing daily into the hands of Hague, Portillo and Widdecombe. The nightmare of a far rightwing Tory government is now a possibility; many of your readers would never forgive you should you play a part in that nightmare becoming a reality.
Roger Hall
Shrewsbury
PlantPot21@aol.com

Booed by the Women's Institute. I've ticked that off on my checklist for credibility with traditional Labour supporters. Still lots to go, but well done, Tony. Suggest the state pension's link to inflation next.
Dan Lloyd
Bristol

Blair could have fared worse. What if the glam WI calendar girls had all got their kit off in protest?
Geoff Woollen
Glasgow

Blair's courtship of the WI was doomed from the start as he seemed to mime the words of Jerusalem. A dead ringer for Redwood in Wales in fact.
Dennis Ruston
Newbold Coleorton, Leics

A WI government? Why not?
Nigel Baldwin
Portsmouth

webTitle: Girl of 12 must give up her baby

fields.headline: Girl of 12 must give up her baby
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old girl who received money from the Roman Catholic church in Scotland to enable her to keep her baby has been ordered to give the child up for adoption.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old girl who received money from the Roman Catholic church in Scotland to enable her to keep her baby has been ordered to give the child up for adoption.

The girl, who is understood to have learning difficulties, is said to be devastated after a court in Exeter last week approved a custody application by social workers in Torbay, Devon, forcing her to hand over the infant.

The girl, who is in foster care, cannot be identified for legal reasons.

Her case sparked controversy last year when it emerged that the church-backed Pro-Life Initiative had provided financial support during her pregnancy.

The girl, who was 12 at the time, was the youngest person to have received money from the scheme, which was set up three years ago by the leader of the Roman Catholic church in Scotland, Cardinal Thomas Winning, to provide financial and practical support to young pregnant women.

Co-ordinators of the scheme denied the payment was tantamount to a bribe to stop the 12-year-old having an abortion.

They said that the girl was determined to keep the baby and that her father had approached them for help because he could not afford to support her.

Abortion law reformers yesterday renewed their criticism of the Pro-Life group's payments.

Jane Roe, campaign manager of Abortion Law Reform Society, said it had been clear from the beginning that any 12-year-old girl would find it very hard to bring up a child even with a great deal of family support. "Our real concern was that the church offered money for something which was not in the girl's best interests and I don't think they looked very carefully into the circumstances of this case before they gave that help."

Roseann Reddy, who runs the Pro-Life group, was unavailable for comment yesterday. But a spokesman for the Catholic church in Scotland defended the decision to protect the unborn child.

"We don't make any comment on people who come to us for help. We don't set about judgment. We are there to help to save life," he said.

Torbay council last night refused to comment about the case.

The girl, who is understood to have learning difficulties, is said to be devastated after a court in Exeter last week approved a custody application by social workers in Torbay, Devon, forcing her to hand over the infant. The girl, who is in foster care, cannot be identified for legal reasons. Her case sparked controversy last year when it emerged that the church-backed Pro-Life Initiative had provided financial support during her pregnancy. The girl, who was 12 at the time, was the youngest person to have received money from the scheme, which was set up three years ago by the leader of the Roman Catholic church in Scotland, Cardinal Thomas Winning, to provide financial and practical support to young pregnant women. Co-ordinators of the scheme denied the payment was tantamount to a bribe to stop the 12-year-old having an abortion. They said that the girl was determined to keep the baby and that her father had approached them for help because he could not afford to support her. Abortion law reformers yesterday renewed their criticism of the Pro-Life group's payments. Jane Roe, campaign manager of Abortion Law Reform Society, said it had been clear from the beginning that any 12-year-old girl would find it very hard to bring up a child even with a great deal of family support. "Our real concern was that the church offered money for something which was not in the girl's best interests and I don't think they looked very carefully into the circumstances of this case before they gave that help." Roseann Reddy, who runs the Pro-Life group, was unavailable for comment yesterday. But a spokesman for the Catholic church in Scotland defended the decision to protect the unborn child. "We don't make any comment on people who come to us for help. We don't set about judgment. We are there to help to save life," he said. Torbay council last night refused to comment about the case.

webTitle: Rethink probable on plans for Stonehenge

fields.headline: Rethink probable on plans for Stonehenge
fields.standfirst:
Stonehenge Campaign (for free access)
The Complete Stonehenge site
fields.trailText: The government may be forced to rethink its plans for Stonehenge, abandoning the proposed new visitor centre and building a far longer and more expensive road tunnel under the site, following publication of a much delayed management plan.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The government may be forced to rethink its plans for Stonehenge, abandoning the proposed new visitor centre and building a far longer and more expensive road tunnel under the site, following publication of a much delayed management plan.

Successive governments, English Heritage, which owns the stones, and the National Trust, which owns thousands of surrounding acres, have been struggling for 20 years to resolve the problem of Stonehenge, where the visitor facilities have been condemned by the Commons public accounts committee as "a national disgrace".

The plan's emphasis on the importance of the entire site, not just the area around the stones, could cause havoc for the highways agency, which may be forced to rethink its proposed road tunnel across the site. Both government and local authorities are bound to consider the management plan in all future planning decisions.

The management plan has been prepared for the government by an expert committee, after a public consultation process. It was required to produce the plan by Unesco as Stonehenge is ranked among the most valuable and sensitive sites in the world, along with the Taj Mahal and the pyramids.

Archaeologists and environmentalists welcomed the plan as their best weapon yet against the highways agency proposals. The agency is proposing a two kilometre tunnel, with entrance portals outside the saucer-shaped plain around the stones, but still within the world heritage site.

The objectors are demanding a tunnel twice as long, which would pass under the entire site. They are also demanding a bored tunnel, instead of the highways agency's cheaper "cut and cover" version, involving digging a trench across the landscape and then filling it in over the tunnel roof.

The highways agency estimates its tunnel at £125m, and the bored tunnel at £300m.

The management plan does not explicitly back the long tunnel, but repeatedly stresses the unique importance of the entire site, a 5,000-year-old ritual landscape littered with thousands of ancient monuments apart from the stone circle.

The plan backs proposals to return the land to open chalk downland grazing, and says that farmers will have to be compensated for abandoning arable farming and deep ploughing.

It also stresses that the site must be protected from noise and light pollution from traffic, which the objectors believe would be impossible with the shorter tunnel.

Local archaeologist Kate Fielden, who represented the Council for the Protection of Rural England at consultations on the plan, demanded yesterday that the road scheme, which she called "hugely damaging", should be abandoned.

The plan may also force reappraisal of the location of a proposed new visitor centre. It says that profits from a "world class" centre should be spent on managing the site, which almost certainly kills off the chances of a major commercial operator taking it on.

A source in the Stonehenge management group said the plan would place such tight restrictions on the visitor centre, and the possible profits, that it was "highly unlikely" any commercial operator would take it on. It is believed that several potential operators, including the Tussauds group, have examined the proposals and concluded that the sums do not stack up.

Geoffrey Wainwright, former chief archaeologist at English Heritage, and a member of the Stonehenge steering group, said yesterday: "At last we have agreement, after dozens of site visits, months of consultation with all the interest groups, four drafts and some pretty major amendments. We now have a consensus on how to proceed."

A spokesman for the highways agency said the road proposals were still at "a very early stage". Consultants were appointed in March to produce detailed plans by 2002, with construction hoped to begin in 2005.

fields.headline: To the wall
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
Northumberland

Did you know that you cannot call yourself a true Northumbrian until you have walked Hadrian's wall and visited the wild white cattle at Chillingham? Both are unique and irreplaceable. The wall seemed to be safe enough when I walked it last month and the cattle remain, as they were thousands of years ago, untamable. The park wall, wickedly pointed horns, uncertain temperament and wild independence of these hardy cattle, as well as the curiosity value attached to them since the reign of George III. have ensured their survival as a pure strain for centuries.

Herdsman Austin Widdows has been with cattle all his life and can take visitors as close to the herd as prudent although he stays upwind and if one of the beasts looks threatening everyone retreats to a safe distance. If you want to see the wild cattle you can either walk up the track to the hut at the entrance to the park or the warden will take you in the landrover. There are currently 48 beasts, with six calves born this year. One survived only two weeks because the mother was young and in experienced and despite her baby bellowing she had not got the sense to get to her feet to let it feed. Last year a heifer calf was born without a tail, an extraordinary phenomenon. That too died this spring. "Mutants never survive," said the warden. "Nature kills them off, deformities in a herd like this one are just not acceptable, a tail in a wild beast is a vital appendage. We did a post mortem and the calf had a belly full of hay but failed to thrive."

The warden enjoys taking visitors into the park and it is a beautiful place for an interesting walk with stunning views south to the Cheviots. He told me that school parties are a pleasure to lead but some holiday children are a nightmare. Some of the children who come with their parents expect to be allowed to kick footballs about in the park. "We had one eight-year-old boy who was quite paranoid about walking on grass," said Austin. "He came from Manchester and had been told to keep off grass by his mum because of dog dirt. Here of course there is sheep shit - so he wouldn't put a foot down. He had to be carried."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Dairy link to prostate cancer
Cutting out dairy foods may protect men against prostate cancer, according to research published yesterday. Scientists found men eating a vegan diet, which excludes meat and dairy products, had reduced levels of a chemical linked to the disease. Earlier studies suggested the growth factor IGF-1, which helps regulate cell growth, might play key roles in both prostate and breast cancer. The study carried out among 696 British men found vegans had IGF-1 levels 9% lower than meat eaters and 7% lower than vegetarians. Levels of testosterone, also linked to prostate cancer, were similar for all diet groups.

A burglar who broke into a house tuned into Radio 4 rather than a local station, it emerged yesterday. The intruder at the home in Worthing, West Sussex, switched from one of the local stations while stealing goods worth £3,000.

Soliders go after drugs test
Eleven soldiers based at Fort George barracks, near Inverness, are to be dismissed from the army after testing positive for ecstasy and cannabis, it was confirmed yesterday. The troops, all privates serving with the the Black Watch, were among those who were subjected to a random test last month.

Eight vie for Grant's seat
Eight candidates had thrown their hats into the ring when nominations closed for the June 22 byelection at Tottenham, north London, caused by the death of Labour MP Bernie Grant.

A fine wine for £24,200
An 1811 bottle of the claret Chateau Lafitte, the greatest vintage of the 19th century, fetched £24,200 at a wine sale at Christie's yesterday.

fields.headline: Nurse 'murdered paraplegic husband'
fields.trailText: A nurse murdered her paraplegic husband by deliberately injecting him with a massive dose of insulin, Birmingham crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A nurse murdered her paraplegic husband by deliberately injecting him with a massive dose of insulin, Birmingham crown court heard yesterday.

Senior ward sister Deborah Winzar, 36, used her medical knowledge to kill her husband, who was paralysed from the chest down following a road accident, the jury was told.

Dominic McCarthy, who was 34, died in Hinchingbrooke hospital, Huntingdon, on February 9 1997, after lapsing into a coma at their home in Stonely, Cambridgeshire, on January 31.

There was no reason for Mr McCarthy, a departmental manger in a drop-in centre for disabled people in Peterborough, to have insulin in his body, the court was told.

Stephen Coward QC, prosecuting, said: "If the defendant, knowing what she did about drugs and their dangers, deliberately injected into her husband such a quantity of insulin as to give the readings found, then her intention is clear - it was not an accident.

"It was a deliberate use of a substance to render someone either completely incapacitated or dead."

The jury heard that while Mr McCarthy lay in a hospital bed, a machine used to pump a sedative into his body "malfunctioned" twice while Winzar was visiting. Mr Coward said on February 2 a nurse found it switched off. Two days later another nurse noticed air in the pipe.

Winzar, a senior ward sister at Kettering general hospital, denies murder.

The court heard that Mr McCarthy, who had a three-year-old son, Tadgh, was not a diabetic and there was no reason for him to take insulin.

Blood tests showed he had high levels of insulin in his body and low levels of the protein C-peptide. A healthy body would normally have equal levels of each.

Mr Coward said: "If at the end of all the evidence you come to the conclusion that there was no natural medical explanation for the difference between the insulin level and C-peptide level, then you are forced to conclude that the massive quantity of insulin ... had to come from outside the body."

The jury heard there was no evidence that Mr McCarthy was suicidal, that he enjoyed life and was not negative about his disability.

Mr Coward said that he used the "significant compensation" he received after his accident to buy a house which was modified so that he could do things in his wheelchair.

The trial continues today.

fields.headline: Ex-head admits indecency
fields.trailText: A former head teacher of a prep school where the Countess of Wessex was a pupil yesterday admitted nine charges of indecent assault on pupils.
fields.body:
A former head teacher of a prep school where the Countess of Wessex was a pupil yesterday admitted nine charges of indecent assault on pupils.

Robin Peverett, 66, of Battle, East Sussex, was given an 18-month jail sentence suspended for two years.

The offences involved girls and a boy, aged 11 to 13, while he was in charge of Dulwich College Preparatory School in Cranbrook, Kent, from 1969 to 1978.

The offences came to light when Peverett was interviewed by the media about the countess's marriage to Prince Edward last summer, Maidstone crown court was told.

Brendan Finucane, prosecuting, said the first victim to come forward was a woman, now aged 33. Other complaints followed his arrest in September last year. Mr Finucane said the countess had no involvement in the case.

Peverett was originally charged with 16 counts of indecent assault on nine girls and two boys, aged 10 to 13, at the school from 1965 to 1978, but after his guilty pleas yesterday Judge David Griffiths ordered the other seven cases be left on file.
