fields.headline: Commission fights disability test case
fields.trailText: An accountant who lost his job at Lambeth council in south London because he suffered from depression will today become the first test case for the newly formed disability rights commission.
fields.body:
An accountant who lost his job at Lambeth council in south London because he suffered from depression will today become the first test case for the newly formed disability rights commission.

The commission is a statutory body, set up in April to combat discrimination against disabled people in much the same way as the equal opportunities commission fights discrimination on grounds of sex.

In an action in the appeal court, it is supporting Pravin Kapadia who was medically retired in 1997 after seven years at Lambeth council. He was told that his depression made him unfit for work.

Mr Kapadia argued that he would have been able to resume his duties if the council made reasonable adjustments so that his work fitted the job description. He said his depression was affected by appointment to a new post at the council in April 1996 for which he was not given the necessary staff or training.

The case demonstrates the commission's broad interpretation of its role to include mental health as well as physical and sensory impairments.

An employment tribunal decided Mr Kapadia was not unfairly dismissed and was not disabled as defined under the 1995 Disability Discrimination Act.

Mr Kapadia overturned this judgment at an employment appeals tribunal.

Bert Massie, the commission chairman, said: "Our first court case shows our determination to support disabled people, regardless of their impairment, at any stage in the legal process."

The commission said that about 5m people in the UK have diagnosed depression. People with mental health problems are more likely to be unemployed than those with physical or sensory impairments.

fields.headline: Woman lost job over pregnancy
fields.trailText: A woman who was turned down for a job because she was pregnant has won substantial but undisclosed damages for sexual discrimination at an employment tribunal in Liverpool.
fields.body:
A woman who was turned down for a job because she was pregnant has won substantial but undisclosed damages for sexual discrimination at an employment tribunal in Liverpool.

Ellen Sealey, 25, applied for work at a packing warehouse in November last year on the day she was made redundant from another job on the same industrial estate in Knowsley, Merseyside.

But she told the tribunal that John Roberts, who interviewed her on behalf of Gardman Ltd, had said she could not be considered because she was four months pregnant.

Two witnesses supported Mr Roberts's claim that discrimination never happened but the tribunal accepted Ms Sealey's account.

"When I entered the office, [Mr Roberts] said he would not be employing anyone who was pregnant," she said. "I was shocked and insulted. He made me feel hat I could not do the job because I was pregnant. But I've since learned that I could do the job. There was no heavy lifting involved."

The company denied sexual discrimination and insisted that Ms Sealey's pregnancy had nothing to do with the decision not to hire her. "At no time did I say I would not be employing her because she was pregnant," Mr Roberts said. "There is no reason whatsoever that the job could not be done by a pregnant woman - her pregnancy is of no relevance. I employed people who had been recommended to me. She wasn't."

The tribunal unanimously decided that Ms Sealey had suffered discrimination. "I have no doubt [Ms Sealey] was not hired because of her pregnancy and that is sexual discrimination," said the chairman, Eryl Lloyd-Parry.

webTitle: Costs spiral as sponsors go football crazy

fields.headline: Costs spiral as sponsors go football crazy
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 is gearing up to make sports history
fields.trailText: Euro 2000 is gearing up to make sports history as compamies jump on the football bandwagon.
fields.body:
Football, the seemingly unstoppable cash cow, is set to grow even fatter during Euro 2000. The event is expected be one of the most lucrative in sports history. Against a backdrop of 100% increases in the cost of Champions League sponsorship and protests from potential sponsors of the event including General Motors-owned Opel about the price increases, the cost of Euro 2000 sponsorship rights has soared to £7m for each of the main sponsors - including Coca Cola, Carlsberg and Mastercard, with KLM and Alitalia as the tournament's official airlines. This compares with fees of about £3m for Euro 96.

European TV rights are estimated to have reached as much as £1.6m and the 40 official merchandise licensees for the tournament stand to make significant gains as retail sales are predicted to double from £150m in 1996 to more than £300m, said Copyright Promotions, the tournament's licensing agents.

Mike Reynolds, spokesman for the Institute of Sports Sponsorship, says that to stand out "companies must spend above and beyond the initial investment". The ISS estimates that football sponsorship in Britain alone is worth more than £100m per year - a figure matched only by formula one motor racing.

Value for money
Mr Reynolds claims that while these sums may appear high, the major global players who invest the most, stand to gain the most. The downside is that those companies which do not supplement initial investments may not see the full benefits.

Carlsberg, a long-term European Championships sponsor, says Euro 2000 is so central to Carlsberg's strategy that it is backing up its investment with an additional £10m in Britain alone - or the whole of Carlsberg's marketing budget for the time of year, a spokesman confirmed.

Steve Cumming, sponsorship manager for Carlsberg in Britain, said that in addition to branding at the tournament, the company will have promotions and advertising, including a one-off competition via pubs and promotions at Tesco.

Merchandising licenses are expected to reap rewards greater than World Cup 98 for companies such as Marks & Spencer, Adidas, Electronic Arts and Character Group, which are making and selling products ranging from clothes and accessories to cuddly toys and face paints. Competition for licences was fierce, according to one licensee. The amounts paid for the licences are undisclosed but if the licensees get it right they will find themselves in a strong position for upcoming events including the World Cup in 2002.

M&S, with exclusive rights to boyswear ranging from sweatshirts to toddler outfits, confirmed that the range "has already almost sold out".

Bernard Phee, sponsorship manager for M&S, said: "Football is undoubtedly something we will continue to look at. We are involved in England's bid to host the 2006 World Cup and if this is successful, even greater involvement would be something to consider."

The business of licensing can be hit and miss as Character Group learned when its share price suffered when it issued a profit warning in April after substantially overestimating demand for Star Wars: The Phantom Menace merchandise.

Jon Diver, marketing director at Character Group, said the company had gone into the Euro 2000 deal with the lessons of the the Phantom Menace in mind.

"We have definitely protected our position. Our strategy has been to go in, get out and move on. We are on course to clear most of the merchandise at retailers before the tournament even starts but there is a possibility we may have under supplied the market this time."

Even when an event is a runaway success, investors' revenues are under threat. Companies can often avoid paying for sponsorship yet still capitalise on an event by other means. Sources at Opel, for example, say they get better value for their money by sponsoring individual teams, such as AC Milan, at the big tournaments.

Counterfeit threat
Counterfeiting is a very real threat for merchandisers. ISL, the marketing company responsible for Euro 2000, say it is working closely with trading standards officers in the host countries to minimise the threat. However, a spokesman for Copyright Promotions conceded that goods will slip through the net. "It is impossible for me to put a figure on it but we can't deny that this is a problem. Rotterdam is Europe's largest port after all."

At the heart of the anti-counterfeiting effort is Delta Labelling, a small British garment labelling company based in Tamworth. It supplies all Euro 2000 licensees with labels that have hidden security codes sewn into them which can then be identified by customs with a simple test.

Jim Bowman, one of the company's directors, said: "As these types of events escalate in size, security is becoming extremely important. Counterfeiting is a big problem and we identified this area as one of growing importance." Delta Labelling is already negotiating for the World Cup 2002 licence.

Euro 2000 is also benefiting broadcasters. ITV is set to make £25m with demand for air-time surging, compared with an £8m decline in revenues during the 1998 World Cup when it was accused by many advertisers of overpricing.

Eurosport, which is screening the tournament across Europe, will run 450 hours of coverage sponsored by Carlsberg, Fuji, Philips and Hyundai, says it has already sold its complete advertising inventory.

If Euro 2000 tells us anything, it is that the football bubble is far from bursting.

Where the money goes

 European TV rights cost upwards of £1.6bn

 Event sponsors paid £7m each, double that for Euro 96

 Retail sales of merchandise worldwide are expected to double that of Euro 96 to £300m

webTitle: Panic as new quake hits Indonesia

fields.headline: Panic as new quake hits Indonesia
fields.trailText: An earthquake off the Sumatran coast yesterday sparked mass panic and prompted an angry mob to protest at the Indonesian authorities' slow response to Sunday's massive quake in the same area that left about 100 people dead.
fields.body:
An earthquake off the Sumatran coast yesterday sparked mass panic and prompted an angry mob to protest at the Indonesian authorities' slow response to Sunday's massive quake in the same area that left about 100 people dead.

Just as residents of the devastated town of Bengkulu were starting to piece together their lives, a 15-minute tremor centred 75 miles offshore and measuring 6.2 on the Richter scale rocked Bengkulu province. People ran screaming from their homes but there were no reports of casualties.

Shortly after the quake more than 100 people barricaded one of the main roads into the town with rubble from ruined buildings to protest against what they described as the local and central governments' apathy towards the disaster.

Carrying sticks and rocks, they only allowed vehicles carrying foreign relief workers past the blockade. "We are hungry, we are sick. Why doesn't the government care?" read one protest banner.

"The government is no good. No aid has reached us here yet," said Yudi, 40, whose home was flattened and five-year-old son hurt on Sunday. "We need tents, food and medicine. There are many here who are injured and many houses have been destroyed."

The protesters scuffled with armed riot police until the provincial governor arrived and told them that he would immediately send in aid.

Indonesia's geological agency said yesterday that more than 400 aftershocks had been recorded since Sunday, adding that they would continue for at least a fortnight.

Local authorities claim the crisis has overwhelmed them.

"We are doing what we can," said Husni Hasanuddin, a spokesman at the disaster coordinating post in Bengkulu. "But we do not have the resources to cope with the scale of the earthquake. We are still waiting for more help from Jakarta."

He said that heavy rain and destroyed roads were adding to the problems.

The Indonesian Red Cross was also critical of the Bengkulu authorities. Jonny Mamoadi, the head of its disaster planning division, said that if the governor had declared a state of emergency, the arrival of aid would have speeded up dramatically.

The central government, racked by scandals, economic turmoil and unrest in eastern Indonesia, has done little for the earthquake victims. The parliamentary speaker, Amien Rais, visited Bengkulu yesterday and accused President Abdurrahman Wahid, who left on Wednesday for a foreign tour, of neglecting the victims.

"It is shameful. My president is not wise at all. Instead of coming to this miserable region he travels overseas for nothing," said Mr Rais.

Foreign aid has been pouring in. A 20-strong medical team from Singapore has been helping to treat the 1,900 injured and Taiwan, Japan, Belgium and the Netherlands have also sent aid. Britain has given £250,000, to be channelled through the Red Cross.

Doctors say that shortages of medical supplies, combined with an inadequate supply of clean water and heavy rain, mean there is a strong likelihood of disease spreading.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Iranian defector 'was a convict'
fields.body:
Iranian defector 'was a convict'

An Iranian defector who claims he coordinated the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 was an escaped convict, the Intelligence Ministry was quoted as saying yesterday.

Tehran radio quoted from a statement saying that Ahmed Behbahani, 32, was convicted for "cooperation" with a rebel Iranian group in Iraq, but escaped.
AP, Tehran

Foreigners flee coup island

The Australian navy began evacuating foreigners from the Solomon islands yesterday amid fierce fighting between rival militia after Monday's attempted coup. A Commonwealth delegation is due to arrive at the weekend to help halt the clashes.
Reuters, Canberra

Power struggle flares in Gaza

Feuding Palestinian intelligence officers opened fire on each other at their headquarters yesterday, wounding five agents, witnesses said. The shootout erupted over a power struggle between the head of the General Intelligence Service, Amin al-Hindi, and his deputy, Tarek Abu Rajab, the witnesses said.
AP, Gaza City

Cuban baseball star sent home

A Cuban baseball star, Andy Morales, hoping for a major league career in America, was repatriated with 30 others by the US coastguard yesterday after being picked up at sea. An official said Morales did not qualify for political asylum.
AP, Washington

Police break up anti-tax rally

Police in northern Pakistan yesterday fired teargas to again disperse a rally of merchants protesting against the government's drive to record business transactions and levy sales taxes.
AP, Islamabad

fields.headline: Methodists split over teetotal tradition
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A consultation among Methodists in advance of the church's annual conference this month has produced a split over whether alcohol should be allowed on church premises for the first time.
fields.body:
A consultation among Methodists in advance of the church's annual conference this month has produced a split over whether alcohol should be allowed on church premises for the first time.

Organisers are bracing themselves for sharp differences at the conference in Huddersfield on contentious issues such as whether wedding receptions in Methodist halls should be allowed to serve drinks or whether alcoholic communion wine should be permitted at services.

So sensitive is the issue that a report drawn up by the Methodist Council fails to make any recommendation on how delegates should vote.

The decision will go to the heart of Methodism's 200-year-old teetotal traditions, but lurking behind it is an awareness of the amount of money lost in bookings at premises from Methodist Central Hall in Westminster downwards.

Geraldine Ranson, the church's spokeswoman, said: "Methodists are allowed to drink like anyone else but you are not allowed to offer so much as a glass of wine in church offices or halls."

fields.headline: Olympic torch lights up Australia
fields.standfirst:
Olympic Torch Route
Sydney 2000 Olympic Games
fields.trailText: The longest ever Olympic torch relay began its 16,740-mile journey across Australia yesterday against the backdrop of the massive monolith of Uluru, or Ayers Rock, in the spiritual centre of the continent.
fields.byline: Christopher Zinn at Uluru, central Australia
fields.body:
The longest ever Olympic torch relay began its 16,740-mile journey across Australia yesterday against the backdrop of the massive monolith of Uluru, or Ayers Rock, in the spiritual centre of the continent.

The first Aborigine to win an Olympic gold medal, Nova Peris-Kneebone, 29, was handed the torch by tribal elders. Holding aloft the sleek blue and silver torch, she started to run toward the giant glowing Ayers rock, which she described as the heart and "belly of Australia".

The local Anangu people, the traditional owners of the area, played a key part in the elaborate ceremonies.

In his welcoming speech Reggie Kunmanara Uluru, a member of the Uluru family, said in the local Pitjantjatjara language: "We have been using traditional firesticks since ancient times, and we are proud to welcome this special torch here today."

The second runner at the most sacred of sites for black Australians was the Aboriginal actor Ernie Dingo, followed by the former Wimbledon tennis champion Evonne Goolagong Cawley.

The flame, which left Olympia in Greece a month ago, had arrived in Australia after travelling through 12 Oceanic nations and had last touched down in New Zealand en route to Australia.

Despite a strong wind which blew out the flame twice, the handover ceremony at Uluru was described by many Australians as a moving and historic moment.

Peris-Kneebone, who ran barefoot, was the first of 11,000 runners who will carry the torch around Australia, taking in an underwater section of the Great Barrier Reef before arriving at Stadium Australia on September 15.

"This will never happen again, and to have the honour of [being] the first Australian is probably something that I'll sit back and have a good cry about," Peris-Kneebone said after her mile-long run.

Accompanied by a phalanx of police, standby runners and 40 vehicles, the torch reached Alice Springs by sunset.

After a swag of public acrimony about the games concerning unfair ticketing, nepotism and other breaches of the Olympic tradition, the prime minister, John Howard, said the arrival indicated an end to the bickering.

"I think from now on everybody's going to focus on the positives and in great Australian adaptive style we'll forget about all the negative stuff that's gone on over the last couple of years," he said.

 More than 100,000 condoms are expected to be made available to the 10,000 competitors at this year's Sydney Olympics in a range of colours, including gold, silver and bronze.

fields.headline: Surface tension leaves Surrey gasping
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 191 & 119-3
Surrey 138 & 218
fields.trailText:
Derbyshire 191 & 119-3
Surrey 138 & 218.
fields.body:
Surrey, to a man, are in the mood to get out of Derby as quickly as possible, but they had to remain for an extra night after narrowly averting a two-day defeat on a surface that they have privately condemned as unsuitable.

Derbyshire, requiring 166 for victory, closed on 119 for three, with their Australian Michael Di Venuto unbeaten on 57. The counties then clashed again in late evening over their assessments of a pitch that had merited investigation by the England and Wales Cricket Board. Its panel, chaired by Mike Denness, will deliver a verdict today.

Surrey, schooled on the Oval's firm and arid sprawl, captained by an Anglo-Aussie and replete with test players, are always likely to be offended by the more gamesome county surfaces.

Thirty-three wickets have fallen in two days, but yesterday's evidence suggested that Surrey's griping had more than a whiff of "Bloody Derby" about it. The champions are not cheered to find themselves near the foot of the table.

That the pitch had not entirely dried out is hardly surprising after the wettest May, well, this century anyway. Before preparation work could begin here, they had to sweep away hailstones. Neither is the pitch overly grassy, a common charge against Derbyshire in the past. The ball jagged appreciably off the seam but the classiest players, such as Surrey's Alec Stewart and Di Venuto, had the skill to prosper.

After such a gruesome, rain-ravaged start to the season, here at least was welcome entertainment: fluctuating cricket, packed with incident, and a wonderful sunlit evening.

Surrey's left-handed trio was soon dispensed with. Ian Ward was caught at gully off a leading edge and Mark Butcher edged to slip. Graham Thorpe was bowled off his forearm, which did not lift his mood.

A stand of 80 between Stewart and Ally Brown, assisted by mediocre Derbyshire change bowling, cleared the first-innings arrears of 53, but Dominic Cork plucked a magnificent one-handed catch in his follow-through to dismiss Stewart and Brown, after sallying to 75 from 110 balls, became one of three middle-order victims for Matthew Cassar.

When Derbyshire replied Di Venuto, bowled by an Alex Tudor no-ball, dashed to his fifty from 47 balls, then blocked for the morning. Martin Bicknell's disgust, when Rob Bailey was not given out caught at the wicket, brought delighted howls from the recesses of the old racing stand. They love Surrey-baiting around here.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Club highs for the first and last wickets in successive innings? Bill Frindall would bet his reputation against it. Yet that, improbably, is precisely what Nottinghamshire will accomplish should Usman Afzaal and Andy Harris, their final pair, cobble together 14 more runs against Worcestershire this morning.
fields.body:
Club highs for the first and last wickets in successive innings? Bill Frindall would bet his reputation against it. webTitle: Hinds the casualty of Welsh resistance

fields.headline: Hinds the casualty of Welsh resistance
fields.standfirst:
West Indians 176 & 97
Glamorgan 140 & 113
West Indians win by 20 runs
fields.trailText:
West Indians 176 & 97
Glamorgan 140 & 113
West Indians win by 20 runs.
fields.body:
The closer the match, the harder they are to beat. Glamorgan discovered, like Zimbabwe and Pakistan before them, that this West Indies team like nothing better than the challenge of a tense final day.

The home side, needing 134 for their first win over the tourists since 1939, were well-placed at 49 without loss and marginally favourites at 91 for four. But, heeding the instructions of their captain Jimmy Adams to concentrate on line and length, the fast bowlers Nixon McLean and Reon King wrapped up the innings just before tea.

The build-up may have been painstaking but the end was swift. Glamorgan's last four wickets went down with the score on 113 in the space of three overs, McLean finishing with five for 30.

"There are times when it comes down to how badly you want it," said Adams afterwards. "I was really happy that we have a bunch of guys who still wanted to win in spite of who the opposition might have been or what the circumstances were.

"We've been down this road a few times," Adams added, referring to recent close calls in the Caribbean. "The main thing was the character that came through from the whole team. We have a group of young men committed to turning things round. That takes more than talent."

In the first hour's play there was little hint of what was to follow. Matthew Elliott and Steve James ran aggressively and seized on every loose ball to confound those who considered the target too testing on such an unreliable pitch.

But the game turned in one over from McLean. James, anticipating another quick single, was sent back and run out after his partner had played the ball too close to Wavell Hinds in the covers. Elliott was then caught at mid-on by Adams. Their stand of 49 had come off 15 overs; the next 64 runs occupied 45.

There was scarcely a bad ball bowled. Mahendra Nagamootoo, again exercising exemplary control with his wrist spin, tied up one end while the fast men kept it straight and full at the other. Only one bouncer was delivered all day.

Keith Newell was their main obstacle. He batted nearly two hours for 12 and caused Hinds to leave the field after being struck at silly point. His left ankle was described as "very sore" last night and he may need an x-ray this morning.

If Hinds's injury proves serious enough to rule him out the first test next Thursday, it would be a massive blow for West Indies. He is a man in form, scoring 162 and 52 in the recent Pakistan test as well as remaining unbeaten on 105 out of 176 in the first innings here. However his absence would simplify the selection for Edgbaston, with Brian Lara slotting into an otherwise unchanged side from the Pakistan test.

And there was a warning from Adams about Lara's form. "He's as committed as anybody. It's only a matter of time before the runs start coming."

fields.headline: Gloucester stumble in brief encounter
fields.standfirst:
Essex 263 & 199
Gloucestershire 268 & 85
Essex won by 109 runs
fields.trailText:
Essex 263 & 199
Gloucestershire 268 & 85
Essex won by 109 runs
fields.body:
As Noel Coward used to insist, perhaps with more psychological guile than conviction: "It's almost obligatory to have a disastrous dress rehearsal, my dears."

But it is unlikely that Gloucestershire, on the point of going off to play at Lord's in the Benson & Hedges Cup final, will be much impressed with theatrical superstitions and the master's camp words of consolation as they survey the wreckage of their final innings.

Without much sign of fibre, though maybe preoccupied thoughts, they were all out for a demoralising 85 in 2 hours of token resistance to lose by 109 runs. Ronnie Irani and Ashley Cowan made the early inroads and Danny Law snatched the last four wickets. It was a sheepish batting performance and there should be no excuses offered for the absence of four key players the county chose to rest.

One hopes that Gloucestershire's selection for tomorrow, from a squad of 14, will not be influenced too directly by the nervous foibles that allowed Essex to wrest back the initiative with such intent. The composition of the team is going to be a difficult job all the same.

Jon Lewis, at least, should ensure a place on the strength of his six for 47 in 22 challenging overs. He has taken 29 wickets this season but has had no guarantee of inclusion for his county's one-day matches.

Lewis found bounce and increased pace yesterday to disconcert several batsmen, including the England captain Nasser Hussain, for whom nothing much is going right at the moment.

Defeat, conceded in this fashion, was bad enough. There are also the murmurs of disappointment over the meagre financial rewards that are likely to come Gloucestershire's way from their third appearance in a Lord's final inside a year. The county will be paid only 6% of the gate receipts.

This was Essex's second consecutive win. That they got to 199 in their second innings, commendable as it turned out, was largely down to the fifth-wicket stand of Paul Grayson and Irani.

Grayson, at his own pace and with nine boundaries, was in no serious trouble until surprised by varying bounce to be bowled by Mark Hardinges immediately before lunch. Irani went soon afterwards, caught in the slips, again to Hardinges's tidy medium pace.

It was a triumph for Essex and their third-day revival: not quite for Hussain, who badly needs runs again following his modest form against Zimbabwe. Tim Hancock alone stayed for a while; Matt Windows, a century-maker the previous day, discovered the grimness of the levelling process as this time he went for a duck, flicking unwisely down the leg side to be caught by the wicketkeeper Barry Hyam.

webTitle: Gibbs says 'I agreed to fix match'

fields.headline: Gibbs says 'I agreed to fix match'
fields.standfirst: Opener claims Cronje offered him £10,000 to throw away his wicket
fields.trailText: South African opener Herschelle Gibbs claims Cronje offered him £10,000 to throw away his wicket.
fields.body:
South African cricket was dealt its second devastating blow in two months yesterday when Herschelle Gibbs told the King Commission that he had agreed to accept $15,000 (£10,000) to help fix a one-day international against India on March 19 this year.

Gibbs is the first South African player to admit to match-fixing since the disgraced former captain Hansie Cronje was sacked in April after confessing that he had received money from an Indian bookmaker.

The visibly distressed opening batsman described how Cronje had come to the hotel room he was sharing with the fast bowler Henry Williams "with a big grin on his face, early on the morning of the match in Nagpur, and said: 'Someone can pay you $15,000 if you score less than 20'.

"Henry was just getting out of the shower and Hansie told him he could get the same amount for bowling his 10 overs for not less than 50. Henry said yes." Another condition was that South Africa should not score more than 270 runs.

Asked why he agreed to accept, Gibbs explained that his parents had just divorced and that his father was unable to support Gibbs' mother financially. "I knew I was going to have to look after her for the rest of her life and I was thinking of her," Gibbs said.

The United Cricket Board of South Africa's counsel, Jeremy Gauntlett, took Gibbs through seven instances when he had lied about his involvement and asked him to explain why he had lied.

"I was scared and uncertain, and I was protecting Hansie," Gibbs replied, frequently drinking water and wiping the palms of his hands on his trousers. Gibbs said that Cronje had contacted him on at least three occasions and told him to keep lying.

He was eventually persuaded to confess by the South African wicketkeeper Mark Boucher. "Mark wanted to know if I had been honest the whole time," Gibbs said. "I kept on saying 'yes'.

"He said: 'If you don't come clean now and you lie in court you're going to go to jail.' Then I told him the truth."

Gibbs, who eventually did not receive any money, said he "forgot" about the deal during the match in question, lashing his first two balls to the boundary on his way to blasting 74 from 53 balls. He then described the extraor dinary scenario where Cronje came out to join him and Gibbs asked: "What do we do now?"

Cronje said that one of them needed to get out but that Gibbs should carry on while Cronje sacrificed his own wicket.

In the end South Africa's total still exceeded the "goal" as they made 320 for seven. Williams then failed to achieve his "target" when he broke down with a shoulder injury after bowling 11 balls.

Earlier yesterday the inquiry received a copy of Cronje's handwritten confession which was handed to the board's security chief Rory Steyn in the early hours of April 11 and later passed on to the priest Ray McCauley. Steyn, who had been summoned to Cronje's hotel, told the inquiry that Cronje was fully clothed, his bags were packed and he was in a poor emotional state.

"His eyes were wide open and he was on the verge of tears. He must have broken down on two or three occasions ... He said he couldn't live with the lies, they were eating him up."

Steyn said Cronje wrote that he had accepted "$20-25,000" before crossing that figure out and writing "$10-15,000".

Cronje, in his confession, said his troubles began when Mohammad "Hamid" Cassim approached him after the fifth test against England at Centurion Park, when Cronje's surprise last-day declaration set up an England win.

"He told me that, if only he knew I was going to declare, he could have made himself some good money," Cronje wrote.

"Since that day, in a moment of stupidity and weakness, I allowed Satan and the world to dictate terms to me, rather than the Lord."

The former spinner Derek Crookes said yesterday he was shocked when Cronje told him about an offer to lose a match in India in 1996. "I asked him if he was joking. Hansie replied that I should think about it."

The current test batsman Daryll Cullinan told the inquiry he had laughed off the proposal as a "stroke of genius" designed to boost team morale. "I dismissed it as typical of his sense of humour."

Williams, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom are due to give evidence today.

Gibbs, meanwhile, has probably seen the last of his international career. The UCBSA is meeting this morning and is likely to decide to exclude him from the tour of Sri Lanka, which begins in July.

webTitle: Flintoff blows Hampshire into batting crisis

fields.headline: Flintoff blows Hampshire into batting crisis
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 95 & 139 Lancashire 269
Lancashire win by an innings and 35 runs
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 95 & 139 Lancashire 269
Lancashire win by an innings and 35 runs.
fields.body:
Southampton may have avoided their traditional drawn-out dogfight against relegation from the Premiership this spring but their neighbours from just up Northlands Road are facing an uphill struggle to cling on to their place in English cricket's elite.

Hampshire slid tamely to their third innings defeat in six matches this season after lunch yesterday, the game lasting almost exactly six sessions after the first morning's wash-out at Aigburth, so next week's meeting with their fellow strugglers Durham at Basingstoke will be the County Championship's version of a six-pointer.

The implications of relegation would be grim for Hampshire, who had hoped to move to their new "Rose Bowl" ground on Southampton's outskirts next season as members of the First Division of both the championship and the National League.

To make matters worse they are £5m short of the £19m cost of the project and are still seeking a title sponsor.

This was not what was supposed to happen following the signing of Shane Warne and Alan Mullally but it is not hard to pinpoint Hampshire's problem. Yesterday's collapse made it 1,846 runs from 11 completed first-class innings, at an average of 168 for a total of three batting points.

Of the recognised batsmen Derek Kenway and Will Kendall have barely scraped past 200 and Jason Laney and the captain Robin Smith have fared even worse. "We cannot keep making excuses," said Smith. "The way we have been batting is not acceptable."

The problem is that there are few obvious alternatives, save thrusting two highly rated youngsters in James Adams of Winchester and Lawrence Prittipaul of Portsmouth, a cousin of the West Indies batsman Shivnarine Chanderpaul, into the deepest of deep ends.

Kenway, who was brilliantly caught behind by Warren Hegg in the first innings, was unlucky again yesterday, battling to 35 only to be bowled by arguably the best ball of the match from Joe Scuderi, who traded mainly in outswing then produced the perfect off-cutter.

But Kendall, Adrian Aymes and Mullally all fenced feebly outside off stump, John Stephenson was also exposed by the moving ball and Warne, having hooked Andy Flintoff for one four, lobbed the next ball to Glen Chapple at deep square leg. Flintoff, the fastest bowler here, ended with match figures of seven for 30 to go with his return to batting form.

Chris Schofield had another blank match, bowled by Mullally for a first-ball duck and his leg-spin not called upon at all - almost identical to his England debut at Lord's. But, even without Mike Atherton, Sourav Ganguly and the injured Peter Martin, Lancashire secured their third win in six matches and with it a return to the top of the table.
